**I. Daoist Lineages**
The learning of the Daoist school, also called the Mysterious Learning, is the most ancient in China. Formerly, Duke Ai asked Zixia: “Did the Five Emperors have teachers?” Zixia replied: “Your servant has heard that the Yellow Emperor studied under Da Fen, Zhuanxu under Lu Tu, Ku under Chi Chengzi, Yao under Wu Chengzi, Shun under Yin Shou, Yu under the Queen Mother of the West, Tang under Cheng Bozi, King Wen under Xi Chouzi, King Wu under the Grand Duke, the Duke of Zhou under Guo Shu, and Confucius under Lao Dan. Without encountering these teachers, these eleven sages could not have established their achievements in the world or transmitted their names to later generations.”

I note: Most of the eleven sages mentioned were ancient immortals. Ancient immortals manifesting in the world were too numerous to count. Among those who wrote books and established doctrines, the Yellow Emperor and Laozi are foremost; today, Laozi is universally honored as the founding ancestor of the Dao. This is because Laozi composed the *Daodejing*, which expounded the profound mysteries of the Daoist school and became the model for later generations.

Laozi transmitted his teachings to Chen Xiyi (Chen Tuan), Xiyi to the True Man of Fire Dragon, Fire Dragon to Zhang Sanfeng, and Sanfeng to Shen Wansan, Qiu Yuanjing, Master Li, and Wang Yuantong, among many other disciples. This lineage is known as the Wenshi (Literary Beginnings) School, also called the Hidden Immortals School.

**II.**
Second, Laozi transmitted his teachings to Wang Xuanyu, styled Donghua, also called Shaoyang. Shaoyang transmitted to Zhongli Quan, known as Zhengyang. Zhengyang transmitted to Lü Yan, known as Chunyang. From Master Lü’s disciples emerged four branches:

1. Lüzu transmitted to Yan Xiang Liu Haichan, and Haichan to Zhang Ziyang. Ziyang founded the Southern School.
2. Lüzu transmitted to Wang Chongyang of the Southern Song, who established the Quanzhen (Complete Perfection) Teaching and founded the Northern School.
3. During the Jiajing reign of the Ming, Lüzu transmitted to Lu Xixing of Huaihai, styled Qianxu, founding the Eastern School.
4. During the Daoguang reign of the Qing, Lüzu transmitted to Li Xiyue of Jiading, Sichuan, styled Hanxu, founding the Great River Western School.

This lineage is known as the Donghua School, also called the Shaoyang School.

In the Southern School, Ziyang transmitted to Shi Xinglin, Xinglin to Xue Zixian, Xue to Chen Niuwan, and Chen to Bai Ziqing. From Zhang to Bai, there were five transmissions, collectively known as the “Five Southern Patriarchs.” Ziqing transmitted to Peng Helin, Peng to Xiao Zixu, and thereafter the lamp of transmission was passed to many, all direct lineages of the Southern School.

Chongyang, a native of Xianyang, was of the Northern School. During the reign of Emperor Gaozong of the Southern Song, he wandered to Mount Zhongnan, where he encountered the two patriarchs Zhong and Lü and cultivated the Dao in seclusion. Emerging from the pass, he established the Quanzhen Teaching and initiated Ma Danyang, Sun Bu’er, Qiu Chuji, Liu Chuxuan, Tan Chuduan, Wang Chuyi, and Hao Datong, who attained the Dao in succession. These seven are known as the “Seven Northern Perfected.”

Among the Seven Northern Perfected, the most far-reaching in their transmission of the teachings were Patriarch Ma and Patriarch Qiu. Those such as Song Piyun, Li Qizhen, Zhang Ziqiong, Zhao Yuandu, Chen Zhixu, and Zhang Tianyu were all descendants of Danyang’s lineage. Those such as the True Man Zhang of Tiger Skin Seat, Li Xu’an, Cao Huanyang, and Wu Chongxu were all descendants of Chuji’s lineage.

The Quanzhen Teaching flourished in the north. Reading Jin Xueshi Yuan’s *Record of the Purple Tenuity Abbey* (*Yishan Collection: Record of the Purple Tenuity Abbey*) provides an overview: “Since the Zhenyuan and Zhenglong eras, there has been the teaching of the Quanzhen School. Wang Zhongfu (i.e., Chongyang) of Xianyang initiated it, and Tan, Ma, Qiu, Liu, and others followed. It was based on the teachings of profound tranquility, without the absurdities of yellow-capped priests’ exorcisms, and incorporated the teachings of Chan meditation without the hardships of ascetic bondage. They tilled fields and dug wells, sustaining themselves, and extended their surplus to others. Compared to the tumult of the world, they seemed to live with ease. Thus, the indolent and indigent flocked to them. From the Huai River in the south to the deserts in the north, from Qin in the west to the sea in the east, mountain forests, cities, and dwellings stood in sight of one another, with groups of ten or a hundred. After the chaos of the Zhenyou and Xiang eras, when all standards of order and culture had collapsed, the restless people had nowhere to turn. The only teaching available was this one school. From this, one can see the flourishing of the Quanzhen Teaching and the immense benefit it brought to sentient beings—far beyond those who cultivate in seclusion in deep mountains, merely perfecting themselves.”

The lineage of the Eastern School has no surviving texts for reference. As for the Western School, Patriarch Li transmitted to Wu Tianzhi of Shaanxi, and Grand Preceptor Wu transmitted to Ke Baozhen of Hubei and my teacher, Master Wang Tizhen. From the founding ancestor to my teacher, six transmissions have spanned over two thousand years—a truly long span. This is the general succession of the Donghua and Wenshi lineages.

Further examination of *Marvelous Encounters in Mountains and Seas* reveals that Lüzu and Liu Haichan once transmitted the elixir formulas to Chen Xiyi, and the True Man Zhang Sanfeng also transmitted elixir formulas to Li Hanxu. Thus, from the Five Dynasties onward, the lineages of the Wenshi and Donghua schools have in fact merged, a convergence brought about by the times and conditions.

The emergence of the Northern, Eastern, Southern, and Western Schools under Lüzu’s disciples was due to regional divisions, not differences in true formulas or cultivation and verification. Investigating further, Ziyang opened his teachings on Mount Tiantai, thereby becoming the founding ancestor of the Southern School.

Wang Chongyang propagated the teachings in the northern regions, thus becoming the patriarch of the Northern School. Xixing was born in Huaihai, and Xiyue in southern Sichuan, thereby becoming the founding ancestors of the Eastern and Western Schools respectively.

Master Wang observed: "The Southern and Northern Schools both originated from the transmission of the two patriarchs, Zhongli and Lü. If one distinguishes them by geography, it is acceptable; but if one divides them by the Great Dao, such reasoning is unsound." This may be called an immutable truth.

II. The Origins of the Dao

Fu Xi drew the trigrams, revealing the secrets of creation; Nüwa mended the heavens, disclosing the marvel of "taking from Kan to fill Li," yet these were but images without written records. As for the teachings of self-cultivation, those set down in writing began with the words of Guangcheng to the Yellow Emperor.

The *Zhuangzi*’s "Renyou" chapter states: "When the Yellow Emperor had been on the throne for nineteen years, his decrees were implemented throughout the world. Hearing that Guangchengzi dwelt on Mount Kongtong, he went to visit him, saying, 'I have heard that you, Master, have attained the Perfect Dao. May I venture to ask about the essence of the Perfect Dao? I wish to draw upon the essence of heaven and earth to aid the five grains and nourish the people. I also wish to regulate yin and yang to ensure the flourishing of all living things. How may this be done?'

"Guangchengzi replied, 'What you wish to inquire about is the substance of things; what you wish to regulate is the dregs of things. Ever since you began governing the world, clouds have rained before gathering, plants and trees have withered before turning yellow, and the light of the sun and moon has grown ever more dim. With the sly and flattering heart you possess, how could you be fit to speak of the Perfect Dao?'

"The Yellow Emperor withdrew, relinquished the world, built a solitary chamber, spread a mat of white couch grass, and dwelt in seclusion for three months before returning to seek an audience. Guangchengzi lay with his head to the south. The Yellow Emperor approached from the lower side, crawling on his knees, bowed twice, touched his forehead to the ground, and asked, 'I have heard that you, Master, have attained the Perfect Dao. May I venture to ask how to cultivate the body so as to attain longevity?'

"Guangchengzi rose abruptly and said, 'Excellent question! Come, and I will tell you the Perfect Dao. The essence of the Perfect Dao is profound and obscure; its ultimate reaches are dark and silent. See nothing, hear nothing, hold fast to the spirit in stillness, and the body will right itself. Be still, be pure; do not weary the body, do not agitate the essence—then you may attain long life. Let the eyes see nothing, the ears hear nothing, the mind know nothing, and the spirit will guard the body, and the body will attain long life. Guard your inner self, close off your outer senses; much knowledge brings ruin. I will lead you to the great brightness above, to the source of utmost yang; I will guide you into the gate of profound obscurity, to the source of utmost yin. Heaven and earth have their offices, yin and yang have their storehouses. Guard your body carefully, and things will naturally flourish. I preserve the One and abide in harmony. Thus, I have cultivated myself for one thousand two hundred years, and my body has never declined.'

"The Yellow Emperor bowed twice, touched his forehead to the ground, and said, 'Guangchengzi is truly heaven itself!'

"Guangchengzi said, 'Come, and I will tell you. That which is boundless, yet men all deem finite; that which is unfathomable, yet men all deem limited.'"

"Those who attain my Dao shall ascend as emperors and descend as kings; those who lose my Dao shall rise as mere light and sink into dust. Now, all the myriad beings are born from earth and return to earth—thus I shall leave you, enter the Gate of the Boundless, and wander the Wilds of the Infinite.

I share radiance with the sun and moon, I endure with heaven and earth—am I near? Am I far? All men shall perish, yet shall I alone endure?"

This is the essential principle of Daoist life-nurturing, the mysterious pivot of longevity and enduring vision. The most crucial passage lies in the four characters *"guard the One and abide in harmony"*—the practice of mind and breath interdependent.

The study of the Golden Elixir traces its origins here. When the adept unites mind and breath, spirit and qi merge, yin and yang harmonize; in stillness, one enters profound obscurity—this is the *Kun* storehouse, the utmost yin. Yet once I return to pure *Kun*, the pure *Qian* within the void must respond and come, meeting in a fleeting encounter where timing and spirit converge. As the alchemical texts say: *"After lead arises in gui, a single yang returns"*—this is the utmost yang, the Great Brightness.

*"Yin and yang have their storehouses"* refers to concealing mind and breath within the Mysterious Orifice. *"Embrace spirit in stillness"* means that as spirit and breath interdepend, one gradually enters quiescent concentration. *"Dim and silent"* describes the state of prolonged dependence entering into emptiness, the realm of primordial chaos.

*"Guard the One"* means preserving this true primordial qi to congeal the Dao-embryo. *"Abide in harmony"* describes the equilibrium of water and fire, the perfect harmony of true qi, where the entire body becomes supple, blissful, and intoxicated.

In elixir practice, as I become empty and still, I attract the true qi of yang from *Qian*; through daily and monthly accumulation, it coagulates into the Elixir. Ultimately, the boundless primordial qi of heaven and earth nurtures both my physical and dharmic bodies. Over time, qi transforms, and the form becomes immortal.

In this state, there is no labor, no movement, no seeing, no hearing, no knowing—all are essential principles for nurturing spirit and settling breath. Only when spirit is settled does qi return; only when qi returns does the Elixir form. Thus, nurturing spirit is the first step in mysterious cultivation, the precursor to reversion.

If spirit is unsettled, the Dao cannot bear it. The terms *"enter,"* *"lead,"* *"conceal,"* and *"guard"* all reveal the subtleties of the firing process, which ultimately converge in *"abiding in harmony."*

*"Enter the Gate of the Boundless"* and *"wander the Wilds of the Infinite"*—uniting with the constant virtue of heaven and earth—depicts the image of Great Quiescence and True Emptiness. *"Things will naturally flourish,"* *"that which is boundless,"* and *"that which is unfathomable"* all point to the profound subtleties of the medicinal substances.

These three instances of *"thing"* refer to the *"One"* in *"guard the One"*—namely, the primordial true *yi* qi. Preserve it in stillness, gather it in movement; through long accumulation, body and mind both transform, form and spirit both become wondrous, and the Dao gathers within me. All men perish, yet I alone endure.

Though brief, this wondrous passage encompasses the medicinal substances, firing process, true earth, gathering, and warming nurturance—all the principles of longevity and enduring vision. As Lu Xixing of the Ming Dynasty wrote in *The Nanhua Secondary Ink*: *"Reading a thousand volumes of alchemical texts is not as good as studying a single passage from 'In the Realm of Yu.'"* Truly, he was a connoisseur of the Dao.

Some say Guangchengzi was an emanation of the Dao Ancestor. Yet this interpretation remains superficial. When the Yellow Emperor ascended Kongtong and met Guangcheng, it was the Yellow Emperor himself who had attained Great Quiescence and True Emptiness, thereby perceiving his own dharmic body. The dharmic nature is vast and boundless; the three realms of existence (the realm of proper vessels, the realm of sentient beings, and the realm of correct awakening) are established upon it—hence the name *Guangcheng* (Vast Completion).

This original self-nature is inherent in all, yet due to deluded thoughts, attachments, and defilements of discriminative views, one cannot realize it. If one attains emptiness of dharmas and exhausts the defilements of consciousness, the true suchness of dharmic nature will naturally manifest—luminous and all-pervading, like the sun emerging from behind clouds.

This is the esoteric meaning behind the Yellow Emperor’s ascent of Kongtong to meet Guangcheng. As *The Song of Realizing the Dao* by Yongjia says:
*"The mind-mirror shines, reflecting without obstruction,
Vast and clear, it illumines the ten directions.
The myriad forms and shadows appear within,
A single orb of radiance, neither inside nor out."*

Master Ziyang said: *"The wondrous awakened radiance shines through inner and outer,
Enveloping the six directions, without near or far."*
Master Miaozheng said: *"Mind and Buddha are equal to emptiness,
The wonders within emptiness are unfathomable.
The azure sea’s light holds myriad rays,
The green mountains’ hues stand tall with a thousand peaks.
Cease groping, do not exert effort,
Formless and imageless, all traces vanish.
The true suchness of wondrous form is originally formless,
The six penetrations and wisdom are not true penetrations.
Where dust arises, things manifest,
Where realms recede, minds become empty.
Recognize the single pearl of mani,
And the light of the Ganges’ sands shines eternally."*

Is this not the dharmic image of Guangcheng?

Thus, the Daoist Guangchengzi is the Tathāgatagarbha of Buddhism, the true mark without marks and the wondrous mind of Nirvana in Chan, the One True Dharmadhātu of the Huayan school. Those who perceive it not only ascend as immortals and attain longevity (as the *Nirvana Sutra* calls *"eternal abiding"*), but as the Yellow Emperor, who met Guangcheng, naturally attained the Dao and became a perfected being.

The teachings of the Dao—caution within, closure without, guarding the One and abiding in harmony, preserving essence and nurturing spirit, merging form with the Dao—are the Yellow Emperor’s embodiment of the teaching, inaugurating the lineage of China’s mysterious tradition.

*The Book of Liezi* records four passages of the Yellow Emperor’s teachings on the Dao.

The first passage states: *"When form moves, it does not move—yet from it arises shadow. When sound moves, it does not move—yet from it arises echo. Without movement, nothing is born; from nothingness, being arises. Form must perish—do heaven and earth also perish? They perish with me."* The essential meaning here lies in the cycle of arising and ceasing, all rooted in movement. To reverse the flow of birth and death, one must attain non-movement. For movement departs from the root, while stillness returns to it. The phrase *"Without movement, nothing is born"* strikes to the very core. If a Dao practitioner reaches the state of a mind without movement, they transform arising-and-ceasing into quiescent extinction, and liberation from the cycle of birth and death is assured.

The second passage states: *"The Valley Spirit does not die—this is called the Mysterious Female. The gateway of the Mysterious Female is called the root of heaven and earth. Subtly it endures, its use never exhausted."* This chapter secretly reveals the *"outer Mysterious Pass."* The principle of mind and breath interdependent, neither forgotten nor forced, is the sole path of ascent in the Mystery School, the guiding principle for returning the breath to the origin. Master Hanxu said: *"The Valley Spirit is the original nature. The valley symbolizes emptiness; the spirit, numinosity. When the nature-body is empty and numinous, it is not obscured. Not obscured means it does not die. Yet why is the Valley Spirit also called the Mysterious Female? The Mysterious is heaven; the Female, earth. When heaven and earth unite, the Mysterious Female is formed—within it, emptiness and vastness."* The sage in cultivating the body borrows this empty and vast Mysterious Female to nurture the empty and numinous Valley Spirit, hence naming the Mysterious Female after the Valley Spirit—this is the meaning of naming by function. Yin and yang course within it; Kan and Li unite within it. The harmony of heaven and earth is nothing beyond this. Thus it is also called the root of heaven and earth, meaning the root wherein heaven and earth mutually reside. The root of heaven and earth is the place of returning to the origin and reverting to the primordial, the realm of refining qi and transmuting spirit. *"Subtly it endures"* refers to nurturing the Valley Spirit, naturally attaining fetal breathing. *"Its use never exhausted"* refers to the external furnace’s waxing and waning, naturally aligning with the fire. *"Never exhausted"* means without labor. The formula states: *"Concentrate the spirit in emptiness, follow the breath’s natural flow, abide in spontaneity, subtly it endures."* This is the marvel of *"never exhausted."* The *Cantong Qi* says: *"Float and wander, guarding the center of the compass"*—this is the same formula.

The third passage states: *"When spirit and essence enter its gate, the bones and frame return to their root—what then remains of me?"* This chapter reveals the dual stabilization of spirit and breath, the merging of being into non-being, the return to the fundamental root, the dissolution of both root and realm, and the attainment of the marvel of self-emptiness. As the *Lankavatara Sutra* says: *"When the notion of a personal self is absent, one approaches this."* Yang Renshan said: *"Ultimately, it reveals my true self."* The gate is the gateway of the Mysterious Female. The root is the root of heaven and earth. Like bubbles dissolving into the sea, if one seeks the form of the self, it is utterly unattainable. The culmination of this chapter lies in the phrase *"what then remains of me?"* Those who oppose the Dao are harmed by the grasping of self. The formula states: *"Mind and breath interdependent, until external breath is entirely cut off, one abides in great serenity. With prolonged stabilization, one enters quiescence, forgets form and image, wondrously merges with true emptiness. Even if yang arises, it is as if unnoticed—this may be called 'what then remains of me?'"*"Enter"* and *"return"* both reveal the marvel of reversing the flow to transcend birth and death. This *"gateway of the Mysterious Female"* was called by the ancients the *"Gate of Life and Door of Death."* If spirit and essence exit its gate, one follows the flow and dies; if they enter its gate, one reverses the flow and lives. Exiting leads to dispersion, entering to gathering; exiting to annihilation, entering to preservation. Thus it is said: *"The Door of Death and Gate of Life take this aperture as their foundation."* This chapter of the Yellow Emperor reveals the principle of *"revolving the primordial and returning to the origin"*—what the Old Master called *"returning to the root and recovering the mandate."* The previous chapter revealed *"regulating the breath and nurturing the spirit,"* while this chapter reveals *"form and spirit returning to emptiness"* and entering the realm of the Great Void. The latter is deeper than the former, yet the practice is originally one continuous progression. If one can put these two chapters into practice, the path of return is already open.

The fourth passage concerns the Yellow Emperor’s spirit-journey to Huaxu. The *Liezi·Huangdi* states: *"Thereupon, he set aside the myriad affairs, left his palace chambers, dismissed his attendants, silenced the bells and chimes, reduced his meals, and retired to dwell in leisure in the Hall of the Great Court. Purifying his mind and disciplining his form, for three months he did not attend to government matters. One day, he lay down and dreamed of traveling to the land of Huaxu. The land of the Huaxu clan lay west of Yanzhou and north of Taizhou, countless thousands of miles beyond this state of Qi. It was a place beyond the reach of boats, carriages, or foot—accessible only by spirit-journey. In that land, there were no rulers or leaders—all was spontaneous."*

Its people knew no cravings or desires—all was spontaneous. Unaware of delight in life, unaware of aversion to death, thus they knew no premature demise. Unaware of closeness to self, unaware of distance from things, thus they knew no love or hatred. Unaware of opposition, unaware of compliance, thus they knew no profit or harm. Entirely without attachment, entirely without fear or taboo, they entered water yet did not drown, entered fire yet felt no heat, endured blows without pain, suffered scratches without itch. Treading the void as though it were solid ground, resting in emptiness as though upon a bed, clouds and mist did not obstruct their sight, thunder and lightning did not disturb their hearing. Beauty and ugliness did not unsettle their minds, mountains and valleys did not trip their steps—all was spirit-travel alone.

When the Yellow Emperor awoke, he was joyful and content. Summoning Tian Lao, Li Mu, and Tai Shan, he reported to them: “For three months I dwelt in leisure, purifying my mind and disciplining my form, seeking the Dao of nurturing the body and ordering things. Yet I found no method. Exhausted, I slept, and dreamed thus. Now I know: the supreme Dao cannot be sought through emotion. I have attained it, yet cannot convey it to you.”

This passage, too, is allegory. The land of the Huaxu clan is the realm of the formless and soundless, the realm of great stillness. By relinquishing the myriad entanglements, forgetting both body and mind, stilling both emotion and perception, the Yellow Emperor suddenly awakened to the Dao of true constancy. This effortless operation is the most transcendent and free.

The saying “the supreme Dao cannot be sought through emotion” is an unchanging truth for all ages. Master Zao Bochang observed: “In the present, one is mortal; when emotion is forgotten, one becomes immortal.” Thus, forgetting emotion and stilling perception is the essential task in learning the Dao.

After the Yellow Emperor, those who wrote books to elucidate Daoist teachings must first honor the Old Sage. The *Daodejing* begins with the two characters “being” and “non-being.” As it states: *“Abide in constant non-desire to observe its mysteries; abide in constant desire to observe its manifestations.”* These two lines, in terms of practice, describe the interdependence of mind and breath. What is called “the gate of all mysteries” is the Mysterious Pass. Where it says: *“Vague and indistinct, yet within it are images, within it are things, within it are essences, within it is sincerity,”* this refers to the gathering of primordial qi. Where it says: *“Can you embrace the One and not depart from it? Can you concentrate your qi and attain suppleness like a newborn babe? Can you open and close the Gate of Heaven without partiality?”* all point to the principles of regulating the breath. Where it says: *“Empty your mind, fill your belly,”* this is refining the self and laying the foundation. Where it speaks of “nourishing the Mother” and “guarding the Mother,” this refers to gathering and nurturing. Where it says: *“Guard the center and embrace the One,”* this is the long nurturing of the sacred embryo. Where it says: *“Attain emptiness and guard stillness, return to the root and recover life,”* this describes refining the form with jade liquid, the practice of self-cultivation that encompasses all. Where it says: *“A great state flows downstream”* or *“descend and take,”* this reveals the secret of the alchemical reversal of yin and yang, the union of heaven and earth. Where it says: *“Disregard the body,”* *“place the body last,”* this is the essential principle of guarding against danger. Where it says: *“Block the openings,”* *“shut the doors,”* this is the subtle truth of nurturing. Where it says: *“The Dao is empty, yet its use is inexhaustible; the empty qi brings harmony,”* this describes the circulation of qi through the celestial orbit. Where it says: *“Good conduct leaves no tracks,”* this describes the circulation of spirit through the celestial orbit. Where it says: *“Return to a state of no-thing,”* *“return to the limitless,”* this is the return to emptiness and union with the Dao.

Alas! The profound meanings of the alchemical classics are fully revealed here.

When Laozi was about to enter the Western Regions, Yin Xi encountered him at the pass and asked about the Dao. Laozi said: “Emptiness and indistinctness are the root of the Dao. It gives birth to me from the void, it leads me to non-being. Thus, what gives birth to me is spirit; what brings death to me is the heart. Therefore, the body is the chariot, the dwelling, the master. When the body is tranquil, spirit resides within it; when the body is restless, spirit departs from it. Thus, if one disregards the body and preserves spirit, essence and radiance remain. When virtue and Dao unite, one communicates with the Dao. The good person does not contend with the myriad things, is humble and without desire. Thus, desire is the root of misfortune and harm. Non-being is the origin of heaven and earth. The sage eliminates desire and enters non-being to assist the body. Therefore, when I look, I see nothing of desire; when I listen, I hear nothing of desire; when I speak, I say nothing of desire; when I eat, I taste nothing of desire. Serene and tranquil, thus I am clear and still, non-active, and qi naturally returns to its pre-birth state.

I see that those who love others do not love as much as those who love their own bodies; those who love their own bodies do not love as much as those who love their spirit. Those who love their spirit do not love as much as those who relinquish their spirit; those who relinquish their spirit do not love as much as those who guard their bodies. Those who guard their bodies—this is constancy! Spirit gives birth to form; form completes spirit. Thus, if form does not obtain its spirit, it cannot live of itself; if spirit does not obtain its form, it cannot be completed of itself. When form and spirit unite, they mutually give birth, mutually harmonize and complete—only then is it achieved. The highest filial piety in the world may be called the ability to nurture one’s body. Those who can love their mother—thus their bodies endure long. When the body is empty, the myriad things arrive; when the heart is without, harmonious qi returns. Thus, those who skillfully nurture the body conceal themselves within the body yet do not emerge, conceal others within others yet do not appear. Why? They constantly take emptiness as the body, take non-being as the heart—this is called the body without body, the heart without heart. Thus, guarding spirit and attaining mysterious communication—this is called union with the Dao.”

My life rests in myself alone, not in Heaven and Earth. If I do not see, do not hear, do not know, then spirit does not leave the body—thus it endures with the Dao. I share a single qi with Heaven and Earth, guarding my own root. Nothing in the world is more yielding than qi, nothing more yielding than the Dao. The Dao’s yielding nature encompasses Heaven and Earth, permeates the myriad things. For the soft can give birth to the hard, the weak can overcome the strong—yet none in the world know whence its root arises.

Being arises from non-being as its mother, non-being from emptiness as its mother, emptiness from the Dao as its mother—this is the root of the Dao. What is called a Daoist? One whose spirit, though within the body, ensures it never departs. Prosperity is born of decline, yin is born of yang, and so being and non-being give rise to one another, emptiness and fullness complete one another. Thus life returns to being, and non-being returns to non-being.

Man exists within the Dao as a fish exists within water. When the Dao departs, man perishes; when the water dries, the fish dies. Therefore the sage returns to the state before birth—his form concealed, his spirit abiding—so the world turns to him. By non-action and non-affair, the state is full and the people prosper. Preserving the constancy of the Dao is called profound unity.

Man is born by obtaining spirit, yet does not know where spirit resides. Only the sage conceals it within, so that the corporeal soul does not depart. Guard the mother, and the child is preserved—thus the people flourish. The Way of cultivating the body is to penetrate the primordial chaos of primal qi, to resolve and guard one’s own being.

Heaven does not desire clarity, yet clarity returns to it; Earth does not desire turbidity, yet turbidity returns to it. Dampness does not desire water, yet water returns to it; dryness does not desire fire, yet fire returns to it. Emptiness and non-action do not desire the Dao, yet the Dao returns to them. From this we see: what nature of things is not spontaneous?

When Laozi had finished expounding the Dao, he again addressed Master Yin: “I tell you the essentials of the supreme Dao: still the heart and guard the One—then all defilements vanish, and all affairs are complete.”

The subtlety of this teaching lies in concealing spirit and guarding the mother, in emptiness and spontaneity—this is the original teaching of the Daoist school. The opening phrase, “Vague and indistinct, it is the root of the Dao,” subtly instructs that the breath of spirit is settled in external emptiness, guiding it to return to oneness and enter samādhi. Thus the following text says: “It gives me life in emptiness, places me in non-being.” Again: “Exteriorize the spirit, preserve the spirit.” And again: “Though spirit is in the body, ensure it does not remain in the body”—is this not teaching one to “concentrate spirit in emptiness, empty body and heart”?

Thus, embracing spirit to nurture nature, and harmonizing with the mean to nurture qi, mother and child remain in mutual affection, nature and life unite—this is the essential Way of cultivating the body. To “nurture the mother,” “love the mother,” “guard the mother” is the teaching of “feeding the mother and guarding the mother” in the *Daodejing*. When body and heart are both settled, wondrously merging with true emptiness, one returns to the state before birth. When form unites with the Dao, concealment and manifestation are at ease—thus we know that emptiness and spontaneity are the fundamental principles of the Great Dao and the path to true attainment.

The text says: “When the body is empty, the myriad things arrive; when the heart is without, harmonious qi returns. Constantly take emptiness as the body, take non-being as the heart—this is called the body without body, the heart without heart.” And again: “Emptiness and non-action—yet the Dao returns to them.” What better transmission of the essentials of cultivating the profound mystery could there be? This truly may be called the subtle warp of the myriad wonders, the ultimate purport of the five thousand characters.

The secret formula says:
Spirit and breath wondrously unite, returning to primordial chaos.
Guard the center and embrace the One—body and heart are tranquil and still.
Empty, still, and serene—this is the dwelling of all sages.
Return to the state before birth, and the source of the Dao is seen.
The nature of emptiness, the original substance—beyond words and explanation.
The great compassion of sages and worthies reveals the essential principles.
When body is empty and heart is still, the Dao naturally returns.
Constant virtue does not depart, returning to the infinite.
