"Of old, Subhūti in tranquil sitting saw heavenly flowers drift in the void." During the Five Dynasties, Chan Master Yongming Shou of Mount Tiantai’s Tianzhu Peak practiced samādhi for ninety days, whereupon Avalokiteśvara Bodhisattva anointed him with sweet dew, and he attained unobstructed eloquence. In the Sui dynasty, Great Master Zhizhe cultivated the *Lotus Sutra* samādhi; in stillness, he entered samādhi and beheld the assembly at Vulture Peak, as if it had never dispersed. In the Tang, Great Master Sengqie entered samādhi on the wild plains of the Central Terrace of Mount Qingliang, where heavenly flowers gathered about his knees, and he arose only after seven days. The sublime manifestations of samādhi are beyond the ink of oceans to record; here, a mere one or two are cited to inspire faith.

Seventy-Five
The Most Wondrous Forgetting
At the apex of samādhi, one enters the samādhi of no-mind, unattached to being or non-being—this is wondrous forgetting. Yanzi’s "sitting in forgetfulness" transcended form and relinquished knowledge, merging with the Great Thoroughfare; Confucius, in emptiness, exhausted both extremes. This is the forgetting of the Confucian school.

Master Tan’s *Book of Transformations* states: "Forget form to nurture qi; forget qi to nurture spirit; forget spirit to nurture emptiness. When emptiness and reality interpenetrate, this is called Great Harmony." Elder Yu Chan said: "Forgetting form to nurture qi is the golden elixir; facing scenes without emotion is the great return. Forget form, transform qi; transform qi into spirit—thus the Great Dao penetrates the Three Passes." Cao Wenyu said: "Merge into one and forget the one; then may you emerge and submerge with the primordial transformation." He also said: "This Dao is easy to know but hard to practice; only when one forgets what is practiced is the Dao complete." Sun Bu’er said: "Qi flows through the Three Isles; spirit forgets and merges with the Great Void." She also said: "Forget spirit, unattached to form; unite with the ultimate, leaving emptiness behind." Ancestor Lü said: "The pine wind intoxicates me with twofold forgetting." He also said: "Cease thoughts, forget scheming, and merge with the natural." And: "In stillness seek the true—true stillness; from forgetting the mind, reach forgetting-forgetting." And: "From this, the solitary spirit silently unites with the Great Void, pure and still, forgetting form." Master Sanfeng said: "Facing scenes, forget emotion and play with moonlight." He also said: "In the immortal’s chamber, qi and blood are utterly forgotten; the precious tripod and golden furnace need not be watched." Li Qing’an said: "Suddenly forget self and others, and the Three Flowers gather." He also said: "In worldly affairs, forget scheming and tasks anew." And: "Harmonizing light and blending with the vulgar, forget self and others; only the self knows what precedes the Emperor of Images." Elder Ziyang said: "Forget circumstances, exhaust emotions, and follow natural truth to realize the forbearance of the unborn dharma." The *Ancient Scripture of the Red Writ* states: "Forget the eyes, and light overflows without limit; forget the ears, and the mind’s awareness abides in profound depths. When both mechanisms are forgotten, the gate to all wonders is cut off." The *Jade Pivot Scripture* states: "When wisdom’s light arises, it becomes one with the Dao—this is called true forgetting." This is the forgetting of the Mystery School.

The Chan Master Huangbo said: "Forgetting both mind and realm is the true Dharma. Forgetting the realm is easy; forgetting the mind is most difficult." Great Master Sengcan said: "In oneness, embody the mysterious, suddenly forgetting conditions." He also said: "The infinitesimal merges with the vast—this is the realm of forgetting conditions." Great Master Zhenjue said: "Thoughts do not cease without forgetting dust; dust does not cease without stilling thoughts. Forget dust and still thoughts, then forgetting occurs; still thoughts, and dust is forgotten and stilled. Forgetting dust and stilling, there is nothing to still. Stilling thoughts and forgetting, there is nothing to forget. Dust has nothing to oppose; when dust is relinquished, there is no opposition. Nothing to still, thoughts extinguished, not-knowing. The nature of not-knowing differs from wood and stone. This is the place of the initial mind—difficult to comprehend."

Chan Master Huangpan said: "Simply still and forget the mind, merge with the Dharma Realm, and attain freedom." This is the forgetting of the Chan school. The Chan school must suddenly forget delusion and awakening to penetrate the final barrier, not abiding in initial awakening, obscurely merging with original awakening. The power of the word "forget" is most wondrous, its force the greatest. At the apex of cultivation and realization in the Three Teachings, all draw strength from the word "forget." Only through forgetting can subject and object, nature and emptiness be cast off; only through forgetting can emotions cease and views vanish, utterly without inside or outside; only through forgetting can the power of samādhi grow and the embryo of the Dao be perfected.

The late Master once said: "If scholars can make the word 'forget' their master, the effects will be like splitting bamboo. Though ten thousand study the Dao, ten thousand do not know—what is most precious is the single word 'forget.'" Layman Yuanming said: "In learning worldly matters, without utmost effort of the mind, learning cannot be accomplished; in awakening to the Dharma beyond the world, without utmost effort of no-mind, awakening cannot be thorough." How profound these words! The "utmost effort of no-mind" refers to the realm of absolute forgetting. Thus, the three times are perfectly interpenetrated, the ten thousand conditions are clarified and still, one enters the wondrous gate of all wonders, and accords with the Great Dao of true constancy.

True Man Ziqing’s *Revealing the Secrets of the Mysterious Pass* states: "Master Tan said: 'Forget form to nurture qi; forget qi to nurture spirit; forget spirit to nurture emptiness.' This single word 'forget' is nothingness. 'Originally, not a single thing—where can dust alight?' Does this not refer to this?" If one can savor this principle and cultivate the effort of the single word "forget," one can enter the profound subtleties of the Great Dao, seize the wondrous functioning of the natural, establish the foundation of the elixir in an instant, and move the transformations of creation within a single body. In his *Commentary on the Treasure Chapters of the Dao and Virtue*, the essentials are to forget things, forget self, forget mind, forget nature, forget form, forget spirit, and forget words—without deep attainment in the Dao, one cannot express this.

Cultivating the Dao is not difficult; what is difficult is thorough forgetting. The *Zhuangzi*, throughout, demonstrates the use of the word "forget.""

As it is said: "To nourish the will, forget the form; to nourish the form, forget profit; to attain the Dao, forget the mind." Again it says: "Fish forget one another in rivers and lakes; men forget one another in the arts of the Dao." And again: "Forget things, forget Heaven—this is called forgetting the self. Those who forget the self are said to enter into Heaven." And again: "Nothing is not nothing, nothing is not being—serene and boundless, all beauties follow from this." And again: "When the spring dries up, fish find themselves together on land, moistening one another with breath, wetting one another with foam—better to forget one another in rivers and lakes. Rather than praise Yao and blame Jie, better to forget both and be transformed by the Dao." And again: "Who can ascend to Heaven and wander in the mists, stirring and turning without limit, forgetting life together, without end or exhaustion?" And again: "The fish-trap exists for the fish—once the fish is caught, the trap is forgotten. The rabbit-snare exists for the rabbit—once the rabbit is caught, the snare is forgotten. Words exist for meaning—once the meaning is grasped, the words are forgotten. Where can I find a man who has forgotten words, that I might speak with him?" And again: "Cast off your form, expel your cleverness, abandon all relations with things, and merge with the vast darkness." And again: "One must fast to still the mind. After fasting for three days, one dares not entertain thoughts of reward, rank, or emolument; after five days, one dares not entertain thoughts of right and wrong, skill and clumsiness; after seven days, one suddenly forgets one’s four limbs and physical form." And again: "Forget the feet, and shoes fit well; forget the waist, and the belt fits well. Without inner change or outer compliance, one attains perfect accord with events. From the beginning of accord, one never fails to be in accord—forgetting accord is the true accord." And again: "Forget the liver and gall, disregard the ears and eyes, wander in vagueness beyond the dust and grime, roam in the workings of non-action." And again: "Forget years, forget righteousness, rouse oneself in the boundless—thus lodge in the boundless." And again: "In such a state, the mind is forgotten." And again: "Forgetting and returning," "Returning to the source without nourishment, forgetting others—forgetting others, one thereby becomes a Heavenly person." And again: "It is not that I do not tell you—my mind desires to speak but forgets." And again: "I have served you so thoroughly that I forget, and you have served me so thoroughly that you forget. Though you may worry, what is there to fear? Even if we forget our former selves, there is something I do not forget."

Zhuangzi may be said to excel in expounding the divine subtleties of the word "forget." Within, forget the liver and gall; without, forget self and others—when nothing is not forgotten, nothing is not possessed. Serene and boundless, all beauties follow from this. If this is not the utmost wonder of the world, what could compare?

In the *Free and Easy Wandering*, it speaks of the "perfected person without self"—this is forgetting the self. In the *Equality of Things and Opinions*, it begins with Nan Guo Ziqi "responding as if he had lost his counterpart," and again says: "Now I have lost myself"—this is forgetting the form. In *The Human World*, it reveals the wonder of Yan Hui’s "fasting of the mind": "Before I, Hui, was sent, it was truly myself; once sent, there was no longer myself—can this be called emptiness?" This is the forgetting of both body and mind. In *The Great and Venerable Teacher*, it speaks of "putting the world outside, putting things outside, putting life outside"—this is forgetting everything within and without. It also shows Yan Hui’s "sitting in forgetfulness," merging with the great thoroughfare—this is the sudden realization of the wondrous identity of inner and outer, body and mind, after long forgetting of both. In *Letting Be and Exercising Forbearance*, it reveals "great unity without self." In *Heaven and Earth*, it reveals "Xiangwang obtaining the pearl"—all these are the subtle and wondrous workings of the word "forget." Thus, the *Zhuangzi* reaches its summit in the single word "forget." Once one attains the state of forgetting both mind and circumstances, entering the One True Dharma Realm is not difficult.

In the cultivation of the Mysterious School, stillness is the foundation, and forgetting is the return. Yet if mind and breath are not forgotten, stillness cannot be attained. Thus, it may be said that the entire process of the elixir Way, from beginning to end, can be encompassed in the single word "forget"—there is nothing it does not include. When refining essence to transform qi, if one cannot forget the form, one will surely suffer the calamity of essence leakage. When refining qi to transform spirit, if one cannot forget qi, one will surely suffer the calamity of qi leakage. Master Yuchan’s *Poem on Failing to Refine the Elixir* says: "In the middle of the night, sudden wind and thunder, mist and vapor fill the vast emptiness. Such feelings and flavors—even a mute would bite through his tongue." This may serve as a warning from past experience.

When refining spirit to return to emptiness, if one cannot forget spirit, one cannot embody the Great Void and attain the wondrous realization of the Dharma Body pervading empty space. Thus, in the "Transformation of the Dao" chapter of Tanzi’s *Book of Transformation*, the three stages of cultivation—nourishing qi, nourishing spirit, and nourishing emptiness—are all subsumed under the single word "forget." No one who has spoken profoundly of the Mysterious School through the ages has matched this in subtlety and wondrous simplicity.

Generally speaking, in both precelestial cultivation and postcelestial arts, if one does not reach the state of forgetting, transformation cannot occur. Thus, the *Zhuangzi* says: "You are about to forget your spirit and qi—then you may approach it!" Is this not the meaning of Cao Wenyi’s words: "Merge into one (mind and breath interdependent), then forget the one (forget both mind and breath)—thus may one emerge and submerge with the primordial transformation"?

Scholars of the Mysterious School know only the wonder of mind and breath merging as one, yet they do not know that forgetting both mind and breath is the wonder within wonder—for without forgetting, there can be no stillness. Profound and subtle indeed!

Regarding the fire phases of the Mysterious School, if one were to summarize their essentials in a single word, they may be divided into four stages: first, harmony; next, intoxication; then, stillness; and finally, forgetting.

Yet harmony is never without stillness, stillness is never without intoxication, and intoxication is never without forgetting. Observe the utterly drunk: when they fall from a carriage to the ground, they suffer no injury—precisely because, in drunkenness, both mind and breath are forgotten. If this is true even for the postnatal, how much more so for the prenatal! Thus, though four words are given, they may in truth interpenetrate and merge. Ah! The essentials of Daoist cultivation are here laid bare.

Master Yulin Xiu, a great Chan monk of the early Qing, composed a work titled *Questions from a Guest*, in which he exhaustively extolled the word *forgetting*. He declared: “One who cannot forget the body cannot study the Dao; one who cannot forget the mind cannot study the Dao; one who cannot forget the world cannot study the Dao; one who cannot forget fame cannot study the Dao; one who cannot forget profit cannot study the Dao; one who cannot forget wife and children cannot study the Dao; one who cannot forget household and career cannot study the Dao; one who cannot forget knowledge and views cannot study the Dao; one who cannot forget learning and habit cannot study the Dao.” Only when body and mind, inner and outer, are all forgotten together—when all is relinquished at once, and the dusty world is wholly forgotten—does one daily draw nearer to the Dao.

In the Mysterious School’s initial practice of interdependent mind and breath, if one does not reach the stage of dual forgetting, one cannot even fall asleep—if sleep is unattainable, how much less stillness? Thus, *forgetting* is most wondrous, *forgetting* is most sublime!

---

**76. Leisure is Most Precious**

What is leisure? It is the state of body and mind at ease, free from the disturbance of miscellaneous toil and vexation, and imbued with a sense of serene contentment. As the *Zhuangzi* says: “Can you be together without contrivance? Be bland and still? Be vast and clear? Be harmonious and at leisure?” This expresses the meaning.

Generally, the study of the Dao encompasses three kinds of leisurely delight. The first is *tranquil leisure*: when the practitioner externally quiets all conditions, single-mindedly enters meditation, and internally generates a stillness of pure peace, putting an end to the disturbance of worldly toil—this is the true beginning of entering the Dao. The second is *secluded leisure*: as poetry speaks of the “recluse,” one retreats to the peaks and riverbanks, delights in one’s own aspirations, seeks neither fame nor advancement, contends not with kings and lords, and spends each day in carefree ease—moving with the white clouds in their unfolding and closing, sharing the unbounded freedom of waterfowl. Such is the “idle Daoist.” Once the foundation of the elixir is attained, one may preserve and nurture the sacred embryo, living for decades as a lofty hermit—yet only those who have seen through glory and set their hearts on simplicity can achieve this.

Long ago, Chan Master Zuoxi Shanlang wrote to Chan Master Yongjia Jue during their mountain retreat: “Since arriving at Lingxi, my mind and will have been at peace. I wander with my staff among the high and low peaks, sit in meditation in stone chambers and cliffside niches, where green pines and azure pools give rise to their own moonlight. The wind sweeps the white clouds, and my gaze stretches a thousand miles. Fragrant flowers and ripe fruits are brought by the beaks of mountain birds; the cries of gibbons echo near and far. My hoe serves as a pillow, fine grass as my mat. The world’s strife and contention over self and others—only those whose hearts have not yet awakened engage in such things. If you have a moment, I hope you will visit.” This reveals the purport of *secluded leisure*!

The third is *pure leisure*. Chen Tuan wrote: “I see the world’s people busy—each as frantic as fire. Yet those who toil do not do so for themselves; if they toiled for themselves, it would be acceptable.” Shao Yaofu said: “A thousand miles cannot escape the clarity of two eyes; in a hundred years, not one person is seen at leisure.” And again: “Flowing water follows its course, the scene ever still; flowers fall frequently, yet the mind remains at ease. Unlike worldly people, who age in idleness, never once in their lives breaking into a smile.” Zhou Maoshu remarked: “In the red dust and white sun, no one is at leisure—how much less one bound by official robes and sashes!” Chen Baisha observed: “Both marketplace and mountains have their affairs; what modern people call busy, the ancients called leisure.” Clearly, the blessing of *pure leisure* is most difficult to attain.

Worldly people rush about day after day, year after year in tumult, with never a moment’s respite for body or mind. Only Daoists enjoy the blessing of pure stillness and leisure. Thus, an ancient worthy said: “Among the toils of life, only monks are free from affairs. If one awakens to the true vehicle, one grows even more at leisure in old age. In a garden with three paths, the Chan nature remains; in a thatched hut, the Dao mind returns with the wind and moon.” The Qing Emperor Shizu declared: “A hundred years—thirty-six thousand days—cannot compare to half a day’s leisure for a monk.” Master Yuchan wrote: “There is but one thing in which I surpass others: even emperors lack this pure leisure.”

To enjoy the blessing of *pure leisure* stems from having no desires in the breast, releasing the mind into utter emptiness. Thus, one can withdraw, return to the mountains, dwell in tranquil seclusion, rest in serene stability, and abide in boundless harmony—where wondrous function is naturally sufficient. Chan Master Weizhong Fu wrote: “After Zhang Liang no longer prized his noble title, how could he bear to record his merits on the imperial tower? Winning a leisurely body with nothing to do, he often wandered by the water with Red Pine.” This is what Chan Master Yongjia Xuanyue called “the idle Daoist who has abandoned learning and effort.”

An ancient worthy said: “The ‘idle Daoist’ is one who accords with the Dao, unconstrained by worldly toil. His eyes roam through the ages, his mind rests in a single realm. By water and beneath trees, he nurtures the sacred embryo, finding freedom in the moonlight, at ease in the sound of springs—thus is he called the ‘idle Daoist who has abandoned learning and effort.’”

In the Song dynasty, Chao Wenyuan’s *Fragments of Gold* states: “Someone asked: What is the joy of living in leisure? I replied: It is to harmonize and smooth the qi of Great Harmony, to savor the flavor of Heavenly Truth, to study subtle and profound words, to wander in the most wondrous Dao, to share the lofty sentiments of Master Zhuang, to befriend the transformations of nature, to grasp the sublime teachings of India, and to refine the spirit.”

I say: If one can still both thoughts and extinguish them, wandering in the realm of *wuheyou* (“nothing whatsoever”), roaming in the vastness of *Fenghong*—this is indeed the ultimate journey of Zhuangzi’s “forgetting and ease.”

The difficulty of leisure lies precisely in achieving leisure of both body and mind. If the body is at leisure while the mind is not—thoughts surging like tides, friends and concerns crowding the heart—this cannot truly be called leisure. Those of higher attainment may have a mind at leisure while the body is not, as when Confucius journeyed through the states; yet even this does not compare to Vimalakīrti’s illness in Vaiśālī. When both body and mind are at leisure, as when the World-Honored One rests in the ocean of *mahāparinirvāṇa*, this is the highest state.

Lü Dongbin said: “A day of pure leisure is a day as an immortal; the six spirits harmonize and all is naturally at peace.” Master Yinshan said: “In a three-room thatched hut I have always dwelt; a single ray of spiritual light makes all realms at leisure.” Chan Master Yongming Yanshou said: “Best is when in stillness nothing stirs, and the sprout of the Dao grows effortlessly alone”—he was called the “Master of No Affairs,” a rare attainment indeed. Leisure of both body and mind is most conducive to the practice of the Dao. When the mind and breath are harmonized, one wanders in the realm of *wuheyou* (“nothing whatsoever”), the state of *xiyi* (“rare and subtle”), which Zhuangzi called “wandering in Heaven.” Zhi Gong said: “In the light of formlessness, one is ever at ease.” Yuanwu said: “Entering the realm of equality and tranquility,” and again: “Together entering the dharma-nature ocean of non-action and no-affairs.” These are all the subtle principles of “wandering in Heaven,” and so *Zhuangzi* says: “Without the Heavenly wandering of the mind, the six senses vie in confusion.”

When external circumstances do not disturb, the body is at peace; when the inner mind is still, the heart is at peace. Leisure of body and mind is the foundation of entering the Dao; emptiness and stillness of body and mind are its beginning. Only through stillness can samādhi arise, and in all cases, leisure is the condition for entering the Dao. Dongshan said: “Releasing all, sit upright; white clouds deeply enter leisure.” This is the leisurely spirit of Chan. Lü Dongbin said: “Do not say the recluse has nothing to do—within leisure lies the work of stillness. After reading in the quiet of a closed room by day, sweep the floor, burn incense until dusk.” *Zhuangzi* said: “In such a state, the mind is at leisure and without affairs.” Master Yuchan said: “A single leisurely guest, with nothing weighing on the heart.” Su Dongpo said: “The perfected one awakens to a single word: the Dao gathers from inner emptiness. The mind at leisure reflects itself, bright as a lotus.” Zhang Sanfeng said: “Stillness disturbed is not true stillness; only in leisure can one find peace.” This is the leisurely spirit of the Esoteric Dao.

Shao Yaofu said: “In leisure, the flavor is true; in truth, one is a child of Heaven.” And again: “In leisure, observe the waxing and waning of years; in stillness, illumine the being and non-being of heaven and earth.” And again: “Observe human affairs from the stillness of embodiment; refine the emotions of things in the freedom of leisure. Dispel all waves to preserve the still water—what in the world cannot be made level?” Zhou Maoshu said: “Only in leisure is one a man of understanding; busyness is but a life of toil.” Wang Yangming said: “In leisure, the mind is like empty water; in stillness, the subtle workings of Heaven become visible.” This is the leisurely spirit of the Confucians.

Our Buddha, the World-Honored One, having realized bodhi, dwells in constant bliss—this is the ultimate tranquility. **77. Retreat is most steadfast.**

The *Xugua Zhuan* of the *Book of Changes* says: “Retreat means withdrawal.” The *Dun* hexagram states: “Good retreat brings good fortune to the noble person, but not to the petty person.” And again: “Excellent retreat is steadfast and auspicious; abundant retreat brings no disadvantage.” The *Xiangci* of the *Daguo* hexagram says: “The noble person stands alone without fear, retreats from the world without vexation.” The *Zhongyong* says: “The noble person abides in the Mean; though unseen in retreat, he does not regret—only the sage can do this.” The Confucian tradition extols the virtue of reclusion to the utmost.

In the *Daodejing*, “wearing coarse cloth while holding jade” is retreat; “achieving merit and fame, then withdrawing the body” is retreat; “blending one’s light and merging with the dust” is also retreat. Yet these are but the actions of one who retreats from the world, not the ultimate retreat. When the spirit of the self enters the cavern of qi to nurture it, withdrawing and concealing in secrecy, ultimately transforming together with breath, entering true emptiness, returning to the Great Void—body and mind utterly still, roots and realms both within and without extinguished—this may be called retreat of both body and mind, utterly without trace, leaving no footprint, like the horn of the antelope hanging in the air. This is the ultimate retreat, and the *Book of Changes*’ “excellent retreat” and “abundant retreat” also contain this meaning.

Thus *Zhuangzi* says: “The Gate of Heaven is non-being; within the non-being of non-being, the sage conceals himself.” The *Cantong Qi* says: “Returning to the hidden origin, the inner light illumines the body.” And again: “Between the dark and the new moon, the tally moves within; the primordial chaos of *hongmeng*, the union of yin and yang, fluids moistening and flowing, circulating without obstruction. The spirits of heaven and earth are beyond measure; their use is to secure the body, concealing form and hiding.” Yang Xiong’s *Tai Xuan Jing* says: “Conceal the heart in the abyss, beautifying the spiritual root.” This is the true work of retreat and concealment in the Esoteric Dao—not merely dwelling in mountain forests where no human trace reaches.

**78. Compassion is most auspicious.**

Among the Three Treasures of the Old Sage, compassion comes first. It is said: “Through compassion, one becomes brave.” And again: “With compassion, one triumphs in battle and stands firm in defense. Heaven will save him, guarding him with compassion.” And again: “Thus the sage is always good at saving people, and so leaves no one behind; always good at saving things, and so leaves nothing behind. The sage in the world is reverent, blending the hearts of all under heaven. The hundred clans fix their ears and eyes upon him, and the sage treats them all as children.”

It is also said: “Repay resentment with virtue. For the good, I treat them with goodness; for the ungood, I also treat them with goodness—thus virtue is perfected in goodness.” All this illustrates the practice of the great compassion samādhi. The bodhisattva cultivates the Four Immeasurables (loving-kindness, compassion, sympathetic joy, and equanimity), yet takes compassion as the foremost guide, which suffices to prove the shared ground between Buddhism and Daoism. Those who study the immortal arts extend benevolence even to insects, refraining from harming any sentient being. With a compassionate heart, they embrace all beings, teaching and transforming them according to their capacities, gradually leading them out of the苦海 of birth and death to ascend the shore of the Dao. In this way, they embody the gateway of the Old Sage’s great compassion, becoming the upright banner of the teachings beneath the pillar.

The *Avataṃsaka Sūtra’s* “Departure from the Worldly” chapter expounds ten kinds of compassion, which may serve as the paradigm for the great compassion practices of both Buddhism and Daoism, and as the bridge for guiding beings in the degenerate age. The sūtra states:

“The bodhisattva mahāsattva possesses ten kinds of pure compassion. What are the ten?
1. **Compassion of equal mind**, pure because it universally embraces all beings without discrimination;
2. **Compassion of bestowing benefit**, pure because whatever is done brings joy;
3. **Compassion of regarding beings as oneself**, pure because it ultimately leads all out of birth and death;
4. **Compassion of not abandoning the world**, pure because the mind constantly contemplates the accumulation of good roots;
5. **Compassion that brings about liberation**, pure because it universally enables beings to eradicate all afflictions;
6. **Compassion that gives rise to bodhi**, pure because it universally inspires beings to seek the mind of omniscience;
7. **Compassion unhindered by the world**, pure because it radiates great light, illuminating all equally;
8. **Compassion that fills empty space**, pure because it saves and protects beings without fail, wherever they may be;
9. **Compassion bound to the Dharma**, pure because it realizes the true suchness of reality;
10. **Compassion without conditions**, pure because it enters bodhi, free from the nature of birth.

These are the ten. All bodhisattvas who abide in this Dharma attain the Tathāgata’s supreme, vast, and pure compassion.”

I observe: When the Old Sage says, “For the good, I treat them with goodness; for the ungood, I also treat them with goodness,” is this not “universally embracing all beings without discrimination”? When it is said, “Always good at saving people, and so leaves no one behind; always good at saving things, and so leaves nothing behind,” is this not “saving and protecting beings without fail, wherever they may be”? When it speaks of “blending the hearts of all under heaven,” restoring them to the uncarved simplicity of infancy and the unfeeling innocence of a newborn, is this not the “compassion of not abandoning the world”? When it says, “Constant virtue does not depart; constant virtue does not err, returning to the limitless, returning to nothingness,” is this not the “compassion that brings about liberation”? When it teaches, “Without knowledge, without desire, revealing the plain and embracing the uncarved, purifying to become the norm under heaven—who can stir the turbid to gradually clear?” and further, “Attain the utmost emptiness, guard the profound stillness; while the ten thousand things arise together, I observe their return. Things flourish abundantly, each returning to its root. Returning to the root is called stillness; stillness is called returning to life; returning to life is called constancy; knowing constancy is called illumination,” is this not the “compassion bound to the Dharma”? When it speaks of “dwelling in good earth, the mind like a deep abyss, befriending goodness, speaking with sincerity, governing with uprightness, handling affairs with skill, and acting at the right time”—these seven all exemplify “the highest goodness is like water, which benefits the ten thousand things without contention, accomplishing its work yet not dwelling in it”—is this not the “compassion without conditions”? Thus, the gateway of the Old Sage’s great compassion practice aligns in secret with the *Avataṃsaka*.

In the *Avataṃsaka Sūtra’s* “Entry into the Dharma Realm” chapter, when the youth Sudhana visits the eighteenth kalyāṇamitra, King Great Light in the city of Wondrous Light, he is taught the gateway of the great compassion banner, which deeply accords with the Old Master’s principle of “taking great compassion as foremost, relieving suffering and bestowing joy.” From this, one may also perceive the wondrous responsiveness of great compassion, which transcends the reach of thought and discourse—truly, it is the Buddha’s supreme virtue in transforming others. The sūtra states:

At that time, the king declared: “Good son, I have purely cultivated the bodhisattva’s practice of the great compassion banner; I have fulfilled the bodhisattva’s practice of the great compassion banner. Good son, in the presence of immeasurable hundreds of thousands of myriads of koṭis of buddhas, beyond reckoning or description, I inquired into this Dharma, pondered, observed, cultivated, and adorned it. Good son, I take this Dharma as my sovereign; with this Dharma, I instruct; with this Dharma, I embrace; with this Dharma, I follow the world; with this Dharma, I guide beings; with this Dharma, I lead beings to cultivate practice; with this Dharma, I lead beings to enter the path; with this Dharma, I provide expedient means; with this Dharma, I inspire beings to be imbued; with this Dharma, I arouse beings to action; with this Dharma, I establish beings in contemplating the self-nature of all dharmas; with this Dharma, I establish beings in the mind of compassion. Taking compassion as the foundation, perfecting the power of compassion, I thus enable them to abide in benefit. With a mind of joy, a mind of pity, a mind of embrace, a mind of guarding beings without abandonment, a mind of tirelessly relieving the suffering of beings—through this Dharma, I enable all beings to attain ultimate bliss, ever delighting in themselves, as if their bodies were free from all suffering, their minds purified, cutting off the craving for birth and death, delighting in the joy of the true Dharma, washing away the defilements of afflictions, shattering the obstructions of evil karma, severing the flow of birth and death, entering the ocean of true Dharma, cutting off all attachments, seeking omniscience, purifying the ocean of the mind, and generating unshakable faith. Good son, I have abided in this practice of the great compassion banner and am able to teach and transform the world with the true Dharma. Good son, in my land, all beings have no fear of me. Good son, if there are beings who are poor and destitute, coming to me with requests, I open my treasuries and storehouses, allowing them to take freely, saying to them: ‘Do not commit evil, do not harm beings, do not arise views, do not generate attachments. You who are poor and lacking—if there is anything you need, come to me and to the four directions; all things, in great variety and abundance, are here for you to take as you wish. Do not hesitate or doubt.’”

"Good son, in this land, when the world is in the Five Defilements, all beings delight in committing various evils. My heart grieves with compassion and desires to save and protect them, so I enter the gateway of the bodhisattva’s samādhi, with great compassion as its foremost, following the ways of the world. When I enter this samādhi, all the fearful, afflictive, demonic, and contentious minds of those beings instantly vanish. Why is this so? Because when one enters the bodhisattva’s samādhi with great compassion as its foremost, following the ways of the world, the Dharma is thus.

Good son, wait but a moment, and you shall witness it yourself. Then King Great Light entered this samādhi, and within his city, six kinds of tremors arose. The jeweled ground, jeweled walls, jeweled halls, jeweled palaces, terraces, pavilions, towers, stairways, doors, and windows—all emitted wondrous sounds, each bowing in reverence toward the king. All the inhabitants of the Radiant Light City simultaneously rejoiced and leapt with joy, prostrating themselves before the king. From villages, encampments, and cities, all people came to see the king, rejoicing and bowing in reverence. Even the birds and beasts near the king’s dwelling gazed at one another, arousing minds of compassion, and all bowed in reverence before the king. Every mountain, plain, and all grasses and trees turned toward the king in reverence. Ponds, pools, springs, wells, rivers, and seas all surged and overflowed, flowing before the king. Ten thousand dragon kings raised great clouds of fragrance, flashing lightning and rumbling thunder, pouring down a fine, gentle rain. Ten thousand deva kings—such as King Śakra of the Trāyastriṃśa Heaven, King Yama of the Suyāma Heaven, King Tuṣita of the Tuṣita Heaven, King Nirmāṇarati of the Nirmāṇarati Heaven, and King Paranirmitavaśavartin of the Paranirmitavaśavartin Heaven—led the host, playing wondrous music in the sky. Countless celestial maidens sang praises, raining down clouds of innumerable flowers, clouds of incense, clouds of jeweled garlands, clouds of jeweled robes, clouds of jeweled canopies, and clouds of jeweled banners, adorning the sky in offering to the king. The great elephant king Airāvaṇa, by his sovereign power, spread countless jeweled lotus flowers in the sky, hanging countless jeweled necklaces, jeweled ribbons, jeweled garlands, jeweled ornaments, jeweled flowers, and jeweled incense, adorned with all manner of wondrous embellishments. Countless celestial maidens sang praises in various melodies.

Within Jambudvīpa, there were further countless hundreds of thousands of myriads of koṭis of rākṣasa kings, yakṣa kings, kumbhāṇḍa kings, and piśāca kings—some dwelling in the great seas, others on land, drinking blood and devouring flesh, harming beings—yet all aroused minds of compassion, wishing to act for the benefit of others, clearly discerning future lives, refraining from evil, and joining their palms in reverence, bowing their heads to the king. Just as in Jambudvīpa, so too in the other three continents, and even throughout the three-thousand great-thousand worlds, extending to the ten directions in hundreds of thousands of myriads of nayutas of worlds, all poisonous and evil beings were likewise transformed."

The great compassion banner practice cultivated by King Great Light, and the great compassion samādhi he entered, moved even grasses, trees, birds, and beasts to bow in reverence. Towers and jeweled pavilions emitted wondrous sounds in praise, bowing in reverence—truly inconceivable. For when compassion pervades the world, both sentient and insentient beings throughout the world are moved without exception. The power of the mind is boundless, and thus the power of compassion is boundless. The mutual resonance of response and Dao is beyond all reckoning.

In the degenerate age of the final kalpa, when strife and conflict are entrenched, humans slaughter one another, blood flows like a river, and bombardments reduce cities to ruins—apart from taking the bodhisattva’s gateway of practice, with great compassion as its foremost, following the ways of the world, how else could one transform their poisonous minds, avert this great calamity, and restore harmony among all beings?

Confucius said, *"Repay resentment with uprightness, and repay virtue with virtue."* Yet Laozi taught, *"Repay resentment with virtue,"* treating friend and foe equally. Thus, the compassion of the sage Laozi surpasses that of the sage Confucius, equaling that of the Buddha, the World-Honored One.

When the Perfected One Tao Hongjing of the Liang dynasty had completed his Daoist cultivation and awaited the imperial summons for his ascension, the summons was long delayed. One day, two azure youths and a white crane descended from the sky. The Perfected One thought the celestial decree had arrived, but one youth proclaimed an edict from the Most High, summoning Huan Kai to ascend to heaven—not Tao. At that time, Kai was serving the Perfected One Tao. Tao then said to him, *"I have cultivated the Dao with utmost diligence. Why this prolonged delay in the world? I wish you to inquire on my behalf."* Three days later, Kai descended again to Tao’s chamber and said, *"Your hidden merits are manifest. In compiling the *Bencao* (Materia Medica), you used gadflies and leeches as medicine. Though your work benefits people, it harms living creatures, and thus your ascension is delayed. After another twelve years, you shall be released."* The Perfected One then composed a separate *Bencao* using only herbs and plants that could replace living creatures. Later, he indeed achieved liberation through the body.

The Perfected One Sun Simiao of the Tang dynasty compiled the *Qianjin Fang* (Prescriptions Worth a Thousand Gold). A celestial being descended and said to him, *"The prescriptions you have compiled harm living creatures. You shall become an immortal through liberation of the body, but you will not ascend lightly."* Sun Simiao then replaced the gadflies and leeches with herbs and plants, composing the *Qianjin Yifang* (Supplement to the Prescriptions Worth a Thousand Gold) in thirty scrolls.

Consider this: if killing even the smallest creatures to save people runs counter to the will of Heaven, how much more so does the slaughter of fattened animals to fill one’s belly? The sage Laozi taught people to be compassionate toward others, urging them to always save living beings. Yet if one kills living creatures to fill the kitchen, does this not greatly contradict his teachings? Those who learn from the sage Laozi’s teachings on longevity but disregard his compassion toward others act out of selfishness and self-interest, their virtue deficient. They shall never succeed—this can be stated with certainty.

Formerly, Master Wang told me: "In cultivating oneself, emptiness and quiescence are the fundamental principle; in conducting oneself in the world, benevolence and compassion are the essentials. Yet what is called benevolence and compassion also divides into active and passive forms. Active compassion lies in relieving suffering and bestowing joy, in delivering and aiding sentient beings; passive compassion merely refrains from afflicting or harming any sentient being and restrains all actions that would disadvantage them. Mencius said: 'A man must first refrain from certain actions before he can act.' Thus, only by practicing passive compassion—refraining from afflicting all sentient beings—can one then relieve suffering and bestow joy, practicing active compassion with full strength. Beginners in compassionate practice may first cultivate passive compassion."

**79. Sincerity Is Most Potent**
My late master taught: "In cultivating the Dao, one must attain utmost sincerity and single-minded focus. This character *cheng* (sincerity) cannot be transmitted even between father and son, let alone between master and disciple. At the extreme of sincerity, even metal and stone yield." *The Doctrine of the Mean* states: "There has never been one who remained unmoved by utmost sincerity; without sincerity, none can move others. Only the utmost sincerity under heaven can effect transformation, for utmost sincerity is spirit-like."

I say: Sincerity is the true and real mind. Utmost sincerity is the mind’s essence concentrated into oneness, untouched by extraneous thoughts. It proceeds without calculating fortune or misfortune, gain or loss, harm or benefit, never looking back. With unwavering single-mindedness, it possesses the three powers of the mind: great faith, great courage, and great stability. When the firing process reaches this stage, the eight winds cannot shake it. The mind’s essence becomes dense and aligned, achieving unimpeded communion. Thus, it can resonate with the Dao and interact without obstruction. Without the mind of utmost sincerity, one can never achieve the Dao. This is the sole provision for the path to the Dao. All past sages and worthies perfected the Dao’s fruit within this. Scholars ought to set their minds to it!

*The Perfect Wanderer’s "True Admonitions"* states: "Once there was a man who loved the Dao but did not know its methods. Day and night, he faced a cypress tree and bowed to it, seeking longevity. After twenty-eight years, the tree blossomed abundantly, its sweetness like malt sugar. He ate of it and became an immortal. Some bowed to Mount Taihua and received the Dao from the Old Man of the Western Peak; others bowed to the Yellow River, and after ten years, the River Earl taught them the method of walking on water without drowning. There is no other reason for this—it is the power of utmost sincerity." Examples like Wang Xiang lying on ice to catch a carp or Geng Gong praying to a well to draw forth water are also cases of utmost sincerity. When the light of the mind is concentrated and unshaken, whether in movement or stillness, it can move things and achieve communion. This is what Buddhism calls "the three realms are only mind."

*The Book of Master Lie*’s "Emperor Huang" chapter relates: "The Fan family had a son named Zihua, who was skilled at cultivating his private reputation. The entire state admired him, and he was favored by the Lord of Jin. Though he did not hold office, he ranked above the three ministers. Whatever he glanced at, the state ennobled; whatever he spoke ill of, the state demoted. Those who frequented his courtyard equaled the court’s officials. Zihua had his retainers attack one another with cunning and vulgarity, bully the weak, and though they were wounded before him, he paid no heed. Day and night, he made this his amusement, and the state nearly became accustomed to it.

Two men, He Sheng and Zi Bo, discussed Zihua’s fame and power, saying he could make the living die and the dead live, the rich poor and the poor rich. Shang Qiu Kai, who had long suffered from hunger and cold, secretly listened from behind the north window. He borrowed grain and carried a basket to Zihua’s gate. Zihua’s disciples were all from noble families, dressed in fine silk and riding grand carriages, walking slowly with haughty gazes. Seeing Shang Qiu Kai—old, weak, dark-faced, and poorly dressed—they all sneered at him. Soon, they mocked and deceived him, stopping at nothing. Shang Qiu Kai never showed anger, and the guests’ tricks were simple, exhausted by their taunts.

Then, they all ascended a high terrace. Amid the crowd, someone casually said: 'Whoever can throw themselves down will be rewarded with a hundred gold.' The crowd all clamored to comply. Shang Qiu Kai believed it was true and jumped first. His form soared like a bird, landing lightly on the ground without injury. The Fan family’s followers thought it a coincidence and did not yet find it strange.

They then pointed to a deep bend in the river and said: 'There is a treasure pearl in there; you can swim to retrieve it.' Shang Qiu Kai again swam after it. When he emerged, he indeed held a pearl. The crowd began to suspect. Zihua then ordered that he be given meat, fine clothes, and silk. Soon after, a great fire broke out in the Fan family’s storehouse. Zihua said: 'Whoever can enter the fire to retrieve brocade will be rewarded according to how much they bring out.' Shang Qiu Kai went without hesitation, entering and exiting the flames. Not a speck of dust clung to him, nor was his body scorched.

The Fan family’s followers, believing him to possess the Dao, all apologized: 'We did not know you possessed the Dao and deceived you; we did not know you were a divine person and humiliated you. You must think us fools, deaf, or blind. We dare ask: what is your Dao?'"

Shang Qiu Kai said: "I possess no Dao. Even in my own heart, I know not how this came to be. Yet there is one thing—let me try to speak of it to you.

Once, two guests lodged at my home and spoke in praise of the Fan family’s power, saying they could make the living perish and the dead live, the rich poor and the poor rich. I believed them without doubt, and so I came without hesitation. When I arrived, I took your followers’ words as truth, fearing only that my belief was not sincere enough, that my actions fell short. I knew not where to place my body or where profit and harm lay—I simply focused my heart, and nothing opposed me. That was all.

Today, I realize your followers deceived me. Within, I harbored suspicion; without, I clung to appearances and perceptions. Now, recalling how I once escaped unscorched and undrowned, I burn with shame and tremble with dread. How could I ever again draw near to water or fire?"

From then on, the disciples of the Fan family, whenever they encountered beggars or horse-doctors on the road, dared not humiliate them, but would alight from their carriages to bow.

Zai Wo heard of this and told Confucius. Confucius said: "Did you not know?"

The person of utmost sincerity can move all things. Stirring heaven and earth, moving ghosts and spirits, traversing the six directions without obstruction—how could this be limited to treading perilous paths or entering water and fire? If even Shang Qiu Kai, deceived by false things, remained unobstructed, how much more so when both self and other are sincere? Take heed, disciples!

This passage describes the efficacy of perfect sincerity, all arising from the congealing of the heart’s light and the singularity of focused sincerity. For those who cultivate the Dao, when the firing times reach this stage, the elixir may be formed. Shang Qiu Kai could cast himself to the ground unharmed, swim through water without drowning, and enter fire without scorching—all because his body and mind remained unmoved, so that events merged with principle and things could not oppose him. This is what is meant by "harmony enters the great sameness with things."

Alas! The function of sincerity is indeed supreme.

The eighty-first chapter, *Hui Zui Chao* (Supreme Wisdom)

Sincerity is the congealing of the heart’s essence into oneness, without falling into a second thought—this belongs to the power of concentration. When concentration reaches its peak, illumination arises, and unimpeded wisdom manifests. This is the power of wisdom.

*Zhuangzi* says: "Correctness leads to stillness, stillness to clarity, clarity to emptiness." It also says: "That and this find no counterpart—this is called the pivot of the Dao. When the pivot is grasped at the center of the circle, it can respond to the infinite. This is one infinity, that is another infinity—thus it is said: nothing compares to clarity." Again: "When one follows the inner communication of the ears and eyes while transcending the knowledge of the heart-mind, even ghosts and spirits will come to dwell—how much more so humans? This is the transformation of the ten thousand things." And: "Only after one has transcended life externally can one attain morning clarity. With morning clarity, one can see the solitary. Seeing the solitary, one can transcend past and present. Transcending past and present, one can enter the realm of neither birth nor death."

The commentary states: Clarity, penetration, and morning clarity—all are states where wisdom arises. Clarity is the radiance of the heart’s light, illuminating all dharmas with perfect illumination—this is the wondrous luminosity of original wisdom. With original wisdom, all realms are pervaded and embraced without obstruction or stagnation. When realm and wisdom interpenetrate, self and other become identical, allowing one to transform adversity and prosperity, life and death, at will—all perfectly fitting. This is the wondrous function of the center of the circle, enabling one to respond to conditions and interact with beings with infinite transformation.

In the *Great Master* chapter, this is also called "Zhan Ming" (Illuminating Clarity), referring to this same wondrous luminosity. Moreover, "the inner communication of the ears and eyes" signifies the perfect realization of the one mind, while "transcending the knowledge of the heart-mind" means departing from the deluded knowledge of the six senses. This is the true state where wisdom arises—seeing without eyes, hearing without ears, the six senses restored, different natures merging into sameness, the solitary radiance of spiritual light transcending the roots and dust. This is what is called true knowing.

*Zhuangzi* says: "Only after there is a true person is there true knowing; knowing arises from not-knowing." Guan Yinzi says: "Knowing yet forgetting emotion, being capable yet not acting—this is true knowing and true capability." I note: The phrase "knowing yet forgetting emotion" deeply accords with the *Śūraṅgama Sūtra*’s principle of "knowing without seeing, which is the untainted purity of nirvāṇa." The phrase "knowing arises from not-knowing" especially resonates with the Chan school’s saying of "the first glimmer of awareness in the skull without perception." This is indeed the crux of the Daoist school’s wisdom and the ultimate teaching of Lao-Zhuang’s mind-ground Dharma.

Thus, the Chan master Sanping’s verse says:
*"This seeing and hearing are not the mind’s hearing,
No other colors or sounds can be presented to you.
Within this, if you fully understand, all is settled—
Substance and function pose no obstacle, whether divided or undivided."*

The Perfected One Miaozheng says: "Only when seeing and hearing are extinguished within seeing can one attain the great rest." The Perfected One Ziyang says: "When encountering realms, if the mind is absent, only then can one see the face of bodhi." All these express the profound principle of "knowing yet forgetting emotion."

Such clear seeing of one’s nature is true wisdom, also called the wisdom of thusness, untainted wisdom, unstained wisdom, unmoving wisdom, the wisdom of all-wisdom, and the wisdom of self-awakened sagacity. The *Lotus Sūtra* states: "The Tathāgata appears in the world to open, show, awaken, and cause entry into the Buddha’s knowledge and vision"—this refers precisely to this. The *Avataṃsaka Sūtra*’s *Departing the Worldly* chapter says:

"The bodhisattva mahāsattva possesses ten kinds of discriminating wisdom. What are the ten? They are: the wisdom of knowing the distinctions among sentient beings, the wisdom of knowing the distinctions among faculties, the wisdom of knowing the distinctions of karmic retribution, the wisdom of knowing the distinctions of rebirth, the wisdom of knowing the distinctions among worlds, the wisdom of knowing the distinctions among buddhas, the wisdom of knowing the distinctions among dharmas, the wisdom of knowing the distinctions of the three times, and the wisdom of knowing the distinctions of all languages and paths—these are the ten. If bodhisattvas abide in this Dharma, they attain the Tathāgata’s supreme, vast, and boundless discriminating wisdom."

It also says:
"The bodhisattva mahāsattva possesses ten kinds of wisdom that follow awakening. What are the ten? They are: the wisdom that follows awakening to the immeasurable distinctions of all worlds, the wisdom that follows awakening to the inconceivable distinctions among all sentient beings, the wisdom that follows awakening to all dharmas entering one into many and many into one, the wisdom that follows awakening to the vastness of the entire dharma realm, the wisdom that follows awakening to the ultimate nature of all space, the wisdom that follows awakening to all worlds entering the past, the wisdom that follows awakening to all worlds entering the present and future, the wisdom that follows awakening to all the immeasurable vows and practices of the tathāgatas being perfectly fulfilled in one wisdom, and the wisdom that follows awakening to all buddhas of the three times attaining liberation through the same practice—these are the ten. If bodhisattvas abide in this Dharma, they attain the autonomous luminosity of all dharmas, fulfilling all vows in a single thought-moment, instantly comprehending all buddha-dharmas, and attaining perfect enlightenment."

It further states:
"The bodhisattva mahāsattva possesses ten kinds of wisdom that give birth to wisdom. What are the ten?"

The ten kinds of wisdom that give birth to wisdom are as follows:

The wisdom that knows how all sentient beings attain liberation,
The wisdom that knows the various distinctions among all buddha-realms,
The wisdom that knows the divisions of the ten-directional net,
The wisdom that knows the arising of all worlds—whether inverted or upright,
The wisdom that knows all dharmas, their one nature, their various natures, and their vast abiding,
The wisdom that knows the arising of all kinds of bodies,
The wisdom that knows all dharmas ultimately attain liberation through the one Dao,
The wisdom that knows the tathāgata’s divine power enters all dharma-realms,
The wisdom that knows the buddha-nature of all sentient beings in the three times is unbroken—
these are the ten.

If bodhisattvas abide in this Dharma, they comprehend all within it without exception.

It further states:
"The bodhisattva mahāsattva possesses ten kinds of anuttara-samyak-saṃbodhi wisdom vast as the ocean. What are the ten?

Entering all immeasurable realms of sentient beings—this is the first ocean-like wisdom.
Entering all worlds without discrimination—this is the second ocean-like wisdom.
Knowing the immeasurable, unimpeded vastness of all space, universally entering the ten directions and all differentiated world-nets—this is the third ocean-like wisdom.
The bodhisattva mahāsattva skillfully enters the dharma-realm, that is: unimpeded entry, unbroken entry, non-abiding entry, immeasurable entry, unborn entry, undying entry, all-pervading entry, and complete comprehension—this is the fourth ocean-like wisdom.
The bodhisattva mahāsattva fully comprehends all the roots of goodness accumulated by buddhas, bodhisattvas, dharma-teachers, voice-hearers, solitary realizers, and all ordinary beings in the past, present, and future—whether already accumulated, presently accumulating, or to be accumulated in the future—as well as all the roots of goodness of the three-time buddhas in their attainment of anuttara-samyak-saṃbodhi—whether already attained, presently attaining, or to be attained—and all the roots of goodness from the three-time buddhas’ teachings and subduing of all sentient beings—whether already taught, presently teaching, or to be taught—this is the fifth ocean-like wisdom.
The bodhisattva mahāsattva, in each thought-moment, enters the past for incalculable eons. In a single eon, there may be a hundred koṭis of buddhas appearing, a hundred thousand koṭis of buddhas appearing, or an uncountable, immeasurable, boundless, incomparable, innumerable, inconceivable, unmeasurable, inexpressible number of buddhas appearing—even an inexpressible, inexpressible number beyond all calculation. All such tathāgatas arise in the world, along with their assemblies at the bodhimaṇḍa, their voice-hearers and bodhisattvas, their teachings and subduing of beings, the lifespans of all beings, and the duration of the Dharma—all of this is clearly perceived. Just as in one eon, so too in all eons. Even in eons without buddhas, all sentient beings who plant roots of goodness for anuttara-samyak-saṃbodhi are fully known. If there are sentient beings whose roots of goodness have matured and who will encounter a buddha in the future, this too is fully known. Observing the past for inexpressible, inexpressible eons in this way, the mind is never wearied—this is the sixth ocean-like wisdom.
The bodhisattva mahāsattva enters the future and observes, discerning all eons—immeasurable and boundless—knowing which eons have buddhas and which do not, how many tathāgatas appear in each eon, the names of each tathāgata, the worlds they inhabit, the names of those worlds, the number of beings they liberate, and their lifespans. Observing in this way throughout the entire future, all is fully known without exhaustion, yet without weariness—this is the seventh ocean-like wisdom.
The bodhisattva mahāsattva enters the present and contemplates, observing in each thought-moment all the immeasurable, inexpressible worlds of the ten directions. In each, buddhas have attained, are attaining, or will attain supreme enlightenment. They approach the bodhimaṇḍa, sit beneath the bodhi-tree on auspicious grass, subdue the demon armies, and attain anuttara-samyak-saṃbodhi. Rising from there, they enter cities and ascend celestial palaces, expound the subtle Dharma, turn the great Dharma-wheel, display supernatural powers, and subdue beings. Finally, they entrust the Dharma of anuttara-samyak-saṃbodhi, relinquish their lives, and enter parinirvāṇa. After entering parinirvāṇa, they compile the Dharma-store, ensuring its long abiding, and adorn stūpas with various offerings. They also see all beings in those worlds who encounter buddhas, hear the Dharma, receive and uphold it, recite and contemplate it, and develop wisdom. Observing in this way, they universally perceive the ten directions without error in the buddha-Dharma, entering the count of eons without weariness—this is the eighth ocean-like wisdom.
The bodhisattva mahāsattva, for inexpressible, inexpressible eons, in each eon, makes offerings and pays homage to inexpressible, inexpressible, immeasurable buddhas. Manifesting rebirth from one life to the next, they make offerings with all requisites surpassing the three realms, and also make offerings to bodhisattvas, voice-hearers, and all great assemblies. After each tathāgata enters parinirvāṇa, they make supreme offerings to the relics and widely practice generosity, fulfilling the needs of all beings and bodhisattvas. With inconceivable mind, non-seeking mind, ultimate mind, beneficent mind, and for inexpressible, inexpressible eons, they make offerings to the buddhas for the sake of anuttara-samyak-saṃbodhi, benefit sentient beings, uphold the true Dharma, and expound it—this is the ninth ocean-like wisdom.
The bodhisattva mahāsattva, at a single buddha’s place, bodhisattva’s place, or dharma-teacher’s place, single-mindedly seeks the Dharma taught by bodhisattvas—learning, teaching, practicing, purifying, and the Dharma of total retention. Having obtained this Dharma, they receive, uphold, recite, and explain it without weariness, inspiring immeasurable beings to arouse the mind corresponding to omniscience in the buddha-Dharma, enter true reality, and attain non-retrogression in anuttara-samyak-saṃbodhi. The bodhisattva, in this way, for inexpressible, inexpressible eons, is never wearied—this is the tenth ocean-like wisdom."

Bodhisattvas, mahāsattvas, these are the ten ocean-like wisdoms of anuttara-samyak-saṃbodhi. If all bodhisattvas abide in this Dharma, they will attain the great wisdom-ocean of all buddhas’ supreme omniscience.”

The *Sutra of the Six Pāramitās* states:
“Wisdom is the root,
Giving rise to the sprout of wholesome dharmas.
The great bodhi-fruit of the buddhas
Is wrought by nothing but wisdom.”

Thus it is known that the wisdom of the buddhas is most transcendent and supreme. From the Song and Yuan dynasties onward, those immortals who realized the Dao—such as Sanfeng, Ziyang, and Miaozheng—all fully awakened to the One Mind, subtly accorded with true reality, and truly entered wisdom. They may be considered equal in measure to the patriarchs of the Chan school.

81. **Abandoning the Most Difficult**

The *Compendium of Divine Immortals* records that the Dark Emperor perfected the Dao and ascended from the Flying Ascension Cliff on Mount Wudang, demonstrating to disciples the essential principle of abandoning the body. The venerable Laozi taught, “Put the body outside, place it behind”—this is the meaning of abandoning the body. Master Tan’s “forgetting form, forgetting qi, forgetting spirit” is also the practice of abandoning the body. Alas, how deeply worldly people cling to attachment! Even external wealth and possessions they are unwilling to relinquish—how much less this body? My late teacher lamented this and composed *The Three Teachings Unified*, teaching everywhere that one must abandon this corporeal form and nurture spirit, regulate breath, in the emptiness beyond the body.

In the *General Explanation of the Unified Teaching*, it is said:
“The great Way of the Golden Elixir is entirely a matter of the emptiness beyond the body. If even the slightest thought clings to the post-heaven corporeal form, it is already off by a hair’s breadth, and the elixir will not be formed.”

He also once told me:
“To speak of it in ultimate terms, saying it has no connection with this body is still superficial. The practice must be carried to the point where it has no relation whatsoever to mind, knowing, intention, or consciousness—only then is it true pre-heaven. Not only must the corporeal form be abandoned, but the mind and consciousness must also be relinquished. Only when one reaches the state of great samādhi and true samādhi, the realm of emptiness of both body and mind, does one accord with the profound meaning of ‘putting the body outside yet preserving it,’ and personally realize what is prior to the image of the Lord. One transcends the other shore of Sound-Before-Sound. When cultivation reaches this point, reversing aging and restoring youth becomes as easy as turning one’s palm.”

My late teacher, in replying to Meng Junhan on the meaning of abandoning the body, said:
“These two words, ‘abandoning the body,’ are most crucial. Let me explain further. Disciples must first know that only by relinquishing the corporeal form can one cultivate the Dharma-body. The corporeal form, being formed, is inevitably subject to decay; the Dharma-body, being formless, is truly real. If one does not first abandon the post-heaven corporeal form, the pre-heaven Dharma-body cannot ascend. The scriptures say: When the heart dies, the spirit lives; when the consciousness-spirit is extinguished, the original spirit appears. *Laozi* says: ‘Place it behind, and it comes first; put it outside, and it is preserved.’ It also says: ‘Put it outside, and it is cultivated; forget the form, and the form is perfected.’ ‘My greatest worry is that I have a body; if I had no body, what worry would I have?’ Confucius said: ‘If one hears the Dao in the morning, one may die in the evening.’ Lüzu said: ‘To kill life after it is born, to learn death before one dies—this is long life.’ All these teach one to abandon the corporeal form and cultivate the Dharma-body. Bai Yuchan said: ‘A word or half a phrase can penetrate the mystery—what need is there for a thousand or ten thousand volumes of elixir scriptures? If one is not burdened by form, the Great Brahmā Heaven is right before one’s eyes.’ In learning the Dao, the greatest fear is clinging to the corporeal form.

Let me make this even clearer: In all practice, if one feels even the slightest flicker, the faintest movement, or the briefest stirring within the body, one must swiftly turn to the mutual reliance of heart and breath outside. This is the true oral instruction of the two words ‘abandoning the body.’ Thus, the True Lord of Emptiness and Stillness said: ‘Let him do as he will, let him act as he pleases, pay him no mind—he is he, how can he affect me?’ Ponder this deeply!

The ten thousand volumes of elixir scriptures all speak of guarding against danger. But what danger is there in learning the Dao? What is this danger? In practice, if one feels even the slightest flicker, the faintest movement, or the briefest stirring within the body, and does not swiftly turn to the mutual reliance of heart and breath outside, this is great danger. Over time, it will surely lead to serious illness. But if one knows to swiftly turn to the mutual reliance of heart and breath outside, there is no danger. Even if there are one or two, three or four instances of leakage, it is of no concern. With long practice, the illness of seminal leakage will naturally disappear. This is the verified effect of my own past practice.”

He also said:
“If wandering thoughts arise and vanish of their own accord, this is precisely the danger of not swiftly turning to the mutual reliance of heart and breath outside. From now on, whenever you practice, if you feel even the slightest flicker, the faintest movement, or the briefest wandering thought in the mind, you must swiftly turn to the mutual reliance of heart and breath outside. If you feel even the slightest flicker, the faintest movement, or the briefest stirring of internal qi within the body—whether it brings ease or joy—you must even more swiftly turn to the mutual reliance of heart and breath outside. If you feel even the slightest stirring, the faintest movement, or the briefest arousal of the yang organ, regardless of whether it is firm or soft, you must swiftly turn to the mutual reliance of heart and breath outside. Practice this for three months, and body and mind will naturally become still and settled, qi and blood will naturally harmonize and flow smoothly, and leakage will naturally cease. The effects are truly swift—do not take this lightly!

I endured over twenty years of hardship seeking the oral instructions of a teacher, and this is precisely the oral instruction I sought. I see that you cling to images, words, and the snares of the corporeal form—this is truly lamentable. Thus, I speak from the depths of my heart to tell you this.

In sum, the great Way of the Golden Elixir, from beginning to end, entirely takes the mutual reliance of heart and breath outside the body as its starting point and its conclusion. Thus, the ten thousand volumes of elixir scriptures all say it is most simple and most easy. If even the slightest flicker, the faintest movement, or the briefest thought clings to the corporeal form, it is no longer most simple and most easy.”

Alas! Once you have seen and believed, when practicing the work, swiftly and urgently abandon the body.”

Master Jialingyin of the Qing Dynasty states in *Essentials of Sectarian Inspection*: “The effort of breaking through must involve doubt; after breaking through, the effort must be abandoned. If even the slightest perception, hearing, awareness, or knowledge—even wisdom and virtuous attributes—is not relinquished, nothing will be complete; if even the smallest thing is not abandoned, nothing will be perfect. The two layers of effort—doubt and abandonment—are such that doubt is easy, while abandonment is difficult.”

This is why the ancients devoted their entire lives to diligent practice, refusing to halt their transformation midway: they would not deceive their own hearts. Master Yuanyu Qin of the Song Dynasty said: “A true master of the school permits only the abandonment of knowledge and views, leaving not even a hair’s breadth in the mind. Empty and vast like the great void, nurtured and ripened over time—this is the original scenery, the original face.”

He also said: “In walking, standing, sitting, and lying down, there is nothing that is not thoroughly penetrated, no separation in any phenomenon. This is called ‘pure as the bright dew,’ the singular clarity of one’s own mind. Yet one must not merely guard it, for guarding leads to stagnation. Instead, one must bravely sever and utterly abandon it. The more one abandons, the clearer one becomes; the farther one turns away, the nearer one draws. Only by resolutely dismantling, casting aside one’s very life, does one become a corpse devoid of breath—then, and only then, can one tread the path beyond. This is known only to oneself; even knowledge is not established. Śākyamuni, Maitreya, Mañjuśrī, Samantabhadra, Deshan, Linji—none dare gaze directly upon it. Is this not a wondrous matter?”

The insights of both Chan and Daoist adepts on the effort of abandonment are exceedingly subtle and meticulous. Generally, those who enter the Way must be able to abandon at all times, not merely during practice. Whenever one encounters attachments to worldly affairs or the arising of habitual tendencies and sensory desires, one must wield the Diamond King’s precious sword, fiercely severing all without leaving the slightest residue. The mind of clinging is the most difficult to cure; the most wondrous method of dealing with it is to separate it from the corporeal body and lodge it within the emptiness of space. Once it beholds the King of Emptiness, it can only surrender, powerless to develop further schemes.

Thus, the profound tradition of refining spirit in the void, harmonizing with the breath, and dissolving into formlessness, merging with the great emptiness, is truly the wondrous method for subduing the mind, the secret treasury of abandoning the body, the swift path to attaining truth, and the precious raft for transcending the mundane. From the ancient sages to the present, over four thousand years have passed, with transmission from master to master unbroken. For those of us who love the Way and encounter this teaching, how can we not rejoice and resolutely commit to cultivation?
