**155. Knowing Glory and Guarding Humility**
The ancient sage said: “Know its glory, guard its humility, and become the valley of the world. As the valley of the world, the constant virtue is fulfilled, and one returns to simplicity.”

Explanation: Glory and humility are metaphorical expressions, ultimately pointing to body and mind. The mind’s essence is vast, embracing the ten thousand images—this is the ever-abiding true mind, the inherently pure and luminous substance, unchanging through kalpas, utterly transcendent. This is the image of glory. The four great elements of the physical body are a temporary aggregation, impure and turbid—this is the image of humility.

If one forgets the body and unites the mind with the breath, empties all that exists, and harmonizes mind and breath, forgetting both glory and humility, gradually attaining great tranquility, then inner and outer both become empty, forming a circle ○. This image is called the “hollow center,” the valley of the world.

When body and mind are both forgotten and the roots and dust are extinguished, the primordial true yang qi surges through the passes to the crown, embracing the dharma-body and nurturing the physical form, nourishing both inner and outer. Body and mind become one, guest and host merge, form and emptiness unite, equality without duality, wondrously accordant with thusness. The constant virtue is fulfilled. The six consciousnesses forgotten, the three poisons extinguished, one returns to the primordial chaos, where being and non-being are not established, and neither the realms of sage nor ordinary can contain it. This is the ultimate return to the source.

Alas! What surpasses this in the wonder of returning to simplicity?

**156. Spontaneous Arising and Conditioned Arising**
*Spontaneous arising* depends on the original source of self-nature, arising naturally and effortlessly. The ancient sage said: “Good conduct leaves no tracks, good planning requires no schemes, good closure has no bolts yet cannot be opened, good binding has no cords yet cannot be untied.”

*Zhuāngzǐ* said: “Neither this nor that can be deemed odd or even—this is called the pivot of the Dao. Only when the pivot is at the center of the ring can it respond endlessly.” He also said: “The clan of Rǎnxiàng attained the center of the ring and followed its completion, harmonizing with things without beginning or end, without near or far.” And again: “The perfected one’s mind is like a mirror—neither grasping nor rejecting, responding without concealing, thus able to master things without harm.” This is the teaching of spontaneous arising in the traditions of Lǎozǐ and Zhuāngzǐ.

In Buddhism, only the Chán and Huáyán schools speak of spontaneous arising; all other schools teach *conditioned arising*. The dharmas of conditioned arising are a mixture of truth and delusion, hence distinctions of defilement and purity arise. But self-nature is purely true, without delusion, pure and undefiled, responding to things without attachment, universally compliant without partiality. Though adorned with the ten thousand practices, not a single dust arises—only this is noble.

In the *Avataṃsaka Sūtra*, there is a bodhisattva named Wondrous Virtue of the Tathāgata’s Spontaneous Arising. Moreover, the adornments of the Flower Treasury World are all the great manifestations of the wondrous virtue of spontaneous arising. In the *Entering the Realm of Reality* chapter, Vasumitrā’s traces appear licentious, yet whether she licks, kisses, embraces, grasps, gazes, or touches, she enables beings to be liberated from emotional bondage and attain great benefit. This reveals the great function of the Tathāgata’s wondrous virtue of spontaneous arising. Since spontaneous arising is effortless, it can transform things.

Dependent arising follows things, thus is turned by them.
Turned by things, one sees things yet does not see the mind.
The wondrous action of non-action is ever dynamic, ever quiescent.

Moreover, the spontaneous arising of nature reveals the solitary truth alone;
dependent arising gives rise to the six senses’ conditioned blaze.
Spontaneous arising allows events to merge with principle, mind and realm dissolved;
dependent arising engages subject and object, knowledge and perception proliferating—
unable to attain purity, tranquility, or unity, as is only natural.

The Mysterious School’s Dharma-gate of spontaneous arising accords with the *Avataṃsaka*’s teaching of the Tathāgata’s wondrous virtue of spontaneous arising.
Thus the ancient sage said: “The Dao gives them birth; virtue nurtures them.”
Dependent arising mixes purity and defilement; spontaneous arising holds purity without defilement—
hence the ancient sage said: “Purity is the norm of the world.”
Dependent arising clings to mind, for subject and object have not perished;
spontaneous arising has no clinging mind, for subject and object do not arise.
Thus the ancient sage said: “It gives birth yet does not possess, acts yet does not rely, matures yet does not dominate—this is called mysterious virtue.”

Dependent arising establishes measure, inner and outer unmerged;
spontaneous arising transcends all measure, revealing the inexhaustible.
Thus *Zhuangzi* says: “Embodying the boundless, roaming without trace, without inner or outer, without beginning or end, without limit or time.”
Dependent arising belongs to duality; spontaneous arising belongs to non-duality—
hence *Zhuangzi* says: “The Dao unites as one.”
And again: “Knowledge unites as one.”
And: “The myriad things neither complete nor destroy, returning to unity.”
And: “After thirty thousand years, they form a single purity.”
The ancient sage said: “When united as one, the myriad things are complete.”
And again: “The sage embraces the One, serving as the world’s model.”

Thus the Mysterious School’s Dao fuses and pervades, the solitary truth alone revealed—
spanning past and present, manifesting perfect completion, dissolving self and other into unity.
Were one not of the highest wisdom, few would not sigh in awe.

The general outline of the Mysterious School and Chan School’s Dharma-gate of spontaneous arising is as above.
May I ask: what is its great function?
It is answered: emptiness, quiescence, and spontaneity—purity, tranquility, and unity.
Its wondrous aspect may be encompassed by the ancient sage’s two phrases:
“Non-action yet nothing left undone” and “Acting without acting.”
The Chan School calls this the “Dao of no effort.”

By “non-action yet nothing left undone,” it is ever quiescent, ever dynamic;
by “acting without acting,” it is ever dynamic, ever quiescent.
Ever quiescent yet ever dynamic, thus dwelling in non-being, nothing is not non-being;
ever dynamic yet ever quiescent, thus abiding in being, nothing is being.
Dwelling in non-being, nothing is not non-being—hence the great function flourishes, and the myriad virtues manifest.
Abiding in being, nothing is being—hence sagely wisdom fuses in emptiness, not a single dust arises.

As the *Treatise of Sengzhao* says: “Responsive transformation is boundless, yet it has never acted; quiescent and unmoving, yet it has never ceased acting.”
And again: “Not exhausting action, not abiding in non-action.”
This is truly the wondrous function of spontaneous arising, the profound practice of prajñā.
Chan and the Mysterious interpenetrate; the thousand sages share the same path.
Though its dust and chaff may seem insignificant, they suffice to mold the likes of Yao and Shun.

In Buddhism, the Hīnayāna relies on karmic dependent arising;
the Yogācāra school relies on the dependent arising of the eight consciousnesses;
the Three Treatises school relies on the dependent arising of true suchness;
the Esoteric school relies on the dependent arising of the six great elements.
The Tiantai school speaks only of nature-possession, not nature-arising—
nature-possession remains the tathāgatagarbha in bondage, whereas nature-arising reveals the wondrous function of the unobstructed true suchness.

In Chan, raising a fist or lifting a whisk, carrying water or moving firewood—
none are not the supreme truth.
Even a single staff-strike or shout can instantly open the wise one’s eye of wisdom,
instantly realizing the patience of non-arising—all the wondrousness of spontaneous arising.
*Zhuangzi*’s “acting without one” is likewise of this kind.

**Birth-and-death and death-and-birth**

The *Nirvāṇa Sūtra* says: “All conditioned things are impermanent; this is the Dharma of birth-and-death.”
The *Śūraṅgama Sūtra* says: “All conditioned things are impermanent; the nature of thought is unborn and undying.”
All teachings speak of birth-and-death, yet only the Chan and Mysterious Schools reveal death-and-birth.

As Chan Master Yuanwu said: “Leap from the precipice, willingly take responsibility; revive after absolute death—no deceiving the sovereign.”
The Chan tradition often speaks of “great death, great life”—this is the wondrous principle of death-and-birth.

The Mysterious School’s *Cantong Qi* says: “When the nodes are exhausted, they alternate and succeed; the embodied dragon revives.”
And: “The number of one and nine ends and begins anew; containing the primordial, empty and perilous, it scatters essence into the child.”
And: “From darkness to dawn, thunder arrives to receive the tally.”
And: “Concealing its frame, it sinks into the cavernous void; when metal restores its original nature, the cauldron’s radiance blazes.”
And: “When qi is exhausted and life nears its end, rest the death of the po and hun; the color shifts to purple, resplendently forming the returned elixir.”

This too reveals the wondrous principle of death-and-birth.
Birth then death is the forward course;
death then birth is the reverse turning—the mysterious mechanism of returning to life, the esoteric mystery of the elixir school.

To grasp the mysterious mechanism of death-and-birth and return to life,
one must first recognize the “empty space beyond the body”—this is where I am born.
Only by dying where one is born can one avoid falling into emptiness.
As the *Cantong Qi* says: “Know the white, guard the black—spirit and brightness will come of themselves.”
If one does not recognize the birthplace and merely seeks stillness, ceasing thoughts, with mind extinguished and will dissolved,
one falls into withered Chan and barren emptiness—spirit and brightness do not come, not the realm where “the withered tree sings like a dragon.”

Thus Confucius said: “Without knowing life, how can one know death?”

Dongshan said: “On withered trees, flowers bloom in a spring beyond kalpas; riding backward on a jade elephant, one chases the qilin.” This reveals the wonder of dying-and-living. The *Book of Changes*’ hexagrams *Bo* and *Fu* follow one another, conveying the same meaning. Likewise, the image of the *Ge* hexagram: the *Book of Changes* states, “Water and fire mutually extinguish.” Through mutual extinction, *Ge* is formed—this takes the meaning of extinction giving rise to life. Great death, great life—this is precisely the wonder of dying-and-living. The *Great Learning* says: “Things have roots and branches; affairs have ends and beginnings.” It does not speak of “beginning and end,” but of “end and beginning,” which also accords with the meaning of *Bo* and *Fu* following one another. Thus, the Daoist, Chan, and Confucian traditions—all reverse the current to emerge from the sea of birth and death—all grasp the esoteric principle of dying-and-living.

**The Small Self and the Great Self**
Zhuangzi said: “The perfected person has no self.” He also said: “In great sameness, there is no self.” This “no self” means only the absence of the small self, not the absence of the great self. The small self is the deluded attachment of sentient beings to this seven-foot body as “I.” The great self is the true self, the great Dharma-body. The ancient sages called it the “Great Image”; Zhuangzi called it the “Great One.” Master Donghua said: “The Dharma-body is vast and firm, pervading heaven and earth; the true nature is perfectly luminous, spanning past and present.” Master Heyang said: “I ask myself, who am I? Not knowing the true self, one vainly seeks truth. How could one know that the Great One contains the primordial beginning, penetrating earth and heaven as one body?” All these refer to the great self. The *Mahāparinirvāṇa Sūtra* sets forth the four virtues of permanence, bliss, self, and purity. The “self” here also refers to the great self, the Dharma-body. Thus the sutra says: “Because there is the great self, it is called the great *nirvāṇa*.” Chan Master Shoushan said: “In a silver world, a golden body—sentient and insentient share one truth.” Chan Master Xiaoshou said: “Mountains, rivers, and the great earth fully reveal the Dharma-king’s body.” The *Avataṃsaka Sūtra* says: “Only the one solid, dense body manifests in every speck of dust.” The *Great Comprehension Sūtra* says: “Suchness is natural, boundlessly vast.” All these illustrate the meaning of the great self. The small self is like a single bubble in the sea; the great self is the pure, vast ocean. Once the attachment to the body is shattered, the seventh consciousness transforms, the small self dissolves, and the great self manifests—mind and realm become one, self and other are undivided.

Master Sanfeng said: “The true heart is vast and boundless; infinite immortals emerge from within. Worldly people cling to the small form; the single pearl of mystery, people do not recognize.” The “small form” refers to the physical body, the small self. The “true heart vast and boundless” refers to the great self, the Dharma-body. The *Sūtra of Perfect Enlightenment* says: “All sentient beings, from beginningless time, have been variously inverted, mistakenly recognizing the four great elements as the form of their own bodies, and the shadows of the six sense-fields as the form of their own minds.” The *Śūraṅgama Sūtra* says: “It is like abandoning a hundred thousand clear seas and recognizing only a single bubble as the whole tide, exhausting the vast ocean—you are the awakened among the deluded.” This rebukes the inversion of clinging to the physical body as the small self. The Confucian practice of “overcoming the self” is precisely overcoming this small self. When “all under heaven returns to benevolence,” the original face of *Qian* appears, and the great self, the great Dharma-body, is revealed.

The Ming Confucian Zhao Dazhou’s *Admonition on Overcoming the Self* says: “I have a great self, which looks down upon the myriad things and observes heaven and earth. If the great self is not pervaded, the small self stands alone. Once the small self is overcome, the great self flows freely. The ancients who were good at overcoming the self saw the formless and heard the soundless. Their movements left no tracks; their words were not mere quotations. The four functions returned to the one; the one truth flowed freely. Without form or direction, ritual was refined and flourished. If one has even a slight intention, stubbornness, or attachment to the self, the wondrous function becomes stagnant, leading to paralysis—this is not benevolence, but clinging to the small self. Thus, ‘no self’ is overcoming; the ‘true self’ is great. The greatest is benevolence, embodying no duality. Without seeing great and small, how can one know inner and outer? Realizing this is called sagehood; next is worthiness. The foolish cling and grasp.”

I note that the sages of the Three Teachings all teach people to empty the small self and realize the great self. In the Daoist tradition, the practice lies in the interdependence of the heart and breath beyond the body. Through extreme dependence, one transforms and enters great samādhi, merging with true emptiness—this is precisely abandoning the small to pursue the great, dissolving the boundaries of inner and outer, revealing the whole of the one truth. As Master Sanfeng said: “The heart is as vast as the sun and moon; I and heaven-and-earth are inside and out.” And again: “The yang spirit’s wondrous body is one with the great void; a single grain of millet contains heaven and earth.” Master Ziyang said: “Send off the child riding a crane; when empty space shatters, the whole body is seen.” All these reveal the wonder of realizing the great self.

Zhuangzi’s “Seven Greats” says: “The Great One unites it; the Great Yin dissolves it; the Great Eye sees it; the Great Balance connects it; the Great Square embodies it; the Great Faith verifies it; the Great Samādhi holds it.” All these are images of the great self. Thus, the ancient worthies of the Chan school said: “The Dharma-realm is I; I am the Dharma-realm.” Those who merely take this seven-foot illusory body as “I,” not knowing to take the Dharma-realm as their body—how could they know the wonder of the great self?

**Nurturing Life and Preserving Life**
Zhuangzi was skilled in discussing nurturing life; Laozi was skilled in discussing preserving life. Zhuangzi said: “The true person of old did not dream in sleep, had no worries when awake, did not relish food, and breathed deeply. The true person’s breath reached the heels; ordinary people’s breath reaches only the throat.”

He also said: “Following the central channel as one’s guiding principle, one can preserve the body, perfect life, nurture one’s kin, and fulfill one’s years.” This is the essential purport of nurturing life: the primordial harmony circulates within, qi flourishes and spirit is whole.

Laozi said: “Attain utmost emptiness, abide in profound stillness; the myriad things arise together, and I observe their return. Returning to the root is called stillness; stillness is called recovering life; recovering life is called constancy; knowing constancy is called clarity.” He also said: “Return to simplicity, return to infancy, return to nothingness, return to the boundless.” Thus, returning to simplicity means the six dusts do not defile—this is the sublime truth of preserving life.

“Nurturing” means to cultivate and foster; “preserving” means to revolve and return. Revolving through arising and ceasing to enter cessation, proceeding from life after life to accord with non-arising, one returns to the true boundlessness, the image before the Lord of Creation.

Laozi said: “Coming forth into life, entering into death: of those who follow life, ten or three; of those who follow death, ten or three; of those whose lives move them toward the realm of death, also ten or three. Why is this so? Because of their excessive clinging to life.”

It is said that those who skillfully preserve life walk on land without encountering rhinoceroses or tigers, and enter battle without being struck by weapons. The rhinoceros has nowhere to thrust its horn, the tiger nowhere to place its claws, and the weapon nowhere to lodge its blade. Why is this so? Because they dwell in no place of death.

This is what it means to skillfully preserve life: one realizes the true emptiness and no-self, so that neither inner nor outer things can cause harm. Emptiness thus entails no birth, and no birth entails no death. When arising and ceasing are extinguished, quiescent extinction appears—this is the meaning of preserving life, which those who merely nurture life cannot endure. Why? Because those who nurture life have not yet emptied their perception of life, and the attachment to self still remains. Where there is a view of self, there arises a view of others; where there is a view of self, there arises a view of things. Self and things perpetually stand in opposition, and thus the mind cannot remain unmoved. When the self’s mind moves, things’ minds also move (for example, when I intend to catch a fly, the fly immediately takes defensive action. Before my hand reaches the fly, it has already flown away). Thus, the rhinoceros finds a place to thrust its horn, and the tiger finds a place to set its claws.

Those who preserve life maintain an unmoving body and mind, a body and mind in quiescent extinction. Those who nurture life value a broad mind and a relaxed body, with supreme harmony filling their being and the root of life eternally secure. If one comprehends and unifies these approaches, one sees that though preserving and nurturing life differ, their effects are not distinct. The practice is nothing other than the interdependence of mind and breath. When great samādhi is attained, the true yang of heaven and earth arrives unbidden. The body and mind remain unmoving, responsive yet ever quiescent, quiescent yet ever responsive. With this, one may nurture life, and with this, one may also preserve life.

**160. Precelestial and Postcelestial Nurturing of Life**
Zhuangzi said: “The Dao has essence and sincerity, yet is non-actional and formless.”
Guangchengzi said: “The essence of the supreme Dao is profound and obscure; the ultimate of the supreme Dao is dark and silent. See nothing, hear nothing, embrace the spirit in stillness, and the body will naturally become upright.”
Kangcangzi said: “My body harmonizes with my mind, my mind harmonizes with my qi, my qi harmonizes with my spirit, and my spirit harmonizes with nothingness.”
Guanyinzi said: “Unify your nature, nurture your qi, contain your virtue, and engage with things as they are created.”

All the above discourses take spirit and qi as primary, emptiness and stillness as their function—this is the study of precelestial nurturing of life.

Westerners who pursue hygiene know only six principles: light, heat, water, air, diet, and exercise. They say that light must be sufficient, air must circulate, drinking water must be clean, food must be rich in nourishment, and the body must move often. They also emphasize deep breathing. When they discover microorganisms in water, they use disinfection. When they learn that the human body requires vitamins, they analyze foods containing vitamins A, B, C, and so on, extract their essence, and use it to supplement the diet. All such methods remain postcelestial. They do not know how to extend one’s spirit and qi into the outer emptiness for cultivation, or how to return from the postcelestial to the precelestial.

True qi steams and scorches—no heat is more intense than this.
Wisdom-light inwardly radiates, the empty chamber brightens—no light is more brilliant than this.
Harmony circulates within, the Three Fields are moistened—no qi surges more powerfully than this.
Chan bliss serves as food—no food is more precious than this.
Amṛta fills the drink—no drink is purer than this.
The unmoving movement—movement that never departs from stillness, penetrating the subtle without obstruction—no movement is more wondrous than this.

False Dao nurtures the form; true Dao nurtures the spirit.
The *Liezi·Huangdi Pian* and *Zhuangzi·Dasheng Pian* both record Guan Yinzi’s teachings on concealing the spirit and guarding qi.
This is the profound school’s method of heart and breath interdependent, the spirit submerged in emptiness, merging with the breath to reverse and emerge as wondrous fetal breathing.
Concentrating qi to attain softness, embracing the One without separation—when spirit is whole and qi is full, the form naturally aligns.
“To nurture the form, one must first have things, yet there are cases where things are in excess and the form is not nurtured.
To have life, one must first not depart from form, yet there are cases where form is not departed from and life is forgotten.
Life’s coming cannot be refused, death’s going cannot be halted—how lamentable!
The world’s people believe that nurturing the form suffices to preserve life, yet if nurturing the form truly does not suffice to preserve life, then what is the world worth?”

Those who devote themselves to precelestial nurturing of life:
To comprehend the nature of life, one must be empty, still, tranquil, and desireless.
To comprehend the nature of destiny, one must conceal the spirit, guard qi, embrace the One, abide in harmony, and attain great samādhi to merge with true emptiness.
From having life, one returns to the original non-life—thus transcending beyond form and image.
Non-life yet nothing not alive—this is the ultimate in nurturing life.

---

**Precelestial and Postcelestial Investigation of Things**
Western science studies the atoms of matter and their dynamics for utilitarian purposes—this is postcelestial investigation of things.
What it employs is the deluded mind.
Deluded thoughts favor movement, hence all Western inventions—machinery, steamships, trains, automobiles, airplanes, submarines—operate through movement and manifest dynamic states.

Our cultivation of the Dao is precelestial investigation of things.
What it employs is the true mind.
The true mind is fundamentally unmoving, taking non-movement as its homecoming.
The *Yijing* states: “Still and unmoving.”
The *Vajracchedikā Sūtra* states: “Thusness, unmoving.”
The *Śūraṅgama Sūtra* states: “Wondrously pure, perfectly contained, the unmoving honored one.”
The *Sūtra of Perfect Enlightenment* states: “Thus, even to the extent of empty space, encompassing the three times, all is equal, pure, and unmoving.” It further states: “Since empty space is thus equal and unmoving, know that the nature of awareness is equal and unmoving. Because the four movements are unmoving, know that the nature of awareness is equal and unmoving. Thus, even to the eighty-four thousand *dhāraṇīs*, all are equal and unmoving—know that the nature of awareness is equal and unmoving.” And again: “Since the nature of awareness pervades and fills, pure and unmoving, boundlessly round, know that the six sense faculties pervade the dharmadhātu.”
The *Renwang Huguo Bore Jing* states: “Entering the immovable dharma-stream, forever without segmentation, transcending all existence.”
Ziyang’s *Four Hundred Words on the Golden Elixir* states: “Lead and mercury return to true earth; body and mind are still and unmoving.”
The *Zhuangzi* states: “The Great One penetrates it; great samādhi sustains it,” and “Without beginning or end, without nearness or time”—all revealing the principle of the nature’s immovability.

Because it is unmoving, it is perpetually stable; when stability reaches its peak, clarity arises; when clarity reaches its peak, awareness is full. Inwardly, true knowing emerges; outwardly, the dusty realm merges. Mind and realm are thus, boundlessly vast, roundly luminous, and silently illuminating—this is called the Golden Elixir, also known as Perfect Enlightenment.
This is the verification of the precelestial investigation of things.

Now, movement is the cause of flux, the gateway of arising and ceasing.
Non-movement is the cause of quiescence, the gateway of suchness.
This is the distinction between Daoist learning and science.

Postcelestial investigation of things establishes knowledge through knowing.
Precelestial investigation of things has no seeing in its knowing.
Postcelestial investigation of things does not transcend the six dusts.
Precelestial investigation of things transcends the six dusts.
Postcelestial investigation of things pits thing against self.
Precelestial investigation of things unites thing and self.
Postcelestial investigation of things is the conditioned-arising dharma-gate.
Precelestial investigation of things is the nature-arising dharma-gate.
Postcelestial investigation of things gives rise to mind with attachment.
Precelestial investigation of things gives rise to mind without attachment.
Postcelestial investigation of things does not transcend the present measure.
Precelestial investigation of things transcends the present measure.

Thus, all buddhas and sages, through the utmost power of cultivation and realization, all penetrate the one mind, dissolve the myriad existences, exit the abode of the five aggregates, and transcend beyond the ten thousand images—truly, they may be called the dharma-kings, self-mastered in the dharma.

**Inner Joy and Outer Joy**
In the profound school’s practice, when heart and breath wondrously merge, inner and outer harmonize. Upon reaching the state of indistinct obscurity, breathing becomes faint, and the eighty-four thousand pores all open.
Precelestial true yang responds to the summons, enters the body, and irrigates it above and below. The entire body becomes supple, blissful, and delightful—like the harmonious warmth of spring, intoxicating and indescribable.
This is called pure and wondrous joy, also known as inner joy.
The *Yijing* states: “Stopping and rejoicing—thus it is smooth.” It also states: “Yellow at the center, penetrating the principle, rightly positioned in the body—beauty resides within and flows through the four limbs.” This describes this scene.
The Buddhist tradition calls it *chan* bliss, also known as the joy of sacred quiescence, or the bliss of self-awakened sagely wisdom.
The *Huayan Song* states: “Of all the joys in the world, the joy of sacred quiescence is supreme.”
As for quiescence, only when body and mind are still and settled does inner joy arise—joy within samādhi.

As for the joys pursued by worldly people—sounds and sights, wealth and profit—these stir the inner heart, inevitably unsettling one’s essence. Lost in their allure, one forgets to return; essence scatters and spirit races, joy turning to sorrow at its peak, and the great life-force follows in its wake. This is called external joy, arising from outer circumstances rather than welling forth from within as inner joy does. Inner joy suffices to nourish life, while external joy suffices to shorten it. Inner joy arises from nature; external joy arises from emotion. Inner joy is the stairway to sagehood; external joy is the cause of downfall. In inner joy, stillness and delight unite—though delighted, the heart remains ever quiescent. In external joy, movement and delight unite; when sights, sounds, flavors, and fragrances appear before one, there has never been a case where the heart does not stir and the spirit race. Thus it depletes and exhausts the spirit, shortening the lifespan.

Moreover, external joy is the joy of following the current, while inner joy is the joy of reversing the current. Inner joy responds with quiescence; external joy responds with emotion. The heavier the emotion, the deeper the downfall—hence those on the Dao keep their distance and guard against it. Master Sanfeng said: “One should seek inner joy, not outer joy.” Confucius’s “joy lies within” refers to inner joy. If one merely attends to externals, one seeks joy only to generate affliction instead. How profound these words are!

**163. Worldly Dharma and Daoist Dharma**
Worldly dharma and Daoist dharma, when viewed through the lens of perfect interpenetration, are not two. When viewed through the lens of sequential unfolding, their tendencies differ. To say they are not two means that for those who see the truth, one rectification makes all things true. Whether coughing or waving one’s arms, nothing is not the Dao’s intent; whether carrying water or moving firewood, all becomes wondrous function. Thus the ancient sage said: “Non-doing yet nothing left undone.” To depart from all forms is to be one with all dharmas—this is the wondrous function of non-abiding for those who see the truth, something vulgar learning cannot endure.

Next, when viewed through sequential unfolding, their differences are as follows: worldly dharma values firmness, Daoist dharma values softness; worldly dharma values solidity, Daoist dharma values emptiness; worldly dharma values knowledge, Daoist dharma values not-knowing and not-recognizing; worldly dharma values sharp clarity, Daoist dharma values muddled simplicity; worldly dharma values scheming, Daoist dharma values stilling the mind’s machinations; worldly dharma clings to forms at every step, while cultivating the Dao departs from forms at every step; worldly dharma values recollection, cultivating the Dao values forgetting; worldly dharma esteems movement, cultivating the Dao esteems non-movement; worldly dharma takes the self as master, cultivating the Dao takes the self as guest; worldly dharma follows the current, cultivating the Dao reverses it; in worldly dharma, heart and realm stand opposed, while in Daoist dharma, heart and realm are one; worldly dharma establishes subject and object, Daoist dharma empties subject and object; worldly dharma operates through the human heart, Daoist dharma operates through the celestial heart; worldly dharma responds with emotion, Daoist dharma responds with quiescence; worldly dharma is defiled, Daoist dharma is pure; worldly dharma is a dharma of arising and ceasing, Daoist dharma belongs to the dharma of ceasing and arising; worldly dharma is bounded, Daoist dharma transcends bounds; worldly dharma has leakage, Daoist dharma has no leakage; worldly dharma is conditioned arising, Daoist dharma is nature-arising; in worldly dharma, roots and dusts intertwine, while in Daoist dharma, roots and dusts are utterly free; worldly dharma is impermanent, Daoist dharma is truly constant; worldly dharma chases after shadows while deluded about the head, Daoist dharma observes shadows while abiding at the head; worldly dharma belongs to the non-duality of duality, Daoist dharma belongs to the non-duality of absolute non-duality; worldly dharma strengthens habitual tendencies, Daoist dharma purifies habitual tendencies; worldly dharma multiplies afflictions, Daoist dharma empties afflictions; worldly dharma leads to downfall, Daoist dharma leads to transcendence. These are all their points of difference.

Thus the *Cantong Qi* states: “Reversal is the function of the Dao.” The ancient sage said: “Alone I am dull,” “Alone I am dim,” “I seem to be lost,” “Alone I drift, as though without sign,” “Alone I am stubborn and coarse, differing from others in valuing the nourishment of the Mother”—are these not proofs of reversing the current?

**164. Spiritual Transformation and Material Transformation**
East Asian culture emphasizes virtue and morality, cultivating the spirit...

Western European culture emphasizes utility and profit, cultivating materiality. This metaphysical spiritual transformation through virtue and this physical material transformation through utility—these are the points of divergence between Eastern and Western cultures.

Since antiquity, the sages of our Hua land have guided the world and instructed the people, establishing their teachings with clarity of purpose, none but taking the cultivation of body and mind as their foundation. Thus, Yao and Shun transmitted the teaching: *"Refining essence to enter the numinous is for practical application. Utilizing things to secure the body is for exalting virtue. Exhausting the numinous and knowing transformation—this is the flourishing of virtue."* It is also said: *"The sage employs the numinous Dao to establish teaching, and all under heaven submits."*

*Zhuangzi* states: *"Thus, when the sage has no choice but to govern the world, nothing compares to non-action. Through non-action, the natural conditions of life and destiny are secured. Therefore, if the noble person can refrain from loosening the five viscera, refrain from overtaxing their hearing and sight, dwell in stillness yet manifest like a dragon, remain profound and silent yet resound like thunder, move spiritually and heaven follows—then, at ease in non-action, the myriad things are steamed and piled up. What leisure do I have to govern the world!"*

It further states: *"The person of royal virtue moves plainly yet disdains entanglement in affairs, standing firm in the root and origin, knowing communion with the numinous. Thus their virtue is vast, and when their heart issues forth, it is met by things. Therefore, form does not arise without the Dao, and life does not become luminous without virtue. Preserving form and exhausting life, establishing virtue and illuminating the Dao—is this not the person of royal virtue? Vast and boundless, suddenly emerging, vigorously moving, with the myriad things following—this is the person of royal virtue. Gazing into the obscure, listening to the soundless, within the obscure they alone perceive the dawn; within the soundless, they alone hear harmony. Thus, profound beyond profundity, they can embody things; numinous beyond the numinous, they can attain essence. Therefore, in their interaction with the myriad things, they meet all demands with utmost emptiness, galloping in time to bind their abode."*

From this, we know that the ancient sages’ teachings all valued inner cultivation, returning to simplicity and restoring purity, penetrating the root and illuminating nature, attaining the harmony of the center—neither resisting nor anticipating. Only then can the spiritual function be boundless, responding to opportunities without obstruction, engaging with things without being ensnared by them. This is the esteem of spiritual transformation.

Material culture, by contrast, must seek after things, preparing objects to nourish form, indulging in extravagance and gratifying desires. The spiritual source daily dries up, and one grows ever more distant from the Dao. As *Zhuangzi* says: *"Chasing the myriad things without return, exhausting echoes for sound, form racing with shadow."*

If spiritual transformation through inner cultivation is pursued, then one finds sufficiency within oneself. The heart and breath are harmoniously balanced, form is preserved and the Dao is complete, containing light and inwardly illuminating, penetrating the three origins of virtue. As *Zhuangzi* says: *"Above, they wander with the Creator; below, they befriend those beyond life and death, without beginning or end."* Gains and losses support one another—truly, this cannot be measured by conventional standards.

*Zhuangzi* also states: *"Those who cultivate the inner act without seeking fame; those who cultivate the outer aspire to expenditure. Acting without seeking fame, only the commonplace has luster; aspiring to expenditure—this is the merchant. Thus, the distinction between the merchant and the Daoist is the difference between Western material culture and East Asian spiritual culture."*

Material transformation takes form-dharmas as its focus, using form-dharmas to nourish form and mind, satisfying the demands of the environment. Western civilization often boasts of this, unaware that as the environment constantly changes, needs become endless. Human desires grow daily, the original nature darkens, the six thieves attack in concert, and the source of life dries up. Thus, the more material civilization advances, the shorter human lifespans become; the more intense competition grows, the more bitter life becomes.

*Zhuangzi* says: *"To nourish form, one must first rely on things. Yet there are cases where things are abundant but form is not nourished. Life necessarily does not depart from form, yet there are cases where form does not depart but life perishes. Life’s coming cannot be refused, its going cannot be halted. Alas! The world believes that nourishing form suffices to preserve life, yet if nourishing form truly does not suffice to preserve life, then what is the world worth?"*

Wang Dashen states: *"All sentient beings rely entirely on form and mind for sustenance. The five aggregates are at peace, the six senses enjoy their use, the six dusts serve as attendants—self-satisfied, they pass their days in pleasure, unaware that their original, luminous nature is trapped within form and mind. The five aggregates bury it, the six senses entangle it, the six dusts seal it off, so that this luminous nature is defiled for a thousand lives, wandering for ten thousand kalpas, without the slightest chance of liberation."*

Liu Chenggan writes: *"By today, with foreign lands interconnected, people are increasingly astonished by material inventions, mistaking them for principle—as if heaven created humanity, endowing them with a hundred bones and four limbs, solely to enjoy this world’s material things. Exhausting their thoughts and talents, they sink into greed, anger, delusion, and arrogance, striving to fulfill their desires. If this continues, will they not be reduced to beasts—or worse, devour one another? Morals grow filthy, human nature treacherous—what could be more terrifying, more lamentable!"*

I say: The greatest harm of material transformation lies in following the self and chasing things. Once one chases things, conflict and struggle inevitably arise. Today’s new weapons, used to bombard cities and harm living beings—are these not gifts of material transformation?

The greatest benefit of spiritual transformation lies in preserving the Great Harmony, maintaining serenity of body and mind, being without contention in the world, without competition among people. Like Emperor Yao’s tranquility, King Wen’s harmony, Confucius’s ease, Zhuang Zhou’s stillness—thus one may roam freely in the sea of nature, dissolving self and other in the Great Unity.

**165. Steam Baths and True Qi Baths**

In recent times, Westerners have pursued hygiene with great precision. Beyond cold-water bathing, they have devised what they call "steam baths," using pipes to channel water vapor and wash the entire body. When the limbs and bones undergo such a steam infusion, it can harmonize the blood and bring comfort to the whole body.

Yet this is but acquired *qi*, capable only of external fumigation, not internal permeation—it can cleanse the body but not the mind. It does not compare to the Daoist teachings of *mao-you* purification, which entirely relies on the primordial *True Yi’s* *qi* to scour both inner and outer, saturating the *ying* and *wei*, replenishing *qi* and blood, and strengthening both body and mind.

*The Kinship of the Three* depicts the *True Qi* bath in most wondrous terms:

> *"Cultivate it without cease,
> And the *qi* moves like clouds and rain.
> Drizzling like spring’s gentle soak,
> Flowing like ice’s slow release.
> From head it streams to feet,
> Then ascends once more in full.
> It courses through the boundless void,
> Pervading all within the frame.
> Reversion marks the Dao’s proof,
> Weakness holds virtue’s key.
> It weeds out old impurities,
> Refining even the minute.
> The turbid finds the path to clarity,
> Prolonged dimness yields to light."*

Master Zhongli Quan said: *"True Qi’s fumigation knows no cold or heat—this is the loftiest Daoist sage."*

Master Cui Xu said: *"True Qi’s fumigation knows no cold or heat, pure Yang flows without birth or death."*

Master Lü (Dongbin) said: *"True Qi’s fumigation strengthens the limbs."*

Cao Wenyi said: *"It melts the meridians, transforming sinew and bone."*

Master Ge (Hong) said: *"Jade nectar irrigates, the Grotto Chamber streams with tassels, the celestial mechanism is revealed—no myriad sounds can compare."*

Zhuo Hu said: *"It arises like oil, ascends like mist, steams like billows, congeals like haze. The skin knits inch by inch, white *qi* pierces the sky."*

Lu Qianxu said: *"Harmonious *qi* fills and suffuses the whole body, coursing up and down, harmonizing the hundred vessels. It flows through the four limbs, pervades the frame, filling the heart with spring’s warmth—its state like mild intoxication."*

Zhang Ziyang said: *"At first, it is like the moon filling a thousand mountains; then, like the moon cradled in ten thousand waters. The pores feel as if freshly bathed, the bones and meridians as if deeply asleep. The spirit is like lovers’ joyous union, the soul and body like mother and child’s tender clinging. A single intent of harmonious *qi*—the skin becomes refreshingly permeable."*

Zhang Sanfeng said: *"Wait for that single point to return and submit, and the body transforms into the four seasons’ spring. A wisp of white cloud, a waft of fragrance, each rain’s passing brings renewal. All day, it lingers like a drunkard’s haze, serene in guarding the Grotto’s spring. When all yin essence is stripped away, it becomes a lump of pure Yang gold."*

These are the inner visions of the Daoist *True Qi* bath, the wondrous path of cleansing body and mind. How could mere scientists ever speak of such things?

**166. Longevity and Non-Birth (Part I)**

Someone asked: *"Buddhism proclaims non-birth, Daoism proclaims longevity. Are non-birth and longevity opposed in their aims?"*

I answer: *"Non-birth" employs apophatic discourse, while "longevity" employs cataphatic discourse—the difference lies in negating delusion versus manifesting virtue. The sages’ methods for liberating the world fall into two gates: breaking and embracing.*

*"Non-birth" emphasizes the breaking gate, while "longevity" emphasizes the embracing gate. Master Mazu first established "mind is Buddha," then later swept away traces to say "neither mind nor Buddha"—this is a shift from the embracing gate to the breaking gate.*

*Non-nature and non-birth* are Buddhism’s breaking gate, yet it does not ignore the embracing gate. The *Lotus Sutra’s* "Lifespan" chapter states: *"Thus have I attained Buddhahood for an immeasurable, boundless asamkhya of kalpas, my lifespan eternal, ever-abiding, never perishing."* Its verse says: *"My wisdom-power is thus, my radiance illumines the boundless. My lifespan spans countless kalpas, gained through long-cultivated karma."*

The *Mahāparinirvāṇa Sūtra’s* "Longevity" chapter recounts Kāśyapa Bodhisattva asking in verse:

> *"How does one attain long life,
> A vajra body unbreakable?
> By what cause and condition
> Does one gain great firmness?
> Among all dharmas,
> All arise from blissful nature.
> I pray, Great Sage,
> Explain this to me in detail."*

Observe: Kāśyapa is a Chan patriarch, yet he addresses the Buddha as "Great Sage" and earnestly inquires about the method of longevity—how could there not be profound meaning in this?

The Tathāgata then expounded the Dharma gate of birth, death, and long life. Kāśyapa further asked: *"If bodhisattvas cultivate equanimity toward all beings, should they not attain long life, know past lives, abide in the world without change? Yet now, World-Honored One, by what cause and condition is your lifespan so short, like that of ordinary humans? Does the Tathāgata not hold enmity toward beings? What past evil karma did you commit, how many beings did you harm, to receive this short lifespan of less than a hundred years?"*

The Buddha told Kāśyapa: *"Good son, why do you speak such coarse words before the Tathāgata? The Tathāgata’s long life is supreme among all lifespans, the foremost. The eternal Dharma he attains is the highest among all eternal things."*

Kāśyapa Bodhisattva again addressed the Buddha: *"World-Honored One, how can you say the Tathāgata has attained immeasurable life?"*

The Buddha told Kāśyapa: *"Good son, just as the eight great rivers—first the Gaṅgā, second the Yamunā, third the Sarasvatī, fourth the Airavata, fifth the Mahā, sixth the Sindhu, seventh the Vakṣu, eighth the Sītā—along with all smaller rivers, all flow into the great ocean..."*

Kāśyapa, just as all the lifespans of humans, gods, earth, and empty space—along with the great rivers—all flow into the ocean of the Tathāgata’s lifespan, so too does the Tathāgata’s lifespan become immeasurable.

Furthermore, Kāśyapa, it is like Lake Anavatapta and the four great rivers. The Tathāgata is likewise the source of all life.

Kāśyapa, just as among all eternal things, empty space is foremost, so too is the Tathāgata foremost among all eternal things.

Kāśyapa, just as among all medicines, ghee is supreme, so too is the Tathāgata’s lifespan foremost among all beings.”

Kāśyapa Bodhisattva again addressed the Buddha: “World-Honored One, if the Tathāgata’s lifespan is thus, should he not abide for an eon, or pass away after an eon, constantly revealing the wondrous Dharma like a ceaseless downpour?”

“Kāśyapa, you should not conceive of the Tathāgata’s realm in terms of arising and ceasing. Kāśyapa, if there are bhikṣus, bhikṣuṇīs, upāsakas, upāsikās, or even non-Buddhist *ṛddhi*-attaining immortals who gain mastery—whether abiding for an eon or passing after an eon, walking through empty space, sitting and lying at ease, emitting fire from their left side and water from their right, their bodies wreathed in smoke and flame like a blazing pyre—if they wish to extend their lifespan, they can do so at will, freely determining its length. Even such *ṛddhi*-attaining beings possess such wondrous powers. How much more so the Tathāgata, who has attained mastery over all dharmas, and could not fail to abide for half an eon, a full eon, a hundred eons, a thousand eons, or countless eons? For this reason, you should know that the Tathāgata is the eternal Dharma, the unchanging Dharma. This body of the Tathāgata is a transformed body, not born of sustenance. To liberate beings, he manifests like a poison tree, and thus relinquishes his body to enter *nirvāṇa*.”

Here, the Tathāgata demonstrates that the Buddha’s lifespan is immeasurable, and though his manifested body enters *nirvāṇa*, it is not true extinction, for his Dharma-body and reward-body abide eternally. The manifested body is like the moon reflected in water—sometimes appearing, sometimes not—while the true moon in the sky remains constant and unceasing. The Tathāgata’s Dharma-body and reward-body are likewise eternal and imperishable.

The *Mahāparinirvāṇa Sūtra*, in the “Four Marks” chapter, states: “It is like a potter who, having made a vessel, then breaks it. Liberation is not like this. True liberation is true birth without extinction. Therefore, liberation is the Tathāgata. The Tathāgata is likewise—neither born nor extinguished, neither aging nor dying, neither broken nor destroyed, not a conditioned dharma. For this reason, he is called the Tathāgata. Entering great *nirvāṇa*, he is neither aging nor dying—what meaning could this have? Aging is called transmutation: white hair and wrinkled face. Dying is the breaking of the body and the end of life. Such things do not exist in liberation. Because they are absent, it is called liberation. The Tathāgata has no white hair or wrinkled face, no conditioned dharmas—thus, the Tathāgata is without aging. Without aging, there is no death. Furthermore, liberation is called freedom from illness. What is illness? The four hundred and four diseases, and other external harms that assail the body. Where these are absent, it is called liberation. Freedom from illness is true liberation. True liberation is the Tathāgata. The Tathāgata is without illness, and thus his Dharma-body is also without illness. Such freedom from illness is the Tathāgata. Death is called the breaking of the body and the end of life. Where death is absent, it is *amṛta*. This *amṛta* is true liberation. True liberation is the Tathāgata. The Tathāgata possesses such merits. How then could one say the Tathāgata is impermanent? To say he is impermanent is without basis. How could this vajra-body be impermanent? Therefore, the Tathāgata is not called one who meets his end.”

Here, the Tathāgata demonstrates that he is neither born nor extinguished, neither aging nor dying, neither broken nor destroyed, without white hair, wrinkled face, or other blemishes, and without illness—this is called true liberation. It is no different from the immortality of the immortals. One might say that immortals and Buddhas share the same essence, like water and milk perfectly blended.

Furthermore, the *Avataṃsaka Sūtra*, in the “Departure from the Worldly” chapter, speaks of ten kinds of mastery. The first is mastery over lifespan, for he abides for incalculable eons. The Buddha, in the *Sūtra of Immeasurable Life*, extensively reveals the long and distant lifespan of the Buddha of Immeasurable Life, saying: “The lifespan of the Buddha of Immeasurable Life is so long and vast that it cannot be reckoned or measured. Can you comprehend it? Suppose all the beings in the ten directions, having attained human form, were to become *śrāvakas* and *pratyekabuddhas* and gather together. With single-minded meditation and the full extent of their wisdom, they were to calculate and estimate his lifespan over hundreds of thousands of myriads of eons—still, they could not exhaust it or know its limit. The lifespans of *śrāvakas*, bodhisattvas, gods, and humans are likewise beyond the reach of calculation or analogy.” Taking “Immeasurable Life” as the Buddha’s name reveals the ultimate fruit of immortality. Thus, the Buddhist teachings do not fail to proclaim longevity.

Moreover, *Liezi* says: “The doubt of the unborn is unique.” *Zhuangzi* says: “Only after transcending past and present can one enter the state of neither death nor birth.” *Laozi* says: “Only one who does not take life as something to be prized is better than one who values life.” Li Daochun says: “In quiescent realization, there is no birth.” Thus, the Daoist tradition does not fail to proclaim the unborn. Some speak of the unborn, others of long life—both employ the two gates of severing and embracing, guiding beings according to their capacities, using expedient and ultimate teachings, alternating between affirmation and negation, all fundamentally the same principle. One should not cling to one and criticize the other, giving rise to disputes over superiority and inferiority.

**167. Longevity and the Unborn (II)**

*Laozi* says: “That by which Heaven and Earth endure long and last long is their not living for themselves—therefore they attain long life.” Thus, to attain longevity, one must not dwell in the appearance of life; one must relinquish the form of the long-lived, forget the body and abandon form, living yet without life—unlike the ten kinds of immortals in the *Śūraṅgama Sūtra*, who fix their thoughts to preserve form and cling to the vital principle as ultimate. Yongjia Xuanjue, the Chan Master, says in his *Song of Realizing the Dao*: “Who is without thought? Who is without birth? Truly, in the absence of birth, nothing is not born.” This means that if one truly accords with the unborn nature, there is also no extinction. Therefore, the longevity of the Daoist school does not fall into the view of eternalism, nor does the unborn of the Buddhist school fall into the view of annihilation. Because it does not fall into eternalism, though living, it does not dwell in the appearance of life; because it does not fall into annihilation, though unborn, it naturally lacks nothing in birth. The unborn who are born are Buddhas; the living who are unborn are immortals. How can one lump them into two separate categories, rank them as superior or inferior, and reject longevity in favor of the unborn?

**168. The Perfected and the True Person**

Within the *Nanhua Jing*, the virtues and attributes of the Perfected and the True Person appear repeatedly. I have gathered and compiled them here to spare the reader the trouble of searching and to glimpse the essential meaning of the ancients’ teachings.

The “Free and Easy Wandering” chapter says: “The Perfected is without self.”
The “Equalizing Things” chapter says: “The Perfected is spirit-like: great marshes may burn, yet they cannot be heated; the Yellow River and the Milky Way may freeze, yet they cannot be chilled; swift thunder may split mountains, yet they cannot be harmed; violent winds may shake the seas, yet they cannot be startled. Such beings ride the clouds and qi, mount the sun and moon, and wander beyond the four seas. Life and death bring no change to them—how much less the beginnings of profit and harm?”
The “Revolutions of Heaven” chapter says: “The Perfected of old borrowed the Way of benevolence, lodged in the abode of righteousness, and roamed the wilds of freedom. They ate from fields of simplicity, stood in gardens of non-transaction. Freedom is non-action; simplicity is ease of nourishment; non-transaction is no expenditure. The ancients called this ‘gathering the true in wandering.’”
The “Attaining Life” chapter says: “Have you alone not heard of the Perfected’s self-conduct? They forget their liver and gall, abandon their ears and eyes, wander in vagueness beyond the dust and grime, roam freely in the work of non-action—this is called acting without reliance, growing without control.”
The “Responding to Emperors and Kings” chapter says: “The mind of the Perfected is like a mirror: it neither advances nor retreats, responds without storing, and thus can master things without harm.”
The “Mastering Life” chapter says: “Life has that from which it sprouts; death has that to which it returns. Beginning and end revolve without end, yet none know where they exhaust. If not this, then what is their source? To attain this is the utmost beauty and joy. To attain the utmost beauty and wander in the utmost joy is called the Perfected.” It also says: “As water in a ditch flows without effort and its talent is natural, so the Perfected’s virtue: without cultivation, things cannot depart from it. Like Heaven’s natural height, Earth’s natural dignity, the sun and moon’s natural brightness—what cultivation is needed?”
It further says: “The Perfected: above, they peer into the azure sky; below, they plunge into the Yellow Springs. They brandish and cast off the eight directions, yet their spirit and qi remain unchanged.”
The “Knowledge Wanders North” chapter says: “The Perfected do nothing; the great sages do not act—this is called observing Heaven and Earth.”
The “Gengsang Chu” chapter says: “The Perfected share food upon the earth and share joy in Heaven. They do not entangle themselves with the profit and harm of others, do not conspire in strangeness, do not scheme together, do not act in concert. They come and go with ease and openness—this is called the warp of preserving life.”
The “Lie Yukou” chapter says: “Those Perfected return their spirit to the beginningless and delight in the realm of nothing-whatsoever. Like water flowing without form, they issue forth into the Great Purity.”
The “Under Heaven” chapter says: “Not departing from the true is called the Perfected.”
The “Way of Heaven” chapter says: “The Perfected have a world—is this not vast? Yet it is not enough to burden them. The world may wield power, yet they do not join it; they discern the absence of falsity and do not shift with profit. They exhaust the true in things and can guard their root. Thus, they leave Heaven and Earth behind, abandon the myriad things, and their spirit is never troubled. Penetrating the Dao, uniting with virtue, they withdraw from benevolence and righteousness, make guests of ritual and music—the mind of the Perfected is settled.”

Surveying the above passages, the phrase “the Perfected is without self” is most pivotal. “Without self” means transforming the seventh consciousness into the wisdom of equality. When the attachment to self is emptied, one can roam freely in the sea of non-action’s nature and attain the joy of true purity. The passage stating that “great marshes may burn, yet they cannot be heated; the Yellow River and the Milky Way may freeze, yet they cannot be chilled” describes the state after the seventh consciousness is transformed. With the discriminating attachment of emotions already gone, cold and heat cannot invade—even life and death bring no change, for the bond of shared-life mechanism has been shattered.

Generally, those who study the Dao must first empty the attachment to self, then empty the attachment to dharmas. The seventh *manas* consciousness is the root of self-attachment; this consciousness takes the seeing aspect of the eighth *ālayavijñāna* as the inner self and clings to the perceived aspect of the sixth consciousness as self-awareness. If this consciousness is transformed, the attachment to self is emptied, and attainment of the Dao is certain. Thus, the *Verses on Consciousness-Only* say: “The second transformation is the consciousness called *manas*.”

With its dependence on that transformed condition as its object, *manas* takes deliberation as its nature and characteristic. It is constantly accompanied by four afflictions: delusion of self, view of self, arrogance of self, and craving of self, along with other associated factors such as contact. It is classified as obscured and indeterminate.

The *Guhyagarbha Sūtra* states in verse:
“*Manas* clings to the *ālayavijñāna*,
As a magnet draws iron.
Like a serpent with two heads,
Each performs its own function—
So too the defiled mind,
Grasping and seizing the *ālayavijñāna*,
Engages in the activities of self,
Augmenting the domain of ‘mine.’
Together with the *manovijñāna*,
It acts as a cause, transforming and declining.
Within the body, it generates warmth and touch,
Movement and all activities.”

Moreover, the First Patriarch Bodhidharma’s *Dharma Gate of Pacifying the Mind* states:
“Question: Why do worldly people study and inquire yet fail to attain the Dao?
Answer: Because they perceive a self, they do not attain the Dao.”

This “self” is the “I.” The perfected person encounters suffering without sorrow, meets joy without delight—because they do not perceive a self, they remain unaware of suffering or joy. By forgetting the self, they attain utter emptiness. If even the self is extinguished, what thing remains that is not extinguished? Thus, when the attachment to self is emptied, the Dao is surely attained. The sage is without self; the perfected person is without “I.” Therein, the marvelous emptiness of objective conditions and wisdom arises, the roots and dust are wholly transformed—this is what all profound Chan and mystery together realize, the common destination of all sages, the secret key of Dao cultivation.

The *Zhuangzi*’s “Great Master” chapter says:
“What is a true person? The true persons of old did not oppose the few, did not presume upon success, did not scheme over affairs. Such were they: if they erred, they did not regret; if they succeeded, they did not take pride. Such were they: they climbed heights without trembling, entered water without getting wet, entered fire without feeling heat. Their knowledge could ascend to the Dao like this.

The true persons of old slept without dreaming, woke without worry; their food was not savory, their breath was deep. The true person’s breath comes from the heels; the common person’s breath comes from the throat. Those who are subdued, their words choke as if retching. Those whose desires run deep, their heavenly mechanism is shallow.

The true persons of old did not delight in life, did not detest death. Emerging, they did not rejoice; entering, they did not resist. Swiftly they came, swiftly they went—no more. They did not forget their beginning, nor did they seek their end. Receiving, they rejoiced in it; forgetting, they returned to it. This is called not using the mind to harm the Dao, not using human effort to assist heaven—this is the true person.

Such were they: their minds were at ease, their countenances serene, their foreheads broad. Cold as autumn, warm as spring, their joy and anger flowed with the four seasons, harmonizing with things yet no one knew their limit.”

It further states:
“The true persons of old upheld righteousness yet did not boast; appeared insufficient yet did not yield. They were angular but not rigid, expansive in emptiness yet not ostentatious.”

Amidst their bearing—was it joy they seemed to wear?
Lofty, as though compelled by fate?
Their presence advanced my countenance,
their stillness stilled my virtue.
Stern, as though they mirrored the world;
towering, as though beyond all restraint.
Linked, as though fond of seclusion;
bewildered, as though forgetting their own words.
*(Here describing the virtue and conduct of the true person.)*

They took punishment as their foundation,
ritual as their wings,
wisdom as their timing,
and virtue as their guide.
Taking punishment as their foundation—they were vast in their capacity to let go;
taking ritual as their wings—they moved through the world thereby;
taking wisdom as their timing—they acted only when unavoidable;
taking virtue as their guide—they spoke of reaching the hills with those who had feet,
yet others truly believed them to be diligent in conduct.
Thus, what they favored was one,
what they did not favor was one.
Their oneness was one,
their non-oneness was one.
Their oneness joined them to heaven’s company,
their non-oneness to humanity’s.
Heaven and humanity do not overcome one another—
this is called the true person.
*(Here describing the true person’s way of benefiting things and governing, even to the point of dissolving love and hate, unifying heaven and humanity, and equalizing the myriad outcomes.)*

The *Ke Yi* chapter states:
“The Way of purity and simplicity guards only the spirit,
holding fast without loss, merging with the spirit as one.
The perfection of this oneness penetrates,
aligning with the heavenly order.
A rustic saying goes:
‘The multitude values profit,
the incorruptible value reputation,
the worthy esteem aspiration,
the sage treasures essence.’
Thus, ‘simplicity’ means nothing is mixed with it;
‘purity’ means its spirit suffers no deficiency.
One who embodies simplicity and purity is called a true person.”

The *Tian Zi Fang* chapter states:
“The true persons of old—
knaves could not sway them with flattery,
beauties could not seduce them,
thieves could not plunder them,
Fuxi and the Yellow Emperor could not befriend them.
Life and death are great indeed,
yet nothing altered their own state—
how much less rank and emolument!
Such were they:
their spirit threaded through great mountains without obstruction,
entered deep springs without getting wet,
dwelt in lowliness and minutiae without weariness.
Filling heaven and earth,
having given all to others,
they themselves possessed even more.”

The *Xu Wu Gui* chapter states:
“Thus, they had nothing excessively dear,
nothing excessively distant,
embracing virtue and warming harmony
to follow the world—
this is called the true person.
Toward ants, they abandoned cunning;
toward fish, they found the right measure;
toward sheep, they abandoned intent.
With eyes, they saw eyes;
with ears, they heard ears;
with the heart, they returned to the heart.
Such were they:
their equilibrium was as straight as a marking-line,
their transformations followed the natural course.
The true persons of old
waited upon heaven with heaven,
did not force humanity into heaven.
The true persons of old—
gaining it, they lived;
losing it, they died.
Gaining it, they died;
losing it, they lived.”

The *Lie Yu Kou* chapter states:
“External punishments are metal and wood;
internal punishments are movement and transgression.
When petty men incur external punishments,
metal and wood interrogate them;
when they incur internal punishments,
yin and yang consume them.
Only the true person can escape both external and internal punishments.”

The *Tian Xia* chapter states:
“Guan Yin and Lao Dan—
ah, the vast and true persons of old!”

I observe: *Zhuangzi*’s depictions of the true person’s virtue, appearance, deeds, and efficacy may be called exhaustive. The true person is one who illuminates the essence of the one true dharma-realm and saves both self and others. The perfected person is one who inwardly realizes virtue and reaches the ultimate extreme. All alike clarify the supreme Dao, accord with true constancy, transcend beyond the ten thousand existents, roam in the realm of the Great One, and revel in the garden of quiescent extinction. That Lao Dan and Guan Yin are held as exemplars of the true person carries profound meaning.

**Virtuous Persons and Spirit Persons**
The *Tian Di* chapter of *Zhuangzi* states:
“I wish to hear of the virtuous person.”
It was said: “The virtuous person dwells without thought,
acts without deliberation,
harbors no judgments of right or wrong, beauty or ugliness.
Within the four seas, sharing benefit is called joy,
sharing provision is called peace.
Yearning, like an infant who has lost its mother;
aimless, like a traveler who has lost the way.
Wealth and resources are abundant, yet they know not whence they come;
food and drink suffice, yet they know not from where.
This is called the bearing of the virtuous person.
I wish to hear of the spirit person.”
It was said: “The supreme spirit rides the light,
vanishing with form—
this is called illuminating the vast.
Fulfilling destiny and exhausting passion,
heaven and earth rejoice and the ten thousand affairs dissolve;
the ten thousand things return to their essence—
this is called merging into obscurity.”

The *Xiao Yao You* chapter states:
“The spirit person has no merit.”

The *Tian Xia* chapter states:
“Not departing from essence—this is called the spirit person.”

I observe: *Mencius* says, “What is sagely yet unfathomable is called spirit.”
The *Book of Changes* says, “What is unfathomable in yin and yang is called spirit.”
Thus, the spirit person attains meaning and gives rise to form,
possessing spiritual penetrations and freedom—
beyond the measure of ordinary sentiments.
The virtuous person embraces virtue yet has not yet entered the realm of transformation.
Lu Fanghu says: “The virtuous person is one of complete virtue.
Dwelling without thought, acting without deliberation—
words, movements, stillness, all are without intent.
Harboring no judgments of right or wrong, beauty or ugliness—
this is what is meant by ‘not thinking of good, not thinking of evil.’
Moreover, they share benefit with the world as joy,
share provision as peace,
entrusting their bodies to heaven without awareness of this body.
Only by not knowing the body do they transcend the infant who has lost its mother—
how much more the drifting, unaware of what they depend upon,
wandering as though having lost the way,
riding without knowing whither they go.
Wealth, resources, food, and drink are abundant and sufficient,
yet they know not whence they come—
free from intent in seeking,
others do not see their lack,
and they ever seem utterly content.
Such is the bearing of one of complete virtue.”

The supreme spirit ascends, and the light of sun and moon turns to shine from below. For the spirit, riding the clouds and qi, embracing sun and moon, roams in unfathomable radiance—thus it achieves this. If it were burdened by the bodily husk, how could it invert the light to gaze downward, empty and luminous, vast and boundless? Hence it is said: “With the perishing of form, this is called illuminating vastness.” The Daoist notion of passing through metal and stone without obstruction, treading sun and moon without shadow—this is the meaning.

Destiny is what heaven bestows; emotion is what nature emits. When one fulfills destiny and exhausts emotion, the center is attained and harmony is also attained. Thus, above and below flow as one with heaven and earth, and the burdens of things vanish entirely. Hence it is said: “Heaven and earth rejoice, and the myriad affairs dissolve.”

As the *Zhuangzi*’s “Free and Easy Wandering” states: “On Mount Miaogu there dwells a spirit-person, whose skin is like ice and snow, whose grace is like that of a maiden. They eat no grain, but inhale the wind and drink the dew, riding clouds and qi, driving flying dragons, and roaming beyond the four seas. Their spirit congeals, causing things to be free from blight and the harvest to ripen.” Such is the virtue and appearance of the spirit-person. The virtuous person’s station is one rank below that of the spirit-person.

In the cultivation of the Mysterious Origin, after attaining the Great Return Elixir, the gate of essence is sealed, the roots of lustful mind and desire are instantly eradicated, body and mind become pure, and one embraces virtue and warms harmony, like an infant—this may be called a virtuous person. When the ten-month gestation is complete and the Dharma-body manifests, spirit transforms freely, wondrous functions arise without limit, riding wind and qi to roam beyond the six directions—this may be called a spirit-person. When one reaches the ultimate of returning to emptiness, and even emptiness crumbles to dust—this may be called a perfected person.

Hong Meng Instructs on the Dao
From the *Zhuangzi*’s “In the World of Men”:
Cloud General said, “Then what should I do?”
Hong Meng said, “Alas! How poisonous! Drift away, drift away, and return.”
Cloud General said, “I have encountered great difficulty from heaven and wish to hear a single word.”
Hong Meng said, “Alas! Nurture the heart. Simply abide in non-action, and things will transform of themselves. Cast off your bodily form, expel your brilliance, forget human relations and things. Merge into the great primordial, release the heart and liberate the spirit, silent and without soul. The ten thousand things flourish, each returning to its root, each returning to its root without knowing it—confused and chaotic, never departing for a lifetime. If one knows it, this is to depart from it. Do not ask its name, do not peer into its nature—things arise of themselves.”
Cloud General said, “Heaven has bestowed virtue upon me and shown me silence. I sought it with my own body, and now I have attained it.” He bowed twice, touched his head to the ground, rose, and departed.

This passage reveals the principle and essential technique of returning to truth. Hong Meng, or Chaos, refers to the state where thoughts and stillness are both extinguished, illumination and quiescence both forgotten, neither knowing nor recognizing, neither self nor other—what the ancient sage called “returning to the limitless.” “Expel your bodily form” means to forget the body. “Diminish your brilliance” means to forget the heart. When body and heart are both forgotten, human relations and the myriad things all vanish without trace. Thus one returns to the Great Beginning, merging with the primordial, dissolving attachments and bonds, silent and without soul. “Each returning to its root” means reverting to simplicity and returning to purity, recovering one’s original true nature. The teaching is to forget both self and others, return to chaos, leave behind the mind’s intentions, emotions, and views, abandon grasping and rejecting, transform through non-action, and restore primordial purity—only then can one drift away and return.

Nie Que Asks About the Dao
From the *Zhuangzi*’s “Knowledge Wanders North”:
Nie Que asked about the Dao from Clothed-in-Rags. Clothed-in-Rags said, “Straighten your body, unify your gaze, and the harmony of heaven will arrive. Collect your knowledge, unify your measures, and spirit will come to dwell. Virtue will adorn you, and the Dao will reside within you. Your eyes will be bright as a newborn calf, seeking nothing from the past!”
Before the words were finished, Nie Que fell asleep. Clothed-in-Rags was greatly pleased, sang as he walked away, and said:
“Form like a withered corpse,
heart like dead ashes,
truly knowing the real,
not clinging to the past.
Vague and obscure,
without mind, one cannot scheme with them.
What sort of person is this!”

This passage of question and answer also illustrates the foundational work of concentrating the spirit and regulating the breath. Here, its meaning is further expounded:

"Straighten your body" means the body remains unmoving so the spirit naturally settles. "Unify your gaze" means containing the light within and inwardly illuminating, silently lowering the inner screen to observe carefully. When this is so, "the harmony of heaven will arrive"—this refers to the coming of primordial true yang, when the whole body becomes warm and harmonious as if intoxicated.

"Collect your knowledge" means the spirit relies on the breath, knowing only the breath’s ingress and egress without generating other thoughts. "Unify your measures" means the breath’s ingress and egress harmonize with the spirit, empty and natural, as if aligned with a marking line. For before the breath is regulated, its coming and going lack measure; but when heart and breath depend on each other and regulation becomes thoroughly familiar, purely natural, then the breath is continuous and subtle, the spirit does not leave the breath, the breath does not leave the spirit—they unite as one, and opening and closing proceed with measure.

The phrase "spirit will come to dwell" is most profound. All previous interpreters of the *Zhuangzi* have failed to connect it with the actual work of breath regulation, so their words miss the mark and lack grounding. "Spirit will come to dwell" means the original spirit appears while the heart’s discriminating consciousness vanishes. Nie Que, practicing the work in the moment, listened and suddenly awakened—then fell asleep. Clothed-in-Rags was greatly pleased, for he rejoiced in Nie Que’s ability to "unite practice and understanding, regulating the breath only briefly before falling asleep."

He then departed singing, his song teaching others to keep body and mind unmoving, in a state of dim obscurity, merging into undifferentiated chaos to nurture one’s nature. Caoshan said: "Those who study the Dao are like cats or white oxen—when hungry, they eat grass; when thirsty, they drink water, never worrying that the Dao will not be attained." This aligns perfectly with the meaning of "eyes bright as a newborn calf, seeking nothing from the past." Thus, to cultivate the Dao, one should emulate the undifferentiated state, like an infant who has not yet learned to smile—only then can one return to authenticity and recover simplicity.
