chunks.original_text: 二者，谦抑下人，如主待宾，所谓“大国者下流”。 《大易·谦卦》：“谦谦君子，用涉大川”之象也。 老圣曰：“江海所以能为百谷王者，以善下之，故能为百谷王。 ”《易》曰：“谦亨，天道下济而光明，地道谦卑而上行； 天道亏盈而益谦，地道变盈而流谦，鬼神害盈而福谦，人道恶盈而好谦。 谦尊而光，卑不可逾，君子之终也。 ”此谦冲之德，孔老所同宗也。 慈为仁德，俭为净德。 不敢为天下先，则与世无争，与人无竞，与物无迕，乃虚中无我之德也。 仁慈之德，所以成人。 成人，即所以成己也。 俭约之德，所以修己也。 世人只知俭于财，而不知俭于心，俭于欲，积精气以自摄其生，斯岂老圣之所谓俭乎？ 谭子曰：“水火者，常用之物，用之不得其道，以致于败家，盖失于不简也。 饮馔者，常食之物，食之不得其道，以致于亡身，盖失于不节也。 欲救之求，莫过乎俭。 俭于听，可以养虚； 俭于视，可以养神； 俭于言，可以养气； 俭于私，可以养富； 俭于公，可以养贵； 俭于门闼，可以无盗贼； 俭于环卫，可以无叛乱； 俭于嫔嫱，可以养寿命； 俭于心，可以了生死。 是谓万物之化柄也。 奢者富不足，俭者贫有余。 奢者，心常贫； 俭者，心常富。 奢者，好亲人，所以过多； 俭者，能远人，所以寡过。 奢者事君，必有所辱； 俭者事君，必保其禄。 奢者多忧，俭者多喜。 奢者好动，俭者好静。 奢者好难，俭者好易。 奢者好繁，俭者好简。 奢者好逸乐，俭者好恬淡。 有毕生用一器而无缺者； 有十年而一裘不弊者，斯人也，可以即清静之道矣。 ”以上谭子俭化之说，正契老圣俭德之旨也。 老圣既举“大慈”为三宝之首。 又曰：“天将救之，以慈卫之。 ”又曰：“常善救人，常善救物，故无弃物。 ”然则玄宗学者，岂可事烹宰生物以恣口腹之欲乎？ 欲长生，当愿一切物类各得长生。 此方谓“平等大慈”，方为老氏之徒。 若捐物命，以益己命，大乖常善救物之训，即去慈远矣。 四、 老氏家法 老圣曰：“致虚极，守静笃。 ”又曰：“归根曰静，静曰复命。 ”又曰：“泊兮其未兆，澹兮其若海，旷兮其若谷。 ”又曰：“恬澹为上。 ”《庄子·天道篇》曰：“夫虚静恬澹寂寞无为者，天地之平而道德之至，故帝王圣人休焉。 ”又曰：“夫虚静恬澹寂寞无为者，万物之本也。 明此以南乡，尧之为君也； 明此以北乡，舜之为臣也。 以此处上，帝王天子之德也； 以此处下，玄圣素王之道也。 以此退居而闲游，江海山林之士服； 以此进为而抚世，则功大名显而天下一也。 ”

Second, to humble oneself and yield to others, treating them as a host treats guests—this is what is meant by “the great state flows downward.” The *Book of Changes*’ *Hexagram of Humility* says: “The humble noble one, crossing the great river”—such is its image. The Old Sage said: “The rivers and seas can be kings of the hundred valleys because they excel in lowliness; thus they become kings of the hundred valleys.” The *Book of Changes* says: “Humility brings prosperity. The Dao of Heaven aids the lowly and illumines them; the Dao of Earth, though humble, ascends. The Dao of Heaven diminishes the full and augments the humble; the Dao of Earth alters the full and flows toward the humble. Ghosts and spirits harm the full and bless the humble; the human Dao detests the full and favors the humble. Humility is honored and radiant; its lowliness cannot be surpassed—this is the noble one’s ultimate attainment.” This virtue of humble emptiness is what Confucius and Laozi both revered.

Compassion is the virtue of benevolence; frugality is the virtue of purity. Not daring to be first in the world means no contention with the age, no competition with others, no opposition to things—this is the virtue of emptiness and selflessness. The virtue of benevolent compassion is what perfects others; perfecting others is how one perfects oneself. The virtue of frugality and restraint is how one cultivates oneself.

People today know only frugality with wealth but not frugality with the mind, frugality with desires—accumulating essence and qi to nurture life. How could this be what the Old Sage meant by frugality? Master Tan said: “Water and fire are things in constant use; if used improperly, they can ruin a household—this is due to lack of simplicity. Food and drink are things in constant consumption; if consumed improperly, they can destroy the body—this is due to lack of moderation. To remedy this, nothing surpasses frugality. Frugality in listening nurtures emptiness; frugality in seeing nurtures spirit; frugality in speech nurtures qi; frugality in private affairs nurtures wealth; frugality in public affairs nurtures nobility; frugality at the gate and courtyard prevents theft; frugality in defense and guards prevents rebellion; frugality with consorts and concubines nurtures longevity; frugality of the heart transcends life and death. This is the key to the transformation of the myriad things.

The extravagant, though rich, are never satisfied; the frugal, though poor, always have surplus. The extravagant are always poor in heart; the frugal are always rich in heart. The extravagant favor close associates, which leads to excess; the frugal keep their distance, which leads to few faults. The extravagant, when serving a lord, will surely be humiliated; the frugal, when serving a lord, will surely preserve their emolument. The extravagant are full of worries; the frugal are full of joy. The extravagant love action; the frugal love stillness. The extravagant love difficulty; the frugal love ease. The extravagant love complexity; the frugal love simplicity. The extravagant love indulgence; the frugal love tranquility. There are those who use one vessel their whole lives without it breaking; there are those who wear one fur coat for ten years without it wearing out. Such people can immediately attain the Dao of purity and stillness.”

The above are Master Tan’s teachings on the transformative power of frugality, which perfectly align with the Old Sage’s principle of frugal virtue. The Old Sage placed “Great Compassion” at the head of the Three Treasures. He also said: “When Heaven is about to save someone, it protects them with compassion.” And again: “Always excel in saving people, always excel in saving things—thus nothing is discarded.” How then could followers of the Mysterious Principle indulge in slaughtering living beings to satisfy their appetites? To seek long life, one must wish for all beings to attain long life. Only this is called “universal and equal great compassion,” and only thus can one be a true disciple of Laozi. To discard the lives of others to prolong one’s own life is a grave violation of the teaching to “always excel in saving things”—such a one has strayed far from compassion.

**4. The Household Teachings of Laozi**
The Old Sage said: “Attain utmost emptiness, preserve profound stillness.” And again: “Returning to the root is called stillness; stillness is called recovering life.” And again: “Serene, without sign; tranquil, like the sea; vast, like a valley.” And again: “Tranquility is supreme.” The *Zhuangzi*’s “Heavenly Dao” chapter says: “Emptiness, stillness, tranquility, silence, non-action—these are the equilibrium of Heaven and Earth and the perfection of the Dao and virtue. Thus the emperors, kings, and sages rested in them.” And again: “Emptiness, stillness, tranquility, silence, non-action—these are the root of the myriad things. When Yao faced south and ruled as lord, he illuminated this; when Shun faced north and served as minister, he illuminated this. Those who dwell in this above become emperors, kings, and sons of Heaven in virtue; those who dwell in this below follow the Dao of the mysterious sages and uncrowned kings. Those who retire to this and wander in leisure are revered by recluses of rivers, seas, mountains, and forests; those who advance with this to govern the world achieve great deeds, renowned fame, and the unity of all under Heaven.”

chunks.original_text: 予谓：“虚静恬澹，寂寞无为，”此八字乃老氏家法，玄学所宗，而亦可以旁通夫儒释，诚为入道之通途，修真之轨躅。 凡治老氏之学，与文华两派之嗣，允宜遵守焉。 虚静恬澹，本性然也。 虚则通，静则明。 恬澹则无欲，而归朴素； 寂寞则罄然独存，无为则无心应远，泯照觉圆矣。 故道以此为本，“静而圣，动而王”，无不以此为归。 学者但能“心息相依”，一到大定、真定，即与此根应，而得“天和”、“天乐”等自受用境界矣。 五、 玄宗三宝 玄宗以耳目口为外三宝，元精元气元神为内三宝。 老氏三宝，乃立身处世之方； 玄宗三宝，乃修炼成真之要。 故《心印经》曰：“上药三品，神与气精。 ”合此三宝而成丹，谓之金丹。 潜虚翁曰：“元神者，混沌之神，非日用忧思之神也； 元气者，洪蒙始判之气，非口鼻呼吸之气也； 元精者，其精甚真，其中有信之精，非交感淫泆之精也。 是三者得而用之，然后可以扶救老残、补续年命、回阳换骨，而成上品九级之天仙。 ”耳目口，亦称三宝者，回光返照，贵乎自见； 无声闻和，贵乎自闻； 初学借此以观修定观。 口为呼吸出入之枢，依气出声，可以说法利生，故亦称为宝。 玄宗工夫，内外相应之际，更有“口对口，窍对窍”、“外口得中，内口得和”之说。 深秘义者，口乃虚无之窟，真空之象焉。 目乃心眼洞开，十方普照，《庄子》所谓：“大目视之”之象焉。 耳乃心闻发明，无幽不知之之象焉。 故知宝耳、宝目、宝口，清净周遍，量等虚空，亦无内外身心之可分，一真之体，充乎法界而已。 三丰真人《道言浅近说》曰：“下手于初候求之，大抵清心寡欲，先闭外三宝，养其内三宝而已。 ”又曰：“死心以养气，息机以纯心。 精气神为内三宝，耳目口为外三宝。 常使内三宝不逐物而游，外三宝不透中而扰，呼吸绵绵，深入丹田，使呼吸为夫妻，神气为子母。 子母夫妻，聚而不离，故心不外驰，意不外想，神不外游，精不妄动，常熏蒸于四肢，此金丹大道之正宗也。 ”《参同契》曰：“耳目口三宝，固塞勿发通，真人潜深渊，浮游守规中，旋曲以视听，开阖皆合同，为己之枢辖，动静不竭穷。 ”此示下手工夫，凝神调息之旨也。 诀曰：大江西派相承，入手调息用反闻法。 反闻闻自息，心与息相依，独借耳根为用，最合此方之机，《庄子》所谓：“无声闻和。 ”若与《楞严》“观音圆通，反闻闻自性”之旨会观，可谓一堂二琴，一奁二镜，极禅玄两家熏修之妙矣。 六、 玄宗三化 玄宗三化者，一曰气化，二曰神化，三曰虚化。 综此三化而一之，则曰“道化”； 犹佛氏天台宗，空假中三观，不出一心也。 所谓气化者，心息相依，愈和愈细，直至神息两定，以我虚寂，外感先天真乙之炁，熏蒸营卫，周流灌溉，无处不通。 古德所谓：“常使气冲关节透，自然精满谷神存”也。 《参同契》曰：“修之不辍休，庶气云雨行，淫淫若春泽，液液象解冰。 从头流达足，究竟复上升，往来洞无极，怫怫被容中。 反者道之验，弱者德之柄，耘锄宿污秽，细微得调畅，浊者清之路，昏久则昭明。 ”此道家气行周天之功效也，是谓“气化”。 第二、神化者，玄宗初步炼精化气之功毕，精关已闭，复成童真，此后神息两定于虚空之中，先天真阳来时，在色身周流一匝后，因神定在外，随即至外面与我法身合而为一。

The eight characters—"emptiness, stillness, tranquility, silence, non-action"—are the foundational principles of the Laozi school, the essence of profound learning, and may also extend to Confucianism and Buddhism. Truly, they are the universal path to entering the Dao and the guiding track for cultivating truth. All who study the teachings of Laozi and the lineages of the Literary and Alchemical traditions must adhere to them.

"Emptiness and stillness" are the natural state of the original nature. Emptiness enables penetration; stillness brings clarity. "Tranquility and silence" eliminate desire, returning to simplicity and plainness. In solitude, one remains utterly alone; in non-action, the mind responds without contrivance, and the light of awareness becomes perfectly round. Thus, the Dao takes this as its root: "In stillness, one becomes sagely; in action, one becomes kingly"—all return to this. If scholars can achieve "the interdependence of mind and breath," attaining great stillness and true stillness, they will resonate with this root and experience the self-realized realms of "Heavenly Harmony" and "Heavenly Joy."

**5. The Three Treasures of the Profound Tradition**
The Profound Tradition regards the ears, eyes, and mouth as the Outer Three Treasures, and original essence, original qi, and original spirit as the Inner Three Treasures. The Three Treasures of Laozi are the methods for establishing oneself in the world; the Three Treasures of the Profound Tradition are the essentials for refining and attaining truth.

Thus, the *Heart Seal Scripture* states: "The three superior medicines are spirit, qi, and essence." Combining these Three Treasures to form the elixir is called the Golden Elixir. Master Qianxu said: "Original spirit is the spirit of primordial chaos, not the spirit of daily worries and thoughts; original qi is the qi at the dawn of creation, not the breath of mouth and nose; original essence is the most genuine essence, the essence that holds true constancy, not the essence of lustful indulgence. Only by obtaining and employing these three can one rescue the aged and infirm, replenish and extend life, return yang and transform the bones, and ascend to become a Heavenly Immortal of the highest grade."

The ears, eyes, and mouth are also called the Three Treasures because, in turning the light inward and reflecting, the value lies in self-perception; in the absence of sound and hearing, the value lies in self-listening. Beginners rely on these to observe and cultivate meditative concentration. The mouth, as the pivot of breath’s entry and exit, can emit sounds to expound the Dao and benefit beings, hence it is also called a treasure.

In the practice of the Profound Tradition, when inner and outer align, there are sayings such as "mouth to mouth, aperture to aperture," "the outer mouth attains the center, the inner mouth attains harmony." The deeper esoteric meaning is that the mouth is the cavern of emptiness, the image of true emptiness. The eyes are the opening of the mind’s eye, universally illuminating the ten directions—the image of "great vision" as described in the *Zhuangzi*. The ears are the awakening of the mind’s hearing, knowing all without obscurity. Thus, the precious ears, precious eyes, and precious mouth, pure and all-pervading, are boundless as empty space. There is no division between inner and outer, body and mind; the single true body fills the entire dharma realm.

Master Sanfeng’s *Simple Explanations of Daoist Teachings* states: "Begin by seeking in the initial stage, generally by calming the mind and reducing desires, first closing the Outer Three Treasures to nurture the Inner Three Treasures." It also says: "Still the mind to nourish qi; quiet the mechanism to purify the mind. Essence, qi, and spirit are the Inner Three Treasures; ears, eyes, and mouth are the Outer Three Treasures. Always ensure the Inner Three Treasures do not wander after external things, and the Outer Three Treasures do not disturb the center. Let the breath be continuous and deep, entering the elixir field, making breath the husband and wife, spirit and qi the mother and child. When mother, child, husband, and wife gather without separation, the mind does not stray outward, thoughts do not wander, spirit does not roam, and essence does not move recklessly. Constantly steaming the four limbs, this is the orthodox path of the Golden Elixir."

The *Triple Concordance Scripture* states: "The Three Treasures—ears, eyes, and mouth—must be firmly sealed and not opened. The true person hides in the deep abyss, floating and roaming while guarding the compass. Turning and curving to see and hear, opening and closing in unison, they become the pivot and axle of the self, moving and stilling without exhaustion." This illustrates the initial work of concentrating the spirit and regulating the breath.

The oral instruction says: The Great Jiangxi lineage, in its transmission, begins by regulating the breath using the method of inward hearing. Inward hearing listens to one’s own breath; the mind and breath interdepend. Relying solely on the ear’s faculty is most fitting for this method—the *Zhuangzi*’s "no sound, no hearing." If this is contemplated alongside the *Śūraṅgama Sūtra*’s "Guanyin’s perfect penetration through inward hearing of self-nature," it may be called "two lutes in one hall" or "two mirrors in one case," embodying the sublime fusion of Chan and Daoist cultivation.

**6. The Three Transformations of the Profound Tradition**
The Three Transformations of the Profound Tradition are: first, qi transformation; second, spirit transformation; and third, emptiness transformation. Unifying these three is called "Dao transformation," just as the Tiantai school of Buddhism’s three contemplations—emptiness, provisional existence, and the middle—do not depart from the one mind.

The so-called qi transformation involves the interdependence of mind and breath, becoming increasingly harmonious and subtle until spirit and breath both settle. With my emptiness and stillness, I externally receive the primordial true qi of the pre-celestial One, which steams and nourishes the constructive and protective qi, circulating and irrigating without obstruction. As the ancients said: "Constantly let qi penetrate the joints, and naturally essence will be full and the valley spirit preserved."

The *Triple Concordance Scripture* states: "Cultivate without ceasing, and the qi will move like clouds and rain, gently like spring rain, fluidly like melting ice. Flowing from head to feet, it ultimately ascends again, coming and going through the boundless, suffusing the entire vessel. Reversion is the verification of the Dao; weakness is the handle of virtue. Weed out long-standing impurities, and the subtle is harmoniously regulated. The path of the turbid becoming clear is that prolonged darkness will eventually brighten." This is the efficacy of the Daoist practice of qi circulating through the microcosmic orbit—this is called "qi transformation."

The second, spirit transformation, occurs after the initial stage of the Profound Tradition’s refining of essence into qi is complete. The essence gate is closed, and one regains the purity of youth. Thereafter, spirit and breath settle together in emptiness. When the primordial true yang arrives, it circulates once around the physical body, and because the spirit is settled externally, it immediately unites with my dharmakāya, becoming one.

chunks.translated_text:
Shi Jianwu said: “Yang comes from the emptiness, embracing my master.” Because the spirit is settled and thus equally settled, the primordial spirit and primordial qi fuse into one furnace, forged into a single whole—Daoist texts call this the “Dao-embryo.” As the primordial spirit is nourished by primordial qi, it grows day by day, and the power of stillness deepens. When the ten-month gestation is complete, only the primordial spirit remains in serene illumination, unaware of qi, for qi has already dissolved. As suchness and serene illumination arise, the numinous light shines alone, the myriad forms merge in harmony, eating and sleeping cease, breath and pulse halt, and brightness endures day and night. Gradually one enters the immortal realm—this is the wondrous efficacy of “spirit transformation,” the efficacy of the spirit circulating through the macrocosmic orbit.

Master Lü said:
*“Nine years of firing have passed in full,
When suddenly the Heavenly Gate bursts at the crown.
The true person appears with great spiritual powers—
From this moment, celestial immortals may offer their congratulations.”*

Master Sanfeng said: “When the firing of the macrocosmic orbit is complete, one sheds the embryo and changes the bones, wholly transforming into a single golden light. The earth becomes a treasure, the body generates another body, and the yang spirit departs the physical form.” The Buddhist tradition calls this the “mind-generated body,” while Daoists term it the “spirit person.” The *Śūraṅgama Sūtra* states: *“Having roamed the Dao-embryo, one personally attends the lineage of awakening,”* and also: *“Having formed and shed the embryo, one becomes a true child of the Buddha.”* This expresses the same meaning—this is called “spirit transformation.”

Third, “emptiness transformation”: In the Profound Tradition’s cultivation, from beginning to end, one never departs from emptiness, practicing entirely within the emptiness beyond the body. The initial return to emptiness (that is, refining the self) and the final return to emptiness (that is, attaining the Dao) proceed as one continuous process—hence it is called the “Profound Emptiness Great Dao.” Focusing now on the final return to emptiness: upon first obtaining the “mind-generated body,” like a newborn infant, it is still weak, so one re-enters profound samādhi. With my emptiness, I connect to the emptiness of heaven and earth; with the emptiness of heaven and earth, I connect to the emptiness of the dharmadhātu. As emptiness interpenetrates, one enters this great emptiness samādhi. After prolonged stillness, spirit and emptiness transform together. The six directions are all mind; the six directions are all body. Merging boundlessly, there is only one perfect illumination, all-pervading and all-containing. One can manifest limitless body forms and immeasurable spiritual powers, universally entering the infinite dharmadhātu, effortless and uncontrived—wherever the mind turns, it is accomplished. The *Laṅkāvatāra Sūtra* calls this: *“No arising of kinds and species, yet the mind-generated body is attained.”* Daoists call this the “perfected person”—this is the efficacy of “emptiness transformation.”

Master Lü said: *“The dharmakāya crumbles and fills the emptiness.”*
Master Zhang said: *“The emptiness crumbles to reveal the whole body.”*
The Seventh Patriarch of the Chan School, Venerable Basumitra, transmitted this verse:
*“The mind is one with the emptiness realm,
Manifesting the Dharma equal to emptiness.
When emptiness is realized,
There is no right, no wrong.”*
The Eighth Patriarch, Venerable Buddhadāna, transmitted this verse:
*“Emptiness has no inside or outside,
The mind and Dharma are likewise.
If one understands emptiness,
One attains the truth of suchness.”*
The Buddhist tradition names this the “King of Emptiness” or the “Dharma King Who Shatters Existence.” When Daoists reach the ultimate return to emptiness, shattering emptiness itself, transcending the world without reliance—is this not the King of Emptiness?

The Northern School’s Li Daochun’s *Song of Refining Emptiness* most precisely expounds the purport of the Profound Tradition’s emptiness transformation—scholars should study it deeply and thoroughly.

**Appendix: Li Daochun’s *Song of Refining Emptiness***

To become immortal, Buddha, or Confucian sage,
The Three Teachings transmit but one emptiness.
From ancient times to the present, those who transcend
All cultivate within emptiness.

To learn immortality, emptiness and stillness are the elixir’s essence;
To learn Buddhism, abiding in emptiness is Chan’s culmination.
As for my learning of the sagely way—what is it?
In emptiness, without self, the heavenly principle is illuminated.

The Dao-body’s emptiness is wondrous and inexhaustible,
Heaven and earth’s emptiness operates with qi in harmonious fusion.
Yin and yang’s transformations are propelled by emptiness’s push—
If one abides in emptiness, all becomes malleable.

The marvel of the returned elixir lies in the valley of emptiness (that is, the emptiness beyond the body),
Begin by attaining emptiness and steadfastly guarding stillness (the spirit is released externally, following the breath).
When emptiness is utterly empty, primordial qi congeals;
In stillness upon stillness, yang returns.

An empty mind and full belly are the Dao’s foundation;
When the numinous emptiness is not obscured, it is time to gather the medicine.
Responding to conditions with an emptied self is true daily practice;
One with the great emptiness is a true man-child.

Gathering lead in emptiness and stillness is effortless action;
Advancing the fire uses emptiness as the bellows and key.
All drawing and adding, increasing and decreasing, proceed from emptiness;
Shattering emptiness, one attains great awakening.

Ultimately, the Dao is quiescent yet functional—
To resolve entanglements and dull sharpness, both must be upheld.
Harmonizing light and blending with the world, forgetting self and others,
Only the self knows what lies before the image of the Lord.

Before the uncarved, how could there be trigrams?
Qian is not above, Kun is not below—
At the center, a single point of utmost emptiness and numinosity,
Eight-sided and flawless, without cracks.

The four edges are firmly sealed, the primordial chaos is refined—
This is the mysterious female gate of central emptiness (indicating the emptiness beyond the body, the so-called “outer mystery pass”).
If one employs emptiness within non-emptiness,
Naturally, opening and closing respond to heaven and earth (mind and breath interdepend, released into the external emptiness, coming and going—this is the wondrous function of natural emptiness).

When the mysterious female gate opens, the work reaches its peak;
The spirit exits and enters here (the breath is subtly regulated).
Exiting and entering, returning again to emptiness (mind and breath settle together, merging with the great emptiness),
Suddenly, a spring thunderclap on level ground (stillness gives rise to movement).

When the thunderclap resounds, heaven and earth open—
From the emptiness, a wheel bursts forth.
Round and full, vast and luminous,
Without lack or excess, it illuminates the bamboo studio.

The master of the bamboo studio is most extraordinary,
Carefully applying it to timely matters.
Abiding the spirit in emptiness, moving in emptiness (seven characters in one line, encapsulating the wondrous subtleties of the elixir method),
Uttering words to reveal the message of emptiness (out of compassion, there are written teachings to share).

VII. The Four Dhyanas of the Profound School
The *Laṅkāvatāra Sūtra* sets forth four kinds of dhyana: "the dhyana practiced by the foolish," "the dhyana of contemplating meaning," "the dhyana of clinging to true suchness," and "the dhyana of all Tathāgatas."
Liezi’s master, Master Hu, also spoke of four kinds of dhyana: "earth-pattern dhyana," "heaven-and-earth dhyana," "Great Thoroughfare dhyana," and "the dhyana that has never departed from my school."
The *Liezi · The Yellow Emperor* states: "A divine diviner came from Qi to dwell in Zheng, named Ji Xian. He knew the life and death, survival and demise, fortune and misfortune, longevity and early death of men, predicting them by year, month, or day with divine accuracy. When the people of Zheng saw him, they all fled. Liezi saw him and was enchanted. Returning, he told Master Huqiu, saying: 'At first, I took your Dao as the ultimate—yet there is something even more ultimate!'"

Master Hu replied: "I have shown you only its outward patterns, not yet its true substance—how could you have truly attained the Dao? A flock of hens without a rooster—how could they lay eggs! You take the Dao to contend with the world, and so you must be seen through. Bring him here tomorrow, and let me show myself to him."

The next day, Liezi brought Ji Xian to see Master Hu. Afterward, Ji Xian emerged and said to Liezi: "Alas! Your master is dead! Beyond remedy! He cannot last even ten days! I saw something uncanny—like damp ashes."

Liezi entered and wept, his tears soaking his lapels, as he told Master Hu. Master Hu said: "Earlier, I showed him the *earth-pattern*—still and unmoving, as if my *virtue-power* were sealed. Bring him again tomorrow."

The next day, Liezi once more brought Ji Xian to see Master Hu. Afterward, Ji Xian emerged and said to Liezi: "Fortunate indeed that your master met me! He is recovering! The ashes show signs of life! I see his sealed *power* now shifting!"

Liezi entered and told Master Hu. Master Hu said: "Earlier, I showed him the *heaven-and-earth*—where names and realities do not intrude, yet the mechanism stirs from the heels. This is the shifting of sealed *power*. He glimpsed the nearness of my goodness. Bring him again tomorrow."

The next day, Liezi brought Ji Xian to see Master Hu once more. Afterward, Ji Xian emerged and said to Liezi: "Your master is unsettled; I cannot read him. Let him fast and purify himself, and I will observe him again."

Liezi entered and told Master Hu. Master Hu said: "Earlier, I showed him the *Great Thoroughfare* where nothing obstructs me—he saw only the balance of my *qi-mechanism*."

chunks.original_text: 按：壶子得自觉圣智，自受用三昧，在玄宗可谓：凤翔云霄，独步千古。 经此一番试验，列子方心折而专志于道。 今试释其义曰：壶子初入地文之禅。 地，表也。 草木丛林，地之文也。 日生夜长，恬然安静，不见其动摇，亦静态也。 地文之禅者，如大地之寂然不动，地中虽有宝藏，闭而不露也。 《度人经》曰：“神风静寂，山海藏云，天无浮翳，四气朗清，一国土地，山川林木，缅本一等，无复高下，”正同此意，藏密不露，无机可见，谓之杜德几，神巫见其尸居而坐忘，气息浑穆，语以为湿灰，断以为将死，是殆窥其迹，而不知其本也。 地文之禅，在佛氏谓之“奢摩他”，极寂静之象也。 “罪乎不震”之一语，以形容此禅境界最妙。 震者，振也，不自动，亦不自止，如山之屹然，寂之至也。 二、壶子入天壤之禅，则较地文稍呈活泼之象矣。 刘须斯曰：“天壤即天地之间，比之地文着矣。 ”玄静曰：天壤者，虚空也。 空中不空，有一气流行，为生生之机，万物得之而萌蘖，所谓“善者几”是也。 地文之禅，离动离静。 今此天壤，虽名实两忘，而机发于踵，神巫认为杜权而有瘳，亦仅识其皮相耳。 至人之静也渊默，其动也天行，皆出于无心应用，奚可执其一端而拟议之哉！ 此“天壤禅”，在佛氏谓之“昆钵舍那”。 此云观照，慧也。 “奢摩他”者，止也，寂也，定也。 三、壶子示以“太冲莫朕”。 云“莫朕”者，冲虚之极，无朕兆可拟也。 《庄子》作“太冲莫胜”，系缮写之误。 “衡气机”者，似水之平静也。 曹山所谓：“混然无内外，和融上下平”是也。 向秀曰：“居太冲之极，皓然泊心，玄同万境，莫见其迹，盖虚之至也。 ”以下历举九渊之差别，而泊然无心、淡然渊默之水性，初无变异，示至人无心而应运，能于差别境中入无差别定。 于无差别定中现有差别身，致神巫无得而相，诿为不齐，是其技已穷矣。 此太冲莫朕之禅，衡气机之妙，乃心境如如，寂照同时，而寂照双忘之妙境也，在佛氏谓之“优毕叉”，此云“中道妙观”。 四、壶子入未始出吾宗之禅。 宗者，心宗也。 一一妙用，不离自性，全身出没，变化罔极，而不离当念。 此自觉圣智，自觉境界，咳唾掉臂，拈槌竖笏，瞬目扬眉，莫非第一义谛。 凡圣罔测，正《楞伽》所谓：“如来禅”也。 茅靡，不穷貌； 波流，浪逐波随貌。 神巫至此，莫知所措。 非耳目心意之所及，不觉自失而走矣。 颇与唐·慧忠国师勘验“他心通”之大耳三藏，情节相同（禅师第三度问三藏云：“老僧即今在甚么处？ ”藏罔测，禅师叱曰：“这野狐精，他心通在甚么处？ ”藏无对。 ）列子于是归家，忘人我相，下一番磨炼，块然无偶，乃能契证。 “一是以终 ”者，得其一，万事毕，圣人抱一，为天下式也。 八、 玄宗十德 《大洞经》云：“十德初成基，同飞七觉元。 ”又云：“太清八景观，十德真文宣。 ”此谓眼、耳、鼻、舌、身、口、意，返乎元初，性真圆融，八识不生，气和道立，文采煊着，十德圆成。 所谓十德者，土数五，二土相合成圭，谓之十德，此是一说。 又玄教自有十德，所谓定、和、净、明、妙，常、乐、素、虚、柔是也。

**Annotation:**

Master Hu possessed self-awakened sagely wisdom and the samādhi of self-reception. In the Mystery School, he may be called: "the phoenix soaring through the clouds, unmatched across the ages." Only after this trial did Liezi’s heart submit, and he devoted himself single-mindedly to the Dao.

Let us now explicate its meaning:

First, Master Hu entered the *dhyāna* of Earth’s Pattern. Earth is the surface. The grasses, trees, and forests are the patterns of Earth. They grow by day and lengthen by night, tranquil and still, showing no movement—this is the state of quiescence. The *dhyāna* of Earth’s Pattern is like the great Earth’s profound stillness; though treasures lie hidden within, they remain sealed and unrevealed. The *Scripture of Salvation* says: "The divine wind is still, mountains and seas conceal the clouds. The heavens are free of drifting haze, the four *qi* bright and clear. The land of a kingdom—its mountains, rivers, forests, and trees—all trace back to one origin, no longer high or low." This expresses the same idea: hidden and dense, with no mechanism to be seen. It is called "the virtue of closure," where the spirit shaman sees only his seated corpse-like stillness, his breath deep and harmonious. They mistake him for damp ashes, declare him near death—this is merely glimpsing his traces while failing to know his root. In Buddhism, this *dhyāna* of Earth’s Pattern is called *śamatha*, the ultimate image of stillness. The phrase *"Alas, he does not tremble!"* most aptly describes this meditative realm. To tremble is to stir; here, there is no self-movement, nor self-cessation—like a mountain’s steadfastness, the utmost of stillness.

Second, Master Hu entered the *dhyāna* of Heaven-and-Earth, which exhibits a slightly more lively aspect than Earth’s Pattern. Liu Xusi said: "Heaven-and-Earth refers to the space between heaven and earth, more manifest than Earth’s Pattern." Xuanjing said: "Heaven-and-Earth is emptiness. Within emptiness, yet not empty, there flows a single *qi*, the mechanism of ceaseless generation. All things receive it and sprout—this is what is called *‘the good is in the incipient.’*" The *dhyāna* of Earth’s Pattern transcends movement and stillness. Here, in Heaven-and-Earth, though name and reality are both forgotten, the mechanism arises from the heels. The spirit shaman perceives only "the power of closure" and a semblance of recovery, yet this is merely grasping its surface. The stillness of the perfected is profound and silent; their movement is the motion of heaven—both emerge from effortless response. How can one fixate on a single aspect and presume to discuss it? This *dhyāna* of Heaven-and-Earth is called *vipaśyanā* in Buddhism, meaning "contemplation" or wisdom. *Śamatha* is cessation, stillness, concentration.

Third, Master Hu demonstrated "the Great Thoroughfare without trace." "Without trace" means the utmost of emptiness and void, with no sign to be imitated. The *Zhuangzi* renders this as "the Great Thoroughfare cannot be overcome," an error in transcription. "Balancing the mechanism of *qi*" is like water’s perfect stillness. As Caoshan said: "Harmoniously without inner or outer, fused and level above and below." Xiang Xiu said: "Abiding at the extreme of the Great Thoroughfare, the heart is limpid and anchored, mysteriously one with all realms, leaving no trace—this is the utmost of emptiness." Below, the nine depths are enumerated, yet the water’s nature—placid and unperturbed, profoundly silent—remains unchanged. This shows the perfected one’s effortless response to circumstances, entering the undifferentiated samādhi amid differentiated realms, and manifesting a differentiated form within the undifferentiated samādhi. Thus, the spirit shaman could not fathom him, dismissing it as "inconsistent"—his skill was exhausted. This *dhyāna* of the Great Thoroughfare without trace, the marvel of balancing the *qi*-mechanism, is the wondrous realm where mind and environment are thus, stillness and illumination simultaneous, yet both forgotten. In Buddhism, this is called *yuganaddha*, the "wondrous contemplation of the Middle Way."

Fourth, Master Hu entered the *dhyāna* of "never yet departed from my source." The source is the source of the mind. Every wondrous function arises from one’s own nature; the entire body appears and vanishes, its transformations boundless, yet never leaving the present thought. This is self-awakened sagely wisdom, the realm of self-awakening. Whether coughing, waving an arm, grasping a staff, raising a tablet, blinking, or raising an eyebrow—all are the supreme truth. Neither sage nor ordinary being can fathom it. This is precisely what the *Laṅkāvatāra Sūtra* calls "the Tathāgata’s *dhyāna*." "Withered grass" describes its boundless appearance; "flowing wave" depicts its following the current. At this point, the spirit shaman was at a loss. Beyond the reach of ear, eye, mind, or intention, he unwittingly lost himself and fled. This closely resembles the episode where Tang Dynasty Master Huizhong tested the "mind-reading" Great Ear Tripiṭaka (the master asked the monk thrice: "Where is this old monk now?" The monk could not answer, and the master rebuked him: "You fox spirit! Where is your mind-reading now?" The monk had no reply). Thereafter, Liezi returned home, forgot the distinction between self and other, and underwent rigorous refinement. Solitary and unmatched, he was able to realize and verify. *"Thus he remained to the end"* means: grasping the One, all affairs are complete. The sage embraces the One as the model for the world.

**Eight. The Ten Virtues of the Mystery School**

The *Scripture of the Great Cavern* states: "The Ten Virtues first establish the foundation, together flying with the Seven Awakening Factors." It also says: "The Eightfold Vision of the Grand Clarity proclaims the true script of the Ten Virtues." This refers to the eyes, ears, nose, tongue, body, mouth, and mind returning to their original state, the true nature perfectly fused. The eight consciousnesses do not arise; *qi* harmonizes and the Dao is established. Radiant and resplendent, the Ten Virtues are fully realized. The Ten Virtues: the number five pertains to earth; two earths combined form a jade tablet, hence the Ten Virtues—this is one explanation. The Mystery Teaching also has its own Ten Virtues: constancy, harmony, purity, clarity, subtlety, joy, simplicity, emptiness, and gentleness.

chunks.original_text: 《庄子》曰：“相造乎道者，无事而生定。 ”又曰：“大定持之。 ”又曰：“虚室生白，吉祥止止。 ”《大洞经》曰：“大定全真。 ”玄宗泰定神宁，心既湛寂，一切动相，自然不生。 至于不动地境界，是则生灭既灭，寂灭现前，妙入希夷之乡，契无为之化，获不思议神用矣。 是谓定德。 玄教心息妙合，神气和融，以人和而招致天和。 先天已得，雪净冰融，一团太和之气，回还充塞，浸淫融洽，销铄群阴，大丹自成。 老圣曰：“知和曰常。 ”《庄子》曰：“一上一下，以和为量。 ”《五厨经》曰：“一气和太和，得一道皆泰。 ”《大通经》曰：“致静不动，致和不迁。 ”《心印经》曰：“太和充溢，骨散寒琼。 ”是谓成和之修，是名和德也。 所谓净者，玄教固以清净宁一设化。 《大洞经》曰：“洞虚清和净，华通引玄明。 ”由心息相依而澄心不动，六根清净，进而至于六识、六尘清净，乃至十方虚空，无边刹海，一时清净。 入此大净法门，获无障碍，自在解脱。 故《大洞经》曰：“九回镜中清，乘景入四明。 ”《玄契》曰：“洞微清净，圣耳梵通。 无障无碍，内外虚明。 洞空清净，玄息气通。 无障无碍，内外虚清。 洞虚清净，灵舌华通，无障无碍，内外玄明。 洞真清净，变应自然，道通长存，十方皆现。 如是背尘合觉，反染为净，心净土净，依正旋转。 寂光真境，任运现前，谓之清净光明藏。 ”以此自利、利他，同脱苦海，同登道岸，最为超绝。 故此净德，最尊最胜。 所谓明者，由本身清净故，发生慧光，洞照十方，周遍无碍。 《大洞经》曰：“灵光八辉，万神俱生。 ”又曰：“流辉六曜，泯邈沈迁。 ”又曰：“洞明光景中，帝一真玄经。 ”又云：“十华妙行仙，制魔生六明。 ”又云：“洞观无碍空，元始通其明。 骊珠现真形，内外洞照清。 ”又云：“洞源与洞明，万道由通生。 ”又云； “洞源清净光，操持有其功。 ”又云：“洞微无窒碍，化极众幽灵。 ”又云：“定和妙明觉，玄息自长生。 ”又云：“洞虚表和净，华通引玄明。 ”《玉枢经》云：“泰定安则圣智全，圣智全则慧光生，慧光生则与道为一。 ”老圣曰：“知常曰明。 ”《庄了》曰：“莫若以明。 ”是则洞明寂照，无碍圆融。 《楞严经》所谓：“明极即如来”是也。 是谓明德。 所谓妙者，虚实相通，依正交参，心境一如，入际平等之源。 性真圆融，无碍周遍。 老圣称为“众妙之门。 ”《养命经》曰：“识无空法，洞观无碍，入众妙门，自然解悟。 ”学者初功，神息妙合，身心和融，即入众妙门之前行也。 故玄教妙德，举一切对待，圆融不二，色空无碍，身心交参，入普贤法界，帝纲重重之境。 实非言思有作所能及也。 是谓妙德。 所谓常者，老圣称谓“常德”。 《涅盘经》称为“常住”。 老圣曰：“常德不离，复归婴儿； 常德不忒，复归无极。 ”又曰：“为天下谷，常德乃足。 ”《清净经》曰：“真常应物，真常得性。 ”又曰：“真常之道，悟者自得。 ”此真常之性体，即是道源。 契之者，得法性身，常住不灭。 故《楞严经》称谓：“常住真心，性净明体。 ”古之大觉金仙，皆圆证此心，入妙觉果海。 性起无作，普现法身。

The *Zhuangzi* states: "Those who meet in the Dao do nothing yet attain stillness." It also says: "Great stillness holds it." And again: "An empty chamber generates brightness; auspiciousness abides where it rests." The *Scripture of the Great Cavern* says: "Great stillness preserves the true."

In the Mystery Teaching, when supreme stillness brings spiritual tranquility, the mind becomes profoundly serene, and all moving phenomena naturally cease to arise. Reaching the realm of immovability, birth-and-death are extinguished, and quiescent extinction manifests. Wondrously entering the realm of the subtle and imperceptible, one accords with the transformation of non-action and attains the inconceivable divine function. This is called the virtue of stillness.

In the Mystery Teaching, when the marvelous union of mind and breath occurs, spirit and *qi* harmonize and fuse, drawing celestial harmony through human harmony. Having attained the primordial, snow melts and ice dissolves, forming a single mass of supreme harmony. This *qi* circulates and fills, permeating and blending, dissolving all yin obstructions, and the Great Elixir naturally forms.

The ancient sages said: "To know harmony is called constancy." The *Zhuangzi* states: "Rising and falling, harmony is the measure." The *Scripture of the Five Kitchens* says: "One *qi* harmonizes with supreme harmony; attaining the One, all is at peace." The *Scripture of Great Penetration* says: "Attain stillness without movement; attain harmony without change." The *Scripture of the Heart Seal* says: "Supreme harmony overflows, and bones scatter like cold jade." This is the cultivation of harmony, called the virtue of harmony.

As for purity, the Mystery Teaching fundamentally establishes its teachings on clarity, stillness, and unity. The *Scripture of the Great Cavern* says: "Profound emptiness, clarity, and harmony—flowers penetrate and lead to mysterious brightness." Through the interdependence of mind and breath, the mind becomes still and undisturbed, the six senses are purified, and further, the six consciousnesses and six dusts are purified, extending even to the ten directions, the boundless realm of lands, all simultaneously purified. Entering this great gate of purity, one attains unhindered, free, and liberated existence.

Thus, the *Scripture of the Great Cavern* says: "In the nine revolutions of the mirror, clarity arises; riding the light, one enters the fourfold brightness." The *Mysterious Accord* states: "Profound subtlety is pure, and the sage’s ears commune with the divine. Without obstruction or hindrance, inner and outer are empty and bright. The profound emptiness is pure, and the mysterious breath connects with *qi*. Without obstruction or hindrance, inner and outer are empty and clear. The profound void is pure, and the numinous tongue flowers with communication. Without obstruction or hindrance, inner and outer are mysteriously bright. The profound truth is pure, and transformations respond naturally. The Dao pervades and endures, manifesting in all ten directions."

Thus, turning away from dust and returning to awakening, transforming defilement into purity, when the mind is pure, the land is pure—dependent and proper revolve in harmony. The true realm of quiescent light manifests effortlessly, called the Treasury of Pure Brightness. Through this, one benefits oneself and others, together escaping the sea of suffering and ascending the shore of the Dao, most surpassing and supreme. Therefore, this virtue of purity is most revered and exalted.

As for brightness, because the original body is pure, wisdom-light arises, illuminating the ten directions without obstruction. The *Scripture of the Great Cavern* says: "Numinous light shines in eight directions, and the ten thousand spirits all arise." It also says: "Flowing radiance of the six luminaries disperses distant obscurity." And again: "Within the bright light of the profound, the true scripture of the Primordial One." And: "The ten flower-like wondrous practices of the immortals subdue demons and generate the sixfold brightness." And: "Profound vision perceives the unobstructed emptiness; the Primordial Beginning communicates its brightness. The dark pearl reveals its true form; inner and outer are clearly illuminated." And: "The profound source and profound brightness—all myriad paths arise from their communication." And: "The pure light of the profound source possesses its own efficacy." And: "The profound and subtle is without obstruction, transforming the utmost of all hidden spirits." And: "Stillness, harmony, wondrous brightness, and awakening—the mysterious breath naturally brings long life." And: "The profound void manifests harmony and purity; flowers penetrate and lead to mysterious brightness."

The *Jade Pivot Scripture* says: "When supreme stillness is secure, sagely wisdom is complete; when sagely wisdom is complete, wisdom-light arises; when wisdom-light arises, one becomes one with the Dao." The ancient sages said: "To know constancy is called brightness." The *Zhuangzi* says: "Nothing is better than to be bright." Thus, profound brightness and quiescent illumination are unobstructed and perfectly fused. As the *Śūraṅgama Sūtra* says: "When brightness reaches its utmost, it is the Tathāgata." This is called the virtue of brightness.

As for the wondrous, emptiness and existence interpenetrate, the dependent and the proper intermingle, mind and realm become one, entering the source of equality at the boundary. The true nature is perfectly fused, unobstructed and all-pervading. The ancient sages called it "the gate of all wonders." The *Scripture on Nourishing Life* says: "Recognizing the non-emptiness of dharmas, perceiving without obstruction, one enters the gate of all wonders and naturally awakens."

In the initial practice of the scholar, when spirit and breath marvelously unite, body and mind harmonize and fuse, this is the preliminary step before entering the gate of all wonders. Thus, the wondrous virtue of the Mystery Teaching encompasses all dualities, perfectly fusing them into non-duality. Form and emptiness are without obstruction; body and mind intermingle, entering the Dharmadhātu of Samantabhadra, the layered realm of the imperial net. Truly, this is beyond what words, thoughts, or contrivance can reach. This is called the wondrous virtue.

As for constancy, the ancient sages called it "constant virtue." The *Nirvāṇa Sūtra* calls it "eternal abiding." The ancient sages said: "Constant virtue does not depart, returning to the state of an infant; constant virtue does not err, returning to the ultimate." And: "To be the valley of the world, constant virtue is sufficient." The *Scripture of Purity* says: "The true and constant responds to phenomena; the true and constant attains its nature." And: "The Dao of the true and constant is attained by those who awaken to it."

This true and constant nature is the source of the Dao. Those who accord with it attain the Dharma-nature body, eternally abiding and indestructible. Thus, the *Śūraṅgama Sūtra* calls it: "The eternally abiding true mind, the inherently pure bright essence." The ancient golden sages of great awakening all perfectly realized this mind, entering the ocean of the wondrously awakened fruit. The nature arises without action, universally manifesting the Dharmakāya.

chunks.original_text: 涅盘四德，以常德居首，以此故也。 所谓乐者，乃自觉圣智善乐，亦称性寂天乐，亦称天乐。 《庄子》：“与人和者，谓之人乐； 与天和者，谓之天乐。 知天乐者，其生也天行，其死也物化。 静而与阴同德，动而与阳同波。 ”此天和、天乐，玄教所宗，洵属优生学之要素也，是谓乐德。 所谓素者，指本元自性，天真而妙，不属迷悟。 《庄子》曰：“纯素之道，唯神是守，守而勿失，与神为一，一之精通，合于天伦。 故素也者，谓其无所与杂也； 纯也者，谓其不亏其神也。 能体纯素，谓之真人。 ”见素抱朴，少思寡欲。 夫一切纷华，皆有生以后事，本源自性，清净恬淡，虚无寂寞，情识未起，更有于何欲习？ 故玄宗归真复朴，乃与道合真。 《庄子》曰：“一而不变，静之至矣； 无所于忤，虚之至也； 不与物交，淡之至也； 无所于逆，粹之至也。 ”是谓素德。 《大易》有“素履”之词，“白贲”之象，均契玄宗“见素养素”之道也。 所谓“虚”者，遗形忘体，恬然若无，是谓“身虚”。 绝念、忘知，三际皆空，情忘识泯，谓之“心虚”。 《庄子》曰：“唯道集虚。 ”又曰：“虚无恬澹，乃合天德。 ”又曰：“休则虚，虚则实，实则伦矣。 虚则静，静则动，动则得矣。 体以虚而运，心以虚而灵。 ”故老圣曰：“致虚极，守静笃”。 玄宗以“虚”为归，亦犹佛氏以“空”为归也。 是谓虚德。 所谓柔者，冲和一炁，细微泽润，熏蒸营卫，革故鼎新。 大周之后，真空炼形，以有返无，身亦炁化。 故老圣曰：“专气致柔，能如婴儿乎？ ”又曰：“天下之至柔，驰骋天下之至坚。 无有入无间。 ”“物壮则老，谓之不道，不道早已。 ”又曰：“人之生也柔弱，其死也坚强。 草木之生也柔脆，其死也枯槁。 故坚强者，死之徒； 柔弱者，生之徒。 ”又曰：“天下柔弱，莫过于水，而攻坚强者，莫能胜之。 柔之胜刚，天下莫不知，莫能行。 ”又曰：“守柔曰强。 ”玄宗炁化，变刚为柔，乃出死入生之要素。 专气致柔，则其长生久视也必矣。 是为柔德。 以上十德，总而为一，则为玄德。 分而为十，各有优点。 十德圆成，道立矣。 九、 玄宗十通 《大洞经》曰：“洞源与洞明，万道由通生。 ”又曰：“洞明清净光，帝心大神通。 ”又曰：“十通由斯生，妙行由此兴。 ”又曰：“初曰通炁，次曰通神，终曰通灵。 万通成真，道备登宸。 ”《庄子》曰：“夫耳目内通，而外于心知，鬼神将来舍，而况人乎？ ”此神通之力，由禅定而发。 小乘诸仙，但得五通，即神境通、天眼通、天耳通、他心通、宿命通是也。 大乘诸仙，于此五通外，兼得漏尽通，共为六通。 若大乘大觉金仙，则得十通。 所谓十通者：一、善知他心智神通。 以得他心智通故，知其三千大千世界众生心无差别，如一世界。 乃至百千亿那由他世界，所有众生心，悉能分别了知。 二、无碍清净天眼智神通。 以得无碍清净天眼智神通故，所谓十方一切世界无量众生，死此生彼，善趣恶趣，福相罪相，悉皆明见。 三、宿住随念智神通。 以得宿住随念智神通故，过去不可说、不可说微尘数劫住宿之事，所谓某处生，如是名，如是姓，如是种族，饮食苦乐，从无始来，于诸有中，展转轮回受生，皆悉了知。

The Four Virtues of Nirvāṇa place constant virtue at the forefront, precisely for this reason.

As for *bliss*, it is the joy of self-awakened sagely wisdom, also called the bliss of quiescent nature or celestial bliss. *Zhuangzi* states: "Harmony with others is called human joy; harmony with Heaven is called celestial joy. Those who know celestial joy move with the course of Heaven in life and transform with things in death. At rest, they share the power of yin; in motion, they flow with the waves of yang." This celestial harmony and celestial joy are the principles revered by the Mystery Teachings, truly essential elements of the art of superior life—this is the virtue of bliss.

As for *purity*, it refers to the original essence of self-nature, wondrous and innate, beyond delusion or awakening. *Zhuangzi* says: "The pure and unadorned Way guards only the spirit; guard it without loss, and you become one with the spirit. When the essence of oneness penetrates, it harmonizes with Heaven’s order. Thus, *purity* means having nothing mixed with it; *simplicity* means not diminishing the spirit. Those who embody purity and simplicity are called *true persons*." To see the plain and embrace the uncarved—thoughts are few, desires are scarce. All worldly splendor arises only after birth; the original source of self-nature is pure, tranquil, empty, and still, before emotions and consciousness stir—what desires or habits could there be? Thus, the Mystery Teachings return to truth and restore simplicity, merging with the Dao in reality. *Zhuangzi* says: "Unchanging oneness is the ultimate stillness; nothing opposing it is the ultimate emptiness; no interaction with things is the ultimate blandness; nothing contrary to it is the ultimate purity." This is the virtue of purity. The *Book of Changes* speaks of "plain treading" and the image of "white adornment," both aligning with the Mystery Teachings' path of "seeing the plain and nurturing simplicity."

As for *emptiness*, to abandon form and forget the body, serene as if nothing exists—this is "bodily emptiness." To sever thoughts, forget knowledge, empty the three temporal realms, dissolve emotions, and extinguish consciousness—this is "mental emptiness." *Zhuangzi* says: "Only the Dao abides in emptiness." And: "Emptiness and tranquility accord with Heaven’s virtue." And: "Rest leads to emptiness; emptiness leads to fullness; fullness leads to order. Emptiness leads to stillness; stillness leads to movement; movement leads to attainment. The body operates through emptiness; the mind is numinous through emptiness." Thus, the ancient sages said: "Attain the ultimate emptiness; guard perfect stillness." The Mystery Teachings take "emptiness" as their return, just as the Buddhists take "emptiness" as their return—this is the virtue of emptiness.

As for *softness*, it is the harmonious and unified qi, subtle and moistening, steaming and nourishing the constructive and defensive energies, renewing the old and forging the new. After the great cycle, true emptiness refines the form, returning from being to non-being, and the body transforms into qi. Thus, the ancient sages said: "Concentrate qi to attain softness—can you be like an infant?" And: "The softest under Heaven gallops through the hardest. The insubstantial enters where there is no gap." "When things grow strong, they age—this is called not following the Dao; not following the Dao leads to early demise." And: "In life, humans are soft and weak; in death, they are hard and stiff. Plants in life are soft and fragile; in death, they are withered and dry. Thus, the hard and strong belong to death; the soft and weak belong to life." And: "Nothing under Heaven is softer than water, yet nothing surpasses it in overcoming the hard. The victory of softness over hardness—none under Heaven do not know it, yet none can practice it." And: "To guard softness is called strength." The Mystery Teachings transform qi, changing hardness into softness—this is the essential element for emerging from death and entering life. Concentrate qi to attain softness, and longevity and enduring vision are assured—this is the virtue of softness.

The above ten virtues, when unified, form *mysterious virtue*. When divided into ten, each has its excellence. When the ten virtues are perfected, the Dao is established.

**Nine. The Ten Penetrations of the Mystery Teachings**
The *Scripture of the Great Cavern* says: "The Cavern Source and Cavern Illumination—from their union, the myriad Dao arise." And: "Cavern Illumination is pure and luminous; the Emperor’s mind attains great spiritual penetration." And: "The Ten Penetrations arise from this; wondrous practices flourish thereby." And: "First is penetration of qi, then penetration of spirit, finally penetration of numinosity. When the myriad penetrations perfect reality, the Dao is complete, and one ascends to the celestial throne." *Zhuangzi* says: "When the ears and eyes inwardly penetrate and the mind’s knowledge is outwardly forgotten, even ghosts and spirits will come to dwell—how much more so humans?" This power of spiritual penetration arises from meditative concentration.

Lesser Vehicle immortals attain only the Five Penetrations: divine power, celestial vision, celestial hearing, knowledge of others’ minds, and knowledge of past lives. Greater Vehicle immortals, beyond these Five Penetrations, also attain the penetration of the exhaustion of outflows, making Six Penetrations. As for the Great Vehicle and Great Awakening Golden Sages, they attain the Ten Penetrations. These are:

1. **Penetration of the Wisdom of Knowing Others’ Minds**: With this penetration, one knows the minds of beings in a trichiliocosm without difference, as in a single world. Extending to hundreds of thousands of nayutas of worlds, one can discern and know the minds of all beings.

2. **Penetration of the Unobstructed and Pure Celestial Eye Wisdom**: With this penetration, one clearly sees all beings in the ten directions—dying here and being born there, ascending to good realms or descending to evil realms, bearing marks of fortune or sin.

3. **Penetration of the Wisdom of Recollecting Past Lives**: With this penetration, one knows the events of past lives spanning incalculable eons—where one was born, one’s name, clan, experiences of joy and suffering, and all the births and rebirths in the cycle of existence since beginningless time.

chunks.original_text: 四、知尽未来际劫智神通。 以得知尽未来际智神通故，了知未来际不可说、不可说微尘数劫之中事。 五、无碍清净天耳智神通。 以得无碍天耳智神通故，于诸一切国土，所有声音，欲闻不闻，随意自在。 六、无体性智神通。 以得无体性智神通故，能不动本际而往诣十方一切刹土，利益群生。 七、善分别一切众生言音智神通。 以得言音智通故，了知不可说、不可说刹海微尘数世界中，所有众生种种言辞，悉能分别了解。 八、出生无量色身智神通。 以得色身智神通故，能示现无量无边妙色身，云令所化者亲近开悟，能起种种神通，作度生事业。 九、一切法智神通。 以得法智通故，善能演说无碍法门，兴布法云，降注法雨，以众妙音，开示悟入，使获清净解脱。 十、入一切法灭尽智神通。 以得灭尽智通故，能住三昧正定，而普现色身，譬如光影，普现一切，而于三昧，寂然不动。 以上十种神通，乃大觉金仙之所证，谓之道通，入圆觉果海，非下位所能企也。 十、 玄宗十胜 玄宗胜相甚多，若举其要，则有十焉。 一曰：康胜。 宋儒周子曰：“饱暖大富贵，康宁无价金。 ”予谓：饱暖尚易得，康宁之福则非人人所能享也。 纵得之，亦暂而非久，忽焉老至，精力衰杇，疾病相侵矣。 玄宗修士，则异乎是，含精养神，身心康健，老而不衰，以能利用先天一炁，煅炼色身，陶融凡质，凡质尽化，阴尽阳纯。 故陈翠虚曰：“透体金光骨髓香，金筋玉骨体纯阳。 炼教赤血流为白，阴气消磨身自康。 ”此现实受用之优异，一也。 二曰：清胜。 道家以清净设化，学者由心息相依，返于希夷之乡，大定之境。 天地灵阳之炁，不召而自来，所谓：“以我真空，感彼妙有。 ”易重浊为清阳，化凡质成灵体，自觉尘劳日歇，物欲不干，众邪不扰，六根虚静，身心清泰。 《庄子》谓之“天游”。 《度人经》曰：“天无浮翳，四气朗清。 ”心地亦然，此清宁之优胜，二也。 三曰：逸胜。 逸谓优逸，非放逸也。 荣辱不干，势位不慕，遁世无闷，抱一湛然，心闲无事，万累都捐，怡焉而夷，泊然而泰，导而弗先，感而后应。 《庄子》曰：“夫虚静恬澹，寂寞无为者，天地之平，而道之至，故帝王圣人休焉。 ”《黄庭经》曰：“观志游神三奇灵，闲暇无事心太平。 ”又曰：“垂拱无为身自安，体虚无物心自闲。 修和独立真人宫，恬淡无欲游德园。 ”又曰：“作道优游身独居，扶养性命守虚无，恬淡无为何思虑，羽翼已成正扶疏，长生久视乃飞去。 ”此乃玄宗身心闲逸之妙，正同禅宗古德所谓：“绝学无为闲道人。 ”世出世间，最为受用，此谓之逸胜，三也。 四曰：吉胜。 老氏无为，为而弗持，功成弗居、和光同尘、不迎不拒，湛若虚空，故动无不吉。 此不争之德，无着之妙，既无心于彼此，亦忘情于去来，如流水行云，无适无莫，翛然自适，超然无累，随缘放旷，任性逍遥。 《庄子》曰：“无不忘也，无不有也，澹然无极，而众美从之。 ”其为吉祥何如哉！ 此之谓吉胜，四也。 五曰：寿胜。 《尚书·洪范》所云“五福”，寿居其一。 《诗》有眉寿之咏，寿比南山之颂。 玄宗修士，丹基立后，已得命自在，优游于洞天福地之间，笑傲于十洲三岛之境。

4. **Penetration of the Wisdom of Knowing the Future Until Its End**: With this penetration, one knows all events in the future spanning incalculable eons—unfathomable as motes of dust in number.

5. **Penetration of the Unobstructed and Pure Celestial Ear Wisdom**: With this penetration, one hears all sounds across every land in the ten directions, whether one wishes to hear them or not, freely and at will.

6. **Penetration of the Wisdom of Non-Substantiality**: With this penetration, one can travel to all buddha-lands in the ten directions without moving from the original ground, benefiting sentient beings.

7. **Penetration of the Wisdom of Discerning All Beings’ Speech**: With this penetration, one knows and distinguishes all the varied speech of beings in worlds as numerous as motes of dust in an ocean of buddha-lands.

8. **Penetration of the Wisdom of Manifesting Limitless Color-Bodies**: With this penetration, one can manifest boundless, wondrous color-bodies to draw near those to be transformed, awaken them, and perform the work of liberating beings through various miraculous powers.

9. **Penetration of the Wisdom of All Dharmas**: With this penetration, one skillfully expounds the unobstructed Dharma-gate, spreading Dharma-clouds and showering Dharma-rain, using wondrous sounds to reveal, instruct, awaken, and lead beings to attain pure liberation.

10. **Penetration of the Wisdom of Entering the Cessation of All Dharmas**: With this penetration, one abides in samādhi’s true concentration while universally manifesting color-bodies, like light and shadow appearing everywhere, yet remaining unmoving in samādhi.

These ten penetrations are what the Great Awakened Golden Immortal realizes, called the *Dao-Penetration*, entering the ocean of perfect enlightenment—beyond the reach of lower stages.

---

**Ten Superiorities of the Mysterious Teaching**

The Mysterious Teaching possesses many superior qualities; to summarize its essence, there are ten:

1. **Superiority of Health**
Master Zhou of the Song Confucians said: *"Abundance and warmth are great wealth and honor; health and peace are priceless gold."* Yet while abundance and warmth are easily attained, the blessing of health and peace is not enjoyed by all. Even when obtained, it is fleeting—suddenly, old age arrives, vitality declines, and illness assails. The cultivator of the Mysterious Teaching differs: nurturing essence and cultivating spirit, body and mind remain robust, never decaying with age. By harnessing the primordial qi, refining the physical form, and transforming the mortal substance, the mortal substance is wholly transmuted, yin exhausted and yang purified. Thus, Chen Cuixu said:
*"Through the body shines golden light, the marrow fragrant,
Golden sinews and jade bones—pure yang.
Refining the red blood to flow as white,
Yin qi dissolves, the body naturally healthy."*
This is the first preeminent benefit in present enjoyment.

2. **Superiority of Purity**
The Daoist teaching transforms through purity and stillness. The practitioner, through the interdependence of mind and breath, returns to the realm of the subtle and imperceptible, the state of great concentration. The celestial yang-qi of heaven and earth arrives unbidden, as it is said: *"With my true emptiness, I resonate with that wondrous being."* The turbid is transmuted into pure yang, the mortal form refined into a numinous body. One feels worldly toils gradually recede, desires no longer intrude, no demons disturb, and the six senses become empty and still—body and mind at peace. *Zhuangzi* calls this *"wandering in heaven,"* while the *Scripture of Salvation* states: *"The heavens are free of floating haze; the four qi shine clear and bright."* The mind-ground is likewise—this is the second superiority of purity and tranquility.

3. **Superiority of Leisure**
Leisure here means ease, not dissipation. Unaffected by honor or disgrace, unmoved by power or rank, one retreats from the world without melancholy, embracing the One in profound stillness. The mind is at ease, free of affairs; all burdens are cast aside. Joyful and content, serene and composed, one guides without leading, responds only after being moved. *Zhuangzi* said: *"Vacuity, stillness, tranquility, and non-action are the equilibrium of heaven and earth, the perfection of the Dao—thus do emperors and sages rest in them."* The *Yellow Court Scripture* states: *"Observe the will, roam the spirit through the three numinous powers; at leisure, without care, the mind is at great peace."* And again: *"With folded hands and non-action, the body is naturally at ease; when the body is empty of things, the mind is naturally free. Cultivating harmony, one abides alone in the true person’s palace, wandering in the garden of virtue, free from desires."* And: *"Practicing the Dao in ease, dwelling alone, nurturing life and guarding emptiness—what thoughts or worries arise? With wings fully grown, one soars aloft, living long and gazing afar, then taking flight."* This is the wondrous leisure of body and mind in the Mysterious Teaching, akin to the ancient Chan masters’ *"unlearned, non-active, leisurely Daoist."* Whether in the world or beyond it, this is the greatest enjoyment—this is the third superiority, that of leisure.

4. **Superiority of Auspiciousness**
The Old Master practiced non-action, acting without attachment, accomplishing without abiding. Harmonizing with the world, blending light with dust, neither seeking nor rejecting, he remained still as empty space—thus, all his movements were auspicious. This is the virtue of non-contention, the wondrousness of non-attachment. Without intent toward self or other, without emotion toward coming or going, like flowing water or drifting clouds, without favor or aversion, one is carefree and at ease, transcendent and unburdened, following conditions with openness, following nature with freedom. *Zhuangzi* said: *"Nothing is not forgotten; nothing is not present. In profound tranquility without limit, all beauties follow."* How auspicious is this! This is the fourth superiority, that of auspiciousness.

5. **Superiority of Longevity**
The *Hongfan* chapter of the *Book of Documents* lists *"five blessings,"* with longevity among them. The *Book of Songs* sings of *"brow-longevity"* and praises *"longevity like the Southern Mountains."* The cultivator of the Mysterious Teaching, having established the foundation of the elixir, gains mastery over life, roaming freely among grotto-heavens and blessed lands, laughing and wandering in the realms of the Ten Continents and Three Islands.

chunks.original_text: 若李脱之八百，安期之三千。 南极广寿仙翁，生于上古，至明初已届万寿之期，见诸仙史，昭然可考。 故张紫阳曰：“一粒灵丹吞入腹，始知我命不由天。 ”《黄庭经》曰：“人皆食谷与五味，独食太和阴阳气，故能不死天相既。 ”又曰：“闭塞命门如玉都，寿传万岁皆有馀。 ”陈观吾曰：“此岸彼涛已脱离，到彼方知寿可跻。 一得归来宜永得，渡河筏子上天梯。 ”道家长生久视之学，独以寿胜。 阆苑天宫，随意寄托。 桑田变沧海，逍遥自如，此真优异之点，五也。 六曰：他力胜。 玄宗三元丹法，地元、天元，均属外丹服食，刀圭一入口，白日生羽翰。 不历时期，瞬息超凡入圣。 其神化之妙，匪夷所思，能度亡亲，点化枯骨，使之复生。 此种不思议方便法门，惟玄宗所独有，此其优异之点，六也。 七曰：拔宅冲举胜。 以神丹服食殊胜故，能使举族超升，阖宅冲举。 如晋·许旌阳真君，与其父族、仙眷四十二口，弟子六人，同时升举，鸡犬亦随逐飞升。 此种“拔宅冲举”盛况，亦唯玄宗所独有，他教所罕觏，此优异之点，七也。 八曰：相承殊胜。 玄宗道脉悠远，祖祖相承，迄今数千载，从未断绝，法灯相续。 尽未来际，转益光辉，因缘遭遇，悉皆现证，此其优异之点，八也。 九曰：传授殊胜。 佛法有正法、像法、末法之分。 玄宗古仙，以法身显化世间，身面言说，接引有缘，数千年如一日，道祖无涅盘之日。 正法住世，亦无时期之限量，此优异之点，九也。 十曰：着述殊胜。 佛教经典，均由弟子追忆编纂而成。 玄宗道经，乃由道祖亲着，亲言出亲口，诵之者，如闻其声，若见其人。 此其优异之点，十也。 十一、 玄宗七大 《庄子·徐无鬼篇》云：“知大一，知大阴，知大目，知大均，知大方，知大信，知大定，至矣。 大一通之，大阴解之，大目视之，大均缘之，大方体之，大信稽之，大定持之。 尽有天，循有照，冥有枢，始有彼。 则其解之也，似不解之者，其知之也，似不知之者，不知而后知之。 ” 释曰：《楞严》七大，显如来藏妙真如性，周遍含容，无所不至，是彰性德之妙。 《庄子》七大，不惟表性德，亦表修德。 性修不二，本末兼赅，所谓“大一通之”，已摄《楞严》地、水、风、火、空、识、根等诸七大矣。 “大定持之”，以表修德，以修合性，故业识忘而天真现。 智照无边，冥应无穷，所谓：“尽有天，循有照，冥有枢”也。 此中“大阴解之”，亦表修德。 老圣所谓：“归根曰静，静曰复命，复命曰常”也。 大阴者，寂静之德，坤象也。 大目者，普眼也。 “大目视之”，表果德，法眼也，见彻法界之谓也。 “大均缘之”，表化他德，平等大慈，普覆众生之谓也。 “大方体之”，表性德，身刹涉入，依正圆融之象也。 “大信稽之”，又表修德，信为道源，功德之母，万行之首，有大信而后证大果，未有不信而行，不行而证者。 故此七大，摄因行证入而无遗。 末谓“不知而后知之”，尤契《般若》：“无知而无不知”之妙，可谓禅玄合辙矣。 陆西星《南华副墨》云：“此节名目，皆庄子自命。 大一者，浑沦未判之谓。 大阴者，至静无感之谓。 大目则分而名矣。 大均者，同而不殊。

Li Tuo’s eight hundred years and Anqi’s three thousand—such are the spans of the immortals. The Venerable Immortal of Broad Longevity of the Southern Culmen, born in high antiquity, had by the early Ming already reached ten thousand years of age, as clearly attested in the annals of the immortals. Thus Zhang Ziyang declared: *"A single grain of the numinous elixir swallowed into the belly—only then do I know my life is not ruled by Heaven."* The *Scripture of the Yellow Court* states: *"All men eat grain and the five flavors, but I alone consume the Great Harmony of yin and yang qi, and thus do not die, for Heaven’s favor is already mine."* It further says: *"Seal the Gate of Life as if it were a jade capital—longevity will be transmitted for ten thousand years and more."* Chen Guanzhi observed: *"This shore’s waves are left behind; only upon reaching that shore does one know longevity may be attained. Once gained, it should be forever kept—like a raft crossing the river or a ladder ascending to Heaven."*

The Daoist teaching of long life and enduring vision finds its superiority precisely in longevity. The celestial palaces of Lang Garden may be freely inhabited. Though mulberry fields turn to azure seas, one remains carefree and at ease—this is the fifth distinction, that of longevity.

6. **Superiority of Other-Power**
The Three Primordials Elixir Methods of the Mysterious Teaching—Earth Primordial and Heaven Primordial—both pertain to the ingestion of external elixirs. With but a single *daogui* measure taken into the mouth, one sprouts feathered wings in broad daylight. Without passing through stages, one is instantly transformed from mortal to sage. The marvel of such divine transformation defies all thought. It can deliver deceased kin, restore desiccated bones to life—such inconceivable expedient methods belong to the Mysterious Teaching alone. This is its sixth distinction.

7. **Superiority of Homestead Ascension**
By virtue of the surpassing efficacy of the divine elixir, one may cause an entire clan to ascend together, the whole household rising in flight. As with the Perfected Lord Xu Jingyang of the Jin, who ascended with his father’s clan, forty-two immortal kin, and six disciples, all at once—even the chickens and dogs followed in their flight. Such grandeur of *"homestead ascension"* is unique to the Mysterious Teaching, rarely seen in other traditions. This is the seventh distinction.

8. **Superiority of Lineage Transmission**
The Daoist lineage of the Mysterious Teaching stretches far into the past, transmitted from master to master without interruption for thousands of years. The lamp of the Dharma has never been extinguished. Into the infinite future, its radiance will only grow brighter. All karmic encounters and circumstances are realized in the present—this is the eighth distinction.

9. **Superiority of Transmission**
Buddhist Dharma is divided into the True Dharma, Semblance Dharma, and Final Dharma ages. The ancient immortals of the Mysterious Teaching manifest in the world through the Dharmakāya, their bodily presence and speech guiding those with karmic affinity. For thousands of years, they have remained unchanged, as the Dao Ancestor has no day of *nirvāṇa*. The True Dharma abides in the world without temporal limit—this is the ninth distinction.

10. **Superiority of Writings**
Buddhist scriptures were all compiled by disciples from recollections. The Daoist scriptures of the Mysterious Teaching, however, were personally composed by the Dao Ancestor, spoken directly from his own mouth. To recite them is to hear his voice, as if seeing his person—this is the tenth distinction.

11. **The Seven Greatnesses of the Mysterious Teaching**
The *Zhuangzi*’s *"Xu Wugui"* chapter states: *"To know the Great Oneness, the Great Yin, the Great Eye, the Great Equality, the Great Square, the Great Faith, and the Great Stability—this is perfection. The Great Oneness unites them; the Great Yin dissolves them; the Great Eye sees them; the Great Equality conditions them; the Great Square embodies them; the Great Faith verifies them; the Great Stability upholds them. They exhaust Heaven’s being, follow illumination, darkly possess the pivot, and begin with the other. Thus, to dissolve them is as if not dissolving; to know them is as if not knowing. Only after not knowing does one come to know."*

The commentary explains: The *Śūraṅgama Sūtra*’s Seven Greatnesses reveal the wondrous Suchness of the Tathāgatagarbha, all-pervading and all-containing, manifesting the marvel of inherent virtue. The *Zhuangzi*’s Seven Greatnesses not only express inherent virtue but also cultivated virtue. Inherent and cultivated virtues are non-dual, encompassing both root and branch. The *"Great Oneness unites them"* already encompasses the *Śūraṅgama*’s Seven Greatnesses—earth, water, wind, fire, space, consciousness, and faculties.

*"The Great Stability upholds them"* expresses cultivated virtue, aligning cultivation with inherent nature, so that karmic consciousness is forgotten and celestial truth appears. Wisdom illumines boundlessly, dark response is inexhaustible—this is what is meant by *"exhausting Heaven’s being, following illumination, darkly possessing the pivot."*

Here, *"the Great Yin dissolves them"* also expresses cultivated virtue. As the Old Sage said: *"Returning to the root is called quiescence; quiescence is called recovering life; recovering life is called constancy."* The Great Yin is the virtue of stillness, the image of *kun*. The Great Eye is the universal eye. *"The Great Eye sees them"* expresses resultant virtue—the Dharma-eye, seeing through the Dharma-realm.

*"The Great Equality conditions them"* expresses the virtue of transforming others—great equanimous compassion, universally covering all beings. *"The Great Square embodies them"* expresses inherent virtue—the interpenetration of body and realm, the image of principle and phenomena in perfect fusion.

*"The Great Faith verifies them"* further expresses cultivated virtue. Faith is the source of the Dao, the mother of merit, the foremost of the myriad practices. Only with great faith can one realize great fruition; there has never been one who practiced without faith or realized without practice. Thus, these Seven Greatnesses encompass all causes, practices, and realizations without omission.

The final phrase, *"Only after not knowing does one come to know,"* perfectly accords with the *Prajñāpāramitā*’s *"knowing nothing yet knowing all"*—truly a meeting of Chan and the Mysterious. Lu Xixing’s *Supplementary Ink to the Southern Florescence* says: *"These terms are all coined by Zhuangzi himself. The Great Oneness refers to the undifferentiated primordial state. The Great Yin refers to utmost stillness without response. The Great Eye is differentiated and named. The Great Equality means sameness without distinction."*

5. **Superiority of Longevity**
The *Hongfan* chapter of the *Book of Documents* lists *"five blessings,"* with longevity among them. The *Book of Songs* sings of *"brow-longevity"* and praises *"longevity like the Southern Mountains."* The cultivator of the Mysterious Teaching, having established the foundation of the elixir, gains mastery over life, roaming freely among grotto-heavens and blessed lands, laughing and wandering in the realms of the Ten Continents and Three Islands.

chunks.original_text: 大方者，广而不御。 大信则其中有信之信。 大定，则以止众止之止，是皆天之所谓，至矣，尽矣，无复有余蕴矣。 于大一，则通之。 通之也者，未始有物之先，可以潜浮，而不可以思虑求，故曰通。 于大阴，则解之。 解之者也，至静无感之时，可以心融，而不可以名相得，故曰解。 大目，则可容吾视矣。 大均，则可缘而求矣。 大方，则可兼而体矣。 大信，则可稽其方动之期。 大定，则可执其有常之柄，知天之所谓者，盖如此。 ” 此《庄子》七大之说，微妙圆通，知此七大为真知。 若了此七大，则与道合真，超然自在矣。 十二、 玄宗戒学 道家戒学，散见诸书。 大抵戒所以遮恶，所以摄心，所以成清净宁一之心德者也。 一心修道，自然无恶，冲和所感，戾气全消，是故“含德之厚，比于赤子，毒虫不螫，鸷鸟不搏，虎兕甲兵，无所肆其厄，”是谓“道共戒。 ”共者，兼有之义。 修道乃善业中最优胜者，成和之德，戒亦随成，是道外不必另立戒也，故称道共戒。 又恶业之造成，原于恶意，若夫息念双忘，寂然不动，泰然大定，杳然无为，洞然大空，则善恶二忘。 念尚不起，如何更造现业？ 故一心静定，戒德圆成。 定外无戒，谓之“定共戒”。 《庄子》曰：“相造乎道者，无事而生定。 ”又曰：“而熟视其状貌，窅然空然终日，视之而不见，听之而不闻，搏之而不得也，光曜曰：至矣，其孰能至此乎！ ”看他定得六根虚寂，浑如太虚，岂非“定共戒”之胜相乎？ 此二者，上乘之戒也。 以身心清净，道业随成，一切戒律，无不圆满也。 其次曰：摄善法戒。 老圣曰：“居善地，心善渊，与善仁，言善信，政善治，事善能，动善时。 ”潜虚翁《玄览》云：“彼上善者，随顺方便，不争险易。 此其居之善地也。 随境而定，不争静躁，此其心之善渊也。 平等行事，不争彼此，此其与之善仁也。 随流得妙，不争权实，此其言之善信也。 泽润万物，不争远近，此其政之善治也。 事善能，则能圆能方。 动善时，则时行而时止。 七者，皆上善若水，利物不争之事。 惟不争，则人己两忘，内外俱顺，怨由何而至哉？ ”此之七种善，摄身、语、意三业，待人接物，自行化他，乃至俯仰进退，动容周旋，靡不赅摄，悉以至善为归，慈和之风盛，众生恶业潜消，悉归清净宁一，玄德之化。 故曰：“摄善法戒。 ” 其次曰：摄律仪戒。 老圣曰：“古之善为士者，微妙玄通，深不可识。 夫惟不可识，故强为之容。 豫兮若冬涉川，犹兮若畏四邻，俨兮其若容，涣兮若冰将释，敦兮其若朴，旷兮其若谷，混兮其若浊。 ”以上七喻，乃老圣形容抱道之威仪也。 《庄子》之赞道家律仪，则更有进矣。 其言曰：“尸居而龙见，渊默而雷声，神动而天随。 ”又曰：“古之真人，不逆寡，不雄成，不谟士。 若然者，过而弗悔，当而自得也。 若然者，登高而不栗，入水不濡，入火不热，是知能登假于道也若此。 古之真人，其寝不梦，其觉无忧，其食无甘，其息深深。 真人之息以踵，众人之息以喉。 古之真人，不知说（同悦）生，不知恶死，其出不欣，其入不距，翛然而往，翛然而来而已矣。 若然者，其心志，其容寂，其颡頱（音恢上声，额宽大貌）。

The Great Vastness is boundless yet unobstructed. The Great Faith contains within it the faith of faith itself. The Great Stillness is the stillness that stills all stillness—these are all what Heaven deems supreme, perfect, and utterly exhaustive, leaving no residue.

In relation to the Great Oneness, one *pervades* it. To pervade it is to abide in the state before the arising of the ten thousand things, where one may drift and float but cannot seek through thought or deliberation—hence it is called *pervading*.

In relation to the Great Yin, one *dissolves* into it. To dissolve is to be in the state of utmost stillness without response, where the mind may merge but cannot be grasped by names or forms—hence it is called *dissolving*.

The Great Eye may then accommodate our vision. The Great Equality may be followed in pursuit. The Great Vastness may be embraced in its entirety. The Great Faith may be examined for its timely movements. The Great Stillness may be grasped by its constancy. To know what Heaven deems supreme is thus.

This exposition of the Seven Greatnesses in *Zhuangzi* is subtly wondrous and perfectly harmonious. To know these Seven Greatnesses is true knowledge. If one fully comprehends them, one merges with the Dao in truth and attains transcendent freedom.

---

**XII. The Precepts of the Mysterious School**

The precepts of Daoism are scattered across various texts. Generally, precepts serve to restrain evil, collect the mind, and perfect the virtue of purity, tranquility, and unity. When the mind is single-mindedly devoted to the Dao, evil naturally vanishes; harmony arises, and all perverse qi dissipates. Thus it is said: *"One of profound virtue is like a newborn babe—poisonous creatures do not sting, birds of prey do not strike, and tigers, rhinoceroses, and weapons cause no harm."* This is called *"the precepts shared by the Dao."* "Shared" means they are inherently possessed. Cultivating the Dao is the most excellent of virtuous practices; as the virtue of harmony is perfected, the precepts are naturally fulfilled. Thus, apart from the Dao, no separate precepts need be established—hence they are called *the precepts shared by the Dao*.

The formation of evil karma originates from evil intentions. If thoughts and distinctions are stilled, if one abides in utter quiescence, great stillness, profound non-action, and vast emptiness, then both good and evil are forgotten. If even thoughts do not arise, how can present karma be created? Thus, when the mind is settled in stillness, the virtue of precepts is perfectly realized. Apart from stillness, there are no precepts—this is called *"the precepts shared by stillness."* *Zhuangzi* says: *"Those who approach the Dao generate stillness without effort."* And again: *"Gazing intently at his form, one sees only emptiness and void, seeing without seeing, hearing without hearing, grasping without obtaining. Radiant and luminous—who can attain this?"* Behold how, in such stillness, the six senses become empty and silent, merging with the vastness of the Great Void—is this not the supreme manifestation of *"the precepts shared by stillness"*? These two are the precepts of the highest vehicle. With body and mind purified, the Dao is naturally perfected, and all precepts are perfectly fulfilled.

Next are the *precepts of gathering wholesome dharmas*. The Venerable Laozi said: *"Dwell in good earth, let the mind be good and profound, be good in companionship, good in speech, good in governance, good in action, and good in timing."* Master Qianxu wrote in *Profound Insight*: *"The highest good adapts to circumstances without contention, neither shunning difficulty nor seeking ease—this is dwelling in good earth. Abiding in stillness without contention, neither clinging to tranquility nor rejecting disturbance—this is the mind’s goodness and profundity. Acting with impartiality, without contention between self and other—this is good companionship. Attaining subtlety in following the flow, without contention between expedience and reality—this is good speech. Nourishing the ten thousand things without contention between near and far—this is good governance. Good in action means being both rounded and square. Good in timing means acting or resting as the moment demands. These seven are all like water, benefiting all without contention. Only by not contending are self and other forgotten, inner and outer harmonized—whence could resentment arise?"* These seven kinds of goodness gather the three karmas of body, speech, and mind; they govern interactions with others, self-cultivation, and transforming others, extending even to every movement and gesture, all of which are subsumed and directed toward supreme goodness. When the wind of kindness and harmony prevails, the evil karma of beings silently dissolves, and all return to purity, tranquility, and unity—the transformation of mysterious virtue. Hence, they are called *"the precepts of gathering wholesome dharmas."*

Next are the *precepts of observing discipline*. The Venerable Laozi said: *"The ancients who were good as scholars were subtly mysterious, profoundly penetrating, and too deep to be known. Because they could not be known, I forcefully describe their appearance: hesitant, as if crossing a river in winter; cautious, as if fearing neighbors on all sides; dignified, as if guests; yielding, as if ice about to melt; simple, as if uncarved wood; open, as if a valley; merged, as if turbid."* These seven metaphors describe the demeanor of one who embraces the Dao. *Zhuangzi*’s praise of Daoist discipline goes even further: *"Abiding like a corpse yet manifesting like a dragon, silent as an abyss yet resounding like thunder, spirit moves and Heaven follows."* And again: *"The True Person of old did not oppose the few, did not dominate success, did not scheme for advantage. Such a one, when erring, felt no regret; when correct, remained self-content. Such a one, climbing heights without trembling, entering water without getting wet, entering fire without feeling heat—this is the knowledge that ascends to the Dao in this way. The True Person of old slept without dreaming, woke without worry, ate without relishing flavor, and breathed deeply. The True Person’s breath reaches the heels, while ordinary people’s breath reaches only the throat. The True Person of old did not delight in life, did not detest death, exited without joy, entered without resistance—coming and going with effortless ease. Such a one’s mind was steadfast, countenance serene, forehead broad and expansive."*
