Meng the Third of San’yi Monastery says:

*"Wenshu’s wisdom, Vimalakīrti’s virtue—
How to enter and exit, how to speak with perfect roundness?
The spring light leaves the east wind’s face unchanged,
Yet lures the cuckoos of Jiangnan to weep."*

Master Xue’an Jin says:

*"Who let the painted tower stand to the west,
Where we meet and laugh in hushed tones?
Home at last, spring’s colors linger late—
Flowers fall, and partridges cry."*

Master Shuzhong Yun says:

*"Crimson strings plucked beneath the night moon,
Emerald sleeves dancing in the spring breeze.
Those who harmonize dwell in carefree ease—
Who else could share such company?"*

Master Juelang Sheng says:

*"With strokes that fail to form ‘eight’ and words that miss the mark,
The spring wind brushes the balustrade—flowers still slumber.
Where has the young lord gone, not yet returned?
Sweet grasses grow thick, sorrow covering the earth."*

Master Baiyun Duan says:

*"If you can turn things as the Tathāgata does,
Warm spring’s mountain blossoms bloom everywhere.
You’ll naturally possess a pair of impoverished hands,
Never lightly dancing the Three Terraces."*

Master Qianguang An says:

*"Rain washes the pale red peach buds to radiance,
Wind sways the light green willow threads with grace.
In the white clouds’ shadow, strange rocks emerge,
While ancient trees stand clear in the green water’s glow."*

Master Xinwen Ben says:

*"Warm sun, gentle breeze—scenery grows ever strange,
Each flower and blade of grass reveals its full mystery.
A gust of fragrant tuan-hua wind arises,
Drawing wandering bees to fly everywhere."*

Master Beijian Wen says:

*"Six senses without function—trust does not pass,
All at once entrusted to the spring wind.
A wisp of incense smoke, a tranquil painting,
A hundred birds stay away, yet flowers bloom red on their own."*

Master Jishui Guang says:

*"A thatched hut hidden by the stream’s edge,
Brushing aside mist to transplant lingzhi in a stony field.
Turning to gaze, the flowers seem drunk—
Unnoticed, a warbler alights before the window."*

Master Yuan’an Nong says:

*"Each crimson path the same red,
A thousand peach and plum trees, ten thousand in full bloom.
Who recognizes the spring wind’s face?
Five-colored fragrance meets you everywhere."*

Master Yangshan Qin says:

*"All dharmas leave behind marks of discrimination,
Yet all marks remain thus, thus.
Within the spring wind’s scene, heaven and earth expand—
Endless rivers and mountains unfold like a painted scroll."*

Master Ciming Yuan says:

*"Chasing bird tracks across the empty sky,
A hidden bird’s call heralds spring again.
If you know the east wind follows no divergent path,
Vimalakīrti’s chamber remains unshaken, never sinking."*

Master Yushi Fang says:

*"Secluded birds call amidst red and green,
A single mat, a waft of warm wind startles midday sleep.
Sleeves dance, a single robe enters the woven dust—
Zhang drinks wine, Li grows drunk."*

Master Tudu Ce says:

*"To see forms, to seek sounds—no harm in this,
Embroidering mandarin ducks amidst a hundred flowers’ shadows.
Since recognizing the golden needle,
Let the wind blow fragrance into full sleeves."*

Master Benzhu Yue says:

*"Ancient trees sealed in clouds exhale sweet scent,
A gentle breeze stirs, birds sing anew.
Turning over beneath the curtained moon,
Sleeves fill with flowers’ fragrance, sleeves fill with spring."*

Master Tiantong Jing says:

*"Raising your brows to answer a question’s start,
I’ve personally seen the Buddha—no need to hide it.
To this day, offerings fill the four quarters of the world,
Spring lingers on plum branches, bearing snowy cold."*

Master Zide Hui says:

*"Nezha Taizi’s original body,
Towering, unattached, unstained by dust.
Clouds scatter, flowing water—heaven and earth purified,
By the fence, yellow leaves vie for spring."*

Master Zu’an Jian says:

*"A face of earth, a head of ash, unstained by dust,
Flower streets and willow lanes delight in true nature.
The golden rooster crows at dawn, waking jade tower dreams—
A single tree blooms, spring through endless kalpas."*

Master Zundao Qi says:

*"The spring colors of Wuyuan always come late,
In second month, willows hang no threads.
Now, when the river’s ice breaks,
It is precisely when Chang’an’s flowers fall."*

Master Daozong Ji says:

*"By the wild inn and mountain bridge, horses’ hooves follow,
Peach and plum trees form paths as they go.
Who knows beyond the ancient bank’s drooping willows,
Another spring wind dances in the green mist?"*

Master Xueqiao Xin says:

*"By the paths, many rape and wheat flowers bloom,
Swallows with mud in beaks paint the painted eaves.
Pitiful—countless scattered springs,
How can they dye crimson gauze with elegance?"*

Master Lingsou Yuan says:

*"Seeking the mind, the mind’s trace is already lost,
Recognizing the eternal as the universal.
From this, idle days dissolve—
When spring comes, accumulated snow melts on its own."*

Master Xinwen Ben says:

*"Leaning half by the fence, bearing snow and frost,
In the vast expanse of shadow, a celestial pose revealed.
Last night, spring arrived in the village ahead—
The old monk in the bamboo hut remains unaware."*

Master Gushan Gui says:

*"On the world’s path of wind and waves, I do not see you,
Each meeting brings fresh sorrow.
Where do flowing water and fallen flowers go?
By the cave’s mouth, peach blossoms hold a different spring."*

Master Yunyan Yin says:

*"Vast and empty, without sage, the whole body revealed,
Face-to-face presentation—already beyond the ford.
Do not ask of Liang’s court or Wei’s gardens,
One flower, five leaves—spring arises naturally."*

Master Tianzhang Yu says:

*"Who lingers in the jade tower, reminiscing?
A single call from a secluded bird touches the heart most deeply.
Do not say you do not know the bitterness of weeping traces—
Spring’s brew, the flower-slave, grows ever more foolish."*

Master Cishou Shen says:

*"In the third month, radiant light, harmonious and warm,
Mountains and rivers of brocade share the same scene everywhere.
Dawn mist over green tiles, Cold Food rain,
Sunlit curtains rolled up in the apricot blossom wind."*

Master Xuedou Zong says:

*"The iron ox plows open the cave’s sky,
Peach blossoms, petal by petal, emerge from deep sources.
The man of Qin has gone, leaving no news—
For a thousand ages, the peaks and ridges grow ever more vivid."*

Master Qingshi Xin says:

*"Spring wind fills the flower dell, sleeves brim with spring,
Red and white, perfectly matched.
Who can bear yet another sentimental one—
A reed pipe’s note passes over the wild pond?"*

Master Caotang Qing says:

*"Rabbit horns need not exist, ox horns need not be absent.
Where existence and non-existence fail,
Fragrance fills the Way’s path."*

Zen Master Zhongfeng Mu says:

*"Flowers fall on the silver bed, spring resplendent,
Moon sinks in the golden tent, night far-reaching.
The empty hall, desolate, no one to share—
Only burning incense sticks to one’s heart’s content."*

Zen Master Qingshan Wen says:

*"Jade Garden and Liang Park enjoy early spring,
The fragrant grove’s full bloom intoxicates wanderers.
Unable to bear the curtain’s edge, the orioles’ urgent cries,
Only deepening the scattered profusion of fallen flowers."*

chunks.translated_text:
Master Shangfang Yi says:

*"Sun-face to the east, moon-face to the west—
Who says carefree drifting falls into the stream?
Mountain peach blossoms scatter, spring departs,
Yet the cuckoo still cries from the branches."*

He also says:

*"Rain clears, the wanderer has not returned,
When suddenly a thunderclap splits the clear sky.
The plum by the ridge has caught spring’s message—
Not like the mountain peach, blooming all alike."*

Master Yizuzi says:

*"Listening to rain through the long night, weary,
A lone lamp shines cold upon the inkstone.
Spring departs with a rustle beneath the flowers,
Everywhere, birds cry in the fading light."*

Master Huiguang Sou says:

*"House to house, all gaze upon the wild fox’s child,
Many see, few truly know.
A hundred spirits, a thousand demons—all traces swept away,
As spring’s wind reaches the ten-thousand-year branch."*

Master Shigu Yi says:

*"Spring wind scatters the green peach blossoms,
A single petal flows past a hundred thousand homes.
Who lingers at the painted pavilion’s wine shop,
Inviting others to share Zhaozhou’s tea?"*

Master Yi[ ]quan says:

*"Flowers planted on stone—how rare the sight,
Branches heavy with spring’s hidden fragrance.
Scent drifts through the realm, yet none detect its trace,
As the wild wind blows at will."*

Master Xiaofeng Zhe says:

*"Spring’s hues fill the garden, yet cannot be contained—
A single red apricot branch breaches the wall.
Do not marvel at the noble scion’s high spirit,
For such grace has ever been heaven’s gift."*

Master Rujiu Xue says:

*"The palace bird roosts deep in the jade tower,
A sliver of moon rises at the eaves, night after night.
The fragrant carriage does not return, flowers bloom on their own,
Spring comes, yet the cold-dispelling gold lies idle."*

Master Nanjian Wen says:

*"Better to accept one’s lot, take what little comes,
Thirst quenched, hunger sated—only the self knows.
Trampling through spring’s radiance, rain-soaked and full,
Who dares claim the cosmos as their own?"*

Master Shanfu Zheng says:

*"Let the nobles of Five Tombs boast of their wealth,
The patch-robed monk scorns not his poverty.
After the second month in Jiangnan’s spring,
Orioles sing through every apricot-blossom village."*

Master Jue’an Xiang says:

*"Three cries of the tripod’s lid open the universal gate,
Yet the toiling souls of the bitter sea cannot be called back.
Ninety days of spring—now half are gone,
Petals drift in vain, dappling the moss."*

Master Dabian Quan says:

*"In toil and courtesy, uphold the Dao’s meaning,
Blending light with the world, welcome the guest.
The great rhythm turns—flowers bloom on a thousand trees,
Yet the traveler’s heart still knows not spring.
Striking from the side, hammering straight—
Losing the whole body.
Beyond the green mountains, a few yellow birds’ calls
Seize all the scenery, claiming mastery."*

Master Kentang Chong says:

*"Light does not illuminate objects, objects do not endure,
When light and object both are forgotten, what trace remains?
A hundred birds do not return—spring has aged,
Falling blossoms, flowing water encircle the lone village."*

Master Yongmi Ding says:

*"Mountains and rivers mock the peach and plum’s folly,
A wisp of mist and cloud levels every tree.
Watching spring’s arrival, admiring the flowers’ splendor,
The partridge’s cry fades deep into the tangled peaks."*

Master Yuan’an Fen says:

*"The yellow bird’s song dries in the green willow’s shade,
The Long Gate Palace still speaks of spring’s absence.
Where the jade flute plays, flowers fall in vain,
As the jade carriage passes, the moon has already set."*

Master Bojian Jian says:

*"Dwelling in the imperial park, spring at its finest,
Why ask the Eastern Lord of spring’s reds and purples?
A breath of fragrant wind rises from the secluded valley,
Beckoning the orioles to sing in the fading light."*

Master Tiantong Jue says:

*"Frozen in the snow-bound hut, night brings collapse,
The wicker gate stays shut, dark and still.
Watching the withered garden transform,
Spring’s wind stirs the ashes in the pitch-pipe."*

Master Xueren Qi says:

*"Warm wind, slanting sun guide the lone staff,
Who pities the stone path sealed by green grass?
Finding home at last, spring has already gone—
Gazing toward Snow Mountain, layers of emerald."*

Master Purong Ping says:

*"Before Mount Luzu, the ancient road runs clear,
A faint path vanishes east and west.
Amid the cuckoo’s cries, spring grows old,
Scattered peach blossoms carpet the earth in red."*

Master Gunan Men says:

*"Mist swirls, rain drizzles on and on,
How many ridges and bridges cross the valley’s stream?
The twelfth-month spring wind still lacks warmth,
Yet beyond the wall, one branch blooms red."*

Master Huanji Ting says:

*"Petals drift one by one, chasing the east wind,
Spring’s radiance lies scattered, a crimson carpet.
Even if gathered up now,
The lingering fragrance still spills over the eastern wall."*

Master Fohui Quan says:

*"Masterless men fill the great Tang realm,
Gorging on wine dregs, yet failing to grasp the essence.
Passing idly by Bamboo Temple, spring deepens,
Falling blossoms dapple the moss in random hues."*

Master Xianyun Bao says:

*"Thunder roars, lightning flashes, unleashing full force,
Just as the hidden dragon lies in deep slumber.
Suddenly waking from a dream, spring’s sorrow breaks—
Dawn’s wind carries rain past the front stream."*

Master Lingyan Chu says:

*"Jade bridle, golden saddle leave the imperial city,
Apricot blossoms drift, willows sway in profusion.
With every crack of the whip, every step in spring’s wind,
Trampling the path of the returned top scholar."*

Master Xueguan Zha says:

*"An expanse of clear sky—yet still a veil,
A thousand waves surge—yet not a true tide.
Grasping both paths, calling them heartless,
Everywhere spring’s wind unfurls willow and peach."*

Master Zuan Jian says:

*"The primal path does not traverse the subtle and profound,
When Dao and peace align, the trigger above is sprung.
Atop the shadowless tree, spring’s light dawns,
The golden rooster crows on the branch that casts no shade."*

Master Boshan Lai says:

*"Not walking the bird’s path, not dwelling in dust,
Drunken eyes caress the white day’s slumber.
Do not say one never errs in meeting others—
Plucking the willow’s bloom marks late spring."*

Master Gaofeng Miao says:

*"Zhaozhou’s dog lacks Buddha-nature,
Yet spring’s full splendor spreads across rivers and lakes.
How many pluck leaves to seek branches,
In vain, leaving the sunlit paths strewn with blossoms."*

Master Yefu Chuan says:

*"The three Buddhas’ forms are never true,
The pupil in the eye is the person before you.
If you can trust the treasure within your home,
The crying birds and mountain flowers share the same spring."*

chunks.translated_text:
Master Wu’an Quan says:
*"Sun warm, wind mild, orioles trill anew,
Willows trail golden threads to bind the Lord of Spring.
The Lord of Spring spares not his selfless power—
Each fleck of crimson blossom, each fleck of spring."*

Master Foyin Yuan says:
*"How could it compare to spring’s wind at ease everywhere,
Flowers blooming, flowers falling—what concern is there?
Even drifting white clouds are too constrained to match,
As they billow, unburdened, filling the world entire."*

Master Baiyun Duan says:
*"Plum blossoms spent, apricot petals unfurl,
Yet spring’s wind cannot help but strip them where it stirs.
Qi, silent, holds all forms within its embrace—
Where do the ten thousand spirits thank its selfless grace?"*

Master Huguo Yuan says:
*"To exhaust the patterns of things is to master one’s home,
To meet the moment’s timing is to know the heart’s own.
How grateful we are to spring’s wind, without favor or slight—
Even the poor man’s peach and plum cast shade in its light."*

Master Fojian Qin says:
*"Though each proof follows the body’s trace,
Departure and stay alike have keepers of their place.
After sandals are worn through and one returns at last,
Falling blossoms and crying birds share the same spring vast."*

Master Meng’an Cong says:
*"Bright, bright the Way—yet none can know,
To whom may this truth its face show?
A gust of spring wind sweeps in,
Scattering petals down the path again."*

Master Tianduo En says:
*"The Five Tombs’ spring grows rich and full,
The wind behind the head blows without end’s pull.
Drunk, I call the wanderer by the river to stay—
The cuckoo’s cry fades where green willows sway."*

Master Yun’an Yan says:
*"Casually lifting the seven-catty robe,
How many Chan seekers strain to probe!
All burrow nests in Qingzhou’s land,
Unknowing spring’s hues grace Jiangnan’s strand."*

Master Baiyan Fu says:
*"Spring mountains’ reflection reddens the river entire,
Orioles and willows, enamored, cling to the steed’s attire.
Do not regret the Immortal’s brush lacks skill—
For you dwell already within the painted hill."*

Master Longmen Yuan says:
*"Willows’ hue like tender gold,
Plum blossoms’ scent like fragrant snow.
If you know spring’s qi and its might,
Every place becomes a splendid sight."*

Master Jingshan Gao says:
*"At Winter Solstice, yang revives,
Heaven and earth share a single thread’s ties.
Pity the countless souls who never see
The face they were born with naturally."*

Master Fojian Qin says:
*"Iron trees bloom with ten thousand flowers,
Stone heads sprout two or three shoots like bowers.
Clay-molded vajras open their mouths to laugh—
Tomorrow, Winter Solstice births yang’s draft."*

Master Haizhou Ci says:
*"Late spring’s red plantain sprouts along the path,
March’s peach blossoms flourish in the garden’s aftermath.
Alas, that men do not know spring’s fragrance,
While in the trees, a hundred tongues sing its cadence."*

Master Tianqi Rui says:
*"Before enduring winter’s depth, do not rejoice too soon,
Let bone-piercing cold seep through the heart’s cocoon.
Suddenly, the dream awakens to spring’s warm embrace—
Ten thousand purples, a thousand reds blanket the earth’s face."*

Master Yunyan Yin says:
*"Curtains stir with spring’s wind, dawn still cold,
Song towers’ voices choke, dreams break like gold.
The golden wheel forsakes the human realm’s domain—
Do not envy the gourd’s sun and moon’s vast plain."*

Master Tian’an Sheng says:
*"How many mistake this body for their own,
Before them, divergent paths resist being overthrown.
Coral glistens in the spring of the Ten Isles’ shore,
Yet none who meet it fathom its depth or more."*

Master Yefu Yuan says:
*"Spring winds ripple waters wave on wave to green,
Autumn rains wash forests leaf by leaf to sheen.
Midnight on the stone bed, pillow in hand, I rest—
For whom does the mountain hermit’s joy attest?"*

Master Lingyan Chu says:
*"Wild waters shimmer in a thousand-cup tide,
From coral branches, the moon hangs far and wide.
The hall’s front pillar lacks a nose to grasp—
Yet it paints spring’s wind into distant brows’ clasp."*

Master Gaofeng Miao says:
*"By the willow-lined stream, green threads descend,
Yellow orioles in the trees trill without end.
How many, lost in play, miss spring’s fleeting trace—
In vain, ten thousand petals fall without embrace."*

Master Xinwen Ben says:
*"Pointing to deep red, it matches the past,
No heavenly splendor lingers in the fragrant mass.
From Nanquan’s brush, spring is swept away—
Only fading crimson remains to intoxicate the bees’ ballet."*

Master Zhengtang Ban says:
*"The jade cave’s primal pass stretches long,
Peaches of Penglai are no common throng.
Hidden, lest the mortal world should see,
Yet spring’s wind may betray its fragrance free."*

Master Gushan Gui says:
*"If you know heaven and earth share one root,
Why return to ask another’s pursuit?
Yet Nanquan’s direct pointing imparts—
Spring blooms in dreams as effortless arts."*

Master Tieji Xin says:
*"Before the cliff, waterfalls rush away,
Behind the hut, piled stones form peaks’ array.
Spring’s intent—where has it gone?
Behold, the earth is strewn with crimson gone."*

Master Cheng Kumu says:
*"Having reached Peach Blossom’s secluded scene,
A flask of bright moon gleams like autumn’s sheen.
Reflecting on the spring’s waning day at the cave’s mouth,
Countless red petals drift upon the stream’s south."*

Master Chanyan Rong says:
*"Beyond Yu’s Gate, three-tiered waves surge,
Dwelling in the clouds, yet knowing not the verge.
Suddenly, a thread of spring wind blows—
Who can tether the flight that soars and flows?"*

Master Bojian Jian says:
*"The highest branches bloom in Shanglin’s grove,
Brushed by clear winds in March’s alcove.
Wind warm, flowers fragrant, spring at its prime,
Courtyard shadows lengthen with the slow-passing time."*

He also says:
*"A stream divides the green mountains’ hue,
Peach blossoms on both banks blush anew.
The ferryman, though asked, does not know—
Silently, they drift with wind and rain to and fro."*

Master Xiaoweng Kan says:
*"A guest in the level fields asks the way,
From a high terrace, a white ox is led astray.
Spring’s light before the eyes is not much to behold—
A pair of mandarin ducks follows the current’s hold."*

Master Falin Yin says:
*"Amid ten thousand greens, a pinch of red,
Boundless spring’s hues flow where they are led.
Bees and butterflies seek in vain—
Blame the dawn wind’s whim in their disdain."*

Master Qingfeng Chu says:
*"The great matter is clear—
Why then mourn like one who’s lost kin?
Without spring’s wind, flowers will not appear,
Yet once they bloom, the wind blows them thin."*

Master Foxing Tai says:
*"By the stream, tender willows, green each thread,
On the paths, peach blossoms, red each spread."*

Plucking the willow’s bloom marks late spring."*

Master Gaofeng Miao says:

*"Zhaozhou’s dog lacks Buddha-nature,
Yet spring’s full splendor spreads across rivers and lakes.
How many pluck leaves to seek branches,
In vain, leaving the sunlit paths strewn with blossoms."*

Master Yefu Chuan says:

*"The three Buddhas’ forms are never true,
The pupil in the eye is the person before you.
If you can trust the treasure within your home,
The crying birds and mountain flowers share the same spring."*

chunks.translated_text:
Do not say the Eastern Lord lacks governance—
Still he adds warm sun and harmonious wind.

Master Zide Hui says:
*"Layer upon layer stripped away, all returns to plainness,
Spring’s warmth, wind’s harmony, days grow long.
Outside the door, birds’ songs in broken whispers,
Rock flowers scattered, filling the mountain chamber."*

Master Zhengjue Yi says:
*"Spring’s warmth, peach blossoms red on every tree,
Lingyun’s ancient words remain the same.
Yuansha’s sayings linger in the groves—
North, south, east, west, the path knows no end."*

Master Huanglong Nan says:
*"The second and third months, scenes soft and mild,
Peach blossoms red near and far on every tree.
Even the masters’ awakening is not yet complete—
To this day, they still laugh in the spring wind."*

Master Fayun Xiu says:
*"When spring rains clear in the second month’s court,
Small peaches bloom, two or three red branches.
Red and white vie in beauty for all to see—
Why then does Lingyun alone not doubt?"*

Master Foguo Bai says:
*"How laughable—the spring wind leaks its secret,
Peach blossoms newly bloom on last year’s branches.
By Luojiang, there’s a fisherman—
He laughs at Lingyun’s unshaken doubt."*

Master Gushan Gui says:
*"The peach blossom seeks the sword-bearing traveler,
Silent, he smiles in the spring wind.
White-haired, he has yet to return—
His home lies east of the sea gate."*

Master Cihang Pu says:
*"Lingyun’s smile at the sight of peach blossoms,
Thirty years passed before he came home.
Since then, after spring’s winds and rains,
His name scatters like petals across the earth."*

Master Shaoshi Mu says:
*"At first sight of peach blossoms, he hides and flees,
Trapped in iron walls, no exit to be found.
How many cling to walls and fences—
Each spring’s arrival breaks another heart."*

Master Falin Yin says:
*"Restlessly seeking willows, his heart unruly,
Trampling peach blossoms, his eyes alone red.
Weary of the garden’s spring now late,
How can he bear the drum’s beat from next door?"*

Master Qingmen Lin says:
*"Every garden blooms in riotous fragrance,
Cuckoos cry, swallows chatter wildly.
A myriad measures of spring’s splendor cannot be contained—
Yet pity the rare poet who meets it."*

Master Furong Kai says:
*"One dharma originally void, ten thousand dharmas empty,
How could this allow awakening to perfect understanding?
One might think Shaolin’s message had ceased—
Yet peach blossoms still laugh in the spring wind."*

Master Changlu Liao says:
*"Jade hidden in Jing Mountain, prized,
A flake of snow in the red furnace—spring.
Returning to the root, wind scatters leaves,
The moonlit pool’s reflection—utterly void."*

Master Fojian Qin says:
*"South of the city, a poor scholar rides a donkey,
North of the market, a young lord rides a horse.
Each with four hooves planted on the earth,
Together in spring, they reach Golden Bright Pond."*

Master Ku Mu Cheng says:
*"Wandering everywhere, north, south, east, west,
Returning late, the moon like a hook.
A gust of spring wind scatters flowers—
Unknowingly, he nods in thought."*

Master Huanji Ting says:
*"Face to face, no one—yet the realm is empty,
Spring’s wind flows warmly everywhere.
Should you see it again as before,
Dare I vow we share life but not death?"*

Master Touzi Qing says:
*"Ancient cliffs, moonlight locked in layers,
Withered trees welcome fragrance, late with spring.
Last night, the Milky Way barred the Southern Dipper,
Golden crow follows phoenix past the wheel of heaven."*

Master Cuiyan Zhen says:
*"Sun scorches, wind lashes—asking whence the ancestor came,
Red dust stretches endlessly, eyes cannot lift.
How many rush and toil—
In deep spring’s second month, earth-shaking thunder."*

Master Fushan Chu says:
*"Grass hall, spring’s warmth, the sun begins to redden,
In the hall, diligent slumber, truly deep.
In dreams, a single sound—heaven and earth grow old,
Fading blossoms again chase the fifth-watch wind."*

Master Baiting Yong says:
*"Wind mild, sun warm, spring at its height,
Willows golden, flowers’ shadows dense.
Entering the old haunts of Peach Blossom Spring,
Each peak locks away another peak."*

Master Zhengtang Bian says:
*"I ask the world—what keeps men so busy?
Better to report spring’s affairs to spring’s light.
Even if drunk before flowers every day,
A season still holds ninety such scenes."*

He also says:
*"Painting true suchness to life,
Unfolding it amid the flowers,
A yellow oriole steals a glance—
Dares not descend from the branch."*

Master Xue’an Jin says:
*"Lost his boat in Dongting Lake,
A barefoot Persian sleeps beneath the waves.
Though all the world calls, he will not wake—
Spring’s wind blows him into Apricot Blossom Village."*

Master Yueting Zhong says:
*"Fallen leaves have followed the flowing water away,
Spring’s wind has not yet released the hundred flowers.
The green mountains’ visage remains as ever—
All day they lie exposed to the fading light."*

Master Tianzi Cui says:
*"In the third month, spring just begins to enjoy peace,
Cuckoos call ceaselessly, summoning the fading light.
Lacking the mood to compose a verse,
He treads the bright moon’s path, singing as he returns."*

Master Danlu Chun says:
*"Spirit soars beyond past, present, and future,
The three realms are but a single point of mind.
Beyond the balustrade, spring’s wind, spring’s butterflies dance,
Before the gate, willows, dawn orioles sing."*

Master Gu Yun Jian says:
*"A single call awakens a thousand autumns’ dreams,
To whom now belongs the boundless scenery?
Lifting his gaze, all is clear—nothing external,
The bright moon still shines on the flowered branches."*

Master Ji Zongche says:
*"Entrusting his feelings to playful bees leaving flowers,
Touching sandalwood, the wind from the precious tree.
Turning to the spring colors in the courtyard,
A pheasant’s cry shatters the vast emptiness."*

Master Cishou Shen says:
*"Eating rice, he bites on grit,
Breaks his third tooth.
After the spring wind passes,
Even his staff blooms."*

Master Qianren Gang says:
*"Amid peonies’ fragrance, the wind sways gracefully,
In pear blossoms’ shadows, the moon is round.
The host, drunk, sleeps on the Emperor Fuxi’s pillow,
Gazing at the red curtains’ inverted reflection."*

Master Huimen Kai says:
*"Wind high, moon cold, the azure sky stretches,
Suddenly the Silver River pours its jade streams.
All at once, everything becomes one hue—
A lake’s waters ripple with a lake’s spring."*

Master Quanjian Xu says:
*"Beholding the same moon, the realm grows profound.
Even Buddhas do not know—who is the true kindred spirit?
Peach blossoms riot in the distant spring wind,
A thousand miles of longing stir the traveler’s heart."*

Master Zifu Guan says:
*"The sky remains vast, the waters clear,
A silver hook suddenly snares the river-crossing man.
Turning back against the current to the village shore,
He finds the path home, his face alight with spring."*

Master Bojian Jian says:
*"At kalpa’s dawn, a patch of idle land—
Only the mud ox and stone maiden can till it.
Before the millet and sorghum bloom bright,
Peach and plum are planted to charm with fragrance."*

He also says:
*"Why do mountain plums so often flourish?
Only because they have endured frost and snow.
Yet the lone rider on his lame donkey stands,
Unknowing of spring’s descent upon the mossy rocks."*

And again:
*"Without the spring wind, flowers do not open;
Once open, they are blown away by the wind.
Scattered petals trampled into mud,
Their lingering fragrance swells in vain."*

Master Zifu Guan says:
*"Spring gardens riot with blossoms like waves,
Butterflies vie in beauty, their scent striking the nose.
As the sun sets behind the thatched eaves and dusk falls,
A frosty moon illuminates the pond."*

Master Xuelun Qi says:
*"A single hair’s turn encompasses Mount Sumeru,
Seized in hand, it brings a smile to the eyes.
Do not say kin are hard to find—
Amid the flames of ice-flowers, spring grows lush."*

Master Sanfeng Cang says:
*"No need for guest and host to meet in kinship,
One who grasps the divine mechanism transcends all dharma.
On a snowy night, plum blossoms usher in spring early,
While the garden’s fragrant herbs remain unaware of renewal."*

Master Gu’an Yue says:
*"Whose peach and plum vie in splendor,
As cuckoos call again and again, beckoning the traveler home?
Once he trod the path by Wuling Stream’s banks—
The grotto’s spring surpasses the mortal world."*

Master Gunan Men says:
*"Each bout of wind and snow brings deeper cold,
Yet when the cold recedes, spring’s warmth expands.
Why labor to repeat what’s already clear?
West of the post station lies Chang’an."*

Master Li’an Ding says:
*"A towering iron staff grinds against the moon,
Enduring frost and snow, its spirit shines brighter.
Suddenly, in the night corridor, it opens a laughing mouth—
By dawn, the earth is steeped in spring."*

Master Hongding Jiao says:
*"Layer upon layer of mist and rain chant the moss,
How does spring’s light arrive from ten thousand miles?
When the partridge calls, the sun warms the clearing,
And the bamboo staff ascends the Terrace of Gazing Home."*

Master Xianghu Ren says:
*"Leisurely he climbs, leaning on the railing,
Gazing at the streams and mountains framed like a painting.
In the immortal garden, spring winds stir pipes and strings,
Amid the throng of songs, the sound of rain grows dense."*

Master Haihui Xing says:
*"To transplant flowers, one loves the fine, misting rain;
To plant willows, one prefers a dim, overcast sky.
Behold the early spring of Shanglin Park—
Flowers cradle pearls of dew, willows veil themselves in mist."*

Master Deshi Xin says:
*"The spring wind brushes wildflowers into crimson,
Their branches high and low, some pale, some deep.
Endless vistas of water and mountain hues—
A single bird’s cry echoes through the empty peaks."*

He also says:
*"To grasp and release is but wasted effort,
Circling thoughts lead nowhere.
Suddenly turning back, spring is late—
At the staff’s tip, a single red orb is won."*

And again:
*"A hidden bird sings in the tall trees,
Fading blossoms drift upon the flowing stream.
Unknowing that spring is late,
The lotus blooms, its fragrance filling the nine continents."*

Master Falin Yin says:
*"Spring reaches the peach blossoms, overflowing the water’s source,
A world apart, its splendor unique.
The fisherman dares not speak of it to others,
Fearing it might stir idle sorrow in his descendants."*

Master Deqing Qi says:
*"All because of the moon over Huaidi,
It illuminates the spring of Yingyang.
A single arrow pierces the layered pass—
His merit high, yet he raises no banner."*

*"A single uncarved lump, the heart of primordial antiquity—

*"The moon over the river, the plum’s sparse shadows sway,

*"For saints and mortals, no separate paths diverge,

The spring wind never reaches Peach Blossom Spring—

Master Tiantong Hua says:
*"The garden’s spring lingers on the branches,

Idly, at dusk, he gazes upon the river—

Master Lan’an Shu says:
*"Watching others ride horses and play polo,

The official road fades as spring reaches its prime—
The plum by the river insists he compose a poem."*

Master Zhe’an Fan says:
*"Honors and favors bind him in a traveler’s dream,
The palace orioles’ calls make him long for home.
When he returns, jade pendants chiming on his steed,

Master Wanshan Ning says:
*"No sign of the pool, no sign of the dragon,
Yet his whole being resides in the Hall of the Empty King.
Awakening from dreams to the dawn orioles’ songs,

Master Touzi Qing says:
*"Clouds darken the eastern crags, western peaks brighten,

The sky’s light is heavy, his robes damp with sleep—

Master Chufang An says:
*"If the favorable wind does not come, spring ages,

A full moon in the sky gifts the traveler,

Master Gushan Gui says:
*"Not retracing the path he came,

Fallen blossoms redden the earth,

Master Qiaozi Yu says:
*"Flowers bloom throughout the garden,
Before the wind, he plays the zither alone.
High mountains and flowing waters—
How many have known such kindred spirits through the ages?"*

Master Shangfang Yi says:
*"Ice melts on the river’s northern bank,
Flowers bloom on the southern branches of the trees."*

"Spring is everywhere—
even at the world’s edge, one returns early."

Master Zhenjing Wen says:
*"On the twenty-fifth day of the twelfth month,
he rides a horse without beating the drum.
Spring winds stir a hundred grasses to life,
new earth mounds the graves."*

Master Shengke Yu says:
*"The Hall of the Empty King is dismantled,
the Lion’s Throne overturned.
In this time of peace, no taboos remain—
everywhere, the fragrance of a hundred flowers."*

Master Huiyin Jing says:
*"Where asked, the answer is clear; where answered, it is new.
Half smiles, half scowls—
Look at the paths in the second and third months:
which tree’s branches do not bear spring?"*

Master Baiyun Duan says:
*"Six ungathered, yet the tune is freshest,
harmony needs no lingering dust.
A breeze fills the balustrade, a thousand trees in bloom—
without a call, heaven and earth know it is spring."*

Master Qingmen Lin says:
*"Spring warms, the wind softens, willow eyes green,
on the branches of the peach, orioles trill.
Before the eyes, a path straight as a lute’s string—
yet travelers refuse to walk it."*

Master Bojian Jian says:
*"Yellow birds flit into the spring woods,
red blooms fill the branches in the late light.
Flowers fall, birds return, spring grows still—
who now walks this quiet path?"*

He also says:
*"Spring turns to Yangzhou, ten thousand trees align,
mist veils tender green, orioles sing.
A traveler stands alone by the clear river,
wasting the slanting sun and western haze."*

Master Shangfang Yi says:
*"The golden vale’s spring light fills the eyes,
peonies on the branches blaze with fragrance.
Last night, a cold western wind blew—
how many fallen blossoms carpet the earth?
The noble scion, drunk, forgets to return,
still clamoring by the railing for a golden cup."*

Master Hansong Cao says:
*"Mist and rosy clouds fill the bamboo hat in the cold dawn,
far steps tread green moss, leaving emerald peaks.
Along the way, pear blossoms quench the horse’s thirst in spring—
riding the bright moon, one arrives in Chang’an by night."*

Master Fachang Yu says:
*"How to distinguish hemp from its skin?
Boil snow to brew tea and sober the drunk.
Beyond the path travelers have not trod,
wildflowers smile on old branches in spring."*

Master Zhenjing Wen says:
*"Great function manifests, affairs unfold—
where does spring not bloom?
Send them to the hall for three meals of inquiry:
the four seas will know we are one family."*

Master Xuedou Xian says:
*"Spring mountains layer in jumbled green,
spring waters ripple in empty blue.
Alone in the vastness of heaven and earth,
I stand gazing—where is the limit?"*

Master Wushi Dao says:
*"Xuedou’s family treasures,
the things he has used all his life—
he flings them all out to everyone.
Here at Wushi, though possessions are few,
you must understand them thoroughly.
Now, what is Wushi’s livelihood?"*

Master Zhuozhu Zhang says:
*"Swallows chatter, orioles sing in the warm spring sun,
everywhere in the gardens, a hundred flowers perfume the air."*

Master Songru Mi says:
*"Water’s gleam, mountain hues—no one around,
who at dawn beholds the first spring?
The red sun rises, strings and pipes stir—
half the lake’s mist is but drifting dust."*

Master Tianyi Huai says:
*"Answering the invitation to Mount Shan,
entering the hall to address the assembly—
for twenty years, I longed for this mountain,
and today, at last, conditions align.
Before I arrived, my body had already reached it;
now that I am here, Mount Shan lies within me."*

Master Cishou Shen says:
*"Shifting step by step, the old heavenly robe,
few care if eyebrows are lost.
If today one understands what happened that day,
in the warmth of Jiangnan, cuckoos cry."*

Master Luohan Nan says:
*"Wind scatters shattered jade—snow on a thousand peaks,
rain drips on cliff flowers—spring in ten thousand lands.
One could listen to the murmuring stream’s flow,
its ceaseless babble unheard all day."*

Master Yuan’an Fen says:
*"The east wind laughs with flowers in spring’s light,
bees and butterflies chase fragrance among the branches.
A cuckoo’s cry darkens the hanging greenery—
how long is the road home?"*

Master Huaiqing Hai says:
*"From the other shore, messages rarely reach,
even when they do, merit still lags.
If you trust the moment when one line transforms,
spring winds will coil on every budding branch."*

Master Nanjian Wen says:
*"Once I washed my ears by the green stream,
a thousand valleys, ten thousand cliffs—paths twist and deepen.
Most wondrous on moonlit, windless nights:
a long whistle echoes through the autumn sea-gate."*

Master Dahong Sui says:
*"You asked with your own mouth for the path to clarity,
a true adept points directly through the murk.
Suddenly, eyes and ears awaken from spring’s dream—
orioles sing, swallows chatter, all is perfectly understood."*

Master Baoyong Ning says:
*"The ancestral intent from the west knows no east or west,
as apes and birds cry in the deep spring woods.
How many travelers gaze in vain—
green mountains stand tall, white clouds hang low."*

Master Su’an Ding says:
*"Summer’s red lotuses sway on the jade-green pond,
fish dart up and down in busy play.
Fragrance rises from both banks, drunken on the warm breeze,
washing body and mind in the water kingdom’s perfume."*

Master Meng’an [ ] says:
*"Rising early to cherish the flowers, sitting in the spring wind,
another has already played with red and green.
Hand in hand, drunk beneath the blossoms,
unaware of the layered shadows of clouds and moon."*

Master Hengchuan Gong says:
*"Why must we join hands to raise one?
Just call the novice over.
The iron pot has no feet, no ears—
beneath the wall, spring deepens, leaves unfurl."*

Master Donggu Guang says:
*"Three by three, two by two, none the same,
hand in hand, walking into the grass.
Turning back, slipping on embroidered shoes—
why not drum up spring in the twelfth month?"*

Master Yongjue Xian says:
*"Turn the pivot at the center—another mechanism,
a side path few have known.
Ancient halls, clouds deep, no footprints—
spring winds, growing grasses cross the former stream."*

Master Tudu Ce says:
*"The nature of mind has always been one,
through being and non-being, emptiness reveals true emptiness."*

From ancient times to now, those lost beyond delusion at the source—
spring enters the garden groves, red in every place.”

Master Yunzhang Han says:
*“Bright, bright the message reveals the whole mechanism,
a thousand-yard Chan radiance shines behind the skull.
Whether this or that, both are lifted away—
in Jiangnan’s third month, the partridge cries.”*

Master Kuimu Cheng says:
*“Spring winds stir, green waves sway,
countless boatmen chase the sea tides.
They see only gulls skimming white waves—
how would they know the bright moon dwells in the cloudy sky?”*

Master Zide Hui says:
*“The buddhas of the three times swallow all in one mouth,
the old mountain deep and still, moon at dusk.
Light splits the crown, the noon gate dawns—
sitting, I watch spring return to the burn scars.”*

Master Minshan Wei says:
*“Spring without feet wanders everywhere,
peach and plum year after year ferment in the valley.
Why is spring earlier in the eastern garden?
A single branch in the snow unfurls fragrant wind.”*

Master Foyan Yuan says:
*“In spring days, among spring mountains,
spring affairs are all spring.
Spring light illumines spring waters,
spring qi congeals into spring clouds.
Spring guests stir with spring feelings,
spring poems renew in spring.
Only those who know spring—
through ten thousand kalpas, the one primordial spring.”*

He also says:
*“Whether you exit or not, from the start it does not depart from samādhi.
Sages arise with worldly passions,
ordinary people become sages.
Inverting use and seizing crosswise,
supporting the crooked and revealing the straight—
spring rain, spring wind, bamboo door cool,
falling blossoms, crying birds, a thousand peaks still.”*

Master Zhenjing Wen says:
*“Moving against or with, all is verdant spring,
whether right or wrong, the spirit does not stir.
Too often we turn with sounds and sights—
turning back, we obscure the original person.”*

He also says:
*“When qi first harmonizes, the ten thousand things spring,
no need for effort, how could it strain the spirit?
Not words, not phrases, not script—
joyous, at the moment, there is a host.”*

He also says:
*“Yunmen, Linji—spring of a hundred blossoms,
each and every numinous mechanism has its spirit.
In the end, it has nothing to do with language—
misunderstood transmission misleads others.”*

He also says:
*“Awakened, nothing is not spring,
in thorny thickets, one nurtures the spirit.
Whether constant or inconstant, emptiness faces fullness—
at the moment of opportunity, all depends on the person.”*

Master Haihui Xing says:
*“Clouds lock the green cliffs, blossoms fill the stream,
travelers come here, yet the path remains lost.
A single cry of a bird from the hidden valley—
just when immortals face each other at chess.”*

He also says:
*“In the Peach Blossom Spring, divining a secluded dwelling,
chickens, dogs, mulberry, hemp—joy in abundance.
Gathering yellow essence and white atractylodes,
all at once stored in the medicine gourd.”*

Master Nantang Xing says:
*“Exhausting form, withered bones—unaware of spring,
grasping meaning, forgetting words, one transcends the dust.
No need for wombs, no borrowing—
the golden crow emerges from the sea, the moon parts from the clouds.”*

The above venerable Chan masters, singing the beauty of spring’s harmony, are all eulogies of ancient works. Gathered here, they form a jade forest of jasper trees, a magnificent sight. Though much within holds profound meaning, beginners may not easily fathom it. Yet even a single recitation stirs the vastness of spring’s qi, the grace of spring’s light, the gentle breath of spring’s wind, boundless spring’s intent—unexpectedly aligning with the profound Dao. This too is wondrous.

When the mind is still and breath harmonized, water and fire merge as one. Entering the garden of radiant spring, continuing the melody of spring’s harmony, one naturally grasps its subtleties, personally savoring samādhi—beyond what brush and ink can fully express.

**61. The Benefits of Emptiness and Stillness**

The Dao enters through emptiness and stillness, and is realized through emptiness and stillness. Emptiness means an empty mind; stillness means tranquil qi—this is the profound essential of cultivating both nature and life. If the mind is not empty, qi is not still; if qi is not still, breath is not harmonized; if breath is not harmonized, spirit does not congeal. Only when both spirit and qi are still, reaching great samādhi and returning to emptiness and nothingness, does one attain the true purport of “returning to the root and recovering life.” Thus the ancient sage said: *“Attain utmost emptiness, guard deep stillness—
the ten thousand things arise together,
and I observe their return.
Things flourish abundantly,
each returning to its root.
Returning to the root is called stillness;
stillness is called recovering life.
Recovering life is called constancy.”*

Master Qianxu writes in *Xuanlan*:
*“The Dao is fundamentally empty, still, and unified. When stillness reaches its extreme, it moves. Wandering qi stirs in profusion, giving rise to the ten thousand distinct beings, and the Dao begins to fall into the realm of later heaven’s names and forms. Thus, those who embody the Dao originally return to the beginning, taking the attainment of emptiness and guarding stillness as their foundation. Constantly observing within purity and stillness, not a single thing clings—how empty and still! With the slightest thing, emptiness is filled and stillness disturbed. The great void, vast and open—yet a single cloud drifts and obstructs its clarity. The deep spring, limpid and still—yet a slight breeze rises and stirs its waves. How can one restore its original essence? Those who embody the Dao must constantly discipline this mind: what is within does not go out, what is without does not enter. Thus, the breast is clear and unburdened, not a speck of dust clings. In this way, one restores the original sky-like, deep, and limpid essence—this may be called attaining utmost emptiness. Who but those who guard deep stillness can achieve this?”*

He also says:
*“Thus, returning to the root is the Dao’s movement reaching its extreme and becoming still. Therefore, beings follow the mechanism to enter—hence, returning to the root is called stillness. Stillness then returns to no-thing, thereby restoring creation—hence, stillness is called recovering life. Recovering life is the Dao of true constancy—hence, it is called constancy.”*

He also says:
*“Those who know constancy are constantly empty, constantly still. Empty, they can receive; still, they can bear.”*

I say: Emptiness is the image of Qian; stillness is the image of Kun. Being empty and still, one embodies the virtue of Qian and Kun. My body and mind merge into the great transformation of Qian and Kun—only then can one assist in the nurturing of creation.

Master Shao says: *“The sage shares the same body as the Great Void and the same function as Heaven and Earth.”* This is precisely the case. The great person harmonizes their virtue with Heaven and Earth—how could one achieve such harmony without the emptiness and stillness of body and mind?

The *Zhuangzi*’s “Heavenly Dao” chapter states: *“The sage’s stillness is not because stillness is inherently good, but because nothing in the myriad things can disturb their mind—hence, they are still. When water is still, it clearly reflects the beard and brows, and its level surface serves as a standard for the great craftsman. If still water is so luminous, how much more so the spirit! The sage’s mind is still—it is the mirror of Heaven and Earth, the reflection of the ten thousand things. Emptiness, stillness, tranquility, and non-action are the equilibrium of Heaven and Earth and the perfection of the Dao and virtue. Thus, emperors, kings, and sages rest in them. Resting in them is emptiness; emptiness becomes fullness, and fullness is order. Emptiness is stillness; stillness moves, and movement attains. Stillness is non-action; through non-action, those who handle affairs bear responsibility. Through non-action, one attains serenity; serenity means cares and troubles cannot abide, and longevity is achieved. Emptiness, stillness, tranquility, and non-action are the root of the ten thousand things. Understanding this and facing south, one becomes a ruler like Yao; understanding this and facing north, one becomes a minister like Shun. Practicing this in a high position, it is the virtue of emperors, kings, and the Son of Heaven; practicing this in a low position, it is the Way of the profound sage and the uncrowned king. Retiring with this and wandering in leisure, it is embraced by recluses of rivers, seas, mountains, and forests; advancing with this to support the world, it brings great merit, illustrious fame, and the unity of all under Heaven.”*

He also says: *“Using emptiness and stillness to ride the waves and assist Heaven and Earth, penetrating the ten thousand things—this is called heavenly joy.”*

The *Carving Intentions* chapter states: *“Emptiness and tranquility accord with the virtue of Heaven.”* *“Unchanging oneness is the perfection of stillness; nothing opposing it is the perfection of emptiness; no interaction with things is the perfection of tranquility; nothing resisting it is the perfection of purity. Thus it is said: Pure and unadulterated, still and unchanging, tranquil and non-active, moving in accordance with Heaven’s course—this is the Way of nurturing the spirit.”*

The *Human World* chapter states: *“Only the Dao gathers in emptiness. Emptiness is the fasting of the mind.”*

The *Liezi* says: *“Nothing surpasses stillness; nothing surpasses emptiness. Stillness and emptiness—these attain their proper place.”*

I observe: What the *Zhuangzi* and *Liezi* expound fully inherits the intent of the ancient sages’ *“attaining emptiness and guarding stillness.”* This is the orthodox lineage of the profound tradition, the bridge to returning to the root and recovering life, the essential element of reversion.

Speaking of practice, it lies solely in the interdependence of the body’s breath and the mind’s rest, thereby attaining great samadhi. The essentials of emptiness and stillness were revealed by the *Laozi*, *Zhuangzi*, and *Liezi*, and later generations of true immortals inherited and expounded upon them.

Master Ziyang’s *Four Hundred Words* states: *“Emptiness gives birth to white snow; stillness sprouts the yellow sprout.”*

Li Daochun’s *Song of Refining Emptiness* says: *“In learning immortality, emptiness and stillness are the essence of the elixir.”* He also says: *“Emptiness reaches its extreme, and primordial qi congeals; stillness reaches its depth, and yang returns.”* And: *“Gathering lead relies on emptiness and non-action; advancing the fire uses emptiness as the bellows. All reduction and augmentation depend on emptiness; shattering emptiness itself achieves great awakening.”*

Master Boyang’s *Triple Concordance* states: *“Inwardly nurture the self with tranquility and emptiness.”*

Master Qianxu’s *Examination and Commentary on the Triple Concordance* says: *“Tranquility and emptiness—these four words are the essential secret of nurturing the self. A thousand sages and ten thousand perfected ones share this single principle. The *Laozi* says: ‘Attain the extreme of emptiness; guard stillness firmly. The ten thousand things arise together, and I observe their return.’ Master Sima’s *On Sitting in Forgetfulness* states: ‘When the mind is at peace and empty, the Dao naturally comes to reside.’ Man is born still—this is Heaven’s nature. Moved by things, it becomes desire. Once there is desire, the ears are seduced by sounds, the eyes seized by colors, and the mouth spoiled by flavors. The true nature is lost, and primordial essence and primordial qi are thereby depleted, and one’s life follows. Thus, nurturing the self takes tranquility and emptiness as its foundation. Tranquility and emptiness mean: Do not labor your form, do not agitate your essence. Not a single thought arises, and the ten thousand conditions are all empty. The mind is like the Great Void, not clinging to a single thing. Master Xu Jing said: ‘To keep the spirit within the mind from departing, do not allow a single thing to remain in the numinous terrace. If things reside in the mind, the spirit is not clear, and true essence is dissipated, harming the sinews and bones.’ If scholars can thoroughly investigate the original state and turn their light inward to illuminate it, they will know that within clarity and stillness, not a single thing exists—and that so-called tranquility and emptiness are attained within oneself.”*

Floating Hill Immortal Ancestor says: *“Resolving to return primordial essence to qi is the beginning; in the midst of emptiness and stillness, one obtains the cloud ladder.”*

Ancestor Lü says: *“Primordial qi is the true mystery; within the mystery lies the mysterious mechanism, which requires stillness and focus.”* He also says: *“Each explores the mysterious mechanism within stillness; in stillness’s subtlety, one attains the profound and wondrous.”*

The secret says: The initial practice of the profound tradition is to concentrate the spirit in emptiness—this is the essential meaning of an empty mind. When breath harmonizes with the mind, it is the true secret of still qi. When breath is regulated and the mind is concentrated, one attains great samadhi. Body and mind become profoundly still, unchanging and unmoving, utterly like the Great Void—thus, the principle of attaining emptiness and guarding stillness is realized.

Floating Hill Ancestor says: *“Wisdom arises from samadhi; samadhi is attained through stillness. The true meaning of stillness is difficult to fathom. Testing within emptiness, stillness is not samadhi. Movement captures the numinous mechanism; clinging is not the profound. The stillness within the profound—its subtlety is hard to express.”*

As a mirror facing objects reveals their forms—
know that the mirror itself holds no such forms.
How then do forms appear?
Seek forms apart from the mirror, and they vanish;
move the mirror to reflect, and forms reappear.
This mirror or that mirror—do they show two forms?
This form or that form—none abide as form.
In the stillness of the profound, contemplate thus.

As a river’s limpid pool reflects the moon—
before the moon ascends, the deep holds no moon;
when the moon hangs aloft, water and sky share one moon.
The moon in water, the moon in sky—are there two moons?
Scoop water to seize the moon, and it is gone;
shift the river to view the moon, and it remains the same.
Know that every river holds no moon of its own.
In the stillness of the profound, contemplate thus.

As plum blossoms at the valley’s mouth unfurl their canopies toward the sun—
while still in bud, they already harbor the yang mechanism.
Were it not for the biting cold, qi would not congeal and quicken.
Even with the return of early yang, without a foundation, it would dissipate or vanish,
ebbing and flowing in accord with creation’s rhythm.
The path into stillness, the profound’s hidden realm.

As a lotus rises from water, standing tall to bear the dew—
a single round pearl congeals at the flower’s heart.
Crush it, and it shatters into countless pearls.
When dew first scatters, each drop becomes a pearl.
Who would know that, when split, every drop forms a pearl?
When the lotus first blooms, it holds within yet does not unfurl;
when the lotus leaves scatter, they do not cling to the pistils.
Only by not clinging does the numinous manifest as pearls.
The wondrous aspect of stillness, the profound’s essential pivot.
Words struggle to convey it—here, a glimpse of heaven’s mechanism is revealed.

This chapter expounds the profound tradition’s principle of emptiness and stillness, its subtlety beyond compare. Know that the stillness of the profound tradition is the stillness of both body and mind—unattached and vast, roundly illuminating and thoroughly penetrating, like the light of a mirror or the moon in water. When both are still, not even the finest dust arises; when both illuminate, one enters layer upon layer. Like the lotus bearing dew, each drop forms a pearl—separation and union are unobstructed. Only by not clinging or abiding does this wondrous aspect appear. The profound tradition does not depart from emptiness and stillness, nor does it dwell in the subtlety of emptiness and stillness—it is thus, and this is called the Great Profound.

The principle of emptiness and stillness in Buddhism is known as *śamatha*. The *Sutra of Perfect Enlightenment* states: “If all bodhisattvas awaken to pure perfect enlightenment, and with a still, awakened mind take stillness as their practice, by clarifying all thoughts, they recognize the disturbance of discriminating consciousness. Still wisdom arises, and the adventitious dust of body and mind is forever extinguished. Thereupon, inner tranquility and light ease emerge. Through this tranquility, the hearts of all tathāgatas in the ten directions manifest within, like images in a mirror. This expedient means is called *śamatha*.” It further states: “If all bodhisattvas take only supreme stillness, by the power of stillness they forever sever afflictions and ultimately attain accomplishment. Without rising from their seats, they enter nirvana. Such bodhisattvas are called those who cultivate *śamatha* alone.” The *Avataṃsaka Sutra’s* “Chapter on the Ten Samādhis” states: “Abiding in *śamatha*, most tranquil, ever dwelling in the one mark—namely, the markless.”

The stillness of the profound tradition is precisely entered through *śamatha*, transcending a single gate to emerge upon the adorned path, sharing the same enjoyment as all buddhas and bodhisattvas. Layman Pang said: “In stillness, one sees the true suchness of nature.” The *Classic of the Unseen* states: “The Dao of nature is still,” and “Supreme stillness is the essence of integrity.” *Zhuangzi* says: “Rectitude leads to stillness; stillness arises from clarity; clarity leads to non-action, yet nothing is left undone.” Thus, both immortals and buddhas cultivate through emptiness and stillness to return to their original nature, aligning with the true and constant Dao.

62. The Purity of the Infant

Laozi said: “Carrying your *po* and embracing the One—can you never part from it? Concentrating qi to attain suppleness—can you be like an infant?” This teaches one to unite mind and breath, harmonizing qi and breath, sleeping without sound, just like an infant. He further said: “The multitude bustle about, as if feasting at a great sacrifice, as if ascending a spring terrace. I alone remain tranquil, showing no sign, like an infant who has not yet learned to smile.” And again: “One whose virtue is profoundly accumulated is like a newborn babe. Poisonous insects do not sting it, fierce beasts do not seize it, birds of prey do not strike it. Its bones are weak, its sinews soft, yet its grip is firm. It does not know the union of male and female, yet its organ stirs—this is the perfection of essence. It cries all day without its throat becoming hoarse—this is the perfection of harmony.”

Laozi repeatedly teaches one to emulate the infant, for it holds a profound meaning. First, the infant has no cunning mind, free from distinctions of right and wrong, high and low, great and small. Second, the infant is supple and soft—Laozi’s words: “In human life, one is soft and weak; in death, one is stiff and strong. The soft and weak are companions of life; the stiff and strong are companions of death.” Third, the infant does not contend—Laozi said: “The Dao of the sage is to act without contending,” and “Because they do not contend, none in the world can contend with them.” The virtue of non-contention is emphasized three times in the *Five Thousand Words*. Fourth, the infant has no lustful desires, seeing form yet not as form, pure and serene. Fifth, the infant embraces the One, guarding only spirit and qi, harmonizing mind and breath, sleeping at night without sound, able to resonate with heaven and earth’s true yang. Those who study the Dao should be like this. Sixth, the infant has no sense of self or others, no clinging mind, muddled and unaware, forgetting things and cares, knowing only to eat when hungry and sleep when tired. Those who embody the Dao must be thus. Therefore, the virtues of the infant are held up for emulation.

Master Qianxu’s *Profound Insight into Laozi* states: “The ancients who cultivated the self concealed and accumulated virtue, deep and unexposed, thus they were often compared to newborn babes.”

The sutra states: *"Carrying the soul and embracing the One."* Profit and harm do not intrude, thus venomous insects do not sting, fierce beasts do not seize, and predatory birds do not strike. Since the mind harbors no scheming, external things do not respond with scheming intent. Moreover, though bones are weak and sinews soft, the grip remains firm—why? Because the essence is perfect. When essence is whole, qi naturally concentrates, thus the grip is firm, and the mechanism operates in due time, without command yet spontaneously. Though crying all day, the throat does not grow hoarse—why? Because harmony is perfect. When qi is harmonious, the voice remains rounded. Yet know this: the harmony of qi arises from the spirit remaining unharmed. Excessive joy, fear, sorrow, or anger—if one cries thus, the spirit and qi are both injured before the day is done. When essence and harmony converge, this is the virtue of the infant. Those who embody profound virtue are likewise. Therefore, constantly embrace the primordial and guard the One, concentrate qi to utmost softness, so that one’s harmonious qi flows in communion with heaven and earth. Then the root of nature remains whole, the stem of life secure, and the unchanging Dao of true constancy resides within.

*The Precious Mirror Samādhi of the Cave School* states: *"Like a worldly infant, the five aspects complete. Neither going nor coming, neither arising nor abiding. Gentle and harmonious, with phrases yet without phrases."*

Master Yuanwu said: *"Whether form or fragrance, all is penetrated at once—only then is it called the realm of no-mind. Cultivate until resembling an infant: pure harmony and tranquil simplicity. Though amidst worldly toil, worldly dust does not stain. Though dwelling in serene wonder, serenity cannot hold one back. In movement and action, all is effortlessly free. Roots, dust, birth, death—realm and wisdom are empty and wondrous. Like hot water melting snow, one always knows the time, without excess—this is the person of no-mind."*

After the *Sage Conduct* and *Brahmā Conduct* chapters in the *Mahāparinirvāṇa Sūtra*, the *Infant Conduct Chapter* follows, stating: *"Good son, why is it called infant conduct? The good son cannot arise, abide, come, go, or speak—this is infant conduct. The Tathāgata is likewise: ‘Cannot arise’ means the Tathāgata never arises in the marks of dharmas. ‘Cannot abide’ means the Tathāgata does not cling to any dharmas. ‘Cannot come’ means the Tathāgata’s bodily actions are without movement. ‘Cannot go’ means the Tathāgata has reached great nirvāṇa. ‘Cannot speak’ means though the Tathāgata expounds dharmas for all beings, in truth nothing is said. Further, the infant does not know suffering or joy, day or night, father or mother. The bodhisattva mahāsattva is likewise: for the sake of beings, they do not perceive suffering or joy, have no marks of day or night, and toward all beings, their mind is equal—thus they have no marks of father, mother, intimacy, or estrangement, serving as an analogy for the Tathāgata’s conduct. Further, the infant cannot undertake great or small affairs; the bodhisattva mahāsattva is likewise, no longer creating karmic actions in saṃsāra—this is called ‘not creating.’"* The sutra extensively illustrates the marks of infant conduct to analogize the Tathāgata’s conduct, perfectly aligning with the Lao Sage’s principle of returning to the infant.

The Mystic School’s teaching of reverting to the child’s body is precisely the practice of returning to the infant. After seven days passing the great kalpa of heaven, the roots of lust, the mind of lust, and the mechanism of lust are all uprooted, restoring primordial purity—thus attaining the Dao becomes effortless. The *Śūraṅgama Sūtra*’s ten abodes include the *Abode of Primordial Purity*. Mañjuśrī, the teacher of seven buddhas, is uniquely called the *Bodhisattva Youth*—this too shares the same principle.

*The Meaning of Mahāyāna* states: *"Infant conduct has two types. Regarding self-benefit, it is named by analogy: conduct free from discrimination, like an infant who accomplishes nothing—this is infant conduct. Regarding benefiting others, it is named for those being transformed: as the sutra says, ordinary beings, śrāvakas, and beginning bodhisattvas resemble infants; transforming these infants is called infant conduct."*

Both the immortal and buddha traditions use the infant to illustrate the cultivator’s practice. However, the *Nirvāṇa Sūtra* shows the marks but not the practice. The Lao Sage not only demonstrates returning to the infant but also reveals the principle of concentrating qi to softness and embracing the One without departure—comprehension, understanding, practice, and realization are all complete. Truly, this is the guiding principle of profound cultivation and the precious raft for transcending birth and death.

---

**Sixty-Three: The Virtue of Primal Chaos**

Primal chaos is the state before yin and yang separate, before black and white divide—a realm of seamless indistinction, where function is forgotten in wondrous perfection. In the Dao, it is the *Great Mystery*, the *Ultimateless*, the *Chaotic Darkness*, the *Prior to the Emperor of Images*. In Buddhism, it is *Before the Sound of Might*; in Confucianism, the *Great Ease*. According to Dongshan’s five ranks of merit, it is the *Merit of Merit*; in the five ranks of correct and partial, it is the *Position of Simultaneous Middle Arrival*. Principle and phenomena merge without trace—this is the ultimate of the Dao.

Thus Dongshan said: *"Seamless, with no need for concealment—beyond this, nothing to seek."* Caoshan said: *"Seamless, without inside or outside, harmonious and level above and below."* And again: *"Seamless, concealing principle and phenomena—its signs are utterly obscure. Before the King of Might’s sound, how could Maitreya awaken?"* Dongshan’s verse states: *"Simultaneous Middle Arrival—who dares harmonize without falling into being or non-being? Everyone wishes to escape the common stream, yet in the end, they fold back and sit in the ashes."*

Master Lu’s verse says: *"Simultaneous Middle Arrival—the tongueless child truly knows the Dao. Where to brush away dust to meet the source? Letting go and returning, the path regains its wonder."*

Hongzhi said: *"Simultaneous Middle Arrival—the Dipper’s handle slants, the sky not yet dawn. The crane’s dream awakens to dew on leaves, cold; from the old nest, it flies into the clouds and pines."*

Among Dongshan’s Five Positions, this alone is the most supreme and most profound. This position leaves no trace to follow, no image to liken. Neither bright nor dark, neither form nor emptiness, neither upright nor biased—both merit and position are concealed, both phenomena and principle wholly dissolved. It is precisely the state Zhuangzi called *"returning to the One without trace."*

Jiu Feng Yu says: *"Though dust holds arts of concealment, how can they compare to entering the imperial realm with one’s whole being?"*

The Old Sage said: *"I alone drift, unmarked; vast, unending."* This is the primal chaos of this position—both Chan and Daoist mysteries esteem it as the ultimate attainment of the Way.

Let us further verify this in the alchemical classics. Zi Yang’s *Four Hundred Characters* states: *"Chaos embraces emptiness; emptiness encompasses the Three Realms."* Master Qianxu says: *"The Three Realms are the Realm of Desire, the Realm of Form, and the Formless Realm. Daily they bored one aperture, and after seven days, Chaos died."

The *Inner Chapters* of the *Zhuangzi* conclude with this passage, its purport profound indeed. That Chaos died after seven days signifies that Chaos represents the primordial, boundless state prior to Heaven, beyond the divisions of heart, intent, and discriminating consciousness. When the six roots become active and the six senses scatter, one falls into the posterior realm of perception and knowledge—no longer the *Book of Changes*’ image of "using the nine, beholding the flock of dragons without a head."

Moreover, Shu and Hu are the heart and the breath. When heart and breath unite, one attains great stillness. With stillness prolonged, inner and outer merge and are forgotten, roots and dust both extinguished—this is Chaos. Concealing heart and breath within Chaos is the esoteric teaching of the Mysterious School, the art of returning to the root and restoring the mandate.

The *Song of Dongshan* says:
*"No sooner do horns appear than they are unbearable—
To seek the Buddha with the mind brings only shame.
Through endless kalpas, none have known,
Who would inquire of the fifty-three in the south?"*

The moment horns appear is when the flock of dragons has a head, when roots and dust arise. The endless kalpas are precisely the primordial, boundless Chaos, the vast primeval mist—timeless, beginningless, without measure or duration. This is the image of "the flock of dragons without a head" in the *Book of Changes*, the wondrous proof of Laozi’s return to the boundless.

The esoteric alchemical arts of the Mysterious School are compiled in the *Triplex Unity*. The *Unity* states:
*"Chaos intertwines and binds,
The first sprouts plant the root’s foundation."*

This speaks of the union of yin and yang, entering into Chaos. Chaos is the source that generates Heaven, Earth, and humanity, and the foundation of the elixir is planted therein. As Ancestor Lü said: *"Who knows the true secret hidden in Chaos?"*

The *Unity* further states:
*"The sage measures and orders the primal foundation.
The four (that is, Qian, Kun, Kan, Li—twofold Heaven and Earth, fourfold yin and yang) merge into Chaos,
Directly entering the void."*

This describes the fusion of prior and posterior Heaven, the return to the homeland of Chaos, the coagulation in the valley of the void. This Chaos and void are the primal foundation—the mechanism of the Mysterious Female.

The *Unity* also says:
*"Between dark and new moon, the tally aligns at the center.
Chaos and vast obscurity—
The female and male follow one another.
Nourishing fluids moisten and enrich,
Bestowing transformation and flowing through.
The numinous brightness of Heaven and Earth
Cannot be fathomed.
Use it to secure the body,
Conceal the form and hide."*

This speaks of Chaos and vast obscurity as the moment when sun and moon conjoin. The sage secures the body therein, washing the heart and retiring into secrecy—like the antelope hanging its horns, leaving no trace. All the spirits of Heaven and Earth cannot plumb its depths; it is most wondrous. This is the pivot of elixir-making, the great furnace of immortal transformation.

The above briefly cites the alchemical classics and Chan texts of the Mysterious and Zen schools to expound the profundities of Chaos. From the formation of the elixir to the shedding of the embryo, there is no moment, no instant, that is not within Chaos. If scholars can embody and diligently practice this, the Way of return is more than half understood.

The Profundities of the Double Mystery

Laozi’s *Dao De Jing* says:
*"Nameless, it is the beginning of Heaven and Earth;
Named, it is the mother of the myriad things.
Thus, constantly without desire, observe its mystery;
Constantly with desire, observe its manifestations.
These two emerge together yet differ in name,
Together called the Mystery.
Mystery upon mystery—
The gateway of the manifold wonders."*

The "without" is the Dharma-realm of principle; the "with" is the Dharma-realm of phenomena. Through the without, observe the with (the wondrous existent); through the with, observe the without (true emptiness). When with and without interpenetrate, this is the Dharma-realm of unimpeded principle and phenomena—encompassing the four Dharma-realms of the *Avataṃsaka*, in accord with the *Heart Sutra*’s principle of non-duality of form and emptiness, having already entered the gateway of Mahāyāna prajñā.

"Mystery upon mystery" reveals the realm of the Double Mystery. Like a thousand lamps in a single chamber, light and shadow layer upon layer, intermingling and interpenetrating, pervading and containing all—matching the *Avataṃsaka* school’s Indra’s Net realm, which is the Dharma-realm of unimpeded phenomena.

This gateway of the Double Mystery contains the one within the infinite, and the infinite again within the one. The Old Sage merely named it, without disclosing its meaning. If interpreted through the *Avataṃsaka* school’s Ten Profound Principles, the wondrous truth becomes self-evident.

The Ten Profound Principles are:
1. The Gate of Simultaneous and Complete Correspondence;
2. The Gate of Unimpeded Freedom in Vastness and Narrowness;
3. The Gate of Mutual Containment of the One and the Many;
4. The Gate of Unimpeded Identity of All Dharmas;
5. The Gate of Secret and Manifest Co-actualization;
6. The Gate of Subtle Containment and Bliss;
7. The Gate of Indra’s Net Realm;
8. The Gate of Displaying Dharmas through Phenomena to Generate Understanding;
9. The Gate of the Ten Times Interpenetrating Different Dharmas;
10. The Gate of the Principal and Companions Perfectly Illuminating All Virtues.

As expounded in the *Avataṃsaka Suspension of Doubts*, taking the Indra’s Net realm as an example, the *Flower Garland Sutra*’s verse says:
*"All the dusts in the Flower Treasury world—
In each and every dust, the Dharma-realm is seen."*

Master Qingliang’s commentary states:
*"In each and every mote of dust, the boundless realms of lands appear;
Within those lands of realms, motes of dust again arise.
Within those dusts, realms of lands once more appear—
Layer upon layer, inexhaustible, beyond the reach of thought and cognition.
Like the pearl-net in the palace of the Heavenly Emperor,
Within a single bright pearl, all images are reflected;
Each pearl is thus, luminous and clear,
Mutually reflecting shadows, shadows reflecting shadows—endlessly.
Like mirrors and lamps, light intermingling layer upon layer,
Buddha upon Buddha, infinite."*

By this standard, the Old Sage’s gateway of the Double Mystery contains wonders within apertures and apertures within wonders. Within these apertures and wonders, each again contains wonders and apertures—layer upon layer, boundless, the mysteries unfathomable.

Thus is it called the gateway of all wonders.

The *Book of Documents* speaks of "layered radiance, layered splendor,"
which shares the same meaning as the Old Sage’s gateway of the Double Mystery.
Yet Confucianism and Daoism merely name it,
while the *Avataṃsaka Sūtra* of the Buddha’s tradition
fully reveals its realm—
there is, indeed, a difference in depth and detail.

Over two thousand years, over a hundred scholars have annotated the *Laozi*,
but those who could expound the wonder of the Double Mystery
and use it to illuminate the boundless pearl-net of the *Avataṃsaka*’s Dharmadhātu—
such minds are as rare as morning stars.
Truly, the difficulty of true insight is evident.

The *Commentary on the Laozi* by Heshang Gong, though spuriously attributed,
at least hints at the gateway of the Double Mystery.
His annotation reads:
*"Mystery (xuan) is Heaven.
Mystery upon mystery (xuan zhi you xuan) means Heaven within Heaven."*
The Song-dynasty Chan master Yongming Yanshou,
in his *Record of the Source-Mirror*,
cited this passage to reveal the wonder of the *Daodejing*.
Yet how lamentable that the Qingliang Chengguan National Preceptor,
in his *Profound Discourse on the Avataṃsaka*,
vehemently disparaged the teachings of Laozi,
equating them with the views of ordinary outsiders,
and failed to recognize this saying of "Heaven within Heaven"
as proof of the *Avataṃsaka*’s boundless pearl-net of wonders.
Does this not contradict the intent of the Third Patriarch Xincan’s teaching:
*"Harmonizing the mind in equality,
all dharmas viewed as one,
non-duality all-inclusive,
nothing left unembraced?"*
