119. Knowing the White and Guarding the Black
The Old Sage said: “Know the white, guard the black—this is the model for the world. As the model for the world, constant virtue does not err, returning to the boundless.” The *Cantong Qi* states: “Know the white, guard the black, and the numinous brightness will come of itself. The white is the essence of metal; the black is the foundation of water. Water is the ultimate of the Dao, its number named One.” Lu Xixing said: “The so-called numinous brightness is the power of spirit. The white is the essence of metal, which is the qi of metal. Among the five phases’ qi, metal can generate water. Yet in the creation of the returned elixir, the primordial white metal is born within the water of Kan. Thus, those who refine the elixir must empty the heart and humble the self, reverently seeking lead from Kan. When the time arrives and the mechanism moves, the numinous brightness will come of itself—then ‘suddenly, in the dead of night, a single thunderclap opens ten thousand doors in sequence,’ and the wondrous interplay of mutual necessity appears.” Master Hanxu said: “The white is the essence of metal; the black is the foundation of water.”

The metal essence arises when yang, the male, sows its seed within the female and is born. Before this essence came to be, the body of Mother Kun was originally empty. Through the mingling of her light with Father Qian’s radiance, Kun became replete and formed Kan. Once the form of Kan was complete, the moon emitted its light from the direction of Dui—this is called the metal within water. The metal within water truly relies on Mother Kun’s nurturing to take form, and so it is called the mother qi. As *The Awakening to Reality* says, “Extracting the white from the black becomes the elixir mother.” The mother qi possesses a white light, known as the yang light. When the yang light appears, one circulates one’s own mercury to welcome it—this is what is meant by “seeking the medicine in the second phase.” When the two correspond, the two eights of the same kind are captured in the same moment, refined into the yang elixir, which is the elixir mother. Yet because its transformation occurs externally, the elixir mother is only considered the outer medicine. The practitioner refines the inner medicine with the outer medicine, subduing the child qi with the mother qi. Within the elixir mother, yang lead is then produced, which is transported by the river chariot, returned in reverse to the original palace, and concealed within the earthen crucible. After the four phases harmonize and the three natures unite in joy, this moment of bliss attains longevity. Though the method of practice is thus, to know the white one must first guard the black; only by guarding the black can one know the white. Yet even after knowing the white, one must still guard the black—within this lies a threefold wondrous function, which serves as the world’s model and standard. If one can practice accordingly, the constant virtue of the natural order will not err, and without error, one may return to verify the limitless, refining the spirit to restore the void.

To know the white one must first guard the black is yang entering within yin. To guard the black and thereby know the white is yin giving birth to yang. To know the white and yet still guard the black is the spirit returning and qi submitting. The principle of heaven, earth, and the myriad things is all thus—hence it is the world’s model and standard.

chunks.original_text: 玄静曰：以上东西二祖，发明丹旨，可谓剀切明着矣。 然所揭者，均属理趣，工夫方面，只是心息妙合，静定阳生，以真空而感妙有，复以妙有而合真空。 神息融和，性命冥合，打成一片，而结成道胎也。 黑白亦属象言，指阴阳言，不出身心神气。 最初以神驭气，息之出入，在外面稍有知觉，不可着意，不可无意。 我只顺其自然而存之，又顺其自然而忘之。 浸于杳冥恍惚，入冲和之境。 阴阳初交，美在其中。 是知白守黑之初功也。 神息两定在外面，外息已断，日月合璧，在于剥复之交，晦朔之间。 此际正入壶子之地文三昧，极寂静不动之境界也。 然我既返乎纯坤，内外俱静，息念双销，成○如此象（在内为己土，在外为戊土），则虚空中之纯乾，必相感而来。 一阳初动，时至神知，妙合自然之符节。 于一觉之顷，即离开色身，向外心息相依（我本无息，因神动而气亦动，故转为有息）。 所谓“起巽风，运坤火，轻轻举，默默运”，是“知白守黑”第二层工夫也。 迨夫神息和融，渐渐又入真定。 此际内外浑忘，心境俱寂，人法双忘，复归于无极。 则所感先天真阳，不致走失，“送归土釜牢封固”矣。 是“知白守黑”第三层工夫也。 学者须知，丹法不可一毫着于色身。 着即漏精走丹，弊病百出。 必要入于混沌，归于无极，如活死人一般，并此定相而忘之。 无无亦无，湛然常寂，然后气凝丹聚，六龙之变化方全。 自初步炼精化气，直至末后炼神还虚，忘虚合道，无不如是一贯进行。 故达者唯简唯易，昧者愈繁愈难。 上乘丹诀，纯以真空为行持之总纲。 入大定真空之时间愈长，则效验愈速。 直至一日十二时中，无刻不在大定之中，虽欲觅呼吸而不可得，则自然胎圆出神（即法身能与色身分离）矣。 以上专约工夫言，乃知白守黑之真口诀也。 最初阳往阴中（凝神入炁穴，太阳移入月明中），所以求铅。 李祖所谓“知白必先守黑”也。 中间阴中阳产，静而复动，所谓“守黑乃能知白”也。 末后神归炁伏，妙入大定之乡，希夷之境，先后二天，自然和融，渐采渐凝，以致结丹，所谓“知白还要守黑”也。 《阴符经》曰：“三反昼夜，用师万倍。 ”昼夜即动静也。 师者众炁也，用者神用之功也。 文烹武炼，止火温养，经三反而后蒇事。 与涵虚祖所揭理趣相符。 岂非复命之玄机，归元之津梁也哉。 一二Ｏ   食母与守母 老圣曰：“有物混成，先天地生，寂兮寥兮，独立而不改，周行而不殆，可以为天下母。 吾不知其名，字之曰道。 ” 释曰：混成之德，即圆觉性海，动则为真一之炁，道家了命之学所由立也。 静则周遍含容，为如来藏，妙真如心，佛氏修性之学所由立也。 动静未分，性命归一。 此混元至真之体，虚寂寥廓，清净周遍，无以立名，强名曰道。 一切出世间法由此出生，一切世间法由此建立，故又称之曰天下母。 傅大士曰：“有物先天地，无形本寂寥。 能为万象主，不逐四时凋。 ”意盖与老圣同也。 《道德经》又云：“众人皆有以，我独顽且鄙，我独异于人，而贵食母。 ”又曰：“天下有始，以为天下母。 既得其母，以知其子。 既知其子，复守其母。 没身不殆。 ”此食母守母之学，乃玄宗所宗，道家所常，返还之要素也。

Xuanjing said: The Eastern and Western Patriarchs have elucidated the essence of the Golden Elixir with utmost clarity and precision. Yet what they revealed pertains primarily to the principles and subtleties of the practice. In terms of actual cultivation, it is nothing other than the wondrous union of mind and breath, where stillness gives birth to yang, true emptiness resonates with wondrous being, and wondrous being in turn merges with true emptiness. Spirit and breath harmonize, nature and life become one, coalescing into a single whole to form the embryo of the Dao.

Black and white are but symbolic terms, referring to yin and yang, and ultimately to the body, mind, spirit, and qi. At the outset, the spirit governs qi, and the breath’s ebb and flow may be faintly perceived externally. One must neither fixate on it nor be entirely without awareness. I simply allow it to exist naturally, then forget it naturally, gradually dissolving into profound obscurity and entering the state of harmonious equilibrium. At the initial union of yin and yang, beauty resides within—this is the foundational work of "knowing the white by first guarding the black."

When spirit and breath stabilize externally, the outer breath ceases, the sun and moon conjoin like jade disks, and one stands at the threshold of *bo* and *fu*, between the dark of the moon and the new moon. At this moment, one enters the third stage of *Huozi’s* "Realm of Earth," a state of utter stillness and immobility. Yet having returned to pure *kun*, with inner and outer both stilled and thoughts and breath dissolved, forming the symbol ○ (internally as *ji* earth, externally as *wu* earth), the pure *qian* of the void must respond and arrive. The first stirring of yang arises, and when the time comes, the spirit knows—this is the natural correspondence of the wondrous tally. In an instant of awakening, one departs from the physical body, and the mind and breath depend on each other externally (for I originally have no breath; only when the spirit moves does qi move, thus transforming into breath). This is what is meant by "arousing the *xun* wind, moving the *kun* fire, lightly lifting, silently circulating"—the second stage of "knowing the white by guarding the black."

As spirit and breath gradually harmonize and merge, one enters true stillness once more. At this point, inner and outer are entirely forgotten, mind and environment both stilled, self and dharma both forgotten, returning to the limitless. The primordial true yang thus evoked will not escape, "sent back to the earthen cauldron and sealed securely." This is the third stage of "knowing the white by guarding the black."

The practitioner must understand that the elixir method must not cling even slightly to the physical body. Clinging leads to leakage of essence and loss of the elixir, giving rise to countless faults. One must enter the state of primordial chaos, return to the limitless, like a living corpse, forgetting even this state of stillness. Where there is no "no," only profound tranquility remains—then qi congeals and the elixir gathers, and the transformations of the six dragons are complete. From the initial step of refining essence into qi to the final stage of refining spirit to return to the void, merging with the Dao in forgetfulness, the process is consistently thus. Therefore, the enlightened find it simple and easy, while the deluded make it increasingly complex and difficult.

The supreme elixir method takes true emptiness as the guiding principle of practice. The longer one abides in the great stillness of true emptiness, the swifter the effects. When, throughout the twelve hours of the day, not a moment passes without being in this great stillness—so that one cannot even find the breath—then naturally the embryo matures and the spirit emerges (the dharmakāya separates from the physical body).

The above speaks specifically of the practice, revealing the true oral instructions of "knowing the white by guarding the black." Initially, yang enters within yin (concentrating the spirit into the qi cavity, the sun moving into the moon’s brightness) to seek lead—this is what Patriarch Li meant by "to know the white, one must first guard the black." In the middle stage, yang is born within yin, stillness giving way to movement—this is "by guarding the black, one can know the white." Finally, the spirit returns and qi submits, wondrously entering the realm of great stillness, the state of profound tranquility, where prior and posterior heaven naturally harmonize. Gradually gathering and congealing, the elixir forms—this is "knowing the white and yet still guarding the black."

The *Yinfu Jing* states: "Three returns in day and night yield ten thousandfold the master’s power." Day and night signify movement and stillness. The "master" is the host of qi, and "power" is the function of the spirit. Refining with literary fire and forging with martial heat, ceasing the fire and nurturing with warmth—only after three returns is the work complete. This aligns with the principles expounded by Patriarch Hanxu. Is this not the profound mechanism of returning to life and the bridge to returning to the origin?

---

The Old Sage said: "There is a thing, formless yet complete, born before heaven and earth. Silent and void, it stands alone and unchanging, circulating without end. It may be called the Mother of all under heaven. I know not its name; I style it the Dao."

The commentary states: The virtue of this formless completion is the ocean of perfect enlightenment. In movement, it becomes the true unity of qi, the foundation of the Daoist practice of fulfilling destiny. In stillness, it pervades and contains all, becoming the Tathāgata-garbha, the wondrous true suchness of mind—the foundation of the Buddhist practice of cultivating nature. Before movement and stillness divide, nature and life return to one. This is the primordial, utterly true body, empty, silent, vast, and pure, pervading all without a name—hence it is forcibly called the Dao. All transcendent dharmas arise from it, and all worldly dharmas are established by it; thus, it is also called the Mother of all under heaven.

Master Fu said:
*"There is a thing before heaven and earth,
Formless, originally silent and void.
It can be the master of all phenomena,
Unchanging through the four seasons."*

His meaning is the same as the Old Sage’s.

The *Daode Jing* further states: "All people have their means; I alone am dull and coarse. I alone differ from others in valuing the nourishment of the Mother." It also says: "The world has a beginning, which may be regarded as the Mother of the world. Having attained the Mother, one knows her children. Having known the children, one returns to guard the Mother. Thus, one does not perish even in death." This teaching of nourishing and guarding the Mother is the essence revered by the profound tradition, the constant practice of Daoists, and the key to returning and restoration.

To "nourish the Mother" means to seek sustenance from the Mother—this is the interdependence of heart and breath, achieving a state of profound obscurity, emptiness, and primordial chaos. Externally, one draws in the primordial unified *qi*, which steeps, irrigates, and nurtures both the Dharma-body and the physical form. Thus, one’s original *qi* grows daily more abundant, true nature is daily restored, the foundation of life is eternally firm, and the nature-body becomes perfectly luminous. This is the essential meaning of nourishing the Mother.

The *Cantong Qi* states:
*"The loving mother nurtures,
The filial son repays her grace.
Thus they clasp and swallow,
Chewing and merging as one."*
This is precisely the Way.

After obtaining the Elixir, embracing the Origin and guarding the One, quietly nurturing the Dao-embryo—this is called "guarding the Mother." To guard means to warm and nourish with gentle fire. Guarding the Mother is the work of nurturing the embryo, while nourishing the Mother is the effort of gathering and refining. By nourishing the Mother and then guarding her, the tasks of warming, nurturing, gathering, and refining are complete.

Master Hanxu said:
*"When yang lead serves as the Mother,
yin mercury becomes the Child.
Yin mercury is the postnatal child-*qi*,
yang lead is the prenatal Mother-*qi*.
Using external yang lead to subdue internal yin mercury—
when Mother and Child meet, this is called 'knowing the Child.'
Yet for this yang lead to arrive, the marvelous function of fire is required.
For lead is born in the Kan palace, sinking and unmoving;
to restrain the true mercury of the Li palace,
one must first employ fierce fire for intense refinement,
only then will it ascend and soar.
Once it meets true mercury,
one should guard the city and bathe—
no further fierce fire may be applied.
At first, the Mother comes longing for the Child;
later, the Child lingers longing for the Mother.
Thus it is said: 'Having known the Child, one returns to guard the Mother.'
When Mother and Child long for each other without cease,
the Great Elixir is accomplished."*

Master Qianxu said:
*"The teaching of guarding the Mother is also called nourishing the Mother—its meaning is most profound. The sages of the Three Teachings share this vital thread. Our Confucians inherit it as the transmission of 'refining the One'..."*

The Buddhists attain it and open the Gate of Non-Duality; the Daoist sages attain it and cultivate the study of Embracing the One. For this is the Way.

What is meant by "guarding the Mother"? To seal the Dui, close the gate—this is guarding the Mother. To perceive the small as yielding—this is guarding the Mother. To use one’s light and return to clarity—this is guarding the Mother. The study of guarding the Mother is the profound mechanism of returning to life. One who can return to life may then inherit the Dao and merge with its truth.

---

**Embracing the One and Attaining the One**
The Daoist sages say: *"The sage embraces the One as the model for all under heaven."* They also say: *"Of old, those who attained the One: Heaven attained the One and became clear; Earth attained the One and became tranquil; spirits attained the One and became numinous; valleys attained the One and became full; the myriad things attained the One and came to life; lords and kings attained the One and became the standard for all under heaven—all these arose from the One."* Zhuangzi said: *"When one is permeated by the One, the myriad affairs are complete."* Baopuzi said: *"The Dao arises from the One, and its value is peerless. It cannot be seen, cannot be heard. When preserved, it is present; when neglected, it vanishes. Facing it brings fortune; turning from it brings misfortune. Safeguarding it ensures boundless blessings; losing it leads to withered form and exhausted qi."* Laozi said: *"Vague and indistinct, yet within it are images; indistinct and vague, yet within it are things."* This refers to the One.

Thus, the immortal classics say: *"If you desire long life, guard the One with clarity. When hungry, the One provides sustenance; when thirsty, the One offers drink. The One can generate yin and engender yang, regulate the cycles of cold and heat. Spring attains the One and sprouts; summer attains the One and grows; autumn attains the One and harvests; winter attains the One and stores. Its vastness cannot be measured by the six directions; its minuteness cannot be compared to a hair’s tip."*

Master Bai said: *"This is the true qi of the One, prior to the ten thousand images, the Great Void, the Great Non-Being, the Great Emptiness, the Great Origin. Dim and obscure, it cannot be measured by inches; vast and boundless, it cannot be fathomed by shores. Its greatness has no exterior; its smallness has no interior. It encompasses heaven and earth, yet enters the tip of a hair. Above, it transcends color; below, it transcends depth. One thing, perfectly complete, manifesting through the ages. That which cannot be named, the sages grasp with their hearts, and out of necessity call it the Dao."*

He also said: *"To concentrate qi and attain suppleness, to contain light and remain silent, to nurture correctness and maintain fullness, to guard the feminine and embrace the One—with the mind unmoving, the myriad conditions grow still. Ten thousand volumes of elixir scriptures are not equal to guarding the One. Guard the One, and the myriad methods return to the One. Attain the One, and one transcends the posterior heaven to avoid death; lose the One, and one decays with things. Build with the One as the foundation, gather with the One as the medicine, refine with the One as the fire, congeal with the One as the elixir, nurture with the One as the sacred embryo, circulate with the One as the withdrawal and replenishment, sustain with the One as the sealing, and purify with the One as the bathing."*

Master Xuanjing said: *"The so-called One is the qi of wondrous existence, called the primordial ancestral qi, also known as the true qi of the One. When speaking of qi, it is in terms of its circulation; when speaking of spirit, it is in terms of its numinosity; when speaking of essence, it is in terms of its coagulation. In reality, it is one thing."*

The Daoist tradition attains the One to achieve truth; the Confucian tradition attains the One to participate in transformation; the Chan tradition attains the One to illuminate the mind. Thus, the Three Teachings all value attaining the One. After attaining it, one guards it like a hen brooding over an egg, like a dragon nurturing a pearl—this is called "embracing the One," the work of ten months of gestation. Attaining the One is the effect of congealing the elixir. One attains it in stillness; one embraces it in quiescence. With body and mind profoundly settled, the effects manifest naturally.

Master Bai said: *"From emptiness and spontaneity, being arises from non-being. The ten thousand things are one thing, and the one is most precious to guard. The whirling wind merges, and the whole day feels like intoxication. The great dream awakens, thunder roars and lightning flashes. Clouds disperse and rain scatters—heaven endures and earth abides."*

He also said: *"Like a dragon nurturing a pearl, the heart does not forget; like a hen brooding over an egg, the qi does not cease. It is like the autumn cicada drinking the morning breeze, or the aged oyster containing the autumn moon."*

The subtlety of embracing the One is most thoroughly expounded by the Perfected One of Purple Clarity.

---

**Forgetting the One and Transcending the One**
Zhuangzi said: *"Act without the One."* He also said: *"As if forgetting the One, as if losing the One—such a one transcends the mundane, leaving no trace."* Master Bai said: *"From the One to the One, the One reaches its ultimate. This is called shedding the embryo, reaching the limit of the limitless. The One unites with nothing, merging with the Dao in truth, enduring with heaven—this is called the true One."*

Cao Wenyu said: *"Merge and become one, then forget the One—thus may one emerge and submerge with primordial transformation."*

Now, to concentrate spirit and guard qi, to attain the One and embrace the One—these principles have already been set forth by the Daoist sages. Here, we reveal the principle of forgetting the One: to dissolve the heart that embraces the One, shattering emptiness, breaking through to the other shore of the Thunderous Sound. Then, one cannot be confined or called back, transcending the ken of saints and mortals, attaining freedom and ease. The Chan tradition calls this "turning the position."

Thus, attaining the One can clarify the affairs of the Dharma-body; forgetting the One can clarify the supreme matters of the Dharma-body. In the Daoist tradition’s cultivation and realization, one must pass through this barrier to reach the field of great rest and great liberation. Otherwise, if there is still something embraced or guarded, one will never erase all traces and enter the gate of perfect penetration.

---

The *Cantong Qi* states: "When metal comes to return to the original nature, it may then be called the Returned Elixir." Yet in recent times, alchemists have further distinguished between the Lesser Return Elixir and the Greater Return Elixir. The *Strange Encounters at Sea and Mountain* records that Li Qi, the Recluse of Huayang, obtained the Lesser Return Elixir and lived for several centuries without his appearance aging. When the Patriarch Lü encountered him in Jurong, he taught him to refine the Golden Fluid Greater Return Elixir. The old man joyfully received the instruction. The Patriarch Lü said: "Reset the furnace, reestablish the crucible, ride the tiger and mount the dragon to leave the mortal realm." This precisely refers to the Greater Return.

Where, then, lies the distinction between the Greater and Lesser Returns? Explanations among authors have varied, but following the transmitted teachings, we here elucidate their meaning: Since the breaking of the original body, the postnatal Kan and Li have taken charge. The practitioner begins with the interdependence of heart and breath, progressing until the ordinary breath ceases entirely, body and mind enter profound stillness, and inner and outer become utterly quiescent. Thereupon, the primordial One Qi emerges from the midst of emptiness, and the work of gathering and absorbing begins. Thus, my pure yin responds to its pure yang, returning from the postnatal to the prenatal. Each time the work is performed, the prenatal true yang arrives once, returning from without to within the body. Hence the *Cantong Qi* says: "When metal comes to return to the original nature, it may then be called the Returned Elixir."

As the work advances, true yang gathers ever more, until qi is full and the fire is withdrawn, forming the Returned Elixir—this is called the Lesser Return. The Lesser Return is the initial return, wherein yin responds to yang, corresponding to the *Yijing*’s *Tai* hexagram: "The small departs, the great arrives." This stage of the work is termed "borrowing from Kan to fill Li" in alchemical texts. When true qi is fully abundant and the Li palace is filled, the Qian body is restored—this is called "returning to youth" in alchemical texts.

After returning to youth, the inner being is purely Qian. The practitioner then enters samadhi and true stillness, using one’s Qian yang to respond to the primordial Qian yang true qi, merging the inner and outer layers of the prenatal to produce the Great Medicine—this is called the Great Elixir, or the Greater Return. It is the work of the seven-day Great Celestial Circuit. The Greater Return embodies the image of double Qian. The Patriarch Lü’s poem on obtaining the Greater Return Elixir says: "Refining and refining until reaching Qian Qian, only then is one a drunken immortal among men." This serves as proof. The *Yijing* states: "All day long Qian Qian, returning and repeating the Dao." The image of Qian Qian is the esoteric principle of the Greater Return. "Returning and repeating" means returning from the postnatal to the prenatal, then from the prenatal to that which precedes the prenatal. Only upon reaching the realm of double Qian are the transformations of the six dragons complete, and one may then govern and command Heaven.

Thus, in the alchemical method, when the postnatal responds to the prenatal, the medicine obtained is called the Lesser Medicine, the elixir formed is called the Lesser Elixir, and the celestial circuit performed is called the Lesser Celestial Circuit. When one’s prenatal pure yang responds to the prenatal pure yang, merging the inner and outer layers of the prenatal, the medicine obtained is called the Great Medicine, the elixir formed is called the Great Elixir, and the celestial circuit performed is called the Great Celestial Circuit. The *Yijing*’s Lesser Accumulation and Greater Accumulation, and the Dao’s Lesser Return and Greater Return, share the same meaning. Though divided into greater and lesser, the progress of the work fundamentally does not depart from the interdependence of heart and breath. Once true emptiness and great stillness are attained, inner and outer harmonize and merge. The Lesser Celestial Circuit proceeds within stillness, and the Great Celestial Circuit likewise proceeds within stillness. The Lesser Return Elixir forms within stillness, and the Greater Return Elixir likewise forms within stillness. Only the depth of stillness differs, hence the results vary.

Furthermore, after the Lesser Return Elixir is formed, one must apply the fire of nurturing the elixir, allowing it to mature fully and perform the Great Celestial Circuit, obtaining the Great Medicine and completing the Greater Return. After the Great Elixir is formed, one must apply the fire of nurturing the embryo, enduring for ten months until the embryo is fully developed and the birth occurs—this is called "emerging as spirit." Beyond this lie further practices of tempering and nourishing, called "nursing." At this point, the great work of becoming an immortal is complete.

---

Laozi said: "Much speech hastens exhaustion; it is better to abide in the center." Zhuangzi said: "Riding things to roam the heart, entrusting to necessity to nurture the center—this is perfection." Abiding in the center and nurturing the center share the same meaning. Master Chongxu said: "The center is not the center of the middle; it is the center of emptiness and void. Abiding is not clinging and guarding; it is the abiding of utmost emptiness." When the practitioner unites heart and breath at the center of emptiness outside the body, this is the study of abiding in the center. From the union of heart and breath, nature and life return to the origin, congealing into the embryo of the Dao. The *Cantong Qi* says: "Managing and nurturing the calyx, congealing spirit to form the body." It also says: "The three luminaries sink into obscurity, warming and nurturing the pearl of the child." This is the work of nurturing the center.

To speak plainly: the original spirit and original qi circulate within emptiness. The original spirit, nourished by the original qi, becomes ever more luminous and yang, ultimately transcending the embryo to manifest as a perfected being. Thus, the union of heart and breath in emptiness is called abiding in the center. The blending of spirit and qi in emptiness into a single whole is called nurturing the center. Master Chongxu said: "One who preserves the substance of the center does not abide in a single thought, remaining utterly still, abiding until food and pulse both cease, sleep and dullness vanish entirely, yet never departing from stillness for even a moment. One who exhausts the function of the center keeps the numinous light unobscured, utterly transcending the roots of the dust."

**125. Nurturing the Elixir and Nurturing the Embryo**

The alchemical practice of *wenyang* (warm nurturing) truly comprises two stages: nurturing the elixir and nurturing the embryo. When refining essence to transform qi is complete, one ceases the fire to prevent leakage of qi. When the cessation of fire takes effect, the result is the formation of the elixir. At the initial formation of the elixir, gazing steadily beneath lamplight, a black dot appears before the eyes—unseen in daylight. Upon seeing this dot, one knows the elixir has formed and must then apply the fire of warm nurturing to cultivate it. The black dot before the eyes gradually turns red and yellow, until it appears golden when viewed in sunlight, signaling the completion of the Lesser Return Elixir.

*The Marvelous Encounter at Sea Mountain* records that Li Qi, the recluse of Huayang, obtained the Lesser Return Elixir and lived for several centuries without aging. When Ancestor Lü traveled to Jurong, he encountered Li in the Golden Altar Grotto-Heaven—this was the Lesser Return Elixir. The fire phases for nurturing this elixir have been transmitted orally from sage to sage and are not recorded in books; this compilation makes no exception. For this work’s purpose is only to reveal the initial steps for prolonging life and enhancing vitality. The most profound oral secrets, not practicable by all, remain unrecorded.

Once the Lesser Return Elixir is fully nurtured, one proceeds to the Greater Celestial Cycle, transcending the mundane to attain sagehood. This Greater Celestial Cycle also involves three fire phases, transmitted orally and not committed to writing. After practicing the Greater Celestial Cycle for an appropriate period, there is a seven-day process of passing through the Greater Celestial Cycle, yielding the Great Medicine and achieving the Greater Return. Following the Greater Celestial Cycle comes the ten-month practice of nurturing the embryo—the second stage of warm nurturing. When the great samādhi is perfected and spirit is whole, one emerges as spirit.

Thus, the first stage of warm nurturing, which matures the elixir, pertains to the Lesser Return and produces earthbound immortals. When a practitioner’s work reaches the stage of elixir formation, even if they encounter calamity and die, their single spirit remains sovereign, allowing them to freely choose rebirth or seize another’s body—far surpassing ordinary people.

---

**126. Facing the Origin and Returning to the Origin**

Longmei Zi’s *Poems on the Verification of the Golden Elixir* discusses *chaoyuan* (facing the origin):

> "When form and spirit are both wondrous, the Dao is their companion;
> Cultivating both nature and life, they merge with the Great Void.
> When the imperial edict descends, one mounts a crane in flight;
> After receiving the jade script, one rides a dragon chariot.
> The glory of immortal officials is debated in terms of rank,
> While the turbid world’s trials are escaped to dwell in peace.
> Through accumulated virtue and diligent seeking, all may attain;
> Why then do you alone hesitate?"

It also discusses *huanyuan* (returning to the origin):

> "Not south, nor east—where is it?
> The wondrous single spirit is originally unobstructed.
> The worthy and foolish are fundamentally without distinction;
> The mundane and sacred have never differed.
> Reddening cinnabar through repetition becomes habit;
> Calling ‘mother’ instead of ‘mama’ is but a skillful means.
> All conditioned things are unreal—
> Awaken to the true source, where emptiness is not empty."

Xuanjing said: *Chaoyuan* confers immortal office, whether ascending in broad daylight or lifting one’s dwelling to soar—akin to passing the imperial examination and receiving an official post. The final step, the emptying of the heart to pass the ultimate test, is the pinnacle of Dao cultivation, where function is exhausted and effort forgotten. Within the ever-quiescent light, there is no attachment or hindrance—what then matters the presence or absence of an imperial edict? Thus, the Mysterious School values *huanyuan* above *chaoyuan*.

---

**127. The Greater Yang and the Greater Yin**

Liu Wuyuan’s *Women’s Elixir Formula* states: "The Greater Yang refines qi—this is the principle for men; the Greater Yin refines form—this is the expedient for women."

My teacher once remarked that these two lines dispel millennia of doubts and greatly benefit the *Women’s Elixir Formula*. Since ancient times, it has been held that men refine qi while women refine form, with different starting points. This has led heterodox schools to seize upon it as justification, creating separate methods for the Greater Yang refining qi and the Greater Yin refining form. Little do they realize this refers to the postnatal realm; in the prenatal Great Dao, men and women begin without distinction.

My teacher said: "The so-called Greater Yang refining qi means heart and breath depend on each other externally, so the heart becomes empty. When the heart is empty, the heart-fire naturally descends, and the water of the lower *kan* transforms into qi and ascends—this is the harmonization of *kan* and *li*. It is like sunlight shining down, causing seawater to transform into qi and rise. The Greater Yang refining qi is nothing more than this principle.

The phrase ‘Greater Yin refining form’ arises because the sun, residing in the *li* position, is inverted to become female—internally yin, externally yang. The internal yin is real; the external yang is illusory. In sum, the Greater Yin is a metaphor for the heart; *form* refers to the body. The ancients spoke of *form and spirit*, or *body and heart*—all ultimately reducible to the two words *yin* and *yang*. The body is qi. Refining qi with the heart is, in reality, the interdependence of heart and breath—identical to the previous line, differing only in wording.

Wuyuan saw through this principle, hence calling it an expedient, not an actual event, though the phenomenon exists. To pierce this with a single word requires one who is truly cultivated."

The above explanation by Master Wang is exceedingly precise. The entire elixir method emphasizes practice in the emptiness beyond the body—there is truly no difference between men and women.

chunks.original_text: 第因后天生理不同，故色身效验，随之而异。 如静中阳生，男子系外阳举动，女子系两乳挺硬。 筑基功成，男子精关自闭，外阳缩如童孩； 女子则经期断绝，两乳缩胸是也。 若论定忘功夫，男女无别也。 一二八   达生与遗生 庄子有达生与遗生之说，今试释其义曰：达生者，通达生命之理而养之也。 遗生者，空此身心，相忘于道也。 《庄子·达生篇》云：“达生之情者，不务生之所无以为”。 又云：“夫形全精复，与天为一。 形精不亏，是谓能移。 精而又精，反以相天”。 又引关尹子语曰：“彼将处乎不淫之度，而藏乎无端之纪，游乎万物之所终始。 一其性，养其气，合其德，以通乎物之所造。 夫若是者，其天守全，其神无郄，物奚自入焉！ ” 释曰：达生之要，在乎养气藏神，工夫即是心息相依。 使神凝而精复，真炁浩瀚，与天地同流，乃能与天地合德，故云“合其德”也。 人之命蒂，系乎真息。 故调息息住，以感天地真阳，乃养生之要素也。 达生而后能养生。 吕祖云：“穷取生身受气初，莫怪天机都泄尽”。 紫阳云：“劝君穷取生身处，返还本源是药王”。 是又达生之要也。 若夫遗生，则工夫深进，身心入寂，内外皆空，而证我空之妙矣。 黄帝曰：“精神入其门，骨骸反其根，我尚何存”！ 老圣曰：“复归于无物，复归于无极”。 皆示遗生之妙旨也。 会而通之，玄宗初下手心息相依，须放在身外虚空中行持，不着形体，此正遗其生也； 心息二定，先天一炁自来，形全精复，此又达生之效也。 老圣曰：“外其身而身存”。 谭子曰：“忘形以养气，忘气以养神，忘神以养虚。 虚实相通，是谓大同”。 白紫清曰：“忘形养气乃金液，对景无心是大还。 忘形养气气化神，斯乃大道透三关”。 曰外，曰忘，岂非遗生乎？ 曰养、曰还，岂非达生乎？ 须知心息在外相依，而至大定，身心二忘，境智俱泯，即遗生而得更生之妙，老圣所谓“无私而能成其私”也。 若抱定色身做工夫，纯属后天作用，不惟不达遗生之理，并不识养生之主，与玄宗正脉相去远矣！ 一二九   达生与达命 《庄子·列御寇篇》云：“知慧外通，勇动多怨，仁义多责。 达生之情者傀，达于知者肖； 达大命者随，达小命者遭”。 陆方壶曰：“知慧，一府也，知慧多外通； 勇动，一府也，勇动则取怨愤； 仁义，一府也，仁义则多责任； 达生，一府也，达生之情，则造于实际，傀然而大解矣。 此一府最为上乘。 达知，一府也，达于知则知天、知人，天之肖子也； 达命，一府也，大达则曰吾随之，小达则曰吾遭之。 盖遭则有委命之意，随则无容心也，又达命之上乘也”。 释曰：达生与达命，乃玄学家之本分。 达者，通达。 达生而后修生，达命而后了命。 工夫只是心息相依，随即依息之谓也。 自有息而返于无息，外感天地之一炁，天机一发，源源不竭，命基于是永固。 傀者，大也，谓与大自然浑化也。 达大命者，随息安神，随缘度日，乃至随心自在，无所障碍。 达小命者，但安于所遭，无怨怼而已。 一三Ｏ   司契与司彻 老圣曰：“圣人执左契，而不责于人。 有德司契，无德司彻”。 秘释曰：契贵符合。 心与息，正天然妙契。

Yet because post-heaven physiology differs, the physical body’s responses vary accordingly. In quiescence, when yang arises, men manifest as external yang stirring, while women manifest as both breasts becoming firm. Upon the completion of foundational work, men’s essence-gate seals itself, and their external yang retracts like that of a child; women’s menstrual cycles cease, and their breasts recede into the chest. Yet when it comes to the work of settled forgetting, there is no distinction between men and women.

**128. Attaining Life and Forgetting Life**
Zhuangzi speaks of *attaining life* and *forgetting life*. Let us now elucidate their meanings: *Attaining life* means comprehending the principles of life and nurturing it. *Forgetting life* means emptying body and heart, becoming oblivious to them in the Dao.

The *Zhuangzi*’s “Attaining Life” chapter states: “Those who attain the essence of life do not pursue what is of no use to life.” It further says: “When form is whole and essence restored, one becomes one with Heaven. When form and essence are unharmed, this is called *shifting*. Refining essence to ever greater refinement is to return and assist Heaven.” It also cites Master Guan Yin: “He dwells in the measure of non-excess, abides in the boundless axis, and roams through the beginning and end of the myriad things. Unifying his nature, nurturing his qi, harmonizing his virtue, he communicates with the source of all things. One who does so preserves the wholeness of Heaven, his spirit unobstructed—how could external things intrude?”

Explanation: The essence of *attaining life* lies in nurturing qi and storing spirit; the practice is precisely the interdependence of heart and breath. When spirit congeals and essence is restored, true qi surges boundlessly, flowing in unison with Heaven and Earth. Thus one harmonizes virtue with Heaven and Earth, hence the phrase “harmonizing his virtue.” The root of human life lies in true breath. Therefore, regulating the breath to stillness so as to connect with Heaven and Earth’s true yang is the essential element of nurturing life. Only after *attaining life* can one nurture life.

Master Lü says: “Exhaustively trace back to the moment of receiving qi at birth—marvel not that the celestial mechanism is fully revealed.” Master Zi Yang says: “I urge you to exhaustively trace back to the origin of your birth; returning to the root is the Medicine King.” This, too, is the essence of *attaining life*.

As for *forgetting life*, the practice deepens, body and heart enter stillness, inner and outer both empty, and one realizes the wondrousness of the emptiness of self. The Yellow Emperor says: “When spirit enters its gate, bones and skeleton return to their root—what ‘I’ remains?” The Old Sage says: “Return to the state of no-thing, return to the state of the limitless.” Both express the wondrous purport of *forgetting life*.

When these are understood and integrated: In the initial stages of the mysterious teaching, the interdependence of heart and breath must be practiced in the emptiness beyond the body, unattached to form—this is precisely *forgetting life*. When heart and breath settle into oneness, the primordial qi arrives of itself, form is whole and essence restored—this is the effect of *attaining life*. The Old Sage says: “Set the body aside, and the body is preserved.” Master Tan says: “Forget form to nurture qi, forget qi to nurture spirit, forget spirit to nurture emptiness. When emptiness and reality interpenetrate, this is called Great Harmony.”

Master Bai Zi Qing says: “Forgetting form to nurture qi is the Golden Liquid; facing phenomena without heart is the Great Return. Forgetting form to nurture qi, qi transforms into spirit—this is the Great Dao penetrating the Three Passes.” To “set aside” and to “forget”—are these not *forgetting life*? To “nurture” and to “return”—are these not *attaining life*?

Know that when heart and breath interdepend outside the body and reach great stillness, body and heart both forgotten, state and wisdom both dissolved, one attains the wondrousness of *forgetting life* and thereby gains *further life*—what the Old Sage called “being selfless yet able to perfect one’s self.” If one clings to the physical body in practice, this is purely a post-heaven function. Not only does one fail to grasp the principle of *forgetting life*, but one also fails to recognize the essence of nurturing life, diverging far from the true lineage of the mysterious teaching.

**129. Attaining Life and Attaining Destiny**
The *Zhuangzi*’s “Lie Yu Kou” chapter states: “Knowledge and wisdom externally connected breed resentment; courageous action invites many grudges; benevolence and righteousness invite many demands. Those who attain the essence of life are *kuai*; those who attain knowledge are *xiao*; those who attain the great destiny follow; those who attain the lesser destiny encounter.”

Lu Fang Hu says: “Knowledge and wisdom form one repository—when knowledge and wisdom are externally connected, they breed resentment. Courageous action forms one repository—courageous action invites grudges. Benevolence and righteousness form one repository—benevolence and righteousness invite many demands. Attaining life forms one repository—those who attain the essence of life progress toward reality, becoming *kuai* and greatly liberated. This repository is the highest vehicle. Attaining knowledge forms one repository—those who attain knowledge know Heaven and know humanity, becoming Heaven’s *xiao* offspring. Attaining destiny forms one repository—those who greatly attain say, ‘I follow it’; those who attain in small measure say, ‘I encounter it.’ Encountering implies submitting to destiny; following implies having no deliberate intent—this, too, is the highest vehicle of attaining destiny.”

Explanation: *Attaining life* and *attaining destiny* are the proper duties of the profound scholar. *Attaining* means thorough comprehension. Only after *attaining life* can one cultivate life; only after *attaining destiny* can one fulfill destiny. The practice is simply the interdependence of heart and breath—this is what is meant by *following the breath*. From having breath, one returns to breathlessness, externally connecting with Heaven and Earth’s one qi. When the celestial mechanism is activated, it flows ceaselessly, and the foundation of destiny is thereby eternally secured.

*Kuai* means great, signifying merging with the great naturalness. Those who *attain the great destiny* follow the breath to settle the spirit, live each day in accord with conditions, and ultimately follow the heart’s spontaneity without obstruction. Those who *attain the lesser destiny* merely accept what they encounter without resentment.

**130. Holding the Contract and Holding the Thoroughfare**
The Old Sage says: “The sage holds the left contract but does not demand of others. Those with virtue hold the contract; those without virtue hold the thoroughfare.”

Secret Explanation: The contract’s value lies in its correspondence. Heart and breath are the natural wondrous contract.

chunks.original_text: 圣人执左契，以待右之来合。 左契，神也。 右契，息也。 凝神于气穴（身外虚空）之中，静待息来就我，不必我去就息，我只至诚以待可也。 若我去就息，息或不就范，而我强制执行，捉紧硬做，则息粗而难调，着相起火，正司彻之象也。 以至诚感化，而使其自动来归，自然和谐。 如帝舜之格有苗，两阶干羽，七旬而有苗格，正是司契之妙也。 强制执行，武力贯彻者，司彻之类也，圣人不如是矣。 一三一   开人与开天 《庄子·达生篇》曰：“不开人之天，而开天之天。 开天者德生，开人者贼生。 不厌其天，不忽于人，民几乎以其真”。 陆西星曰：“修道者，知无心自然之妙也。 是以不开人之天，而开天之天。 开天之天者，虚静恬淡，明其自然之理也。 开人之天者，妄起知识，凿其混沌之窍也。 故开天者德生，开人者贼生。 德谓全其天德之真，贼谓加以人为之害。 天以此理善吾生，而吾贼之，则自绝于天矣。 吾得此理以为生，而不能全之，则自轻乎人矣。 不厌乎天，不忽乎人，将不几返于真乎！ ”归震川曰：“天为自然，人有知欲。 开人自凿窍，混沌死。 守气全人，平情全天，此保生之要也。 ” 玄静曰：世人于六尘境界，分别妍丑，知用繁兴，知识猖狂，谬称物质享受，不知情生智隔，坠落堪虞，心驰神动，精摇气索，渐消渐亡，大命随倾，是即“开人者贼生”也。 若夫修道之士，反见反闻，惟虚惟寂，身心二静，感召先天真阳，荣卫色身，养育法身。 生机一启，源源不竭，行见神全气足，六根虚静，性德自诏，此所谓“开天者德生”也。 开天者，天心用事，寂照不离，性天日朗。 开人者，人心用事，六识纷然。 斯即随流与反流之别也。 一三二   炀和与焚和 老圣揭“冲和”，广成子揭“处和”，庄子揭“炀和”。 《徐无鬼篇》云：“抱德炀和，以顺天下，此谓真人”。 和，谓先天元和之炁。 炀者，微火熏炙也。 以和炁熏于四肢百骸，虚极静笃，消息冲融，而美在其中，谓之炀和。 故《淮南子》亦云：“抱德炀和而万物杂累焉”。 杂累者，成熟之象也。 玄宗炀和之学，极为微妙。 学者工夫一到外息微微，自然身历其境，四肢百骸，如有微为熏炙，渐入酥软麻木，周身壅塞之处，渐次疏通，上至顶而下至踵，全被浸淫于太和一炁之中，如醉如痴，仙宗谓之饮和，乃是长生久视之初阶也。 焚和者，耗丧元和之谓也。 《庄子·外物篇》云：“有甚忧两陷而无所逃，陈蜳不得成，心若悬于天地之间，慰暋沈屯，利害相摩，生火甚多，众人焚和，月固不胜火，于是乎有僓然而道尽”。 陆方壶云：“修真体道之人，虚静恬澹，寂寞无为，五志之火，一时俱伏，利害不干于心，生死无变于己。 不知道者，不耐世故，甚忧两陷于利害之中，无所逃遁。 陈陈蜳蜳，坐不安，睡不宁。 若将此心悬于天地之间，慰愍屯邅，不自解脱。 利害相摩，生火甚多，焚其天和，于是有阴阳之患，以不知外物之不可必，而交战于利害之场，自焚若此，故道人养和，众人焚和。 焚者，煎熬之义。 月固不胜火。 月字下得奇，月者水也。 水不胜火，即医家一水不能胜五火之意。 又解，月，古篆文肉字也。 言血之躯，不胜熬烁，于是乎有僓然而道尽者。

The Sage holds the left contract, awaiting the right to come and join. The left contract is the spirit; the right contract is the breath. Concentrating the spirit within the qi cavity (the emptiness beyond the body), one calmly awaits the breath’s approach—no need for the self to seek the breath. One need only wait with utmost sincerity. If the self seeks the breath, the breath may resist alignment, and through forced control, clinging, and rigidity, the breath turns coarse and hard to regulate. Form clings, fire arises—this is precisely the image of *holding the thoroughfare*. Through sincere influence, one allows the breath to return of its own accord, naturally harmonious. Like Emperor Shun’s pacification of the Miao tribes: two ranks of dancers with feathered shields, and after seventy days, the Miao came to submit—this is the subtlety of *holding the contract*. Those who enforce through coercion and military might belong to *holding the thoroughfare*; the Sage does not act thus.

**131. Opening the Human and Opening Heaven**
The *Zhuangzi·Dashing Through Life* says: “Do not open the human’s Heaven, but open Heaven’s Heaven. Opening Heaven gives birth to virtue; opening the human gives birth to harm. Neither satiate with Heaven nor neglect the human, and the people will nearly return to their true nature.”

Lu Xixing says: “Those who cultivate the Dao know the wondrousness of effortless naturalness. Thus, they do not open the human’s Heaven but open Heaven’s Heaven. Opening Heaven’s Heaven means emptiness, stillness, tranquility, and clarity—illuminating the principle of naturalness. Opening the human’s Heaven means deluded knowledge arising, chiseling the undifferentiated aperture. Therefore, opening Heaven gives birth to virtue; opening the human gives birth to harm. *Virtue* means preserving the authenticity of Heaven’s power; *harm* means inflicting the damage of human artifice. Heaven, by this principle, nurtures our lives, yet we harm it—thus severing ourselves from Heaven. We obtain this principle as life, yet fail to preserve it—thus belittling ourselves as human. Neither satiate with Heaven nor neglect the human, and will we not nearly return to the true?”

Gui Zhenchuan says: “Heaven is natural; the human possesses knowledge and desire. Opening the human chisels apertures, and the undifferentiated perishes. Guarding qi preserves the human; leveling emotions preserves Heaven—this is the essence of preserving life.”

Xuanjing says: “Ordinary people, amid the six dusts of sensory realms, discriminate beauty and ugliness, knowledge proliferates, intellect runs wild, and they falsely claim material enjoyment. Unaware that emotions arise and wisdom is obstructed, they fall into peril. Heart scatters, spirit moves, essence trembles, qi depletes—gradually diminishing, life collapses, and the great destiny topples. This is *opening the human gives birth to harm*. As for those who cultivate the Dao: reversing perception and hearing, embracing emptiness and stillness, body and mind both tranquil—they summon primordial true yang, nourishing the corporeal form and fostering the Dharma-body. Once the mechanism of life is activated, it flows ceaselessly. Soon, spirit is whole, qi is full, the six senses are empty and still, and the power of inherent nature manifests—this is *opening Heaven gives birth to virtue*. Opening Heaven means Heaven’s heart governs, stillness and illumination never part, and the nature of Heaven grows radiant. Opening the human means the human heart governs, and the six senses scatter. This is the difference between following the current and reversing the flow.”

**132. Warming Harmony and Burning Harmony**
The Old Sage reveals “harmony through emptiness”; Guangchengzi reveals “abiding in harmony”; Zhuangzi reveals “warming harmony.” The *Xu Wugui* chapter says: “Embracing virtue and warming harmony, one accords with the world—this is called the true person.” *Harmony* refers to the primordial harmonious qi. *Warming* means gently heating with a subtle fire. Using harmonious qi to permeate the four limbs and hundred bones, in extreme emptiness and profound stillness, ebb and flow merge—beauty resides within. This is called *warming harmony*. Thus, the *Huainanzi* also says: “Embracing virtue and warming harmony, the myriad things amass.” *Amass* is the image of ripening.

The study of warming harmony in the Mystery School is exceedingly subtle. When the practitioner’s effort reaches the point where external breathing becomes faint, naturally the body enters the state: the four limbs and hundred bones feel gently warmed, gradually softening into numbness. Blockages throughout the body gradually dissolve, from the crown to the soles, wholly steeped in the great harmony of the one qi—drunken, entranced. The Immortal School calls this *drinking harmony*, the first step toward longevity and eternal vision.

*Burning harmony* means exhausting the primordial harmony. The *Zhuangzi·External Things* says: “With extreme worry, trapped in dual pitfalls with no escape, the cicada’s molting fails, the heart suspended between heaven and earth, restless and oppressed. Profit and harm grind against each other, generating excessive fire. The multitude burns harmony; the moon surely cannot withstand the fire. Thus, there is exhaustion, and the Dao is spent.”

Lu Fanghu says: “Those who cultivate truth and embody the Dao are empty, still, tranquil, and inactive. The fires of the five emotions are all subdued; profit and harm do not disturb the heart, and life and death do not alter the self. Those who do not know the Dao cannot endure worldly affairs, deeply worried and trapped in the dual pitfalls of profit and harm, with no escape. Restless and anxious, sitting uneasy, sleeping unsettled—this heart suspended between heaven and earth, restless and oppressed, cannot free itself. Profit and harm grind against each other, generating excessive fire, burning Heaven’s harmony. Thus, arise the afflictions of yin and yang. Not knowing the external cannot be relied upon, they engage in battle on the field of profit and harm, self-immolating like this. Therefore, the Daoist nurtures harmony, while the multitude burns harmony. *Burning* means scorching and searing. The character *moon* is uniquely placed—*moon* is water. Water cannot withstand fire, echoing the medical idea that one water cannot overcome five fires. Another interpretation: *moon* in ancient seal script is the character for *flesh*. The blood-formed body cannot withstand scorching and melting. Thus, there is exhaustion, and the Dao is spent.”

"Collapse" signifies decline and death. The *Dao* here refers to the Way of life; when the Dao is exhausted, form and spirit perish with it. The intent is for people to still the heart’s fire through quietude, abiding in the realm of tranquility and non-action, fulfilling their natural lifespan without premature demise—this is the benevolence of saving the world.

I note that Cao Wenyi’s *Song of the Great Dao* states:
*"Palaces and chambers lie empty, yet the spirit dwells within,
The soul’s crucible scorches, drying the blood and fluids.
One sorrow, one joy, one thought, one indulgence,
One exertion, one labor—each gnaws at the body’s form.
Dawn’s harm, dusk’s damage, deluded and unaware,
Spirit scattered, vitality lost, with no place to rest.
Subtly worn away, gradually withering,
Qi and harmony depleted, the spirit departs."*

This precisely serves as a gloss for Zhuangzi’s "burning harmony."

Scholars practice the movement of returning and reversal, where heart and breath depend on the external—then the heart becomes empty. With the heart empty, fire does not flare upward, and the fluids of Wood do not wither: this is the inner nurturing of harmony. When heart and breath settle into emptiness, the true *qi* of Qian’s yang externally steams the four limbs, penetrating the entire body. In an instant, inner and outer yin and yang harmonize: this is the outer nurturing of harmony. When inner and outer mutually nurture each other, vitality flourishes daily, and the foundation of the undying Dao is established.

**133. Having Method and Having No Method**

Zhuangzi’s *Carving Intent* states:
*"Those who carve intent and exalt conduct, distancing themselves from the world and differing from common customs, indulging in lofty discourse and resentful slander, do so merely to be contentious—these are the scholars of mountains and valleys, not men of the world, those who favor withering away or plunging into the abyss (first type).
Those who speak of benevolence, righteousness, loyalty, and trust, practicing reverence, frugality, and yielding, do so merely to cultivate themselves—these are the scholars of peaceful eras, teachers and instructors, those who favor wandering and dwelling in learning (second type).
Those who speak of great achievements, establishing great reputations, honoring ruler and minister, rectifying superior and inferior, do so merely to govern—these are the scholars of court and court, men who strengthen the state and achieve merit, those who favor annexation and consolidation (third type).
Those who dwell in marshes and lakes, abide in leisure and openness, fishing and living idly, do so merely to be without action—these are the scholars of rivers and seas, recluses, those who favor leisure (fourth type).
Those who practice breathing, exhaling the old and inhaling the new, imitating the bear’s climbing and the bird’s stretching, do so merely to prolong life—these are the practitioners of Dao-yin, those who nurture the body, those who favor the longevity of Peng Zu (fifth type).
As for those who are lofty without carving intent, cultivated without benevolence and righteousness, governed without merit and fame, at leisure without rivers and seas, long-lived without Dao-yin—nothing is forgotten, yet nothing is lacking. Serene and boundless, all excellences follow them: this is the Dao of heaven and earth, the virtue of the sage (sixth type).*
Thus it is said: *Serenity, stillness, silence, emptiness, and non-action—these are the equilibrium of heaven and earth, the essence of the Dao and virtue.*
Thus it is said: *The sage rests therein; rest leads to equanimity. Equanimity leads to serenity. Serene and equanimous, worries and misfortunes cannot enter, perverse qi cannot assail. Thus, their virtue is whole, and their spirit is not diminished."*

Qiu Qiongshan said: *"Those who delight in mountains and marshes go forth but cannot return. Those who serve in court enter but cannot exit. Those content with teaching are constrained and cannot extend. Those absorbed in nurturing the body preserve but cannot forget—this is not the true nature of things."*

Lu Xixing said: *"Having enumerated the five types of men with methods, he reverts to the sagely man without method. 'Carving' means strict and exacting; 'exalting' means holding in high esteem. 'Resentment' is indignation; 'slander' is defamation. 'Withering away and plunging into the abyss' means willingly embracing solitude and casting oneself into deep mountains and remote valleys as if plunging into the depths. 'Cultivating' means refining the self. 'Nothing forgotten, nothing lacking' conveys the meaning of 'non-action yet nothing left undone.' 'Serene and boundless' means without limit."*

I observe that the five types Zhuangzi enumerates all carve and refine their intent, pursuing their preferences, yet cannot forget the self or things, returning to the One without trace. As for those who embody the Dao, cultivating nature and reverting to virtue, their bodies merge with true emptiness, their actions leave no tracks—thus, serene and boundless, all excellences follow them. The terms *forgetting*, *resting*, *equanimity*, *serenity*, *emptiness*, and *non-action* all align with the Dao, revealing the wondrous subtleties of restoring nature.

Scholars, in practicing the interdependence of heart and breath, value attaining equilibrium. Equilibrium makes the breath harmonious and the heart at peace. Once spirit and breath are both forgotten, one enters samadhi with ease, forgetting both self and dharmas, merging subject and object, transcending existence and non-existence—this is the moment of serene boundlessness. At this time, the true yang of heaven and earth converges and returns. Silent yet responsive, still yet able to act, the more empty, the more abundant; the more forgotten, the more pure; the more pure, the more transformed—until the dharma-realm and the self are utterly without separation. This is called the Dao merging into oneness. Only when unified does the spirit become unfettered; unfettered, it has no method. Abiding in existence yet not attached to it, dwelling in non-existence yet not devoid of it, neither yin nor yang can constrain it, nor can the workings of creation fathom it—is this not the path of the perfected?

Thus it is said: *"Nothing forgotten, yet nothing to forget; nothing possessed, yet nothing lacking. Serene and boundless, all excellences follow."* This is the wondrous subtlety of the forgotten heart, unattainable by those who carve intent and cultivate; the wondrous subtlety of no-method, unattainable by those whose attachments remain unbroken. Thus, the distinction between carving intent and forgetting intent, between having no method and having method, is the difference between the mind that abides and the mind that does not abide.

chunks.original_text: 《庄子·天道篇》云：“昔者舜问于尧曰：‘天王之用心何如？ ’尧曰：‘吾不敖无告，不废穷民，苦死者，嘉孺子而哀妇人。 此吾所以用心已。 ’舜曰：‘美则美矣，而未大也。 ’尧曰：‘然则何如？ ’舜曰：‘天德而出宁，日月照而四时行，若昼夜之有经，云行而雨施矣。 ’尧曰：‘胶胶扰扰乎！ 子，天之合也； 我，人之合也。 夫天地者，古之所大也，而黄帝尧舜之所共美也。 故古之王天下者，奚为哉？ 天地而已矣’”。 《刻意篇》曰：“虚无恬淡，乃合天德”。 又曰：“一之精通，合于天伦”。 陆西星曰：“天德出宁者，本天德以治，而万物自宁也。 天之德，无为自然而已，故日月自照，四时自行，昼夜自其有常，云自行，雨自施，无心于物而万物自宁也。 天道之运，无所积也； 君人之德，亦如是也。 信乎其天之合，而非人之合也”。 玄静曰：治国与治身，其例一也。 天德者，天心也。 与天心合，则虚无自然，火侯纯乎先天，而返还自易； 与人心合，则起意着相，纯乎勉强，背乎自然，步步落于后天，返还之效，即难见矣。 天德而出宁一语最妙，谓若与天心合辙，则虽出而静，动亦定，静亦定，四威仪内，无不定时也。 斯即“大定持之”之意。 是故虚无恬淡，妙性冲然，寂照忘知，任运无碍，虽有为而不累于有，虽无为而不溺于无。 有无不着，中道不居，斯可以超脱自在矣。 葆真子曰：“今夫人亦甚眇矣。 所以可谓天仙者，以其心天之心，必复其性之初。 不复其性之初，则泊于情之末。 复性所以之天，泊情所以之人。 之人也者，子独察夫子之用心，其同乎人者几，其同乎天者几。 去其人，就其天。 心无不天，乃所以为真人。 人之于真也，斯可语天仙矣”。 玄静曰：情在则为凡人，情忘则为仙圣。 忘情息见，乃转凡入圣之秘要也。 若论工夫，只就偶谐三昧之一行。 心息相依，依极而化，息无出入，念无起灭，泰然入定，身心俱寂，内外混忘，人法双遣，理事俱泯，境智妙空，斯可谓去人而合天矣。 与天合者，与太虚同体，与天地同用者也。 同体者，道通为一也； 同用者，任运无心也。 妙正真人曰：“无心应运，泯照而觉圆，非造道之极，脱体无依者，未易语此也”。 一三五   真空与顽空 真空与顽空，一有造化，一无造化； 一是圆空，一是断空。 若约工夫而论，真空乃外呼吸断绝，神炁同定，息念双销，性命合一。 至静极而动，一阳来复之际，则妙显焉。 此中有无一体，妙窍同玄。 悟元子云：“一轮明月天心照，半夜雷声震神州。 ”契真空不空之妙也。 故真空乃融有于空，至无而含至有，空而不空，体用一元，微显无间也。 此中有无尽生机，无穷造化。 《大通经·真空章》云：“先天而生，生而无形； 后天而存，存而无体。 然而无体，未尝存也。 故曰不可思议。 ”又云：“包含万象体，不挂一丝头。 ”又曰：“心灭性现，如空无象。 湛然圆满。 ”浮邱翁曰：“真空无我，大返大还，浑然一炁，归合先天。 ”此真空之妙旨也。 若夫顽空，乃偏静沉空之类。 冥冥昏昏，只是遏止念头不起，心如止水而已。 古人比之死水不藏龙，良有以也。 所谓身如枯木，心如死灰是也。 是故无生机，无造化，近世枯禅一流，正契此象也。

From the *Zhuangzi*, "The Dao of Heaven" chapter:
Long ago, Shun asked Yao, "How does the Heavenly King employ his mind?"
Yao replied, "I do not scorn the friendless, nor abandon the destitute; I grieve for the dead, cherish the young, and pity women. This is how I employ my mind."
Shun said, "Noble indeed, yet it is not great."
Yao asked, "Then how should it be?"
Shun said, "Manifesting Heavenly virtue, one emerges in tranquility—sun and moon shine, the four seasons proceed, as day and night follow their constant course, clouds drift and rain falls."
Yao said, "How entangled and troubled I am! You are in union with Heaven; I am in union with man. Now, Heaven and Earth are what the ancients held greatest, what the Yellow Emperor, Yao, and Shun all esteemed. Thus, those who in ancient times ruled all under Heaven—what did they do? They simply followed Heaven and Earth."

The "Carving Intent" chapter states: *"Emptiness and tranquility accord with Heavenly virtue."* It also says: *"The utmost in refinement and penetration unites with Heavenly principle."* Lu Xixing remarked: "Manifesting Heavenly virtue to emerge in tranquility means governing by Heavenly virtue so that the myriad things are naturally at peace. Heaven’s virtue is non-action and spontaneity—thus the sun and moon shine of themselves, the four seasons proceed of themselves, day and night follow their constant course of themselves, clouds drift of themselves, and rain falls of themselves. Without intent toward things, the myriad things are naturally at peace. The movement of the Heavenly Dao accumulates nothing; the virtue of one who rules others is likewise. Truly, this is union with Heaven, not union with man."

Xuanjing said: Governing the state and governing the self follow the same principle. Heavenly virtue is the mind of Heaven. To unite with the mind of Heaven is to be empty and spontaneous, with the fire-phase purely of the prior-heaven, making return easy. To unite with the human mind is to generate intent and cling to forms, purely forced and contrary to spontaneity, step by step falling into the posterior-heaven, so that the effect of return is difficult to see. The phrase *"manifesting Heavenly virtue to emerge in tranquility"* is most wondrous: if one’s path accords with the mind of Heaven, then though one emerges, in stillness there is stability, in activity there is stability—within the four dignities, there is stability at all times. This is the meaning of *"held by the Great Stability."*

Thus, emptiness and tranquility, the wondrous nature serene and unobstructed, quiescent illumination forgetting knowledge, acting without hindrance—though engaged in activity, one is not burdened by existence; though abiding in non-action, one does not drown in nothingness. Neither clinging to existence nor nothingness, nor dwelling in the mean, one may transcend and be at ease. Baozhenzi said: "Now, man is indeed minute. What makes one a Heavenly immortal is that one’s mind is Heaven’s mind, and one must restore one’s original nature. Failing to restore one’s original nature, one drifts to the ends of emotion. Restoring nature is the way to Heaven; drifting in emotion is the way to man. As for man—you alone examine how the Master employed his mind: how much was it like man, and how much like Heaven? Abandon the human, approach the Heavenly. When the mind is wholly Heaven, this is how one becomes a true person. When man attains the true, one may speak of Heavenly immortals."

Xuanjing said: With emotion present, one is an ordinary person; with emotion forgotten, one is a sage-immortal. Forgetting emotion and extinguishing perceptions is the secret essential for turning the ordinary into the sagely. As for the practice, it lies solely in the single practice of harmonious samādhi. Mind and breath interdepend, and through extreme dependence, they transform. Breath has no exhalation or inhalation, thought has no arising or ceasing. Serenely entering samādhi, body and mind are both quiescent, inner and outer are forgotten together, person and dharma are both relinquished, principle and phenomenon are both extinguished, realm and wisdom are wondrously empty—this may be called abandoning the human and uniting with Heaven. One who unites with Heaven is of the same substance as the Great Void, of the same function as Heaven and Earth. Being of the same substance means the Dao is pervasively one; being of the same function means acting without intent. Master Miaozheng said: *"Responding without intent, extinguishing illumination yet awareness is complete—unless one has reached the ultimate of the Dao, cast off the body, and has no dependence, one cannot easily speak of this."*

**135. True Emptiness and Obdurate Emptiness**

True emptiness and obdurate emptiness: one has creation, the other has no creation; one is perfect emptiness, the other is severed emptiness. Regarding practice, true emptiness means external breathing ceases, spirit and qi unite in stability, thought and念 are both extinguished, and nature and life become one. When extreme stillness moves, at the moment when the single yang returns, the wondrous manifests. Here, existence and nothingness are one, the wondrous aperture is the same mystery. Wuyuanzi said: *"A bright moon in the sky illuminates the mind of Heaven; at midnight, thunder shakes the divine continent."* This accords with the wondrousness of true emptiness that is not empty. Thus, true emptiness fuses existence into emptiness, in the utmost nothingness contains the utmost existence—empty yet not empty, substance and function are one, the subtle and manifest are without gap. Here, there is inexhaustible life, boundless creation. The *Great Penetration Sutra*, "True Emptiness" chapter, states: *"Born before Heaven, born yet without form; existing after Heaven, existing yet without substance. Yet without substance, it has never existed. Thus it is called inconceivable."* It also says: *"Embracing the myriad images in its body, not clinging to a single thread."* And: *"When mind is extinguished, nature appears, like space without form. Profoundly and perfectly full."*

Fuqiuweng said: *"True emptiness is without self; greatly returning, greatly restoring, it is wholly one qi, returning to unite with the prior-heaven."* This is the wondrous purport of true emptiness. As for obdurate emptiness, it is the kind of biased stillness and sinking emptiness—dim and dull, merely suppressing thoughts from arising, the mind like still water. The ancients compared it to dead water that does not harbor dragons, and rightly so. What is called *"the body like withered wood, the mind like dead ashes"* is this. Thus, there is no life, no creation. The modern school of desiccated Chan precisely accords with this image.

It requires entering the great samādhi of breathless stillness, where practice deepens until body and mind are utterly quiescent and unmoving. Both self and dharmas are relinquished, and the wondrous emptiness of realm and wisdom arises, within and without alike, forming the symbol ○. Original yang daily grows, achieving the wondrous nine restorations. External restoration and internal return proceed simultaneously, bathing and sealing without need for arrangement.

Thus, Master Zhongli said: *"The myriad things flourish, each returning to its root. Master Qianxu of the Eastern Ancestry composed *The Southern Florescence’s Supplementary Ink*, entirely expounding the wondrous discourse on true emptiness. Formerly, Master Wang instructed his inner disciples, also emphasizing true emptiness as the most crucial technique, calling it the mysterious pivot of elixir methods, the secret key of return, the path to perfection, and the swiftest route to enlightenment.

Yet, surveying ancient and modern elixir texts, those speaking of dragon-tiger, lead, and mercury are ubiquitous, while those revealing true emptiness are as rare as morning stars—why is this? Dongshan said: *"Embodying true emptiness requires no forging."* Wan Hui said: *"True emptiness does not destroy the nature of numinous wisdom; wondrous function is ever constant, without contrivance."* The *"Heavenly Gate"* passage in the *Zhuangzi*—*"Exiting without root, entering without aperture, inherently substantial yet without location, inherently long yet without origin or end"*—also illustrates the meaning of true emptiness.

Embodying true emptiness is the non-dual dharma-gate of Chan and the mysterious. Upon reaching true emptiness, *"the cosmos is in hand, the myriad transformations arise in the body"*—this attains the dynamic function of the *Yinfu Jing*. **136. Holding the Rear to Whip the Rear**

The *Liezi*’s "Explaining Symbols" chapter states: "Master Liezi studied under Hujiu Zilin. Hujiu Zilin said, ‘If you understand *holding the rear*, then we may speak of *holding the self*.’ Liezi replied, ‘I wish to hear about *holding the rear*.’ He said, ‘Observe your shadow, and you will know.’ Liezi turned and beheld his shadow: when the body was bent, the shadow was crooked; when the body was straight, the shadow was upright. Thus, crookedness and straightness follow the body and do not lie in the shadow; bending and extending depend on the object and not on the self. This is called *holding the rear to abide in the forefront*."

Explanation: Breath arises from the heart (the ancients, in creating the character for *breath* [息], made it from *self* [自] and *heart* [心], imbued with profound meaning). When breath is regulated, the heart is still; when the heart is agitated, breath is coarse; when the heart is calm, breath is fine. Breath and heart are like shadow and form. Thus, the interdependence of heart and breath is the secret of *holding the rear*. If one can hold the rear, one returns to the prior-heaven and abides in the prior-heaven—this is the wondrous Dao of the posterior-heaven returning to the prior-heaven.

Some say: *Holding the rear to abide in the forefront* is the purport of the old sage’s teaching, *"Putting the self last, one finds oneself first."* Thus, in the profound tradition’s cultivation, heart and breath externally interdepend to reach the state of true emptiness—this is the esoteric principle of *holding the rear to abide in the forefront*.

The *Zhuangzi*’s "Attaining Life" chapter states: "Tian Kaizhi visited Duke Wei of Zhou. The Duke said, ‘I have heard that Zhu Shen was a student of nurturing life. You have associated with Zhu Shen—what have you learned from him?’ Tian Kaizhi replied, ‘I merely sweep the courtyard with a broom—what could I have learned from the Master?’ The Duke said, ‘Master Tian, do not be modest. I wish to hear it.’ Kaizhi said, ‘I heard the Master say: *One who is good at nurturing life is like a shepherd—he watches those behind and whips them* (by whipping those behind, the ones ahead are pressed forward, and the flock moves steadily along).’ The Duke said, ‘What does this mean?’ Tian Kaizhi replied, ‘In Lu there was a man named Shan Bao who dwelt in the mountains and drank from streams, neither contending with others for profit. At seventy, he still had the complexion of an infant. Unfortunately, he encountered a starving tiger, which killed and devoured him. There was also a man named Zhang Yi who frequented the gates of the wealthy and poor alike, yet at forty, he died of internal heat. Bao nurtured his inner self, yet the tiger consumed his outer; Yi nurtured his outer, yet illness attacked his inner.’"

**137. Mutual Propulsion and Mutual Overcoming**
*The Book of Changes* elucidates how yin and yang mutually propel one another to generate creation. As it says: “When the sun departs, the moon arrives; when the moon departs, the sun arrives—sun and moon mutually propel one another, and brightness arises. When cold departs, heat arrives; when heat departs, cold arrives—cold and heat mutually propel one another, and the year is completed.” It also says: “Hard and soft mutually propel one another to produce change.” All these are examples. The final section of *The Classic of Yin Conformity* clarifies how yin and yang mutually overcome one another to return to the unknowable true emptiness of yin and yang. Thus it says: “The art of yin and yang mutually overcoming is luminously manifest, advancing beyond images.” This reveals how yin and yang, in mutual containment, both perish—neither existence nor nonexistence, neither brightness nor darkness, neither arising nor ceasing—precisely the wondrous principle of transcending duality through opposition. Mutual propulsion follows the natural course; mutual overcoming reverses it. Mutual propulsion creates duality—this is the Dao of the *Changes*. Mutual overcoming dissolves duality—this is the Dao of the Elixir. Mutual propulsion entails sequence; mutual overcoming occurs simultaneously. Heart and breath interdependent, nature and life united—this is the image of mutual overcoming.

**138. Ancient Origin and Doubtful Origin**
*Laozi* says: “Meet it, yet you do not see its beginning; follow it, yet you do not see its end. Grasp the ancient Dao to steer the present being. To know the ancient origin is called the discipline of the Dao.” *Zhuangzi* says: “From singing I heard of the Dark and Vast; from the Dark and Vast I heard of the Threefold Void; from the Threefold Void I heard of the Doubtful Origin.”

The commentary states: The nameless is the origin of Heaven and Earth. Though called an origin, it is in truth without beginning or end. Hence it is said: “Meet it, yet you do not see its beginning; follow it, yet you do not see its end.” This is the true emptiness of the Limitless, the source of the Great Dao, the root of nature and life. In cultivation, to unite with the ancient origin is to awaken obscurely to the original awakening. The Doubtful Origin, though without origin, differs in name from the Ancient Origin but shares the same meaning.

**139. Inner and Outer Restraint**
*Zhuangzi*’s “Gengsang Chu” chapter says: “Those who are outwardly restrained (韄, pronounced *huò*, meaning bound) cannot be seized with haste, for they will turn inward to close themselves off. Those who are inwardly restrained cannot be seized with entanglement, for they will turn outward to close themselves off. Those who are both inwardly and outwardly restrained—even the power of virtue cannot sustain them, let alone those who abandon the Dao and act recklessly!”

Lu Xixing says: “In learning, the essential point lies in forgetting both inner and outer restraints entirely. When one is fettered within, it is called inner restraint; when fettered without, it is called outer restraint. *Huò* refers to binding things with leather. The human heart should be empty, still, and tranquil. If, upon encountering things, it cannot pass beyond without lingering, it is seized by grasping and taking—thus the heart is bound by outer restraint. Seeking the original substance amid this restless disturbance is like an object resisting within: the inner is already full, so it closes inward and does not open. If one moves with desire and cannot flow with transformation, thoughts churn ceaselessly—the heart is bound by inner restraint. Seeking the original substance amid this entanglement is like having already been touched by sensation: external conditions are hard to sever, so it closes outward and is difficult to release. *Zhuo* means to seek; *jian* (pronounced *jié*) means to fasten securely. Such newly coined expressions are like clouds drifting beyond the sunset—certainly not something those who consume cooked food could articulate. ‘Those who are both inwardly and outwardly restrained—even the power of virtue cannot sustain them’ means that when inner and outer are both fettered, even those who possess virtue cannot maintain themselves, let alone those who follow the Dao. To possess virtue is to have cleansed oneself thoroughly, naturally free from restraint—this is likely a hypothetical statement.”

Xuanjing says: The above explanations of principle are already quite clear. In sum, outer restraint means circumstances that melt the heart; inner restraint means the heart that clings to circumstances. When the dust of circumstances is empty, outer restraint dissolves; when the mind’s perceptions are forgotten, inner restraint vanishes. Only when both heart and circumstances are forgotten do inner and outer become empty together, and wisdom shines forth. In the cultivation and realization of the Mystery School, one first empties body and mind, then simultaneously liberates inner and outer roots and dust. The work must proceed through the interdependence of heart and breath, gradually entering realization. Once great samadhi is constant, inner and outer naturally merge, and principle cannot restrain what is restrained or close what is closed. As Li Daochun said: “When the heart is still, one realizes non-arising.”
