Just ask yourself: does this accord with the ancient sages’ principle of *"great compassion as foremost"* and their teaching of *"constantly excelling in saving beings"*? If you admire and emulate the sages’ way of *"long life and enduring vision"* yet reject and discard their injunctions to *"practice great compassion, save all beings, and remain tranquil and free from desire,"* then you become self-serving and profit-seeking, turning your back on the sages and betraying the Dao. In such a case, your virtue will be insufficient, and you will find it difficult to attain immortality.

If you truly desire long life, you must also wish for every being to enjoy long life and fulfill its true nature. Only then will you align with the spirit of great compassion. Among those who have eloquently discussed immortality, none surpass *Baopuzi*. In its second scroll, *"On Immortality,"* it states: *"The method of learning immortality requires tranquility, joy, and detachment, cleansing oneself of cravings and desires."* It further says: *"The Dao of immortality demands love extended even to creeping insects, never harming any sentient being."* And again: *"The Dao of immortality requires abstaining from foul and rank foods, fasting to purify the intestines."*

In *"Subtle Principles,"* it declares: *"Those who seek long life must accumulate merit, cultivate compassion toward all beings, extend empathy to others, and show kindness even to insects."* All these teachings align perfectly with the *Daodejing*. Yet if one kills beings to nourish oneself, how far does this stray from the precepts of *"kindness extended to insects, love extended to creeping things, never harming sentient beings"*? And how far does it depart from the admonition to *"cleanse oneself of cravings and desires"*?

Master Sanfeng said: *"A kind heart surpasses kind words; embody the noble person’s teaching to distance oneself from the kitchen."* He continues: *"Nurturing qi naturally nourishes the body; one should follow the perfected person’s prohibition against foul odors."* This clearly shows that harmonious food suffices to nourish the five viscera, rendering unnecessary the *Inner Canon*’s dictum that *"those deficient in essence should supplement it with flavors."*

The *"perfected person’s prohibition against foul odors"* means abstaining from meat, as the *Analects* states: *"Food of displeasing color or foul odor is not eaten."* Between mouth and heart, a kind heart is naturally superior to kind words. Yet how much more sublime is it to observe the precepts with urgency, cultivating both heart and speech in perfect harmony!

chunks.original_text: 予睹丰翁出语无极圆融，君只执其上句，而遗其下文，则成偏见矣。 “酒肉穿肠道在心”当看重下三字。 今之人，酒肉穿腹，心中无道，只贪口味而纵五欲，与三丰境界相去悬殊，似未可执此而生异议也。 总之，仙佛皆重清净心，口既贪乎鱼肉，目必贪乎五色，耳亦贪乎五声。 日在五欲境界中吸引，恐与清净心不相应耳。 何况杀生增加冤对，我既害彼，彼必思害我，因果循环，丝毫不爽。 我辈修道，急欲清理宿欠，减轻业障，岂可再添新债乎？ 仆自十九岁学道，一向随缘吃荤。 直至二十七岁时，得清初周安士所着《万善资集》（此书极好），洛诵再三，恻隐之心，油然而生。 觉杀生以养己命，非大慈之旨，有损天和，损阴德，违孔老仁慈之教，急宜改辙。 不意积习既久，茹素数日即思荤，乃因时制宜，时荤时素，一面停止杀生，鱼虾等一切生物皆不买。 且每月有余钱时，购而放生焉。 如是年余，方吃净素，迄今十七八年矣。 仙佛皆以慈心胜，视物如己，古有慈心仙人，及太乙救苦天尊，君若以慈为宗，则断荤止杀，不成问题。 岂可以仙经所无而疑之乎？ 孔子曰：“忠恕违道不远，施诸己而不愿，亦勿施于人”。 曾子曰：“夫子之道，忠恕而已矣”。 且不谈高深理论，谚云：“将心比心”。 君既不愿被人伤害或杀死，而日以利刃加诸无力抵抗之小动物，是不恕也。 老圣教人慈救慈卫，而君背之，且杀生命以充口腹，是不忠也。 一切蠢动含灵，皆有觉性。 此觉性与果地圣人，初无二致。 毁灭有情，是不仁也。 故此问题，与修德方面，甚有关系。 若谓人道不具足，而能得成仙道，仆窃疑之。 五、仙佛修证，差别之点，请示知？ 答：毕竟水朝东海去，到头云定觅山归。 六、仙佛修证，高下何如？ 答：云定家家月，春来树树花。 七、学仙有碍经世否？ 经世有碍学仙否？ 答：竹密不妨流水过，山高岂碍白云飞？ 八、如何是道人家风？ 答：行须缓步，语要低声，息息相顾，心心离念，一旦撒手归山，方显逍遥自在。 九、我公丹书，想阅过不少，最相契者何书？ 答：《白真人集》。 十、《道书十七种》，究竟是正是邪？ 答：曾游龙藏，自然到眼立分。 若其生长荜门，且任目迷五色。 最忌如猪八戒吃人参果，一口吞下，反问人是何滋味？ 滋味且置，试道人参果为何必生在五庄观？ 五庄观是甚么？ 人参果是甚么？ （按：《道书十七种》当是清·傅金铨所撰辑《济一子证道秘书十七种》，简称《道书十七种》。 内收有《玄微心印》及《三丰丹诀》等，均是人元阴阳法派之专着。 是故，既问《道书十七种》是正是邪，即是云阴阳丹法正邪耳。 海印子答曰：“曾游龙藏，自然到眼立分”。 自然有很清楚的认识，是正是邪，却未明断，当自有不言之隐衷。 从其措辞看，并未力断是邪，尤引“五庄观”、“人参果”云云，启人慧目，耐人寻味也。 ——盛克琦识） 附录二、 答友人书五通   海印山人 一   通 清王梦楼一生学佛，至八十以后又学仙，与仙人往来都有诗。 来函谓“何为老而趋下”等语，是义不然。 学道在解决老病死三种苦难。 年至八十，亦已老矣，精神不济，步履维艰，饮食不畅。 耳目失其聪明，发白面皱，去死不远矣。
chunks.translated_text:
I observe that Master Feng’s words are boundlessly harmonious, yet you cling only to his opening line while neglecting what follows—this becomes a one-sided view. The phrase *"wine and meat pass through the intestines, but the Dao resides in the heart"* should be weighed by its final three characters. Today’s people let wine and meat fill their bellies while their hearts remain devoid of the Dao, indulging only in flavors and yielding to the five desires. Their state is worlds apart from Master Sanfeng’s realm, so one cannot seize upon this line to raise objections.

In essence, both immortals and buddhas prize a pure and tranquil heart. If the mouth craves fish and meat, the eyes will crave the five colors, and the ears will crave the five sounds. Dwelling daily amid the realm of the five desires, one risks losing resonance with the pure heart. Moreover, killing living beings accumulates karmic enmity: if I harm others, they will seek to harm me in turn. Cause and effect circulate without the slightest deviation. We who cultivate the Dao must urgently clear our past debts and lighten our karmic obstructions—how can we incur new ones?

I myself began studying the Dao at nineteen, eating meat as circumstances allowed. Not until twenty-seven did I encounter *The Myriad Goodnesses Resource Collection* by Zhou Anshi of the early Qing—a most excellent book. After reading it repeatedly, a heart of compassion arose spontaneously within me. I realized that killing to sustain one’s own life contradicts the great compassionate principle, harms heavenly harmony, depletes hidden virtue, and violates the benevolent teachings of Confucius and Laozi. It was time to change course.

Yet old habits die hard. After a few days of vegetarianism, cravings for meat returned. Adapting to the circumstances, I alternated between meat and vegetarian meals, while ceasing to kill any living beings—no fish, shrimp, or other creatures were purchased. Whenever I had spare money each month, I bought animals to release in acts of liberation. After more than a year of this practice, I finally adopted a pure vegetarian diet, which I have maintained for seventeen or eighteen years now.

Both immortals and buddhas triumph through a heart of compassion, seeing all beings as oneself. Ancient legends speak of the Compassionate Immortal and the Heavenly Worthy of Great Compassion Who Saves from Suffering. If you take compassion as your guiding principle, then abstaining from meat and refraining from killing will pose no difficulty. How can you doubt this simply because it is absent from the immortals’ scriptures?

Confucius said: *"Loyalty and forbearance are not far from the Dao. What you do not wish for yourself, do not impose upon others."* Zengzi said: *"The Master’s Dao consists solely of loyalty and forbearance."* Setting aside profound theories, the proverb says: *"Put yourself in another’s place."* If you do not wish to be harmed or killed, yet daily wield blades against defenseless creatures, this is a failure of forbearance. The ancient sages taught compassion and protection, yet you turn your back on them, slaughtering lives to fill your belly—this is a failure of loyalty.

All creatures, however humble, possess sentience. This sentience is no different in essence from that of a sage who has attained the fruit. To destroy sentient beings is to lack benevolence. Thus, this matter bears profoundly on the cultivation of virtue. If you claim that one whose humanity is incomplete can still attain the immortal Dao, I remain skeptical.

**Five:** What distinguishes the cultivation and realization of immortals and buddhas?
**Answer:** After all, water flows eastward to the sea; in the end, clouds must seek their mountain home.

**Six:** How do the attainments of immortals and buddhas compare in superiority?
**Answer:** When clouds settle, every home has its moon; when spring arrives, every tree blooms with flowers.

**Seven:** Does studying immortality hinder worldly engagement? Does worldly engagement hinder the study of immortality?
**Answer:** Dense bamboo does not obstruct flowing water; how can high mountains block the flight of white clouds?

**Eight:** What constitutes the family style of a Daoist?
**Answer:** Walk with unhurried steps, speak in a low voice, attend to each breath, and distance the heart from thoughts. Only when you cast off all ties and return to the mountains will true freedom and ease manifest.

**Nine:** You must have read many alchemical texts—with which do you most resonate?
**Answer:** *The Collected Works of Master Bai*.

**Ten:** Regarding *The Seventeen Daoist Books*, are they orthodox or heterodox?
**Answer:** One who has wandered through the Dragon Canon will naturally discern at a glance. But if one was born in a thatched hut, let them be dazzled by the five colors. The worst is like Zhu Bajie eating the ginseng fruit—swallowing it whole and then asking what it tasted like! Never mind the taste—why must the ginseng fruit grow in the Wuzhuang Temple? What is the Wuzhuang Temple? What is the ginseng fruit?

At such a time, if someone could relieve one’s immediate suffering, the heart would gladly follow. This is the natural inclination of human nature. Menglou had a deep affinity for Chan, yet in his exchanges with immortals, they must have transmitted to him arts for prolonging life and dispelling illness—methods for regulating breath and calming the spirit—so that he might attain true benefit and resolve the vexations of old age and sickness. While the Buddha’s teachings are lofty, many discuss its principles, but few have realized them in practice. To claim that the sufferings of old age and sickness cannot be resolved, yet the suffering of death can; or that one cannot attain sagehood in this life, but can after death—these are nothing but self-deception and deceiving others.

The Daoist tradition values only the present moment: if one can calm the spirit and harmonize the breath to gain true benefit, the future will reveal itself without inquiry. Thus, the Daoist path is like a merchant acquiring goods—demanding immediate payment, not promissory notes, and disdaining credit. Today’s Buddhists, however, seek future rewards, rebirth after death, all relying on promissory notes. Yet when the note comes due, whether it can be honored remains uncertain. The proverb says, *"Rejecting cash in hand for credit"*—this perfectly captures the mindset of most Buddhists today.

Have you not read the *Sutra in Forty-Two Sections*, the earliest Buddhist text translated into Chinese? The Buddha asked how long a person’s life lasts, and none of his disciples’ answers satisfied him. Finally, one replied, *"It lasts but a single breath."* The Buddha praised him, saying he understood the Way. What does this mean? How is breath related to the Dao? Know this: where breath resides, the Dao resides. Since life exists in the space between breaths, why not, before the breath ceases, calm the spirit and regulate the breath to avoid bankruptcy? If one waits until the breath is cut off, the cash is already spent. Even with a promissory note, where can it be redeemed? How can one bear to wait for bankruptcy—is this not delusion?

**Second Letter**

Your letter says that *"life lasts but a single breath"* merely illustrates its brevity—*"the incoming breath does not guarantee the outgoing."* My brother, you have grasped only half of it. If the Buddha meant only to speak of brevity, he would have said, *"Excellent! You understand time,"* not *"Excellent! You understand the Way."* Clearly, this is not a matter of time.

The Dao resides in the space between breaths—this is the meaning of *"regulating breath and calming the spirit."* Breath is the wind-like aspect of the heart-mind. When breath is regulated, the heart-mind is settled; when breath is harmonious, the heart-mind is at peace. When one is enraged, the heart-mind rages, and the breath grows coarse. During a race, the heart-mind races, and the breath becomes short. The dead have no breath because the heart-mind has departed; the heart-mind in samadhi has no breath because it is quiescent. Thus, from having breath to regulating it until there is no breath—when external respiration ceases entirely—then the heart-mind has no arising or ceasing. With no arising or ceasing of the heart-mind, no inhalation or exhalation of breath, the state of great samadhi emerges, and the Dao abides there.

Have you not seen the words of Prajñātāra, the twenty-seventh patriarch of Chan, in reply to the King of East India? He said: *"This poor monk’s exhalation does not follow the myriad conditions; his inhalation does not dwell in the skandhas. Constantly turning the sutra thus for hundreds of thousands of millions of volumes—not merely one or two."* Prajñātāra took the regulation of inhalation and exhalation as the turning of the sutra—turning the sutra of one’s own body, not another’s. When spirit and breath are harmoniously blended, continuous yet imperceptible, the inner landscape is pure and still, the outer world empty and merged—is this not what is meant by *"exhalation does not follow the myriad conditions, inhalation does not dwell in the skandhas"*? This is the practice Laozi described as *"focusing qi to attain suppleness, embracing the soul and holding to the One."*

Turning another’s sutra brings great merit, but turning the sutra of one’s own true breath brings even greater merit. Turning the sutra of written words brings great merit, but turning the sutra of wordless truth brings even greater merit. Yet people abandon the near to seek the far, crave the lofty but neglect the practical. If one cannot even master a single breath, how can one speak of anything else?

Today, there are millions of Buddhists, yet all disregard the *Sutra in Forty-Two Sections*, dismissing it as too simple. The meaning of *"life lasts but a single breath"* eludes them entirely. They vainly hope to attain Buddhahood in this very body, yet possess not a shred of the capital required—like a pauper with not a single coin dreaming of becoming the owner of Yong’an Xianshi, the grandest amusement company before Liberation. How absurd!

The *Sutra in Forty-Two Sections* is the first step in Buddhist practice. Establishing the Dao within the space between breaths is its very essence. The Daoist *Huangting Jing* says: *"Behind lies the secret chamber, before the gate of life; sun emerges, moon enters—breath abides."* Chen Xubai said: *"Breath comes and goes without interruption; the sacred embryo is perfected, returning to the primordial."* Xu Jinyang said: *"Internally harmonize true qi with breath; naturally, the transformations restore youthful countenance."* Li Daochun said: *"Opening and closing respond to heaven and earth—this is the gate of the Mysterious Female. From no exit or entry, one alone reigns over the three realms."* And again: *"Carefully observe the books of the sages of the Three Teachings—the character ‘breath’ is simplest. If one works on the practice of breath, becoming a Buddha or an immortal requires no effort."* Zheng Heyang said: *"Where there is a heart-mind, there is breath; heart-mind and breath depend on each other and cannot be separated."*

Your letter suggests setting aside the Lesser Vehicle’s *Sutra in Forty-Two Sections* to discuss the Great Vehicle’s *Śūraṅgama Sūtra* and *Avataṃsaka Sūtra*. Very well—let us speak of these two.

Have you not seen that among the *Śūraṅgama*’s twenty-five sages who attained perfect penetration, two achieved the exhaustion of outflows and realized arhatship precisely through regulating the breath? The first was Śroṇa Koṭīkarṇa, who declared: *“When the Buddha asked about perfect penetration, as I have realized it, reversing the breath to merge with emptiness—this is foremost.”* The second was Sundarananda, who said: *“When the Buddha asked about perfect penetration, I dissolved my thoughts, and through long-continued breath-regulation, illumination arose, outflows were extinguished, and this—this is foremost.”* What is meant by “reversing the breath to merge with emptiness”? It is the cessation of external respiration, the transformation of qi into spirit, and the radiance of spirit-light.

Furthermore, in the *Śūraṅgama*’s ten stages of abiding, the phrase *“body and mind unite and grow daily”* describes the interdependence of heart-mind and breath in forming the sacred embryo. *“Having roamed within the Dao-embryo, one personally attends the lineage of awakening; as the embryo matures, the human marks are complete.”* It also states: *“The ten spiritual marks of the body are simultaneously perfected.”* And again: *“Having taken form and emerged from the embryo, one is personally a Buddha-child—this is called the abiding of the Dharma Prince.”* Here, the Dao-embryo is fully realized, and the true person appears.

People know only that the *Śūraṅgama* criticizes the ten kinds of immortals, yet they do not realize these immortals belong to the earthly immortals—mere Lesser Vehicle practitioners of immortality. The lineage transmitted beneath the pillar aligns with the *Śūraṅgama*’s ten stages of abiding. Within this profound mystery, those who receive the true transmission understand it for themselves. Among the Great Vehicle scriptures, none so wondrously accords with the esoteric teaching of *“regulating the breath to form the embryo, nurture the embryo, and emerge from the embryo”* as the *Śūraṅgama*.

The Tiantai school’s contemplative teachings hold that in a single lifetime, one can only attain the initial stage of perfect abiding. Yet in the esoteric tradition’s cultivation and realization, a single lifetime can indeed attain all ten stages of abiding. Those of superior capacity, having realized the ten stages, leap directly into the two wisdoms of equal and wondrous enlightenment. For once the ten stages of abiding are complete, one has attained the Dharma-body, with boundless lifespan—free to roam and cultivate the Dao. The most difficult part is entering the abiding from the state of an ordinary being. How does one enter the abiding? The abiding is constant abiding; if one dies, one does not understand constant abiding. Constant abiding is longevity—both life and nature are eternally abiding.

Setting aside the *Śūraṅgama* for now, let us turn to the *Avataṃsaka Sūtra*’s *Chapter on Leaving the Worldly*, which expounds the ten kinds of freedom. The first is *“freedom of life”*—abiding in lifespan for incalculable eons. Is this not the Buddha’s longevity? Have you not also seen in the *Entering the Dharma Realm* chapter that Sudhana visited the bhikṣu Ocean Banner, who had transcended inhalation and exhalation, without any other thoughts or perceptions, and entered the great quiescent samādhi, remaining in that samādhi for six months and six days before emerging? What is meant by *“transcending inhalation and exhalation, without any other thoughts or perceptions”* is precisely the esoteric tradition’s state of *“dual extinction of breath and thought, dual stabilization of body and mind”*—what Master Huzi called *“the Great Thoroughfare, without trace.”* The Great Thoroughfare is the image of emptiness and quiescence; *“without trace”* means no sign is discernible, like the antelope hanging its horns—no trail can be found. This great samādhi was attained by the bhikṣu Ocean Banner, and it is also attained by the esoteric tradition’s good spiritual friends. If, in samādhi, the heart-mind abides but the breath does not, this is only a semblance of quiescent extinction, not true quiescent extinction. Such a person, if their breath were obstructed during samādhi, would be unable to maintain it. Thus, only samādhi without breath is true samādhi. Samādhi with breath is worthless—still water does not harbor dragons. How could one then perfect the ten spiritual marks of the body simultaneously, emerge from the embryo, and personally become a Buddha-child?

Furthermore, in the *Entering the Dharma Realm* chapter, Sudhana’s fiftieth visit was to the youth Virtue-Born and the maiden Virtue-Girl. Their city was called *Wondrous Intention Flower Gate*, and the Dharma-gate they taught was called *Liberation through Illusory Abiding*—this too conceals the secret meaning of *“heart-mind and breath interdependent, harmonizing in samādhi.”* Observe that all the good spiritual friends Sudhana had previously visited were solitary individuals, but here they appear as a pair—what else could this signify but the representation of one yin and one yang, the symbolic harmony of heart-mind and breath? The youth and maiden lived and traveled together. In terms of cultivation, at the stage of fruition, samādhi and wisdom harmonize as a pair; at the stage of practice, heart-mind and breath harmonize as a pair. The word *“wondrous”* is also symbolic—it is one yin and one yang. *“Wondrous Intention Flower Gate”* is akin to the Laozi’s *“Gate of the Myriad Wonders”* and *“Mysterious Female Gate.”* At the moment when heart-mind and breath harmonize, there arises a subtle mutual awareness. When, in quiescent stabilization, yang is born, the time arrives and spirit knows—like a child recognizing its mother. It is wondrous beyond words—is this not *“wondrous intention”*? Heart-mind and breath follow each other, phoenixes in harmony, a natural union of husband and wife. Yet the man does not loosen his robe, nor the woman untie her sash—they revere each other as divine, cherish each other as their own child. Is this not *“illusory abiding”*? Thus it is called *“liberation through illusory abiding.”* Only when one reaches the great samādhi, the true samādhi—without going or coming, without exiting or entering, forgetting both inner and outer, body and mind both quiescent, emptiness without reliance—is this called *“non-abiding.”* From illusory abiding, one attains non-abiding—here, the work of esoteric cultivation is complete.

The sūtra further states: *“At that time, the youth and maiden, having expounded their own liberation, used the power of inconceivable roots of goodness to make Sudhana’s body soft and radiant.”* The commentary explains: *“Softness”* refers to the state where, through the interdependence of heart-mind and breath, the entire body becomes supple and pliant. Bai Ziqing said: *“After you practice for two or three days, heaven and earth, sun and moon will become soft as silk.”* This is the true effect.

chunks.original_text: 光泽乃元阳光气之发乎肌肤，见于外表之谓也。 《黄庭经》云：“体生光华气香兰”，钟离翁云：“玉膏流润生光明”，同此意也。 此第五十参之象，甚契玄宗的旨。 但自来疏《华严》者，均言性理，以童男童女表定慧。 而因地凡夫，实无定慧，将如何下手进修乎？ 妙意华门城，亦人人有之。 经师指破玄关一窍，自然知也。 此种深密之表象，外人固未易与言。 故二十年来，弟亦从未揭示，恐生谤故。 兹为我兄言之，庶几别有乾坤，壶中日月，幻住解脱，真有不可思议之神效矣。 四   通 来函云：“仙贵长生，佛贵无生”。 须知无生，只是不着生相，非谓如枯木寒灰，毫无生气。 若果如枯木寒灰，即落空亡之外道，非佛氏不生不灭之的旨也。 老子曰：“天地之所以长且久者，以其不自生，故能长生”。 所谓不自生者，即不执着生，真生而无生也。 《永嘉证道歌》云：“谁无念，谁无生，着实无生无不生”。 此谓苟证无生之理，则亦无死，乃无生无不生也。 是则老氏之长生，非落常见； 佛氏之无生，亦非落断见。 无生而生，佛也； 生而无生，仙也。 奚可打成两橛，而分优劣耶？ 知乎此，即知无佛而不仙，无仙而不佛，真无生即得真长生，真长生即妙契真无生，仙佛两宗，至此藩篱可以尽撤矣。 今之释氏门徒，一闻长生，则斥为外道，非佛本旨。 不知佛为执着命元，情见未破者，示以无生。 若情见已破，正好示以长生。 《法华》开权显实，《华严》情量破尽，皆示命自在之秘旨。 最后说涅盘，则以入大涅盘，不老不死，与东土黄老，心心相印。 奚可泥执一边，以无生归佛，长生归老，尊视无生而藐视长生乎？ 须知无生、长生，不过折摄门庭不同而已。 五   通 《楞严》《华严》，固已仙佛交参矣； 然尤妙者，当推《大涅盘》。 迦叶问佛：“云何得长寿，金刚不坏身，复以何因缘，得大坚固力？ ”是公然问长生矣。 《四相品》云：“譬如陶师，作已还破。 解脱不尔，真解脱者，不生不灭，是故解脱即是如来。 如来亦尔，不生不灭，不老不死，不破不坏，非有为法，以是义故，名曰如来。 入大涅盘，不老不死，有何等义？ 老者名曰迁变，发白而皱，身坏命终。 如是等法，解脱中无，以无是事，故名解脱。 如来亦无发白面皱有为之法，是故如来无有老也。 无有老故，则无有死。 又解脱者，名曰无病。 所谓病者，四百四病，及余外来侵害损身者，是处无故，故名解脱。 无疾病者，即真解脱。 真解脱者，即是如来。 如来无病，是故法身亦无有病。 如是无病，即是如来。 死者名曰身坏命终，是处无死，即是甘露。 是甘露者，即真解脱。 真解脱者，即是如来。 如来成就如是功德，云何当言如来无常？ 若言无常，无有是处，是金刚身，云何无常？ 是故如来不名命终。 ” 此节如来广示得真解脱者，不生不灭，不破不坏，不老不死，无有发白面皱等丑态。 无有疾病，与仙长生无二无别，可称仙佛沆瀣一气，水乳交融者矣。 奈何今之学佛者，高自标榜，藐视仙宗，目为外道，斥为七趣。 而自身疾病之来，既不能免，发白面皱等迁变，亦不能免，与俗人初无有别。 大涅盘之为何？ 真解脱之为何？ 甘露之妙，更不必谈矣。

The radiance refers to the effervescence of primordial yang’s luminous *qi* upon the skin, manifesting externally. *The Yellow Court Scripture* states: *“The body generates radiant splendor, its qi fragrant as orchids.”* Master Zhongli Quan said: *“Jade-like nectar flows and glistens, giving rise to luminosity.”* Both express the same meaning. This is the sign of the fiftieth visitation, deeply resonant with the esoteric Daoist tradition. Yet all previous commentators on the *Avataṃsaka Sūtra* have spoken only of principle, interpreting the youth and maiden as symbols of *samādhi* and *prajñā*. But for those still in the causal stage—ordinary beings without *samādhi* or *prajñā*—how should they begin their practice? The wondrous gateway of the Flower Adornment City exists within every person. Once the masters point out the mysterious pass, one naturally understands. Such profound and subtle manifestations are not easily discussed with outsiders. For this reason, over the past twenty years, I have never revealed this, fearing it might invite slander. Now, for my brother’s sake, I speak of it—perhaps you may glimpse another heaven and earth, the sun and moon within the gourd, the liberation of illusory abiding, and the truly inconceivable spiritual efficacy.

---

Your letter states: *“The immortals value longevity, while Buddhists value non-arising.”* Know that “non-arising” means not clinging to the appearance of arising, not that one becomes like withered wood or cold ashes, utterly devoid of vitality. If one were truly like withered wood or cold ashes, one would fall into the nihilistic heterodoxy, far from the Buddha’s true intent of neither arising nor ceasing. Laozi said: *“That by which heaven and earth endure so long is their non-self-arising; thus they attain long life.”* “Non-self-arising” means not clinging to arising—true arising without arising. *The Song of Enlightenment by Yongjia* says: *“Who is without thought? Who is without arising? Truly, without arising, there is nothing that does not arise.”* This means that if one realizes the principle of non-arising, one is also without death—thus, without arising yet nothing unarisen. In this light, Laozi’s “long life” does not fall into eternalism, nor does the Buddha’s “non-arising” fall into annihilationism. Without arising yet arising—this is the Buddha; arising yet without arising—this is the immortal. How can one rigidly divide them and rank their superiority? Understanding this, one knows there is no immortal who is not a Buddha, no Buddha who is not an immortal. True non-arising is true long life; true long life is wondrous accord with true non-arising. At this point, the barriers between the Daoist and Buddhist traditions may be entirely dismantled.

Nowadays, followers of the Buddha, upon hearing of longevity, dismiss it as heterodoxy, contrary to the Buddha’s original intent. They do not realize that the Buddha, for those attached to the vital essence and whose emotional views remain unbroken, teaches non-arising. But if one’s emotional views are already shattered, it is precisely then that one should be taught longevity. The *Lotus Sūtra* reveals the provisional to manifest the real; the *Avataṃsaka Sūtra* exhausts all emotional measures—both reveal the secret of the freely commanded life. In the final teaching of *Nirvāṇa*, entering great *nirvāṇa* means neither aging nor dying, perfectly in harmony with the Yellow and Lao of the East. How can one rigidly adhere to one side, assigning non-arising to Buddhism and longevity to Daoism, exalting non-arising while disparaging longevity? Know that non-arising and longevity are merely different approaches to cultivation and subjugation.

---

While the *Śūraṅgama* and *Avataṃsaka* sūtras already interweave the paths of immortals and Buddhas, the most wondrous of all is the *Mahāparinirvāṇa Sūtra*. Mahākāśyapa asked the Buddha: *“How does one attain long life, an indestructible vajra-body, and through what causes and conditions does one gain great, unshakable power?”*—this is openly inquiring about longevity. The *Four Marks Chapter* states: *“It is like a potter who, having made a vessel, eventually breaks it. Liberation is not like this. True liberation is neither arising nor ceasing; therefore, liberation is the Tathāgata. The Tathāgata is also thus: neither arising nor ceasing, neither aging nor dying, neither breaking nor decaying, not a conditioned dharma. For this reason, it is called the Tathāgata. Entering great *nirvāṇa*, neither aging nor dying—what does this mean? Aging is called change: hair turning white, skin wrinkling, body decaying, life ending. Such things do not exist in liberation; because they are absent, it is called liberation. The Tathāgata also has no conditioned dharmas like white hair or wrinkled skin; therefore, the Tathāgata is without aging. Without aging, there is no death. Furthermore, liberation is called freedom from illness. What is illness? The four hundred and four diseases, along with other external harms that injure the body—these do not exist in liberation; thus, it is called liberation. Without illness, this is true liberation. True liberation is the Tathāgata. The Tathāgata is without illness; therefore, the Dharma-body is also without illness. Such freedom from illness is the Tathāgata. Death is called the decay of the body and the end of life; where there is no death, this is ambrosia. Ambrosia is true liberation. True liberation is the Tathāgata. The Tathāgata possesses such merits—how can one say the Tathāgata is impermanent? If one claims impermanence, this is impossible. How can the vajra-body be impermanent? Therefore, the Tathāgata is not said to have a life’s end.”*

In this passage, the Tathāgata extensively demonstrates that those who attain true liberation are neither arising nor ceasing, neither breaking nor decaying, neither aging nor dying, and are free from the unsightly marks of white hair and wrinkled skin. Free from illness, this is no different from the immortals’ long life—one might say the immortal and the Buddha are of one breath, like water and milk perfectly blended. Yet how is it that today’s Buddhists, puffed up with self-importance, look down upon the immortal tradition as heterodoxy, dismissing it as one of the seven destinies? They themselves cannot escape illness, nor can they avoid the changes of white hair and wrinkled skin—no different from ordinary people. What, then, is the meaning of great *nirvāṇa*? What is true liberation? The wonder of ambrosia need not even be mentioned.

**Appendix III: An Entry from the Diary of Elder Li Tingguang**

Master Songyao said: “Mr. Wang Dongting propagated the Dao in Shanghai for decades yet could not attain the Way himself, his years having already declined into old age. When Master Hanxu arrived, he taught him the method of *tou-tai duo-she* (rebirth through seizing a womb). At the time of Mr. Dongting’s passing, he instructed him (referring to Xu Songyao) to seek him out at a certain time and place (referring to Wang Dongting). However, as war was imminent, he (Xu Songyao) was unable to go. I believe that as long as one does not forget their ‘original true nature,’ *tou-tai duo-she* remains possible.”

*(This diary entry was provided by Mr. Lin Feng of Shanghai. Mr. Li Tingguang once studied under Xu Songyao, also known as Haiyinzi. In the mid-20th century, Li Tingguang and six others—Jiang Weiqiao, Hu Meicheng, Lu Zidong, Chu Xiangjiang, Gu Boshu, and Lu Huaidao—formed the ‘Seven Gentlemen’s Tea Gathering for Nurturing Life,’ exploring Daoist scholarship. It is said that Li Hanxu, the founding patriarch of the Western Lineage, personally came to Shanghai to transmit the *tou-tai duo-she* method to Ti Zhen Shanren Wang Dongting. According to *A Brief Biography of the Perfected Li Hanxu* by Li Daoshan of the Qing, Li Hanxu ascended in the year *bingchen* of the Xianfeng era (1856). Yet he manifested again in the world no later than the mid-20th century to transmit the teaching to Wang Dongting, more than sixty or seventy years after his passing. Mr. Lin Feng commented on this passage: ‘Upon first reading this, I was truly startled.’ How could I not feel the same! This also demonstrates the extraordinary efficacy of the ancient transmission of inner alchemy, and the truth of self-mastery and rebirth of life is not false. Daoist scholar Chen Yingning (1880–1969) once remarked: ‘Whether *tou-tai* is truly reliable—rather than being troubled by the inability to verify it with facts, one can only believe it to be extraordinary.’ This case is no different. Whether it is true or not, I do not know. It is merely appended here as documentary material, left for scientific researchers to investigate and verify! Furthermore, the method of *tou-tai duo-she* comprises four types: *tou-tai* (rebirth), *duo-she* (seizing a body), *jie-shi* (borrowing a corpse), and *zhuan-shi* (transmigration)—collectively known as the ‘Four Fruits.’”)*

*—Gan Keqi’s note*

**Appendix IV: Excerpt from Mr. Hu Meicheng’s *Postscript to the Exegesis of Southern Lineage Alchemical Secrets***

“In the early 20th century, I made three journeys to Suzhou and personally visited Xu Songyao, the renowned Daoist scholar of Suzhou, Shanghai, and Hangzhou, known as Master Xuanjing. A graduate of Tsinghua University, Master Xu devoted his life to Daoist studies. In his later years, his disciples numbered in the thousands, and his *Collected Writings on Heavenly Joy* circulated widely. However, he avoided discussing the teachings of the Yin-Yang Lineage.”

“The inner alchemical practice of Daoism, whether in solitary or dual cultivation, hinges upon the critical stage of *huo-zi yang-sheng* (the living child’s arousal) and the gathering of the medicine. Yet many Daoist texts do not speak of this openly—it remains an untransmitted secret. The *huo-zi* moment has three types: the true *zi* hour, the proper *zi* hour, and the false *zi* hour. When the living child’s yang arises, one ignites the fire and gathers the medicine. The medicine itself varies in maturity, distinguished as one yang, two yangs, or three yangs. The medicine is called the ‘true seed,’ hence Zhang Ziyang’s *Awakening to Reality* verse: ‘If the cauldron lacks the true seed, do not waste the furnace’s fire on an empty pot.’ Without receiving the true transmission, many find it difficult to recognize the authentic phenomenon of *huo-zi yang-sheng* when gathering the medicine. For instance, Daoist scholar Xu Songyao’s *Collected Writings on Heavenly Joy* states that when the pure yang *qi* stirs during quiet cultivation, the body may experience numbness, tingling, or twitching, and with each twitch, one circulates a minor celestial orbit, gradually gathering and accumulating. Alas! Numbness, lightness, heaviness, and the like are common ‘eight sensations’ in cultivation. To mistake these eight sensations for the *huo-zi yang-sheng* and the gathering of medicine is entirely mistaken. …If one cultivates quiet practice and mistakes the eight sensations for the arousal of yang, then rousing the yang becomes harmful, allowing the original *qi* to leak away and all prior efforts to be wasted—truly a pity.”

*(This postscript by Mr. Hu Meicheng was provided by Mr. Lin Feng of Shanghai. Mr. Hu made three journeys to Suzhou to personally visit Xu Songyao and inquire about the teachings of the Yin-Yang Lineage, only to be told that Songyao ‘avoided discussing it.’ This avoidance was not due to ignorance of the Yin-Yang Lineage’s teachings but rather an unwillingness to speak of them, likely owing to unspoken difficulties. Consider Haiyin’s reply in *Answers to Ten Questions from Mr. Tang Muxuan*: when asked whether the *Seventeen Daoist Texts* were orthodox or heterodox, he said, ‘Having roamed the Dragon Treasury, one naturally distinguishes at a glance.’ Among the *Seventeen Daoist Texts* are included *The Heart Seal of the Mysterious Subtlety* and *The Alchemical Secrets of the Three Peaks*, both renowned works of the Yin-Yang Lineage. Since he claimed to ‘distinguish at a glance’ after perusing the Dragon Treasury, improper transmission would cause grave harm—hence his reticence.)*

Moreover, it is commonly held that the Western Lineage is a dual-cultivation school of Yin and Yang. According to my understanding, the Western Lineage divides into two major transmission systems: one advocates solitary cultivation, the other dual cultivation. Yet the solitary-cultivation school is not without profound mastery of Yin-Yang studies, while the dual-cultivation school must also grasp the essence of solitary practice. Given the differences in time, place, and external conditions, each follows its own path to realization, though all ultimately converge. Those lacking the necessary external conditions keep their insights deeply concealed, remaining reticent to avoid unnecessary interference. As the *Classic of Purity* states: “If one can abide in constant purity, Heaven and Earth all return.” If the essence of Heaven and Earth can be drawn in, how could the human element not be gathered as well?

In *The Precious Raft of Dual Cultivation for the Female Ancestor of the Mud-Pill Lineage*, compiled by Min Yide of the Qing in *Hidden Books of the Ancient Book Concealment Tower*, it is written: “Solitary cultivation is not the supreme Dao; of like kind, each naturally requires the other. Those who attain a body beyond the body can, through forgetfulness of form, accomplish all things.” It further states: “The human element pervades the great thousand worlds; the Three Elements are mastered by one heart. It is nothing beyond a heart serene and empty, nothing beyond a body free of obstruction. In movement and stillness, one harmonizes with the true constant; the self, without origin, naturally merges.” This teaching opens the eye of wisdom.

The Three Elements—Heaven, Earth, and Human—are such that “the human element pervades the great thousand worlds,” not confined to the crucible of the other household. The function of the Three Elements is entirely governed by the mastery of one heart. In essence, the method lies in “a heart serene and empty” and “a body free of obstruction,” which is to say, “forgetting both body and heart, entering the great samadhi of true emptiness”—this is none other than the principle that “if one can abide in constant purity, Heaven and Earth all return.” If one can “forget form” and attain the state of “a body beyond the body,” then “all things can be accomplished.” Solitary is not merely solitary, dual not merely dual; “of like kind, each naturally requires the other.” As the *Cantong Qi* says: “Like a lodestone drawing iron, though separated by barriers, they communicate in secret.”

Thus, within solitary cultivation there is no absence of the principle of dual cultivation, and within dual cultivation there is also the work of purity. True cultivators may well integrate this pure method into dual practice, cultivating together with another, “roaming together in the boundless wilds,” and both will surely benefit, achieving the feat of husband and wife ascending as immortals! Though the dual-cultivation school possesses additional techniques such as “forging the sword” and “regulating the crucible,” with their own subtle methods, these are not as stable and free of pitfalls as the aforementioned approach, which anyone can verify without the need for additional precepts or constraints. Is this not what is meant by “its meaning most profound yet its traces most evident”?

Mr. Hu Meicheng further criticized the error of mistaking “tingling, numbness, and throbbing” for the arising of Yang and the production of medicine. The secret meaning of “tingling, numbness, and throbbing” may be found in detail in the *Collection of Celestial Joy*. Discerning scholars will surely understand what is indicated; I need not elaborate further.

Wei Yao, a fellow disciple of Haiyin, states in *The True Transmission of the Great Dao*: “Since ancient times, those who write books and establish teachings have all addressed the ills of their time.” The critiques of Haiyin and Meicheng are likewise corrective words aimed at contemporary errors. Take, for example, *The Immortal Lineage of Wu-Liu*, which emphasizes the stirring of the external kidneys as a sign of Yang arising. Those who do not comprehend the wondrous workings of nature cling to appearances and forms, failing to reach the state of “attaining emptiness” before vainly seeking the arising of Yang, even falling into attachment to sensual forms—how then can they speak of “abiding in constant purity”?

Thus, Haiyin wrote his books to correct the ills of his time, merely designating “softness, numbness, and tingling” as signs of Yang arising, so as not to lead beginners into attachment to form. If, within “attaining utmost emptiness and maintaining profound stillness,” one experiences “softness, numbness, and tingling,” progressing to “softness and bliss,” then the arising of Yang and the production of medicine occur naturally, and the source of medicine is as clear as pure water. What Mr. Meicheng criticized was indeed the error of mistaking the “eight sensations” for the arising of Yang and the failure to recognize the true signs of Yang arising.

The eight sensations are merely phenomena of the initial stage of entering stillness, signs of the first circulation of qi and blood and the initial quieting of the mind—far from reaching the level of “Yang arising and medicine producing.” With Mr. Meicheng’s vast knowledge, he naturally understood Haiyin’s intentions. Therefore, while Mr. Hu Meicheng’s critique is valid, the teachings of Haiyin also contain profound principles.

Haiyinzi was a master of the Western School. His practice focused on external cultivation, fundamentally distinct from the Wu-Liu School’s method of guarding the lower dantian. What, then, is this "external cultivation"?

**Appendix VI: The Origins of Printing *The Celestial Music Collection***

Works on the esoteric arts abound like cattle filling a barn—many have I perused. Yet most conceal the mother in the child, veil the image in metaphor, and though readable, remain hard to grasp. Inevitably, one gropes like a blind man touching an elephant, misguessing and misconstruing, left only with a sense of gazing at the ocean and sighing in awe.

Last autumn, in the year *guichou*, I sought the Way from the Elder of Hidden Valley. He graciously revealed the wondrous discourse on esoteric practice, imparting the essential subtleties of harmonizing heart and breath, and lent me *The Celestial Music Collection*. A cursory reading of but a few chapters sufficed to open my eyes and illumine my mind. Only then did I realize that the elixir formulas transmitted by the sages of old indeed had worthy successors.

*The Celestial Music Collection* was composed by Master Xuanjing (Haiyin). Its contents are vast—reportedly spanning over one hundred scrolls in eight volumes. The copy I obtained comprises but a tenth of the whole. Yet even this partial glimpse reveals the culmination of the elixir formulas of all past sages. It dissects what earlier alchemical texts left unexamined, stripping away the skin to reveal the flesh, with every word guiding one toward sagehood. The arcane purports of the *Can Tong Qi*, *Wu Zhen Pian*, *Yin Fu Jing*, and *Dao De Jing* are laid bare without reservation. Every elixir formula and experiential insight is expounded in exhaustive detail—truly the great compendium of Daoist learning, the compass of elixir classics, and the key to the esoteric arts.

My fellow cultivator, Xueyangzi—though my senior in the lineage—is also my guide across the ford. The harmony of heart and breath, had he not first illuminated the path, how could I have grasped it so profoundly or embraced it so steadfastly? Bound by the fellowship of immortals, we resonate in voice and seek in kindred *qi*. All that we attain, we refine through mutual exchange, mutually enlightening one another as we advance together.

I lament that fine books are hard to obtain yet easily lost, while lesser scholars cling to the false and stray from the real. *The Celestial Music Collection* resounds like celestial music in the void, suffusing the spirit and nurturing nature. Yet how many lovers of the Way will ever have the chance to read it?

Mindful of the deep bonds with my immortal brethren—Yunzhongzi, Qiqiaoxing, and others—and unwilling to hoard such treasures alone, I resolved to commission the printing of several copies to share with kindred spirits, that we might ascend the cloud-path together. Yet, burdened by worldly affairs and myriad obstructions, I had already pledged to oversee the *Immortal Dao Monthly*—now this vow to print *The Celestial Music* weighs upon me as well. Torn between the two, I can but sigh in helplessness.

I consulted Xueyang, who, through the intercession of Tiyang, readily agreed without hesitation. Undaunted by the labor, he undertook to begin anew, and we settled on printing twenty copies. Such a noble-minded seeker of the Way, so generous in aiding the Dao, fills me with profound admiration and boundless gratitude.

Thus, I have prefaced this edition with a table of contents for ease of reference and briefly recounted its origins.

**I**
Who knows the move within the boundless void?
A child of tiger’s den explores the dark and still.
The true midst Heaven and Earth—how vast, how wide!
Yin and yang’s limits: but a mote of dust.
Heart and breath entwined birth the mystic aperture;
From murky cosmos, cull the jade-like *zhi*.
The *Celestial Music* reveals its subtlest wonders,
Stark and bare, the truth laid bare as *tathatā*.

**II**
As if immortal strains resound across the sky,
One drifts amid a blaze of heavenly blossoms.
Each verse marks the marrow of the mystic spine;
Each chapter mirrors the Buddha’s voice and face.
Our homeland lies in the realm of *wuheyou*;
Our visage belongs to the Lord of Vague Forms.
From fine dust to the coarse Three Realms,
Who but I dares laugh in the spring breeze?

**III**
A body beyond bodies, a grandfather beyond grandsons,
The ear bears the colossal staff that pierces heaven.
Have you seen the *Sea-Print*’s wink, O Lord?
I dare exhaust the craftsman’s artifice of heaven.
Thus I entrust the *Golden Lad* to carve anew,
And bid the *Jade Maiden* hasten its completion.
The silk thread never slips—fit for angling;
Once the golden toad is hooked, I’ll seek the *Jade Palace*.

**IV**
*Qiangu* borrowed *The Celestial Music* to transcribe;
The Innocent One then entrusted it to *Tiyang*.
Eight-tenths of the work remained unfinished,
Yet one corner reflected the whole, all was complete.
Henceforth, read by starlight and moonlight,
Ever revering each breath, pursuing with the heart.
The elixir that extends life and preserves the true—
May all the world partake of it together.

**V**
The book remains, its author gone—deep regret!
How could I receive the *Voice of the Tide* in person?
After *Dongting*, the former master’s line continues;
Since *Xiyue*, I have taken up the mantle.
I still recall *Qiangu* with longing,
And ever remember the *Little Innocent One*.
The world’s affairs shift, human hearts are treacherous—
One must tread with care, as on thin ice.

*Haiyin Shanren* Xu Songyao
